HEADLINE: The Republicans: Can They Get It Together?

BYLINE: By Judith Miller; Judith Miller is the staff writer at The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
"You won't find any registered Democrats in this town," says Robert R. Pyle, the burly, pipe-smoking librarian of Northeast Harbor, Me., a picturesque resort village 180 miles up the coast from George Bush's summer retreat in Kennebunkport.
"If you encounter any, they were either abused by their mothers as children or they're from away," Pyle adds, deploying the local expression for those who've immigrated from someplace else. 
 The 46-year-old Pyle says his forebears "have been in these parts for a while." Since the Mayflower, in fact. The Republican Party seems equally well entrenched among Maine's 1.2 million residents, having been a dominant political force in the state since before the Civil War.
Before he was old enough to vote, Pyle campaigned for Barry Goldwater, then enthusiastically supported Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan and George Bush. He cheerfully acknowledges that he has never voted for a Democrat for President.
If anyone in America should be solidly behind George Bush, it should be a G.O.P. stalwart like Bob Pyle. But this November, Pyle has every intention of voting against George Bush. Which means that he will actually pull the lever for Bill Clinton.
"I feel like I'm turning against a friend," Pyle says hesitantly. "This is painful, hard stuff for me. And I feel sadness, frustration rather than anger. George Bush -- he's become isolated. He doesn't seem to know what the hell is happening to us.
"Since the middle of Reagan's term, and especially since Bush, the rich have gotten richer," he goes on. "The poor have gotten children, and the middle class, like me, have gotten poor. I'm a pro-lifer in principle, so it's not that issue that's driving me away. It's the economy. I know that higher taxes were necessary. I don't hold that against them. It's their insensitivity to its impact on people. George Bush is becoming the new Herbert Hoover."
Pyle says the Republican Party as a whole is as much to blame as George Bush. "The middle-class person doesn't have a voice in the party anymore," he says. "Before the special interests took control -- the PAC's, the wealthy contributors -- we did."
By embracing special interests, Pyle argues, the G.O.P. has betrayed its own philosophy. "We used to call a destitute person someone who was 'on the town,' " he recalls. "We solved our own problems at the local level. But today, the Federal Government takes over and does nothing for him. I would still prefer a system in which localities raise their own money and decide how to solve their own problems. We Mainers don't like to be interfered with. The best place to make a judgment about what is best for us begins with us. That was what Republicans used to believe. It was the Democrats who always favored a big central Government. I won't support four more years of the same."
Down the road at the Docksider Restaurant, Northeast Harbor's most popular seafood house, the air tingles with the aromas of boiling lobster and political defection. The Docksider's owners, sisters Brenda and Gail Webber, and two waitresses, Diana Leonaid and Ann Ritchie, are all "year-rounders," a designation that distinguishes them from the summer residents. They are also all registered Republicans who want a new Administration in Washington.
"It's time for some young blood, some new blood," Leonaid, a 47-year-old mother of two, says.
"We're all fiscal conservatives," says Brenda Webber, 49. "We don't like Government regulation and the soaring deficits and the tendency to look to Washington to solve problems. But we haven't lived up to our social responsibilities. Bush says things aren't that bad. Well, maybe they're not for him. But they are for us."
As the others nod their heads in fierce agreement, Ritchie, who has five children, chimes in: "George Bush and his party have total disregard for women. I mean none." All of the women, it turns out, favor abortion rights -- adamantly so.
Leonaid says she is a Republican today only because her parents were. "But being a Republican doesn't mean anything to me anymore."
IF THE REPUBLICAN bastion of Maine, which has only four electoral votes, were George Bush's only zone of geographic and ideological vulnerability, the Grand Old Party would have little cause for alarm. But on the eve of the Republican National Convention, which starts tomorrow in Houston, disenchantment with Bush can be heard all over the country -- from the very men and women who should be among his most ardent supporters.
Scores of interviews over the last six weeks with registered Republicans in four traditional G.O.P. strongholds -- Maine, Orange County, Calif., New Jersey and Mississippi, places that have almost invariably supported Republican national tickets since 1968 -- reflect not only bitter disappointment with George Bush, but also a party deeply divided against itself.
Under George Bush, the party that the late Republican strategist Lee Atwater dubbed the "big tent," is creaking and groaning from internal strains, contradictions and rivalries. According to Kevin Phillips, the Republican analyst, ever since the election of Richard Nixon in 1968, Republicans have captured the White House by building a coalition of ideologically diverse constituencies: first, Traditional Conservatives, sometimes called "country club" or "Rotary Club" Republicans (who represent about 25 percent of the party's voters); second, Ivy League Moderates, sometimes called Nelson Rockefeller Republicans (about 10 percent); third, the Religious Right, the fundamentalist true believers who seemed to worship Ronald Reagan as much as any deity (about 15 to 20 percent); fourth, the Reagan Democrats, the blue-collar workers who have voted Republican in the last three Presidential elections (20 percent); fifth, the Anti-Communist Ethnics, the Cubans, Vietnamese and other immigrant groups galvanized by this single issue (about 3 percent), and last but certainly not least, given their activism and influence, the Radical Right, a group that George Bush early in his political career called "the so-called nut fringe," but which he has assiduously courted ever since (about 5 percent). (The rest of the G.O.P. voters defy easy categorization.) For years these disparate constituencies were held together with the glue of prosperity and the common adversaries of cold war. But today they are bitterly at odds.
Self-identified Republicans -- as opposed to those who merely vote Republican -- are also torn by doctrinal battles. One is over how to fix the economy. Here, the party faithful are split into what Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, calls "New Testament" and "Old Testament" factions -- supply-siders who favor stimulating growth through tax cuts and incentives (as Ronald Reagan did) versus those who argue that economic salvation is best achieved by balancing the budget and boldly eliminating the nation's crushing $4 trillion debt (as Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, does).
On social issues, like abortion, gay rights and prayer in the schools, the ideological fault line is between Republican traditionalists -- be they fiscal conservatives or moderates -- and the religious and ideological right. While abortion is the ostensible focus of the split, the real source is a far broader philosophical disagreement between those who oppose Government intervention in the private realm and those who favor it. In the 1988 Presidential campaign, economic well-being and Supreme Court protection of the right to an abortion camouflaged the split. But this year, the depressed economy and the Supreme Court decision that opened the door to the states' further limiting abortion rights, have widened and deepened it, leaving both sides feeling betrayed -- and furious at George Bush.
As right-wing influence within the G.O.P. solidifies in many states, moderates and even some conservatives warn that the great tent is now pitched so far to the right on "family values" issues that it is in danger of falling over. "My party, the party of Abraham Lincoln," a Republican abortion-rights activist laments, "has become the party of formaldehyde, condoms and fetus-wavers."
The leap of faith by about one-fourth of the electorate to Ross Perot, before many knew much about the billionaire Texas tycoon's personality and policy views, reflected voter anger at both parties -- but particularly at the G.O.P., from which many of Perot's predominantly white, male, suburban voters came.
Some White House officials initially assumed that because many Perot voters were Republicans, they would go back to their party after the Texan quit the race he never formally entered. But polls and interviews show that, so far, the opposite is true. Last month, the Field Poll of California showed former Perot supporters backing Clinton in that state 4 to 1. "The professionals may have underestimated the 'ABB' sentiment, 'Anybody but Bush,' says Tully Plesser, a Republican consultant.
If there is a bright spot for George Bush in all of this, it is that 74 percent of the electorate still describes itself as either politically "conservative" (32 percent) or "moderate" (42 percent), as opposed to the 20 percent which describes itself as "liberal." And while people mean very different things by those terms, Everett C. Ladd, director of the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research in Storrs, Conn., says that a defining feature of conservatism is skepticism about the capacity of Government to solve problems -- a trend that in Presidential contests tends to help Republicans, theoretically the party of Government minimalism.
Also, possible confrontations in Iraq and the Balkans might enable Bush to play "the military card," which could help him in November.
Another source of consolation for the Bush campaign is that many Republicans, despite their doubts about the President, remain suspicious both of Bill Clinton and the Democratic Party. "To us, Bill Clinton is like Gus Hall, a socialist." says James S. Todhunter, a businessman and conservative activist in Orange County, Calif. "So, of course, we'll support Bush."
Hazel Frank Gluck, a Republican consultant in Trenton, has come to the same conclusion for different reasons. "While we pro-choice Republicans are very disillusioned," she says, "it would be hard for me to vote Democratic."
But a large number of Republican voters interviewed express unqualified contempt for both Presidential candidates. "They're asking us to choose between a preppy tie and a hair dryer," says Jim Bright, a 42-year-old lobster fisherman in Northeast Harbor. Dick Koolhaas, who was born in Holland and for the past 18 years has run a feed store in Perris, Calif., blames both parties for what he calls "the mess we're in. I'm not making as much for my wife and four kids in a year as the Congress gave themselves in a single pay increase," he says with more than a trace of bitterness.
Republican strategists insist that by Election Day many of the disgruntled rank and file will end their political exile and return to the fold. They dismiss Bill Clinton's current 20-to-30-point lead over President Bush in the polls by citing surveys in which 34 percent of the voters say they might still switch their vote before Nov. 3.
But Kevin Phillips contends that the rumbling of discontent from Republicans is an unmistakable sign that a fundamental shift in voting patterns is under way. "Traditionally, Republicans have needed to get about 55 to 60 percent of the independents to win a Presidential election," Phillips says. "But that assumes your base is rock solid. And that's a big part of the problem. Different flavors of rock-rib Republicans are deserting Bush in droves, for very different reasons."
FOR Republicans, Orange County, Calif., has always been sacred territory. Its airport is named after John Wayne. Its main cultural attraction is Disneyland. It still hasn't gotten over Barry Goldwater's failure to win the Presidency in 1964. With 2.5 million residents, Orange County boasts one of the country's most expensive (though now flat) housing markets and a larger economy than most countries in Africa and South America. Since its creation more than a century ago, the county has been synonymous with affluent, loyalist Republicanism.
If any place should be George Bush country, it is conservative Orange County, among whose 1.1 million registered voters Republicans outnumber Democrats almost 2 to 1. But in this strange political year, the President cannot take even Orange County for granted. A poll in mid-July, conducted by The Orange County Register immediately after Perot's withdrawal, found Bush trailing his Democratic opponent Bill Clinton by 42.1 to 34.8 percent. The Register announced its findings as the third in an incredible series of developments over the last three years: "Berlin Wall falls. McDonald's opens in Moscow. Democratic Presidential challenger Bill Clinton is ahead in overwhelmingly Republican Orange County."
Why are Orange County Republicans joining so many other G.O.P. voters across the country in questioning their allegiance to -- and even deserting -- George Bush? First and foremost, the President has drawn the wrath of ultraconservatives here with his unpopular 1990 Congressional budget agreement that broke his "Read My Lips" pledge not to raise taxes.
But even more damaging to the Administration's standing, the recession has plunged Orange County, along with the rest of California, into one of the worst economic slumps since the Depression. Unemployment statewide is more than 1.5 percent above the national average of 7.8 percent. Aerospace, real estate and banking, three perennially booming sectors, are virtually at a standstill. Two weeks ago, the influential Register charged the President with having "failed every bit as much as that last notable failure, Jimmy Carter" and called on him to quit the race.
"What we have here in California is not merely a bad recession, we are experiencing a restructuring of the economy," says Larry Thomas, a former press secretary to then-Vice President Bush and now a senior vice president at the Irvine Company, a private developer and the county's single largest landowner. "We are not going to 'come back' in the usual sense. So people are going through an emotional process similar to a death in the family -- denial, anger, resentment and eventual acceptance. The problem is that the election is occurring in the midst of this cycle."
A Republican Assemblyman, Gil Ferguson of Newport Beach, one of the county's wealtiest communities, says that people are scared. "The biggest business in Orange County these days is moving vans -- immigrants and people dependent on the state for welfare, education and health care moving in, and businesses moving out, fleeing our burdensome regulations."
In a two-way Presidential race, Orange County must deliver a 300,000-vote surplus "to carry Sodom and Gomorrah in the rest of the state," Ferguson says, referring to San Francisco and Central Los Angeles, which vote heavily Democratic. Thus, Republicans would not only have to sustain their 231,000-vote margin in the county, but also cut into about a fifth of the Democratic vote -- no mean task, given the grim G.O.P. mood. "I don't see conservatives breaking their necks for Bush," Ferguson says. "I don't see the foot soldiers coming out for him. They're very independent-minded -- real conservatives, not wishy-washy Republicans. And George Bush has broken every pledge he made to them, all except abortion."
The lack of enthusiasm for Bush among the foot soldiers was unmistakable at a recent meeting in Garden Grove of the Orange County Coordinating Republican Assembly, the conservative caucus. "Look, George Bush broke his word and raised taxes," James Todhunter says. "We screamed the loudest and hardest about that. Bush's campaign slogan ought to be: 'I'm really, really, really sorry. Honest.' "
Debra Allen, a conservative who is running for a judgeship, says she will support the President's re-election -- but only secondarily. "We'll work for Bush, because all of us will be out there working as hard as we can to elect Bruce Herschensohn to the United States Senate. So while we're out canvassing and registering voters for Bruce, we'll be carrying Bush-Quayle literature as well."
An incumbent Republican President is in trouble, political professionals say, when he must rely on the "upward coattails" of an ultraconservative former television commentator and candidate for the Senate to carry a state with 54 critical electoral votes.
At party headquarters in neighboring Costa Mesa, there were also few vital signs. "The volunteers are all out," says Greg Haskin, the executive director of the Republican Party of Orange County, surveying his small, silent office. "Well," Haskin adds tentatively, "we are a little frustrated that the campaign has yet to take shape. The issues of the race have not been defined yet. We're still in a holding pattern. We're ready to go, of course. Rarin' to go, in fact. But until we get our marching orders, there's little we can do. Where are our marching orders?"
AT TIPPY'S charcoal Haven, a 1950's-style, neon-studded fast-food joint on the main drag in Jersey City, two men who declare themselves Reagan Democrats are talking politics. Frank Sclafani, who worked until recently in the shipping division of Colgate-Palmolive, and Frank Giordano, a burly, semiretired hairdresser with a weight lifter's physique, both voted Republican in 1988, as they did in 1980 and 1984. It is bad news for George Bush that neither intends to do so this year. Like most voters in New Jersey and throughout the Northeast, they were never really taken with Ross Perot. "He didn't make that much money being a saint," says Giordano, a Tippy's regular. Sclafani agrees. "Perot's a fraud. But Bush is despicable.
"Bush let Hitler stay on in power," Sclafani says, a less than oblique reference to the President's failure to oust Saddam Hussein from Iraq during the gulf war. Sclafani's son, who graduated from West Point in 1990, served in Saudi Arabia and only recently returned. "I don't understand why George Bush always seems to run away from strength," Sclafani goes on. "For a guy who crashed in the Pacific in combat and survived, he's got no sense of manifest destiny."
New Jersey, the quintessential suburban state with the third-highest per capita income in America, should be solidly pro-Bush. In the last Presidential election, the President got 56.2 percent of the vote. Since World War II, New Jersey voters have supported a Democrat for the White House only twice.
"The most notable feature of political life in New Jersey in the past decade has been the growth in the Republican Party," concludes Alan Rosenthal, director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. Yet New Jersey's 7.7 million people also tend to be fairly progressive, independent-minded ticket splitters who elect Democrats to Capitol Hill and to the State House, as they did three years ago -- to the regret of many -- with Gov. Jim Florio.
Polls and interviews in New Jersey suggest that in the Garden State, George Bush is in trouble. "We've lost 289,000 jobs in the past three years -- almost half of the job gains we made during the boom of the 80's," says Assemblyman Robert D. Franks, the state party chairman. "Per capita income here, when adjusted for inflation, shrank last year for the first time in almost a decade. Business and personal bankruptcies have hit all-time highs. And our unemployment rate is now 9 percent -- more than a point above the national average." The latest Asbury Park Press poll, last month, shows Clinton leading Bush, 50 to 25 percent.
"I voted for Bush as a continuation of the Ronald Reagan era," Sclafani continues, sipping a mug of Tippy's coffee. "Reagan restored the dignity and military strength our nation had lost in Vietnam. He wasn't afraid to call the Soviet Union evil. Sure, he helped create some of the economic problems we have today, but history will be kind to him. He and the Republicans got rid of Communism."
Giordano recalls the days when most of the residents of predominantly white, ethnic Jersey City were Democrats. "But most of us changed with Reagan in 1980," he says. "I'm not afraid to say I think family values are important to me, that pornography disturbs me, yes it does. That crime in the streets bothers me. Republicans talked about those issues. Democrats didn't."
But unlike Democratic Presidential candidates of the past, Sclafani and Giordano agree, Bill Clinton is talking about these issues. And both men loved Clinton's attack on the rap performer Sister Souljah, who after the Los Angeles riots suggested rhetorically that those who commit black-on-black homicides every day ought to devote a week to killing whites. Giordano says he's not surewhether he will even vote this year. Like many Reagan Democrats in this state, he is furious at Governor Florio, whose huge income tax increase three years ago reinforced his fears about the "tax and spend" Democrats.
But Giordano's friend Sclafani is looking hard at Clinton -- one of a growing number of Reagan Democrats around the country who might become Clinton Republicans in November. William Schneider, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute and CNN, says most polls and focus groups show that of all Republican voters, Reagan Democrats are most likely to shift allegiance to Clinton. Four years ago, about half of them did, in fact, abandon Bush for Gov. Michael Dukakis. Schneider and many other campaign strategists say that it is swing voters like Sclafani and Giordani who will decide the election.
CHARLES EDWARDS and his son Jason fix cars for a living in D'Lo, Miss., a tiny speck on the state map that the main highway passed by a decade ago. "We keep voting for change, but it's been so slow in comin' that we can't even see it," says Charles Edwards, 53, who voted for Bush in 1988. "I'm sure Bush is a good man, but he's not in touch with mainstream America. We've got to shut down all this overseas stuff. I don't want to leave any more debt to these children than they already have."
Jason, 22, has been getting news of this year's political campaign from MTV, which, he says, he watches regularly since there isn't much to do in D'Lo other than "eat, drink beer and go into Jackson 30 miles away on weekends." Jason says he is leaning to Clinton-Gore at this point, because "it's kind of appealing to have two Southerners who might be a little more focused on us."
Some Republican strategists fear that the all-Southern Democratic ticket will end the G.O.P.'s Presidential winning streak in Mississippi and other Deep South states. But Clarke Reed, the head of Mississippi's Bush-Quayle re-election campaign, disputes the pessimism. He insists that both Clinton and Gore are out of sync with the bedrock values of the region. "They're both too slick to be relating to the real Baptist culture here," Reed says. "Too yuppie to be fallin' on their knees."
Reed also quarrels with the conventional wisdom that the Republican ticket will be hurt in Mississippi by the state's sagging economy. The reason is a classic case of diminished expectations. "Sure the economy is bad, but it's always bad," Reed says. For years, Mississippi has ranked at the bottom among all states in income, literacy and health.
Mississippi may well rank first, however, when it comes to old-fashioned, flag-waving patriotism. This state sent a higher percentage of young people to the gulf war than nearly any other. "We love the Commander in Chief thing down here," Reed says.
More than a dozen faded "Support Our Troops in Desert Storm" bumper stickers can be seen in the parking lot of the Northpark Mall in Ridgeland, a white-flight suburb of Jackson that has been solidly Republican for two decades. In the mall, one finds that rarity in the political universe nowadays -- strong support for George Bush. "I respect Bush because he let the military handle the gulf war and didn't interfere,"' says 25-year-old Mary Frederick, who works in one of the mall's jewelry stores. "And you just can't blame the economy on Bush. Congress is to blame, too. They wouldn't let him do what he wanted to."
One of the few truly safe harbors for the much-buffeted Bush re-election ship appears to be within the community of evangelical, or fundamentalist, Christian churches in and around Jackson. Here, being a Republican is what many parishioners call a "life-style decision."
"Family values is what motivates a lot of us," says the Rev. Stanley Wachtstetter, the pastor of the Bible Tabernacle Church, in Clinton. It is with this rubric that the Republicans, chiefly Vice President Quayle, have effectively tapped into the evangelicals' staunch opposition to abortion, gay rights and other tolerance issues. Among men and women alike in Mississippi, being against abortion is next to godliness.
Wachtstetter says that rumors about Bill Clinton's drug experimentation and marital conduct are "too flagrant, too blatant" for evangelicals to ignore. "We're not really single-issue people," Wachtstetter says, "because family values -- religion, child care, abortion, how we treat the elderly -- are not single issues."
And yet while most of his parishioners share his views, not all share his unstinting support for the President. "I'm gonna probably hold my nose and vote for Bush," says Byron Duran, a carpenter who voted Republican in 1988. "As a Christian, the Democratic platform is about as anti-God as you can get -- for abortion, for gay rights. But our economy is in real trouble, and Bush always seems to have economic plans for some other people somewhere else in the world."
Again and again, the churchgoers say they don't like the Clinton alternative because the Democrats are "too liberal." But they also express a yearning for a "real leader." Nathan Triplett, 22, says he wishes that Ronald Reagan were running again. "He didn't compromise," he says. "I knew where he stood, and nobody could beat him."
A PRESIDENT WHOSE core constituency base has been reduced to evangelicals is a politician in trouble. And George Bush has only made matters worse by trying to appease both the traditionalists and the right wing within his party. "Bush, a moderate by nature, made a fundamental mistake in 1982 by trying to clone Ronald Reagan," says Rita E. Hauser, a prominent New York Republican who supports abortion rights. By tilting toward moderate-conservatives on some issues like tenant management of public housing and, by political calculation, to the radical right on others, most notably abortion, the President has wound up being trusted by neither side.
If the fight over abortion within the G.O.P. has done nothing else, it has energized the Republican center -- especially women -- a major segment of the party that had been steadily losing influence for the last three decades. "At some point, I realized that what was at stake here was my being comfortable within my own party," says Hazel Gluck, the Republican consultant from New Jersey. "When I was heckled at my own convention for supporting the Equal Rights Amendment, I realized that things had gone too far."
Eileen E. Padberg, a Republican strategist 3,000 miles away in Irvine, Calif., voices similar feelings. "I'm a true-blue conservative and Republican," Padberg says. "But increasingly I ask myself: What are those people doing in the party of Abraham Lincoln, of individual freedom and privacy, of separation of church and state? And what is George Bush doing on their side instead of ours?"
The answer may not reassure them. A series of New York Times/ CBS News polls conducted in June and July show that while many Americans oppose Government interference in the lives of individuals, a majority of Republicans and Democrats alike believe that the Federal Government should help "uphold traditional family values." In addition, only one-third of the Republicans sampled say abortion should be "generally available," while some 60 percent oppose using tax dollars to pay for it for poor women.
But the Padbergs of the party say they will not surrender, even if they lose their fight to overturn the party platform endorsing constitutional restrictions on abortion. They argue that their cause is just, not only on principle but on political grounds. The flight to Perot among Republicans earlier this year, they point out, tended to be heaviest in areas that were not only economically depressed, but also dominated by the radical right. In New Jersey, where the party is controlled by self-described moderates, a Perot groundswell never materialized. But in Orange County, where Perot support was extremely strong, ultraconservatives have long been in control. And in the Republican primary two months ago, Padberg and other challengers to the entrenched right wing were denounced by ultraconservatives as "lesbian spear chuckers."
Ann E. W. Stone, chairwoman of Republicans for Choice and one of the party's most tenacious activists, says that in Washington State, where support for Perot was also strong, the party has been virtually taken over by "zealots who have passed resolutions calling for bans on pornography, witchcraft and yoga."
"We're going to take this party back to its roots," says Stone. "We're going to stop the trend towards church fascism, the tail from wagging the dog. No matter what happens to Bush-Quayle in November, this war will go on."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 4; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: To Budapest Mit Schlag

BYLINE: By By Marian Burros; Marian Burros is a food columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:
It is the perfect setting for a Sigmund Romberg operetta: a Renaissance Revival building of palatial proportions idyllically situated on the edge of a city park, with a zoo at its backdoor and a lake at its front. Sometimes the air is filled with the sound of music, sometimes with the trumpeting of elephants.
But for decades the building in Budapest might as well have been a facade on a Hollywood sound stage. Its imposing exterior concealed the remains of a restaurant that was once the finest east of Vienna. Gundel, the gathering place of the bourgeoisie and the aristocracy when the Danube was still blue and Archduke Ferdinand had not yet been to Sarajevo, had survived two world wars, various occupations, revolutions and counterrevolutions and three months as a stable for Wehrmacht horses, but 45 years of Communist rule brought it to its knees. Inside it looked like a 1950's cafeteria, and the food it dispensed made K-rations seem appetizing. 
 On May 22, 1992, Gundel (pronounced GOON-del) was reborn. Its revival has become a symbol of the country's former glamour, giving Hungarians something to celebrate, even though few of them can afford the joie de vivre dispensed there for $30 to $40 a person. But, for the moment, George Lang, one of the partners in the restaurant, is not counting on the city's residents to fill the tables at Gundel. The Hungarian-born Lang, a successful restaurant consultant and owner of Cafe des Artistes in New York, has turned the operetta facade into a glamorous reality for well-heeled tourists, foreign business travelers and their local guests.
Lang fled Hungary in 1946, after escaping from a forced-labor camp in 1944. None of his immediate family survived the war. It has been a triumphal return. "This is the pinnacle of his career," said Andrew Young, a consultant who has worked with Lang in the past. "He is introducing a whole new way of food and management to a country that has been backward all these years."
So far, Lang's improbable adventure has cost between $15 million and $20 million, most of it coming from his partner, Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetic-empire heir and former Ambassador to Austria. Lang describes the experience of restoring a national treasure in an Eastern European country as a mix of Grand Guignol and soap opera. Hyperbole is to Hungarians what understatement is to New Englanders.
Joseph Wechsberg, the writer and food connoisseur, was not given to hyperbole. He credits Karoly Gundel, who ran the restaurant for almost 40 years, with contributing "more to the fame of Hungarian cooking than any other man." Writing in "Blue Trout and Black Truffles," Wechsberg said Karoly Gundel was "ranked by connoisseurs all over the world in a class with such restaurateurs as Escoffier and Fernand Point." Point was chef and owner of what arguably was once the finest restaurant in the world, La Pyramide in France.
Lang agrees, describing Gundel as "the greatest restaurateur that Hungary ever produced," a combination of Ritz, Escoffier and Prosper Montagne.
Gundel absorbed the hospitality business at his father's hotel in Budapest and then apprenticed in Switzerland and Germany, where he met the famous Swiss hotelman Cesar Ritz, who took him to Paris and London.
In 1910 Gundel purchased a restaurant in the city park and named it for himself. It was not long before the rechristened establishment had an international reputation, and when King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy visited Hungary in 1937, Gundel and his staff cooked for him at the castle where he stayed, adding to the restaurant's cachet. Despite its decline under the Communists, Gundel's reputation survived, and visiting connoisseurs continued to make pilgrimages. They left disappointed.
Lang knew both the food and the setting needed a complete overhaul. He consulted his old friend, the designer Milton Glaser, who helped devise a master plan. The first idea was to re-create that period between the two world wars, when where you sat at Gundel was determined by your station in life, your patronage of the restaurant and your knowledge of food. Karoly Gundel explained to Wechsberg: "People with good food and wine manners would in due time graduate to the terrace," where the socially and otherwise prominent dined, a few steps up from the garden, which was for the ordinary patrons.
But the era's Mitteleuropa style -- fanciful, baroque, luxurious -- was rejected as too sumptuous for late 20th-century tastes. "Vienna Secessionist is very opulent, very decorative, very sexy," said Adam D. Tihany, a designer of the restaurant who was born in Transylvania and is now an American. "We felt it would not sit well, so we went back to sometime between the 1880's and 1920's." The result, says Tihany, "is something that never existed, but you would have felt comfortable in it 100 years ago. We had to create a fantasy. We reconstituted it from the blue air."
The appointments of the 200-seat dining room span the decades, from Belle Epoque through early Art Deco -- from the lush to the linear, with polished rosewood paneling and a coffered plaster ceiling with three elaborate layers of plaster molding. The wrought-iron and brass railings are typically Belle Epoque, the chairs are almost Biedermeier.
With a raised platform and strategic configuration of the blue silk banquettes, the room seems cozy and intimate. The muted gold fabrics on the walls and the carpet with its elephant motif (in honor of the zoo) give it the patina of restoration instead of the glitz of something new.
The second-floor ballroom, which could have been the Czar's summer palace -- dazzling white-and-gold rococo with five Venetian crystal chandeliers and heavy gold and red damask drapes -- was designed by Kornel Baliga, a young Hungarian architect.
In the garden at night, an orchestra plays under an umbrella of trees outlined in thousands of tiny lights.
Not all of the decor is exactly Tihany's taste. "Borderline kitsch," he says.
"Opening up a restaurant of this complexity," says Lang, as he sits in his tiny office, "is one of the pleasures and nightmares of all times. It is a cross between being a Medici and living in a surrealist world."
Lang has come a long way since he arrived in the United States intending to be a violinist. Lacking the talent to be another Jascha Heifetz, he moved on to the restaurant business. Along the way, this short, stocky, bald man with penetrating blue eyes picked up skills as an author, photographer, calligrapher, designer of tableware and cook. He lives in New York with his third wife, Jenifer; they have a 5-year-old son, Simon.
Lang is not modest -- "only good-for-nothings are modest," he says. And he seldom gives short answers to questions, peppering them with references to the past and to his famous friends, especially in the music world. "Name-dropping," says one Hungarian, "is very Hungarian."
Some colleagues at Gundel refer to Lang as King George, and, aware of this teasing, he sometimes appropriates it. One day, as he sits for his portrait in the splendor of the restaurant's gilded ballroom, he describes himself as "the almost benevolent, almost dictator."
Doing business in Hungary has required infinite patience and a sense of the absurd. Near the end of the construction, only a bunker-style office building erected by the Communists next to Gundel intruded on Lang's fairy-tale kingdom. Three days before the opening, the ugly building still needed to be painted. In most places, if you want to paint a building you own, you pick a color and hire a painter. Not in Budapest.
Lang: I want the building painted by Friday. When can you start?
Laszlo Somogyi, supervisor of construction at Gundel and former minister of construction and urban development under the Communists: The law in Hungary is that you cannot paint stone.
Lang: You are kidding.
Somogyi: No.
Lang: We are painting it and if there is any problem it is my problem.
Somogyi: O.K. We paint but it is against the law.
Lang: Who made this stupid law?
Somogyi: The law was made by me.
Laughter throughout the room.
Lang: O.K. You can take a few Valium . . . and then paint the building.
TIHANY LIKENS THE re-creation of Gundel to a military operation. "We called it Budapest Storm," he says. And since this is Hungary, everything takes longer because everyone has something to say. "If there are 10 people," says Tihany, "there are 20 opinions."
Four electricians are putting up the chandelier in the restaurant's foyer. Decorative chains are to be connected from the center post to what Tihany calls "the squiggles" at the edges of the fixture.
"What are the chains for?" asks one of the electricians.
Tihany explains that they are part of the design.
"It's not nice," says the electrician. "I don't like it with the chains. It looks better this way."
"I'm sorry you don't like it," says Tihany, maintaining his cool. "But put it up."
"I don't take orders from you," says the electrician. "Only from Mr. Somogyi."
Tihany fetches the burly construction boss, who tells the electricians: "You must put it up exactly as Mr. Tihany said."
Then he turns to Tihany: "Why do you want the chain. It looks better without it."
There is only one way to end this discussion: Pull rank. "I want the chain," Tihany says, and it is installed.
The five-minute task has consumed half a day.
This is one of the few discussions in which Lang is not involved. Only because he is elsewhere at the time. Little escapes his critical eye. One of the details he has fixed on is the color of the kitchen floor tiles -- a ruddy beige.
"It is a filthy, ugly color," he says, as he shows off the kitchen. At the staff meeting the next morning he asks how they got stuck with the unspeakable color.
Told that the color was deliberately chosen to conceal dirt, he sputters: "You are joking. I can't imagine how they sell this damn thing. I am so disturbed. I came back last night at midnight and scrubbed the damn thing like half an hour. I don't care if we have to break it up. I don't want the damn thing."
Though he hasn't torn out the floor, his desire for perfection and his legendary temper, which he freely acknowledges, frighten many of the employees.
"He is demanding," says Kalman Kalla, who was chef at the Hungarian embassy in Washington before he took the post at Gundel. "He has a finger in every pie and he knows about everything. Many of my colleagues are scared in front of him and don't dare say anything to him. He has a temper but most of the time he is very polite. Before he comes, the people in the kitchen say, 'The beast is coming.' "
Instead of a grand opening, Gundel eased into operation with a few small parties. To work out cooking kinks and to make sure the staff had absorbed Western-style courtesy and learned enough English to converse with foreign guests, Lang held a series of tasting dinners and lunches for friends of the owners living in or traveling through Budapest.
It has been difficult convincing the staff that food preparation has changed in the 40-odd years they have been locked up in a Communist culinary time warp: that Westerners like their fish moist, not dry, their meat pink not gray, their vegetables crisp but tender. Those who have dined at Gundel in the months since it has opened say the food is quite good, certainly without compare in Eastern Europe.
Like Karoly Gundel, Lang mixes Hungarian dishes with those that would be described today as Continental: prosciutto and melon; mushrooms stuffed with wild mushrooms; rare roasted breast of duck; chateaubriand with bearnaise sauce and potatoes Anna; fogas, the famous local fish; gulyas, a meat soup; catfish baked with sauerkraut and fish sausage (an 18th-century recipe). Goose liver, as beloved in Hungary as foie gras is in France, is prepared five different ways. For dessert there is strudel, crepes Gundel style with walnuts, chocolate and rum as well as strawberries with strawberry ice cream and espresso parfait.
Lang is never satisfied. But when he writes notes to the kitchen staff after a tasting lunch, he mixes praise with criticism.
"For a first-time cooking in a kitchen, it was quite remarkable," he wrote in a May 14 memorandum.
"Double breast of chicken:
"A. Chicken was way overcooked. As I mentioned to you before, chicken (especially breast) and shrimp should be cooked exactly half the length that seems logical.
"B. Gauffrettes potatoes were soggy. (When they were fried, they seemed fine.)
"C. Thank heaven, the asparagus was cooked properly.
"D. Cauliflower and Brussels sprouts seemed like a product from an English kitchen: they were just boiled (though fortunately not overboiled); we must discuss this because it needs something extra."
Having the dishes cooked and served just the way Lang wants them is only part of the culinary task in a country where, until a few years ago, everything seemed to come in a pink sauce piped out of a central commissary.
Sources for ingredients have to be cultivated. A vineyard in the famous Tokay region has been purchased to assure a consistent supply of the country's most famous wine. A distiller is making apricot brandy, the preferred before-dinner drink in Hungary, under the Gundel label, and a paprika producer is packaging three types of the seasoning for the restaurant and its gift shop. Lang's Hungarian organization, Langastronomia, K.F.T., the umbrella company for Lang and Lauder's Hungarian businesses, is negotiating to buy a farm to produce goose liver.
Lang is also trying to install an American tipping system, but it is not working well. Europeans, accustomed to having service included, either fail to notice or ignore the discreet wording on the menus that says the tip is not included. With only the Americans tipping well, the waiters say they are not making enough money.
These problems are minor compared with those that faced Lang and Lauder when they first sought to buy the restaurant. It took more than a year after they approached the Hungarian State Property Agency, responsible for privatizing what the Communist Government had appropriated over the previous decades, to close the deal. Following Kafkaesque negotiations, they took title in September 1991. Reconstruction began in November; the restaurant opened in May. Not bad in a land stuck somewhere between Communist bureaucracy and the West's free-market economy.
It's doubtful the Hungarian Government knew that Gundel was a national treasure until George Lang and Ronald Lauder said they wanted to buy it. "No one cared about the restaurant in the privatization," said Gabor Buday, managing director of Langastronomia. "Politicians forgot about the fame Gundel got for Hungary before the war," he said.
That does not mean that Hungary's State Property Agency was anxious to get rid of Gundel. They put an $8 million price tag on it, with the investors and the Government to each own half. This prospect did not appeal to either Lang or Lauder.
The details of how Lang finally got what he wanted remain hazy because Lang chooses to keep them that way.
"So what am I going to tell you?" he says when asked about the negotiations. "How I made 25 different moves; how I made a 125-page gold-embossed hard-cover book about Gundel that I sent the the Ministry of Property; how I researched the goddamn thing?"
Finally the state agreed to sell 50 percent of the restaurant to him and Lauder. Just days before the closing they called and offered all of it. Lang and Lauder took it.
AND THEN THERE were the Gundel heirs to consider. Lang says the Government would have given them an insignificant amount of money; Lang and Lauder felt they owed them more. "Ronald and I felt extremely strongly that morally we couldn't use the name without their permission," said Lang, "and we wanted them to get some money."
How much? Lang will only say, "significant in Hungarian terms." A year ago Lang swore the Gundel heirs to secrecy and a promise that any statements made to the press would be positive. But someone close to the 36 Gundel heirs said they received around $500,000 in total -- $200,000 from the Government, the rest from Lang and Lauder, considerably less than two of the Gundel grandchildren thought was appropriate. "They smelled a killing," according to Lang, "and went to a lawyer and convinced the family they could get $1 million or $2 million more.
"I got to the point where I said, now is the time to act. I invited about 40 of the family, and we had dinner on the terrace. It was a lovely, friendly dinner.
"After dinner I made a speech and I said, 'I will make an offer but it must be agreed to unanimously,' and then I showed them the ad that I would create for the restaurant when it opened if they did not agree. The ad would say: 'Wampetich, formerly Gundel.'
"There was absolute dead silence."
Lang had played his trump card. Wampetich was the name of the restaurant when Karoly Gundel bought it in 1910.
Janos Gundel, a grandson of Karoly, was reluctant to talk about what happened. "We had some problems," he said. "Yes, I think it upset us to think he would not use the name.
"Of course, it would have been much better if we could continue our grandfather's tradition, but the whole family was very happy that the tradition is in good hands."
Gundel, the restaurant, is only the beginning. Products like the apricot brandy, paprika and chocolate tortes are being sold under the Gundel label in a boutique in the foyer. There will be a cooking school and, possibly, a student exchange program with the Culinary Institute of America. The off-premises catering is already more profitable than the restaurant. Even more ambitious are the plans to open several Gundels around the world.
Asked to explain why, at 68, he would take on this monumental and often frustrating project, Lang pauses for a long time before answering. "It must be in your genes when you have to prove yourself over and over again," he says.
Then he looks away, his voice breaking. "I don't know. I guess I want to justify that I was the only one who survived."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 24; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 846 words

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Silver, Jade and Bronzes Hold Their Own on the Block

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
In the lackluster art market of the 1990's, historically important objects, especially those with a royal pedigree, are thriving. Several of the most impressive items have commanded exceptional, even record prices at recent auctions in New York, Monte Carlo and Hong Kong.
The costliest -- a cradle-shaped Imperial Easter egg made in 1905 by Peter Carl Faberge -- brought $3.2 million earlier this summer at Sotheby's in New York. Made for Czar Nicholas II to give to his wife, Alexandra, on the birth of their son Alexei, the bejeweled and blue-enameled bauble rewrote the record at auction for a Faberge work. Neither the seller nor the buyer was identified. 
 On June 25, also at Sotheby's, most everyone was astonished at the bidding war between two Japanese dealers over a gilded silver wine vessel, probably made for a Sassanian king of ancient Persia to give to a nobleman in the seventh century. The winner, Noriyoshi Horiuchi of Tokyo, paid $1.9 million, more than 10 times the presale estimate, setting a record at auction for any ancient Near Eastern artwork.
Birdlike in form with a beaked spout, the ewer, decorated with scrolls and leaves, cost a mere $25,000 in the 1960's, when it was bought by J. J. Klejman, a New York dealer. The unidentified Klejman family member who sold it in June benefited from recent scholarship on the other six known Sassanian vessels.
Prudence O. Harper, the curator of ancient Near Eastern art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, had studied the six previously known examples. She started with the Metropolitan's silver version, embellished with dancing girls, and went on to those at the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris and at the Hermitage in St. Petersburg.
"The Sassanian ewer is a very distinctive form of vessel," Mrs. Harper said. The extant examples were madeduring the sixth and seventh centuries, from Iran to Central Asia. "The one at Sotheby's was a very large late example, mid-seventh century. It's not by chance that a high price was spent for this luxury object."
When collectors and dealers assembled in Monte Carlo on June 21 for a Sotheby's auction, the talk was mostly about a rococo coffeepot, made in 1757 by Francoise-Thomas Germaine of Paris for King Jose I of Portugal. The pear-shaped pot, its spout and handle shaped like coffee leaves and beans, established a record for French silver -- $1.6 million, four times Sotheby's expectations. Auctioned from the collection of Arturo Lopez-Willshaw, the Chilean-born heir who died in 1962, the vessel was bought by an unidentified buyer.
"It was the best coffeepot you could get -- absolutely fabulous," said the dealer who lost out in the bidding, Martin Norton of S. J. Phillips in London. "There is a recession, but the very best things in the European silver market have kept their prices."
Of the six pots Germaine made for the king, four are in two Lisbon museums with the rest of the king's magnificent service, and one is at the Metropolitan. "I polish that coffeepot every 12 months, and it's a high point of my year," said Clare Le Corbeiller, an associate curator at the Metropolitan. "It's one of the great works of French silver in its rhythm, texture, richness, discipline, grace and scale. You've got polished surfaces, matte surfaces and spirals going in different directions. And yet it's controlled. It just sings."
Several aristocratic Oriental artworks also produced heated bidding. An 18th-century Imperial marriage bowl, carved of white jade, was recently sold by Christie's in Hong Kong for $597,700 to an unidentified Taiwan buyer. The price was a record for white-jade carving. Then, a 16th-century Korean lacquer box, made for an emperor or high-placed official, sold for $550,000 at Christie's in New York. "It's very rare to find a document box in good condition," said Yoshinori Munemura, an Oriental art specialist at Christie's.
Also at Christie's this summer, a rare pair of silver inlaid bronzes of mythical beasts, made about the third century B.C. to serve as the corner mounts of an ancient Chinese vessel, brought $550,000. "All those inlaid vessels were found in royal tombs," said Philip Constantinidi of Eskenazi, the London dealer who bought the mounts. "I don't think any other pair has been on the market since World War II."
No royal connection has been uncovered for the golf club that Titus Kendall, a London dealer, bought last month for $175,400, the highest price ever realized for an auctioned golf item. But the 300-year-old putting iron, with a curved blade and an ash shaft, is a historical artifact. It's one of the earliest known examples.
"Golf was always an expensive sport," Mr. Kendall said. Found recently in a garden shed in Scotland, Sotheby's auctioned the golf club at Musselburgh, near Edinburgh. The dealer bought it for the Valderamma Golf Club in Sotto Grande, Spain.
"Ordinary 19th-century clubs have decreased in price about 20 percent," said Jon Baddeley, the Christie's auctioneer who sold it. "But when a rarity appears, buyers will pay whatever it takes."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1386 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: West Side Development;
Capital Cities/ABC Plans New Studios

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THINK of it as as an urban television "back lot," says Capital Cities/ABC, trying to describe the expansion it plans on vacant land behind an existing studio building on the West Side. In the front lot, along West End Avenue from 64th to 65th Streets, there would be three residential towers of 39 stories, with 930 apartments and a 350-car garage.
The company is in the preliminary review phase in the Department of City Planning on a proposal to build two 15,000-square-foot television studios plus support space behind the existing studio, which is at 320 West 66th Street. Public land-use review is expected to begin in October. 
 The residential section would architecturally complement the already approved 1,000-unit Manhattan West project of the Brodsky Organization just south of the Capital Cities/ ABC land, on West End Avenue from 61st to 64th Street. Groundbreaking on that development is scheduled for next year.
It is hard to think of a corporate analogue to the role in Manhattan development that Capital Cities/ABC is taking. Well before American Broadcasting Companies was acquired by Capital Cities Communications Inc. in 1986, it was expanding and shifting about on the West Side, buying property, leasing space, building new and rehabilitating the old, in one real-estate transaction after another over 30 years. But in the latest proposal, it is showing itself in a more unusual role -- working to rezone land for residential use.
Company officials acknowledge that Capital Cities/ABC may not be the builder. Once approved for residential use the land may be resold.
The site is part of a eight-acre tract once owned by The New York Times. The Times used the building at the north end of the tract for production and distribution, and sold the full parcel to Harry B. Helmsley in 1979 when it moved those operations to New Jersey.
In 1982 Mr. Helmsley sold the building and land behind it to Capital Cities/ABC -- a total of two acres. The company rehabilitated the West End Avenue building, No. 125, for the headquarters of ABC's radio networks and other functions, and built the 320 West 66th Street studio where a power house formerly stood.
The rest of the property Mr. Helmsley sold to the Brodsky Organization in 1985. But a year later Brodsky sold off the two northerly acres to Capital Cities/ABC. This is the land now under planning review.
Richard E. Hockman, vice president for real estate and construction, has been at ABC through most of its wanderings, going back to days when Leonard Goldenson was chairman. Mr. Goldenson built ABC from a small network purchased from Edward Noble, the "Life Saver king," in 1953.
CORPORATE headquarters moved from the Upper West Side to midtown in the 60's -- to 1330 Avenue of the Americas, on 54th Street across the avenue from the New York Hilton. But production activities remained uptown.
"It took 20 years to decide that it was unwise to split the company physically," said Mr. Hockman. A plan was hatched to build an elaborate one-million-square-foot headquarters between 66th and 68th Street, and Columbus Avenue and Broadway. The site was assembled, but in the 80's the plan was dropped. Instead, in 1989, the company built 77 West 66th Street, a building of 400,000 square feet at the Columbus Avenue end of a block filled with an assortment of ABC properties. The Avenue of the Americas building was sold to the Shuwa Corporation of Japan for $175 million in 1986.
The northern portion of the land assembled for the canceled headquarters was sold to Millenium Partners for a $234 million mixed-use tower, currently in construction. Capital Cities/ABC still holds the triangularly shaped southern block, between 66th and 67th Streets, but Millienium Partners has an option to buy it.
The emphasis now is on expanding capacity to produce shows -- rather than licensing others to produce them, said Robert T. Goldman, vice president for administration. "Where to do it? The only places are Los Angeles or New York, where the writers, the producers, the on-air talent is," he said. "We've got $125 million invested in our West End Avenue facilities already. We can service two more studios by adding on."
At present, the network has two studios at the location, with 23,000 square feet of space. But the supporting space includes only 1,000 square feet as the staging area -- where trucks can turn around. By industry standards turnaround space should roughly equal studio space.
Capital Cities/ABC is a major New York City employer. It occupies a total of 2.8 million square feet of space citywide, owning 1.7 million square feet of it and leasing the rest. Sixty-three percent of its space is on the West Side. The company paid $23.6 million last year in property taxes.
Fulltime employment stands at 8,400 people, and many more are employed on a per-diem basis. Permanent employment is expected to grow by 450 after the new studios are built.
BY contrast, NBC has 1.25 million square feet in the G.E. Building at Rockefeller Center for corporate headquarters, studios and a local TV station, leased till 2022 after a major tax abatement from New York City. It also has two studios on Avenue M in Brooklyn, but the bulk of its studio space is in Burbank, Calif.
Similarly, at CBS most of the major studio operations are in California, although the company has one million square feet at its broadcast center at 524 West 57th Street and 800,000 square feet in its corporate headquarters at 51 West 52d Street. Game shows, once shot in New York, are in California. "New York is a tough place to find studio space," said Kent Cooper, director of facilities.
As for housing, the near-term prospects for construction are greatest at Manhattan West. The State Legislature in the current session approved legislation permitting 20 years of Section 421a tax abatement in developments planned, like Manhattan West, with a 20 percent lower-income component. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed the bill last week.
The legislation makes the project feasible, according to Daniel Brodsky, president of the Brodsky Organization. The apartments will get 10 years of full tax abatement -- paying only the taxes attributable to the land value -- and the taxes will phase in over the next 10 years. Rents go up to cover these taxes, but the 10 years of full abatement make the units more affordable, and hence more easily rented and more easily financed. The market-rate units are expected to rent initially for about $29 a square foot a year. That works out to about $1,300 a month for a one-bedroom apartment and $2,200 for a two-bedroom, Mr. Brodksy said.
MORE distant is the prospect of development at Donald J. Trump's proposed Riverside South, potentially 5,700 apartments, a film production studio, offices and a park on 57 acres running from 59th Street to 72d Street near the Hudson River to the west of the two other smaller projects. A public review process is under way. Full development would take many years.
One question raised by the Capital Cities/ABC plan is whether new housing would be marketable in the location at the prices developers would need to charge. Some say that if they have paid as much as $50 per developable square foot for the land, a conventionally financed project would not be rentable even with Section 421a subsidies currently available. And in the middle 80's developers paid that much and more.
"With long-term tax-exempt rates in the low 6- to 6 1/2-percent range and with the new 421a program you can start developing rental housing," Mr. Brodsky, the Manhattan West developer, said.
According to Abram Barkan, head of the appraisal and consulting division of Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives, the $115 million price paid by the Trump Organization seven years ago to buy the property for Riverside South will "play havoc with required rental rates when, if ever, anything is built."
Richard A. Kahan, chairman of the Riverside South Planning Corporation, said that the land costs embedded in the project, more than half of them attributable to streets, utilities and parks that the developer must build, are "significantly more" than $50 per buildable square foot.
Nevertheless, "Given a reasonable New York economy, it will be feasible, marginally, as a market-rate project," he said.

HEADLINE: New Haven Rallies for a Tennis Week

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
WHEN Jim Westhall moved the Volvo International Tennis Tournament from Stratton Mountain, Vt., to New Haven two years ago, there were doubters galore.
And no wonder. Since 1970 the tournament was held in such bucolic resort settings as Bretton Woods and North Conway in New Hampshire and at Stratton Mountain. For all its educational, cultural and entertainment amenities, New Haven has never been mistaken for a vacation retreat. 
 But in its first two years in New Haven the tournament has been a success, attracting 265,000 spectators to the first major tennis tournament ever staged in Connecticut. And the largest overall attendance yet is expected for this year's weeklong tournament, which begins tomorrow.
"At the rate tickets are selling, we're projecting a 50 percent increase in sales over last year," Mr. Westhall said. That would result in near-capacity crowds at the year-old 15,000-seat stadium and the field courts at the Connecticut Tennis Center, which is near the Yale Bowl on Derby Avenue, also Route 34, in New Haven.
 
Stadium Blocked at Stratton
 This year's field is the strongest ever. The 56 players, competing for $1 million in prize money, is expected to include the Wimbledon champion Andre Agassi, the United States Open champion Stefan Edberg, Petr Korda, the defending Volvo champion; Ivan Lendl, John McEnroe and Goran Ivanisevic, who lost to Agassi in the Wimbledon final. Day and evening sessions, starting at 11 A.M. and 7 P.M., will be held tomorrow through Friday. Saturday's semifinals will start at 11 A.M.; the final will be played at noon next Sunday. The winner will receive $144,000.
That is a far cry from the $5,000 purse offered at the first event held at the Mount Washington Hotel in Bretton Woods in 1970. From Bretton Woods, where it was held for five years, the tournament moved to North Conway, Vt., and 10 years later to Stratton Mountain.
Mr. Westhall, who has been involved with the tournament from the beginning -- when he was an executive with the corporation that owned the Mount Washington Hotel -- was forced to find a new site when environmentalists blocked the building of a larger stadium near Stratton Mountain.
 
Connecticut Rallies Behind Project
 To a large extent, the decision to move to New Haven was based on a pledge by the Connecticut State Legislature to pay $15 million for the construction of the tennis stadium, which is exceeded in capacity in the United States by only the Louis Armstrong Stadium at the National Tennis Center, the site of the United States Open. The legislature also approved the sale of $3 million in bonds for the construction of 22 tennis courts by the new stadium, which are used by Yale University where the stadium and the courts were built.
Besides offering state residents a world-class sports event, the Volvo tournament was seen by many as a boon to the economy of the New Haven area. Indeed, Paul Johnson, who is president of the Tennis Foundation of Connecticut, Inc., an organization of civic and business leaders that owns and operates the tennis stadium, predicted that the tournament would result in "spectacular benefits to New Haven and the State of Connecticut."
An economic impact study of last year's, prepared by the Yale School of Organization and Management, said the event resulted in a direct economic impact of more than $7 million. Of that, $6 million was spent for tickets, wages, parking and concessions at the Connecticut Tennis Center. Off-site expenditures, most of which were in the New Haven area, totaled about $1 million.
 
Expanding the Market
 Most civic and business leaders interviewed said they felt that the tournament has been beneficial to New Haven, both economically and in helping to enhance the city's image, which has been hurt by a number of drug-related shootings. "We're more than satisfied with the results so far," said Matthew Nemerson, the president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce. "It takes a while before a city can capitalize on a major sports event. A one-week tennis tournament is not going to make or break a hotel, restaurant or anything else. But there can be a spillover that can help create an awareness about New Haven and about all the city has to offer."
Mr. Westhall has put a heavy marketing and advertising focus on Farfield, Hartford and Westchester Counties. "We want to broaden our attendance base beyond the New Haven area," he said.
In persuading the state to pay for the stadium, Mr. Westhall and many of those who helped draw the tournament to New Haven had said the stadium could serve as a site for outdoor concerts. But only one non-tennis event has been held there, a concert by the folk trio Crosby, Stills and Nash, which attracted about 6,000 people in June.
"We hope to have as many as four or five concerts at the stadium next year," said John DeStefano Jr., the executive director of the Tennis Foundation. "In addition, we have made a bid for Davis Cup tennis in 1993, and also hope to stage a women's tennis exhibition." This year, for the first time, the stadium was the site last week of the Pilot Pen Open tennis tournament, an event that features promising young players.
There is no guarantee that the Volvo International -- at times referred to in tennis circles as the "Vagabond Volvo" -- will remain in New Haven. As of now the Swedish car maker is only committed to hold the tournament at the Connecticut Tennis Center this year and in 1993. Volvo officials have said that continued sponsorship depends largely on whether the promoters can continue to attract top players and national television exposure. Part of this year's event will be televised by ESPN, the all-sports cable network, which is based in Bristol.
 
What About the Poor?
 While there has been virtually no opposition to the tournament, others ask why needed, and promised, housing projects in New Haven are not planned and built as fast as the tennis stadium. "The tennis stadium was built with lightning speed, which is both impressive and indicative of what can be accomplished, depending on who is going to benefit," said Jon Alander, the State Commissioner of Human Resources and the former executive director of the New Haven Legal Assistance Association Inc. "Projects built to benefit the affluent are accomplished in record time, but projects for the poor are delayed or never get off the drawing board."
"I'm not opposed to the Volvo tournament, or to the building of the stadium," said Mr. Alander, who lives in Hamden. "But if there's a will behind an effort to build a tennis stadium in such quick time, why can't there be a similar will to build needed housing for poor people in New Haven? For years people who were displaced from their homes in the Dixwell Avenue area, which were then torn down, were promised that the Elm Haven Housing Project would be built in the area. But it still hasn't been done, and God knows when it will.
"I'd like to see the same vigor and energy that was put into the construction of the tennis stadium applied towards housing for the poor. But, when you don't have clout, you always get a lot of excuses."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

BLOCKWATCH TOUR
 It is not a conventional house tour being offered this afternoon in New Haven from 1 to 5 P.M. Organized by Blockwatch 320, a group of property owners in the Park-Howe-Dwight Streets neighborhood bordering Yale, the self-guided walking tour covers 20 private residences built in the 19th century that until recently were threatened with extinction. 
 Ten years ago, when Blockwatch 320 was formed, the 12-block neighborhood was losing a battle with absentee landlords and drug traffickers.
Today, "work still needs to be done," said a lawyer, Diana L. Mercer, who lives in one of the homes, "but we no longer have hundreds of prostitutes working Howe Street, and there is no longer a panic-stricken, crime-fighting mentality among the residents."
Ms. Mercer bought her house two years ago, and like many other professionals, businesspeople, Yale faculty members and working-class residents, has invested time and money in restoring and improving her property.
Several of the homes are listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and the architectural styles are a living textbook of American architecture. Victorian Gothic, Greek Revival and Queen Anne homesteads stand cheek by jowl with brick row houses, undisturbed since they were built in the 1870's.
But improvement has been stalled by the economy. "Suburbanites bought houses and rented them out, paying no attention to the property," Ms. Mercer said. "Many of them over-leveraged themselves, properties were taken over by banks, or reverted back to drug gangs, some were burned out."
A tour of the homes last year produced heightened interest and some funds for neighborhood programs. This year's tour tickets and maps cost $6 and may be obtained at The Inn at Chapel West, 1201 Chapel Street. For more information, 787-3638.
 
HELLCAT'S NEW LANDING
 A Grumman F6F Hellcat, under restoration for 18 years, is on permament loan to the New England Air Museum from the Navy and may be seen daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Twenty-four examples of the aircraft exist today, compared with the more than 12,000 that were built and served in World War II. The aircraft was credited with turning the tide of the war in the Pacific, and the one at the Air Museum is the only example in New England.
Visitors to the museum may also tour the display of about 80 fighters, bombers, helicopters and racers from the turn of the century to the present. And from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today hundreds of antique cars from the 1930's through the 60's will be on view in a one-day exhibition, as well as auto parts, memorabilia and literature supplied by dozens of swap-meet vendors.
The museum is off Route 75 next to Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, and admission is $5.50, $2 for children ages 6 to 11. Information: 623-3305.
 
CATS ON PARADE
 Representatives of most of the 37 different breeds of cats recognized by the International Cat Association will be judged in the cat show scheduled at Connecticut College in New London Saturday and Sunday. Dramaticats, an affiliate of the International Cat Association, is sponsoring the show. Entries will include four Siberian kittens from Germany as well as Bengal, Egyptian Mau, sphynx, Norwegian forest cat, Occicat, Japanese Bobtail and Oriental Shorthair.
In addition to the purebreds there will be judging of house cats, and the Noank Veterinary Hospital will have cats available for adoption. An array of vendors with cat supplies, climbing trees, cat-motif items and other feline paraphernalia will be on hand, and profits from the show will be donated to research and the welfare of cats.
Show hours are 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday in the college's Dayton Arena, off Route 32. Admission is $4, $3 for elderly people and children. For more information, call 535-2917 or 399-6884.
 
CROSS-CULTURAL 'ROMEO'
 Students from Moscow and Darien have combined to produce a dance program of "Romeo and Juliet" by the Moscow Class-Center of Music and Dramatic Art, to be performed Friday and Saturday in the Darien High School auditorium.
Two years ago the Moscow group and Darien High School Theater 308 met at the Samantha Smith World Peace Camp in Poland Spring, Me., where they co-produced a play. They kept in touch, and in January of this year arrangements were made for the Russian students to spend two weeks at the Maine camp, followed by the current visit with their Darien friends for their presentation of "Romeo and Juliet."
Students and parents involved in Theater 308 spent months raising the money for the Russians' trip through various events.
Performances are scheduled at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday, with tickets priced at $10, $6 for students and elderly people. Those who wish to attend a reception on Saturday as well as the performance may become sponsors at $20, patrons at $40, and angels at $100 or more. Call 655-0544 for reservations or more information.
 
SHUBERT OPEN HOUSE
 The Shubert Performing Arts Center in New Haven will stage its annual open house on Saturday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., free of charge. More than 6,000 people took advantage last year of the day of music, dancing, comedy, juggling and storytelling, offered by the theater company.
Children will have their own mezzanine loft where a program of interactive theater and storytelling is scheduled. Visitors will also be guided through the theater's backstage area and dressing rooms.
Refreshments and prizes will be distributed all day, and a long list of on-stage entertainers, including the Shubert Opera Ensemble and Kindercorp, the Connecticut Gay Men's Chorus, the Stony Creek Improv Theater, the Elm City Cloggers, Amazing Andy the Magician, folk and blues singers and ventriloquists. The theater is at 247 College Street and more information may be obtained by calling 624-1825.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Rejuvenating Bridgeport;
A Fully Leased Renovation

 BODY:
Long mired in a seemingly hopeless economic morass, Bridgeport, the largest city in Connecticut, is taking a major step toward rejuvenation with the renovation of the vacant former People's Bank headquarters in the downtown business district.
Mayor Joseph P. Ganim unveiled a rendering of the project this month at the start of renovations for the 11-story, 113,000-square-foot building, which is already fully leased. Among the tenants are an accounting firm, a law firm and the Southern Connecticut Gas Company. 
 Another tenant will be People's Bank, now based across the street in the Bridgeport Center. It will move some of its offices elsewhere into 12,000 square feet.
The bank is paying $4 million to renovate the building, which will be ready for occupancy on Dec. 1. The work includes a new polished granite exterior that architecturally complements the Bridgeport Center. The architect is Fletcher Thompson of Bridgeport.
The new offices will accommodate 300 jobs that would have left Bridgeport. About 50 new jobs will also be created by companies in the building.
"We welcome this new activity in the downtown area and appreciate the committed effort of People's Bank to create jobs, tax revenues and a stronger business community," Mr. Ganim said. "For those who live and work here, the beginning of a revitalized Bridgeport is now real."

GRAPHIC: Drawing of People's Bank building in Bridgeport. (Fletcher Thompson)
