HEADLINE: History Through War Collectibles

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
ON the third Monday of every month, the Veterans of Foreign Wars post here is transformed from a sleepy little gathering hall into a living history lesson, with its instructors as diverse and colorful as the long-ago campaigns to which they are attracted.
The participants, armed with boxes of artifacts like a Civil War cap and a thermos bottle from a B-17 bomber, fill the folding tables with military items that for some collectors represent a lifetime of hunting, scouring and searching to piece together moments of history from the Revolutionary War to the Persian Gulf. 
 The gathering of the Eastern Militaria Collectors Association has only the dedicated history buff in mind. And with observances of the 50th anniversary of World War II, military collectibles have taken on the same importance and value as dealing in rare coins and stamps, hobbyists say.
 
'Each One Has a Story'
 Thomas Flurchick of Waldwick, who, 21 years ago, founded the Paramus-based collectors' association, said: "When we were kids, we read about battles in American history class or saw newsreels and it meant little; its impact was just words on paper. But to see such items, to hold them in your hands and study them and know that each one has a story to tell, a deed to be remembered, that makes history a living concept instead of a boring lecture."
Mr. Flurchick, 50 years old, is a video production director.
The value of military collectibles has risen sharply. Depending upon the item and its historical significance, what was bought at garage or estate sales for next to nothing, Mr. Flurchick said, now has a value of hundreds or even thousands of dollars.
Because of this, and especially in terms of foreign service medals, forgeries are common, and a keen eye must be developed to tell the authentic from the fake. Copying American medals is akin to counterfeiting United States currency and carries similar penalties, Mr. Flurchick said.
It is not uncommon for a collector's table to display a weathered Union Army officer's cavalry sword along with an Iraqi helmet complete with camouflage netting. Before long, collectors and visitors can find themselves exchanging tales of Shiloh, Pickett's Charge, Midway and Basra.
 
Swapping as Well as Selling
 As much swapping as selling takes place at the gathering. For Severino Mendez of Flushing, Queens, the curator of the Sea-Air-Space Museum aboard the decommissioned aircraft carrier Intrepid, the gathering is a chance to upgrade and enhance displays at the museum.
"When people walk through the Intrepid and see all the items on display, one of the first questions we get is, 'Where do you find stuff like this?' " Mr. Mendez said. "The answer is groups such as this, and it's always been a wonderful source of history for myself and the museum."
For Thomas J. McGurr, 61, of Teaneck, a Navy veteran and electrical contractor, a meeting is a welcome chance to "get out of my wife's hair for the night," he said, and swap service stories with other veterans. But, more importantly, it is a hedge against what is for him a failing economy. In recent years, Mr. McGurr's contracting business has suffered, he said, and has forced him to lay off a number of employees.
Mr. McGurr, a collector of memorabilia for some 40 years, said he had been forced to sell off a good part of his collection, particularly a vast assortment of stylized ivory-handled pocket knives from ports around the world that he purchased when he was in the merchant marine. "It helps to make ends meet," he said.
 
'Interesting Characters'
 Mr. McGurr and other collectors say the meetings draw "some interesting characters."
"There was this one guy who used to come here, a Navy vet like myself," Mr. McGurr said, "and every time I saw him, we got to talking about the old days; his rank would change. First time I met him, he was a seaman. The next time he was a higher grade, and a higher one after that.
"Finally it got to the point where whenever I saw him, I'd just call him Admiral and leave it at that. I guess he was lonely and just needed someone to talk to. Maybe his kids and grandkids had heard the stories one too many times."
For Ron Foreso, 40, of Stanhope, the living history lesson is something he takes back and incorporates in lesson plans for his students. A teacher of American history at Parsippany High School, he also teaches an elective course on American military history.
"When we talk about the Civil War in class, it's tough for kids today to have a concept of what took place back then and why," Mr. Foreso said. "But when we talk about the stifling summers when troops marched hundreds of miles to do battle, bringing in a heavy woolen coat from the era, or a sword, brings it home to them in a way like no other."
 
Students Dressed in Uniforms
 He mentioned a recent school program observing the 50th anniversary of World War II in which big-band songs played by student musicians were enhanced by a number of his students dressed in period service uniforms from his collection.
"There were about 200 older veterans in the audience, and when the theme song to each of the services was played, like the Marine Corps anthem, the veterans in that service would stand, and so would the students dressed in that uniform," Mr. Foreso said.
"Well, before you knew it, the kids' eyes would fill with tears, the veterans' eyes would well up and generations were brought together in a moment without a need for words."
Mr. Flurchick said: "What we do here does not glorify war, past or present, nor do we want to give the impression that we condone it, but how many thousands of men and women died for their country or came back maimed in service to it and still went on with their lives? That's what we're trying to remember here. That kind of sacrifice, no matter how great or small, must live on, and in a way, we're its caretakers."

HEADLINE: County Fights Plan on Power For Con Ed

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER officials went to Albany last week to argue against building a transmission line that the county says would bring Con Edison consumers electricity they do not need and cost $1 billion more over five years than the consumers should pay.
Westchester customers would absorb $150 million of that figure, according to the county, which estimates the average county homeowner would pay $35 more a year. The remaining $850 million would be paid by consumers in New York City, the county says. 
 At issue is a contract Con Edison officials say they were forced to sign with a developer planning a massive generating plant in upstate Oswego County. The 1,000-megawatt natural gas-fired plant, the second largest in the country, will "co-generate" two kinds of energy -- electricity for Con Edison and steam for an adjacent industrial plant in the town of Scriba.
But the developer, Sithe Energies, says its Independence Project, as the Oswego plant is known, will provide significant economic and environmental benefits to downstate consumers. Opponents of the project, the developer says, have grossly exaggerated its costs to ratepayers out of fear of the competition an independent producer provides. Sithe estimates that the average homeowner in Westchester would pay $12 more a year for electricity.
The Westchester County Attorney's Office, with the unanimous support of the County Board of Legislators, joined representatives of the New York Power Authority last week to oppose the project at hearings conducted by the Public Service Commission in Albany. The commission's approval is needed to build a transmission line.
Lawyers for the county argued that Con Edison's aggressive conservation measures have reduced demand significantly and that the utility's power reserves exceed the requirements of the New York Power Pool.
The county's major argument, however, is that the contract forces Con Edison to buy energy at prices "more than twice the expected cost of energy from alternative sources," said Michael J. McDermott, the assistant county attorney, who called this a result "of a process gone awry."
 
State Regulations Are Blamed
 Mr. McDermott said the problem stems from regulations put forth by the State Public Service Commission, which regulates utilities in the state and requires Con Edison to purchase energy according to a price schedule the commission develops, as outlined in a 14-year-old Federal energy policy.
Parties in this dispute disagree about the specifics, but all agree that there have been many changes in the years since the adoption of this Federal policy, created to alleviate an energy crisis. In 1972 fuel prices were high and supplies in doubt and so the policy led to a law to stimulate independent fuel production and encourage fuel efficiency. Since then, world market prices have plummeted and supplies are now abundant. But the number of independent fuel producers is growing, under a law guaranteeing them a minimum price for their product. They are building power plants that they say are cleaner and more efficient than those owned by utilities, the majority.
The minimum-price law, the Public Utilities Regulatory Policy Act of 1978, provided that co-generators of "clean" energy would be guaranteed a market, by requiring utilities to purchase the power these plants produced at rates established by state regulatory agencies. Purchasing such co-generated power, according to the Federal law, is not supposed to cost consumers more than the alternatives.
In New York State, the Public Service Commission periodically predicts the costs of energy by evaluating changes in world supplies and conditions. The commission sets rates based on the costs it decides utilities will not incur by having to produce the energy themselves. "Long Range Avoided Cost" estimates are used by the independent producers as the basis for their contracts with the utilities.
 
Rates Revised 4 Months Later
 The Sithe contract with Con Edison was signed in May last year, after negotiations that were described by the Manhattan-based developer as cordial and that Con Edison officials said Federal and state laws "required" them to participate in.
The contract was based on rates that were set by the commission in 1990. But these rates were revised by the Commission staff four months after the contract was signed, in the wake of dramatically reduced prices and increased supplies.
"The 1990 Long-Range Avoided costs overstate the value of a kilowatt hour by more than double," Mr. McDermott argued in his statement to the Public Service Commission last week, pointing to what he said are "huge cost consequences for Con Edison's electrical customers," amounting to more than $1 billion.
"If Sithe had negotiated a contract based on flucutating fuel costs, that would be fine," said Edward M. Gibbs, administrator of the Westchester County Public Utility Agency, an organization established a decade ago to provide sources of low-cost power for Westchester customers.
 
Intervention Requested
 Calling the company's decision to use a fixed rate "an aberration," Mr. Gibbs said the Public Service Commission must intervene. The expected rate increase, he said, is "unconscionable."
"This is the coup de grace for Westchester rate payers," Mr. Gibbs added.
Last week, a spokeman for the Public Service Commission said the agency cannot intervene in contract disputes. Although Con Edison is required to contract with independent power producers for their energy, Edward C. Collins, the spokesman, said, "It was not necessary to sign the one they did. They could have tried to negotiate."
Harold E. Vogt, executive vice president of the County Chamber of Commerce, has also blamed Public Service Commission regulations "for entitling the developer to prices based on outdated utility-cost projections."
In his reply last week, Peter A. Bradford, chairman of the commission, observed: "Con Edison was not forced to sign the contract. Indeed, if they believed that the price for this power was too high, they should not have signed."
 
Why Sithe Chose Con Ed
 The storm of recent opposition to a contract negotiated over a two-year period has surprised representatives of Sithe Energies. The suggestion of a $1 billion "overrun" he said is "an attractive sound bite that is just false," said Bruce J. Wrobel, executive vice president of Sithe Energies.
The new plant is "the most efficient and cleanest" ever proposed in the nation, he said, and downstate customers of Con Edison will receive an estimated $1.6 billion in environmental benefits, such as reductions in the cost of running the emission control systems needed for older plants.
The company chose Con Edison to receive its energy, Mr. Wrobel said, because it is the utility in the state "most in need of new capacity" produced by modern, environmentally safe plants.
"Con Ed has the most oil-fired generation," Mr. Wrobel said. "So the environmental benefits of our plant will be maximized."
 
Benefits for Oswego
 Oswego County has issued a $750 million industrial-development bond to finance the plant in Scriba. Kathryn E. Torba, executive assistant to Mayor Terrence M. Hammill of the city of Oswego, said local residents strongly support a plant that could bring $48 million in yearly earnings and provide 1,300 construction jobs during the two years it would take to build.
Acknowledging downstate concerns, Mrs. Torba said: "Obviously, they have a legitimate right to be concerned, but we're not sure their utility bills will go up. Many plants around the state are getting older and will neeed to be replaced. We're not sure our breathren downstate will be affected."
In Westchester, Mr. Gibbs strongly disagreed. "We support co-generation, and we're certainly in favor of jobs," he said. "But not on the backs of our rate payers."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Decade Later, Mexico Is Loved By Investors

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Happy birthday to a great bull market.
There were no parties to mark the occasion, but the great 1980's bull market turned 10 last week. As it happened, it was Mexico, and the threat it posed, that was scaring many in this country both when that decade began and when it ended. 
 The fear in 1982 was easier to understand. It was on Aug. 12, 1982, that the right of foreigners to withdraw dollar deposits from Mexican banks was suspended. Only devalued pesos were available. The international debt crisis had begun.
Bull markets, the Wall Street cliche says, climb a wall of worry. Never was that truer than a decade ago. Amid a severe recession and talk of financial collapse, the United States stock market hit bottom that very day, and began a rise that, by now, has caused the average stock to more than quadruple.
Just 10 years later, on Aug. 12, 1992, the deal known as Nafta -- North American Free Trade Agreement -- was signed by the Governments of Mexico, Canada and the United States. While there are enough exceptions to make "free trade" an overstatement, the agreement, if ratified, will be a step in that direction.
Anyone who has not focused on Mexico in the last few years must be surprised by the tenor of the current debate. A decade ago, the talk was of a collapsing economy that could not pay its bills and would drag the international economy down with it. Now, to hear some union officials tell it, Mexico is an economic threat that is all but certain to steal every manufacturing job left in the United States economy.
In fact, Mexico has plenty of its own problems, including a shortage of skilled labor, but the financial community is nonetheless in love with it, for the simple reason that the Mexican stock market has been a phenomenal performer. The Financial Times/Actuaries index of Mexican stocks, in dollars, is now more than 70 times higher than it was at the end of August 1982.
It took North American investors a while to warm to the idea of Mexican equities, but by early this year their money was pouring in. The timing was unfortunate. From a peak in March, Mexican stocks fell 27 percent to a low in late July, and have done little since. The signing of the free-trade deal last week caused barely a ripple.
Nonetheless, investment interest remains high. Dividend yields are minuscule -- about 1.3 percent -- but the belief in continued rapid growth is high, and the companies are not trading at huge multiples of forecasted earnings. Luis R. Luis, who watches Mexico for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, a mutual fund group, argues that low dividends are good, because the companies have excellent ways to reinvest their capital.
A decade ago, American stocks traded at low multiples of book value, and were shunned. And everyone knew Mexico was a horrible place to put money. Now, the reverse is true on both counts. Perhaps, just perhaps, the conventional wisdom will, once again, be disappointed.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 9-14

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Mexico Question 

For President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, the tough job now is getting their governments to approve the free-trade pact they negotiated with Mexico. For President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, the job will be easier: "It will be passed immediately," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, president of Ecanal, an economic consulting firm in Mexico City. The problem in the North is that labor groups are worried that Mexico's younger, less expensive work force will siphon away jobs. But Mexican economists are not so sure. "Even if Mexico has relatively low wages, it will take a long time before those wages can be materialized into equivalent productivity," Mr. de la O said. In industries like automobiles, where United States companies already have numerous plants along the border, "Mexican workers receive lower wages," he said, "but they need more supervision."

Getting Drugs to Market
 
Advances in biotechnogy have been a boon to the drug companies and a bane to the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A.'s approval pipeline is backed up, causing delays that the drug companies say can cost them $10 million a month per drug. Last week, Congress, the pharmaceutical industry and F.D.A. Commissioner David A. Kessler came up with a novel plan to cut approval time from 20 months to 12 months for regular drugs and bring it down to six months for potentially life-saving medications. To do so, the F.D.A. would hire 600 new examiners and charge the drug companies extra fees to cover them. The plan would turn over $75 million to the F.D.A. over five years.
 
Well, at Least Prices Look Good
 
As the economy's growth rate continues on its bungee jump downward from 1980's highs -- waiting nervously for that upward yank -- slow growth is providing at least one benefit: Prices are barely budging. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index for July rose by just 0.1 percent, , following a slim 0.3 percent rise the month before.

Productivity on the Rise
 
One way to get productivity gains is to invest like mad in new equipment and training so each worker produces more. That's the Japanese and German way. Another way is to trim the work force while output remains the same; dismissals keep wage demands low. That's the way it's done these days in America. As a result, according to the Labor Department, productivity rose last spring by a strong 2.3 percent. "We have had a full year of markedly lower rises in unit labor costs," said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company.
 
Politics and the R.T.C.
 
It has been one embarrassment after another for the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the savings and loan bail out. In March, the General Accounting Office told Congress the R.T.C. had lost track of at least $7 billion. Last week, R.T.C. lawyers said politics was getting in the way of business. Jacqueline P. Taylor, one of the lawyers, said the agency dropped a plan to sue officials of an S.&L. after one of the officials visited President Bush. She called it "an inappropriate settlement because of political reasons."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japan's Comfortable Slump
 
As slumps go, Japan's is the one to have. While the country's stock market may be hitting new lows, growth is still positive, unemployment is below 3 percent and the trade surplus is soaring. Last month, according to the Finance Ministry, Japan's surplus with the rest of the world reached a record $9.24 billion. But while most analysts expected the trade surplus to rise because of the effects of the slump on Japan's demand for imports, that was not the reason the surplus jumped. Exports were up for the 26th month in a row; they grew by 10.8 percent in July. America's appetite for Japanese goods remained insatiable. Its surplus with the United States jumped 27.3 percent to $3.84 billion.

A Pledge for a Guarantee
 
When Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel returned home after visiting President Bush last week, he was not empty handed. Mr. Bush announced he had reached an agreement with Mr. Rabin on the long-delayed $10 billion loan guarantee package Israel had requested. The United States will not be lending Israel the money, only guaranteeing repayment in the event Israel defaults. That will enable Israel to borrow more cheaply in the world's financial markets. The money will be used to construct housing for Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union. In return for the guarantee, Israel pledged to curtail building new Jewish settlements on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip and to reform its sagging economy. The measure is expected to go to Congress for approval around Labor Day. "I can get it through the Senate," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.

Boeing's New Russian Brains
 
The latest company to acquire some of Russia's formidable brain power is the Boeing Company. Last week it signed an agreement with the Aviation Department of Russia's Ministry of Industry to set up a development center in Moscow. The deal will enable Boeing to take advantage of advances made by Soviet engineers during the Cold War. Though behind the West in avionics and engine technology, the former Soviet Union had been a leader in airframe technology and in wind-tunnel testing. The new center will initially employ 30 Russian engineers and scientists. "The technology there is of great value to Boeing and its customers," said Larry Clarkson, a Boeing vice president.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Arm-Twisting for Chrysler
 
Analysts and car buffs agree that the Chrysler Corporation has a winning line-up in its sleek new LH series of cars. Tell that to the banks. Last week, several banks in the 152-member international consortium that lends to Chrysler refused to renew their loans. Their reluctance may threaten the new $6.8 billion loan package Chrysler is seeking to continue revamping its operations. To get some muscle on its side, Chrysler asked the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to intervene on its behalf with officials of Germany's central bank and get them to persuade an unidentified German private bank to get back with the program. Without the loans, Chrysler's prospects are bleak. "This is the most critically important issue facing Chrysler at this moment, so the agreement had better get done," said Maryann Keller, an analyst at Furman Selz Inc.

The Big Auction
 
Moving commercial properties the old-fashioned way in this real estate market isn't easy. So last week, Kennedy-Wilson Inc., the big Los Angeles auction house, and Jones Lang Wootton U.S.A., a real estate company, held an auction. They put 67 properties worth an estimated value of $500 million on the block. The properties were varied, everything from a Sausalito bayside restaurant to a Wisconsin resort developed by Playboy's Hugh Hefner. And about half were sold. "The U.S. real estate market is at its most depressed in years," said Bill McMorrow, chairman of Kennedy-Wilson. "It is a major accomplishment." Gone were 34 properties for a total of $178.2 million. Bunker Hill Towers, in downtown Los Angles, had the highest bid: It went for $19.1 million to Hon Kwok Land Investment Company Ltd., of Hong Kong.

To trim costs, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said last week it would combine its six military divisions into two divisions and sell off its helicopter business.

A Thriller From Washington
 
It was no ordinary case of theft. High-level members of the Justice Department were accused of stealing a software program developed by Inslaw, a California company, and turning it over to business associates who then sold it internationally and pocketed big profits. Last week, the House Judiciary Committee concluded that the charges were true and that Attorneys General Edwin Meese 3d and Dick Thornburgh had blocked Justice Department investigations of the case. Moreover, it recommended appointing an independent prosecutor and looking into the suicide of a journalist who was investigating the case. The evidence "raises serious concerns about the possibility that a high-level conspiracy against Inslaw did exist and that great efforts have been expended by the department to block,' an investigation, said the committee's chairman, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas.

Hughes Bucks the Trend
 
While many military contractors scramble to diversify into commercial businesses, the Hughes Aircraft Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is sticking with the Pentagon. It made an offer to purchase the division of the General Dynamics Corporation that makes cruise missiles for about $450 million worth of G.M. common stock. Last week the Justice Department said it would not block the sale

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Safety Net for Money Funds?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
At the same time that fund executives revel in the industry's prosperity, more and more of them worry about its Achilles' heel: money funds.
The public has basically been using money funds, with share prices fixed at $1, as substitutes for bank accounts. Prospectuses warn investors that share prices can fluctuate, but none has yet. Nevertheless, as the stakes grow higher -- money stashed in money funds totaled a record-breaking $569.7 billion on June 30, according to Lipper Analytical Services -- if a money fund did fall below the $1 share price a crisis of confidence might reverberate through the entire industry. 
 For some, it's just a question of time. "People are worried about money markets breaking the buck, and they're right -- one day they will," said Marianne K. Smythe, director of the division of investment management for the Securities and Exchange Commission. And that has fund leaders pondering ways to head off problems, from insuring accounts to setting up bad debt reserves to establishing capital requirements.
The fragility of money funds' fixed $1 share price surfaces from time to time. In 1989, Integrated Resources defaulted on $23 million of commercial paper held by the Value Line Money Fund. The following year, the Mortgage and Realty Trust, an investment trust that dealt mainly in commercial real estate mortgages, defaulted on its commercial paper, leaving 10 money funds holding $75 million of sharply downgraded paper.
In these cases, the relatively small size of the bailouts allowed the funds to absorb the losses rather than reduce the share price.
That may change. Today the fund industry owns 36 percent of all commercial paper outstanding, a market that has doubled in size since 1984, according to Michael L. Goldstein, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Commercial paper carries no guarantees and no insurance, and with "funds growing faster than the supply of low-risk commercial paper, eventually a financial accident could occur at a scale beyond that which can be covered by the liquid assets of management companies," he says.
Recent S.E.C. rules that limit a fund's holdings of low-rated commercial paper and force fund managers to scrutinize their credits more carefully may have averted serious problems. "But the sheer scale of the industry, combined with the rapid growth of the commercial paper market and the absence of reserves, ultimately poses a business risk," Mr. Goldstein concludes.
James L. Pierce, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, writes that money funds "present a real, though small, risk to their holders." Even so, he argues in his book "The Future of Banking," money funds are by nature better suited to handle the nation's cash flow than savings accounts, as the savings-and-loan crisis clearly shows.
That is because banks' deposit liabilities are largely backed by illiquid loans, making them vulnerable to runs and liquidity crises. By contrast, money funds back their deposits with highly liquid and relatively safe assets -- a much better match.
He concludes that, with insurance, money funds "could be made safe with little need for additional regulation or supervision."
The concept of a money fund safety net has been tossed around for years. In 1980, as part of his anti-inflation package, President Carter ordered money funds to put 15 percent of all new deposits on reserve with the Federal Reserve, earning no interest. The 34 new funds set up after that ruling yielded about 2.5 percentage points less than existing money funds. The reserve requirement was lifted after about three months, to the relief of fund sponsors, because the Fed feared a recession and wanted to loosen money.
In 1983, Vanguard introduced the Vanguard Money Market Reserves/Insured Portfolio, which bought either insured issues or private insurance for its paper. The insurance drove up the fund's costs; in 1988, its expenses were .79 percent of assets, more than double the expenses of Vanguard's Prime Money Market Reserves. That cut into yield, and investors, given the choice, opted for higher yield. In February 1989, Vanguard termed the experiment a failure and converted the $150 million fund into an all-Treasury money fund, which holds $2.2 billion today.
William E. Donoghue, the money fund guru, scoffs at the idea of insuring money funds. "With proper regulation, you don't need insurance," he said.
Still, worried fund executives are debating proposals to protect the $1 share price, according to Fund Directions, an industry newsletter. They include creating a bad debt reserve, financed by slicing off about 10 basis points of the funds' yield; setting up an industry-wide insurance pool, perhaps through some form of captive insurance company, or requiring a sponsor's capital to equal some minimum percentage of its money fund assets.
Banks pay a premium of about 23 basis points for their deposit insurance, Mr. Goldstein says, which is essentially the historical yield advantage of the average money fund over comparable-term deposits. He concludes: "The challenge for the industry is to set investor expectations about risk at levels that are sustainable."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Rabin Brings a Thaw Because He's Not Shamir

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The scenes from Kennebunkport, Me., almost made you want to rub your eyes in disbelief. Was that President Bush giving a tour of his family's seaside home to the Prime Minister of Israel? Was that Mr. and Mrs. Yitzhak Rabin staying overnight with the Bushes just like other "good friends"? Yes, after almost four years of tension and acrimony the Bush Administration and Israel are having a belated honeymoon.
Democracies have a lot of disadvantages in conducting foreign policy -- domestic constituencies, noisy opinion-makers, multiple power centers -- but the United States-Israel relationship recalls that they also have one big advantage: they can change leaders. They can go to the blackboard, erase what is on it and start over. And to some extent that is what these two long-time allies did last week. But is the rebirth of warmth in their relationship based on a real meeting of the minds between new players, or on political expediency? 
 Undoubtedly, the Rabin-Bush relationship was doomed to succeed in part because both men needed it to work for their own domestic electoral reasons. But there has also been a meeting of minds. Mr. Bush and Mr. Rabin's predecessor, Yitzhak Shamir, loathed and mistrusted one another, making the resolution of the biggest issue between their two countries -- Israel's request for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees to absorb Russian immigrants -- virtually impossible.
Mr. Shamir insisted that he be granted the guarantees without having to freeze Israeli settlement building in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip; Mr. Bush insisted that Mr. Shamir choose between loan guarantees and more settlements. As the former Israeli statesman Abba Eban writes in his forthcoming memoir, the establishment of new settlements in the occupied territories had become the obsession of the Shamir Government. "This aim," writes Mr. Eban, was "held to be more important than the absorption of Russian Jews, than the development of the peace process and the maintenance of a cooperative relationship with the United States. The alleged 'crisis' in U.S.-Israeli relations arose because Shamir required the United States to finance a policy to which American interests have always been unanimously opposed."
Mr. Bush exacerbated the crisis, though, by striking what many American Jews felt was a low blow with his statements of Sept. 12, 1991, that basically implied that there was something disloyal about American supporters of Israel lobbying for the loan guarantees over Mr. Bush's objections.
In any event, the Israeli electorate, when it ousted Mr. Shamir from office, in effect made the choice that Mr. Bush had framed, opting for loan guarantees over more settlements. That was Mr. Rabin's message to the President and Congress this week: Israel has changed "priorities." It will focus on economic development within its pre-1967 boundaries, not on building housing in densely populated Arab areas to satisfy an ideological agenda. Mr. Bush responded by endorsing the loan guarantees, and the biggest thorn in the relationship was removed.
There are others, but at least they can be confronted more amicably. The biggest issue involves the peace talks set to resume on Aug. 24. During the cold war the main issue in the United States-Israel relationship was how Israel could disentangle itself enough from its conflict with the Palestinians to be an effective ally of the United States against the Soviet Union. In the post-cold war Middle East, the biggest threats are radical fundamentalism and missile proliferation, issues American officials believe can be resolved only in peace agreements between not only Israel and the Palestinians, but in agreements that integrate Israel into the wider Arab world.
 
Toughest Issue: Peace Talks
 The door to that wider world is Syria. Whether the Syrians are ready for such a deal is a very open question. But if there is a structural problem between Mr. Rabin and Mr. Bush, it will be Mr. Rabin's desire to focus on granting limited self-rule to the Palestinians, while leaving the explosive issue of Syria until later, and Washington's desire that he offer some of land-for-peace deal with Damascus. The Syrians may be vulnerable to a deal now. The phones don't work there, the roads are in disrepair, the economy is stalled. In many ways, Syria today resembles Rumania or Bulgaria before the fall of their totalitarian regimes.
"In an odd way, the peace process is artificially keeping the Syrian regime alive," argued Stephen P. Cohen, director of the Montreal-based Center for Middle East Peace. "Because of the need to integrate Syria into the Gulf war coalition and the peace process, the full force of the winds of change on the international stage have not hit Syria the way they have hit others. Washington has given the regime there a certain legitimacy, because it is needed for the peace process. This has enabled the Syrians to jump over the barrier from the old world to the new one. But to stay there they eventually have to produce at the peace table."
Will any of this be different if the Democrats win?
"I think Clinton starts with a more positive gut attitude toward Israel than President Bush," said Steven L. Spiegel, an expert on American Presidents and the Middle East, "but I think he would spend less time on the Middle East generally. Baker and Bush cared a lot about the Middle East. It is not that Clinton doesn't, but simply that his focus will be on America. I just don't see him micro-managing Middle East diplomacy. Health care is the sort of issue he will micro-manage, not the Middle East."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Nuclear Power Plants Take Early Retirement

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
IN March, Lehman Brothers, the Wall Street investment house, held a half-day conference titled "Are Older Nuclear Plants Still Economic?" Last week an Oregon utility announced plans to shut a plant that is just 16 years old, the third such retirement announcement this year. Paul C. Parshley, the organizer of the March conference, said that perhaps he had misnamed his event. The question is not whether the older reactors are economically sensible to operate, he said, but whether any are.
When is a reactor old? If Trojan, the Rainier, Ore., plant, is indeed closed in 1996, it would be only halfway through its anticipated 40-year life span. Reactors seem to age on some accelerated calendar. Trojan's steam generator is deteriorating. The part is like a quarterback's worn-out knees: it tends to be the component that forces a decision. Steam generators, which transfer heat energy out of the reactor, are common to one type of plant, but each design has a characteristic weak spot that grows worse with age. 
 The nuclear industry was well on its way to extinction, even before the announcement by Portland General Electric, which owns and operates Trojan. There are few replacements in sight for Trojan and 109 other commercial operating plants.
Throwing in the towel on a plant like Trojan is a painful decision. In the era of "not in my backyard," it means giving up operating permits that will be hard to replace. And running it longer would give more time to accumulate money for tearing it down and disposing of nuclear wastes; so far there is $25 million in the company's piggy bank against a cost it has estimated to be at anywhere from $200 million to nearly $500 million.
But the world has turned nasty for Trojan, in ways the builders never expected. When Trojan entered service, Congress made it illegal to build new gas-fired power plants, because the accepted theory was that North America was running out of gas. Now Canadian gas supplies glut the West Coast, making gas a cheaper power source than a wheezing reactor.
And in the early years of Trojan's life, demand for power was galloping ahead by as much as 7 percent a year. But today, a refrigerator bought at an appliance store in Portland General's service territory uses half the electricity of an average model bought when Trojan was new.
Those factors affect many plants, but not all are threatened. "You're looking at a universe of 110 reactors," said Carl Goldstein, a spokesman for the U.S. Committee for Energy Awareness, the nuclear industry's public relations arm. "It doesn't seem startling to me that you have some defections." Trojan, he said, faced stiffer political opposition than most plants. It survived statewide referendums in 1986 and 1990; another is due this November. It was in a region with so much hydroelectricity that it was not needed year-round, a disadvantage for a capital-intensive technology.
 
Political Challenges
 Some detrimental factors can change, said Mr. Goldstein. The price of gas will rise someday, and the Clean Air Act will make coal, which is the main source of electricity, more expensive.
And some reactors may be able to run much longer. Those that are well-maintained could continue for a long time, said Mr. Parshley, the Lehman Brothers executive who organized the March conference. But their overall durability will only be proven plant by plant. Last year the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved a procedure for utilities to apply for 20-year extensions to their plants' 40-year licenses. The plant that was widely expected to apply first, however, Yankee Rowe in Rowe, Mass., quit at age 32 earlier this year.
Not every piece of machinery wears out early. "You have children of B-52 pilots flying B-52's now," Mr. Parshley said.
Utilities and regulators are scrutinizing the alternatives to reactors more closely. A company might choose to spend $50 million on subsidies to customers who replace their old, inefficient refrigerators and air conditioners, because that will do more to solve the power problem than spending the money on building, fueling and staffing a new plant. Or the company might find it cheaper to buy power from independent generators. Two days after its Trojan announcement, Portland General Electric said that it would put money in windmills.
 
Brain Drain
 Under a new planning system, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation is scheduled to explain this fall to the New York Public Service Commission why operating the Nine Mile Point 1 reactor is more cost-effective than spending the money elsewhere. Commonwealth Edison, which services the Chicago area, has threatened to shut some of its older reactors to save money.
Most companies, however, are reluctant to raise that possibility for fear of destroying morale and setting off a potentially dangerous exodus of trained staff. Scott Denman, a spokesman for the Washington-based Safe Energy Communications Council, predicted that the decision at Trojan would set off a "brain drain."
Mr. Denman and others think more plants will follow Trojan's example. They point to Oyster Creek in Lacey Township, N.J., and Big Rock Point, a tiny plant in Charlevoix, Mich., that opened in 1965, saying they are in a "do not resuscitate" category, unlikely to survive if substantial investment is needed.
Meanwhile, Trojan's status is still not clear. Opponents of the plant have already spent over $1 million promoting a ballot initiative this year to close it, and are not giving up. "If they don't think they can go on," said Lloyd K. Marbet, a leader of the campaign, "why provide them four more years to limp?"

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Rich Get Richer, But Never the Same Way Twice

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
IN the late 1970's, during the Carter Presidency, the super-rich commanded a smaller slice of America's wealth than at any time since the 1830's, when Alexis de Tocqueville was struck by "the general equality of condition among the people" in the fledgling democracy.
By the end of the 1980's, soon after Ronald Reagan left the White House, wealth in this country had become more concentrated than at any time since the Roaring Twenties. The share of net worth -- assets minus debts -- held by the top 1 percent of households jumped from below 20 percent in 1979 to more than 36 percent in 1989, acording to a new historical data series compiled by the economic historians Claudia Goldin and Bradford De Long at Harvard University and the economist Edward Wolff at New York University. 
 Counting wealth rather than income is a dauntingly imprecise task even in the computer age. But the numbers are more than educated guesses. The researchers tapped studies of probate records and estate tax filings for the distant past and elaborate Federal Reserve surveys of consumer finances for recent decades.
By the 1990's, billionaires had became far more common, if not exactly commonplace. There were only 21 in 1982 (one for every 11 million Americans). By 1991, despite recession, there were 71 -- one Bill Gates, Sam Walton or Ross Perot for every 3.5 million ordinary folk.
If the pattern suggested by the data is accurate, the wealthy's share of the total wealth expanded as much during the Reagan boom as it did in the 100 years -- roughly 1830 to 1929 -- in which America transformed itself from an egalitarian land of small farmers into the world's reigning industrial power.
 
Three Great Cycles
 "Economists have conjectured that over the process of economic development the distribution of wealth started out more equal, turned less equal and then got more equal again as education became more widespread," said Professor Goldin. "The 1980's contradict that."
As the United States has prospered over the past 200 years, the share of wealth in the hands of truly rich -- families with mountains of assets to back up rivers of income -- has swung both high and low. Three great bursts of accumulation and at least three periods of growing equality stand out.
Each time the forces that led to greater or less concentration were different and at no time did politicians excercise anything like perfect control, notwithstanding redistributionist impulses on the part of the Democrats and Republican eagerness to disclaim all responsibility for growing inequality.
The end of Jeffersonian democracy came slowly. In the beginning, the country consisted mostly of small farmers, each owning a bit of land and different from one another only in ability, skill and luck. Industrialization was initially a slow process -- flour mills, cloth mills, iron smelters -- that served local markets and created local fortunes.
The age of moguls, which began in the late 19th century and culminated in 1929 in a frenzy of euphoria about capitalism's future, saw not just the creation of corporations, huge industries like oil, steel and meat-packing, and the birth of the mass market, but the emergence of a stock exchange that enabled the owners of capital to cash out. The growth of wages, meanwhile, was held down by a tidal wave of immigration.
In some ways, the 1980's resembled the Gilded Age and the era of robber barons. The wealthiest 1 percent reaped more than half of the $2.5 trillion rise in total net worth in the period, according to Professor Wolff, in part by building great empires in media, computers and financial services. The stock and bond markets boomed.
But history had not, in fact, repeated itself. Government had played a much bigger role in enriching the wealthy. The supply side tax cuts slashed the highest tax bracket from 70 percent to 30 percent, the high interest rates that accompanied the budget deficit and the Federal Reserve's determination to restore the value of money all swelled the value of capital.
The biggest difference, it turns out, had more to do with what was happening at the bottom than at the top. While the pay of corporate presidents soared to 160 times that of the average worker, union membership sank, and pay and productivity, which had advanced handily in the early 20th century, stagnated.
 
In 1929, the Leveling Begins
 Home ownership and participation in pension plans -- more great equalizers -- declined. Young families saw debt mount faster than the value of their assets when house prices did not rise, except in a few hotspots like California and New York.
"John D. Rockefeller was a nasty bastard, but he built the oil industry," said Professor deLong. "It's the combination of rapidly rising wealth for the Forbes 400 and slow productivity growth for the average American that's worrisome."
In the 1930's, 1940's and during the balmy postwar years, wealth also got dispersed in very different ways. The great leveling started with the 1929 stock market crash and continued, with pauses, well into the 1970's. Black Monday, bank panics and, most of all, the Great Depression destroyed fortunes. The New Deal took from the monied and gave to the poor and middle class. Washington collected more income and inheritance taxes. More important, the New Deal saved the homes, farms and businesses of millions of ordinary Americans.
Less well known is that World War II squeezed wealth into the hands of the working classes. With millions of men in uniform, wartime labor shortages pushed up wages while price controls held down profits. What is more, the National War Labor Board -- heeding F.D.R.'s directive to raise substandard wages -- tended to approve raises for poorer workers while turning down raises for the better paid. The rich, meantime, had nowhere to invest except in war bonds whose value evaporated when the country inflated its way out of its huge wartime debt.
It was in the mid-1970s, after Vietnam, the oil crisis and a bad recession shattered business confidence, that the wealthy's share hit a low point -- in no small part because of a 1973-1975 stock market collapse that was worse than 1929-1933 when the inflation of the 1970's and the deflation of the 1930's are taken into account.
"Prices doubled, but so did wages and home values," said Professor de Long, "but holders of financial assets got hammered."
In between, the 1950's and 1960's was a golden age. The rich got richer but the middle class did so even faster. The stock market boomed, but so did suburbia. The middle class acquired houses, cars, appliances and college educations as never before.
 
Two Impalas per Garage
 "The wealth of the average American, many the children of successful immigrants, went up a lot," said Professor Goldin. "Instead of no house, people lived in Levittown," added Professor de Long. "Instead of an old '34 Ford, people had two Chevy Impalas. A bunch more people joined pension plans."
Looking ahead, it's not clear whether there are forces now at work that would repeat the American past and spread wealth and income more evenly again. A pickup in productivity growth could boost the wages of lower paid workers and let more join pension plans. On the other hand, the technological revolution could easily keep holding down the pay of the young and less skilled.
But neither the moguls nor the multitudes are acting as if they expect much change. The stock market, a barometer of the hopes of the well-heeled, continues to dance near all-time highs. In stark contrast, consumer confidence, which measures the expectations of wage earners, remains unusually depressed.

HEADLINE: DON'T LOOK BACK;
As Bush Runs Again, History Nips at His Heels

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LOOKING backward is the last thing President Bush wants to do at the Republican National Convention in Houston this week -- for two reasons. Politically, the clear plan for his campaign is to emphasize the future, to nod to the past only to suggest that the next four years will have domestic success to rival the foreign policy triumphs of the last four.
As James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State, proclaimed as he prepared to leave his second Cabinet office for his fourth Bush Presidential campaign, "It's now time to turn to new challenges." He said that from now on "President Bush will target America." 
 Nor would a longer look back, at other campaigns for re-election to the Presidency, do much for the candidate's morale. The depressing message of history is that when Presidents have run to retain the White House in circumstances like Mr. Bush's, they have lost far more often than they have won.
It is deceptive to recall landslide re-elections from Franklin D. Roosevelt's to Ronald Reagan's, and to conclude from them that there is something normal about eight years in the White House, something extraordinary about denying a President a second term. It may be natural enough; most of the losers were not very memorable Presidents. After all, who spends much time thinking about the accomplishments of one-termers like Martin Van Buren, Benjamin Harrison or even William Howard Taft?
In fact, there have been periods when re-election was the norm, and others when it was extraordinary.
In the earliest days of the Republic, five of the first seven Presidents were re-elected, and without much trouble at that. That changed in 1840, when Van Buren, a Democrat, was defeated by William Henry Harrison. Starting in that year, party strengths were closely matched. So, except for the special circumstances of the Civil War, which accounted for two terms each for Abraham Lincoln and Ulysses S. Grant, no one won a second term until 1900.
The 1840 election has some similarities to this year's. It was held in a lingering depression. The Whigs spurned their old contenders like Daniel Webster and Henry Clay and picked a new face. It was the first election dominated by gimmicks, songs and slogans, like "Tippecanoe and Tyler Too," and the meanest slur against the incumbent -- the Whigs chanted "Van, Van, a Used-Up Man" -- is not all that different from some of today's gibes at Mr. Bush.
One mistake the Republicans seem determined not to replicate is the one Van Buren made in looking backward to his patron, Andrew Jackson, and especially to his old issues. Of course, today the Republicans may occasionally raise old issues out of habit. Their party chairman, Richard N. Bond, last week managed to make up for the absence of Soviet Communists from the scene by accusing Bill Clinton of planning to invite Fidel Castro to a state dinner.
It is not easy to red-bait without Reds. One can expect Mr. Baker to change that, fast, and to see that the campaign looks forward, not back. Of course, this century's elections are more prominent in the minds of candidates and their handlers. And re-elections have been frequent. From 1932 to 1974, there was only one President, John F. Kennedy, who did not take the oath of office at least twice.
But the two-term norm may be over. Prof. Joel H. Silbey of Cornell University thinks that is changing again, with one-term Presidents likely except in cases of exceptional personalities, like Reagan's.
It is not just the decline of parties that he sees as responsible, though that matters, but also the gap between hopes and reality: "Nobody can be a hero for very long. Today we have such a negative attitude toward government, contrasted with such high expectations that no one can succeed."
Still, nobody, least of all Mr. Bush, is going to assume that incumbents cannot be re-elected. At worst, they might agree that it will be harder. And there are plenty of past examples to look to. This is the 19th Presidential election of this century, and the 15th in which an incumbent was running. Many of them were elected to new terms easily. William McKinley, Theodore Roosevelt, Calvin Coolidge, F.D.R. (three times), Dwight D. Eisenhower, Lyndon B. Johnson, Richard M. Nixon and Mr. Reagan all had little trouble.
But not in their wildest dreams do Republicans think Mr. Bush will have an easy victory. So the other five races may have more parallels to today, for in each case the incumbent faced a tough fight. Mr. Taft lost when the Ross Perot of his day, former President Theodore Roosevelt, ran as a third-party candidate and split the Republican vote in 1912. Woodrow Wilson squeaked through in 1916 as the peace candidate, with the Republicans still embittered and divided.
Harry S. Truman ran the classic comeback in 1948. He campaigned nonstop, attacking Republicans and proposing programs of his own, while the Republicans took victory for granted in 1948. Mr. Bush may follow his example and condemn the "do-nothing 102d Congress," but he cannot count on Mr. Clinton's loafing through October the way Thomas E. Dewey did.
Gerald R. Ford in 1976 and Jimmy Carter in 1980 had both confronted serious intraparty challenges for renomination, both had economic problems to overcome, and each had one more special problem. Mr. Ford had pardoned Mr. Nixon, and Mr. Carter had hostages held in Iran.
 
12 Years and OutThe Rule of Dozens?
 There is not, as Arthur Schlesinger, a professor in the humanities at the City University of New York, pointed out, "any profound pattern in all this." But bad economic times have always mattered, and the veteran of the Kennedy White House added cheerfully, "Carter, Hoover, and, one hopes, Bush were casualties of permitting economic troubles to overwhelm them."
Thomas Cronin, a political scientist at Colorado College, says another influence has been at work in the past, and perhaps again today. Except around the Civil War and the Second World War, a party has held the Presidency for more than 12 years only once, when Republicans occupied the White House from 1896 to 1912.
"This is the end of a 12-year run," he said. These days, how often does a sitcom or a play have a 12-year run?" This long into a party's control, he said, "the energy and the batteries wear down." Talent gets stretched thin, he said, and this Administration seems to have only one "savior figure" in the indispensable Mr. Baker.
Some less metaphorically inclined political scientists have developed complex, deterministic formulas that take a dash of economic statistics, a pinch of poll data from questions about whether the public approves of how a President is doing his job, and some secret ingredients to try to predict results. Then, when the results don't quite match the formula, they may tinker with the formula.
Most political scientists think the economy is often the dominant influence on voting, and not just the public's sense of the current state of the economy -- or Franklin Roosevelt would not have been re-elected in 1936 -- but their sense of whether things were getting better or not.
And, since Presidents are given credit or blame, deserved or not, for how the economy functions, those perceptions weigh heavily in poll answers about how a President is doing his job, a question Gallup started asking in the 1930's. Mr. Bush's rating, at 30 percent in the last New York Times/CBS News Poll, is lower than the lowest election year rating of any President who won re-election. Truman's lowest figure in 1948 was 36 percent, before he began campaigning. Mr. Carter's drooped to 26 percent in August 1980, and Mr. Ford's never got below 45 percent in 1976.
There are even simpler formulas. One was suggested last week by Edward R. Tufte, a professor of statistics and political science at Yale. He has a complicated equation involving approval ratings and per-capita disposable income, and it predicts a Clinton victory this time.
 
An Omen for Clinton?
 So does his Eli Axiom, but it goes further. It predicts not only the result this year but the 1996 outcome, too. The Axiom is historically grounded in both election results and the records of Yale University.
Neither William Howard Taft, class of 1878, nor Gerald Ford, Law School class of 1941, could retain the White House. If Yalies just cannot win a second term, then Mr. Bush, class of 1948, will be defeated this time -- and Mr. Clinton, Law School class of 1973, will lose four years from now.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Victim Has a Blue Collar, But Free Trade Has an Alibi

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
To many, the free trade agreement with Canada and Mexico, announced last week by President Bush, carries the weight of inevitability. With Europe being transformed into one great marketplace and Japanese middle managers spending Saturdays learning to speak Thai, the United States can hardly afford to keep a distance from its closest neighbors. And so the President is asking Congress to go along with an accord that would, among other things, virtually eliminate customs duties while opening Mexico to America's muscular financial services industries.
But for all the reassuring econo-babble about reaping the mutual gains from global competition, Americans surely harbor suspicions that what is good for most is not necessarily good for all. And those suspicions focus on the plight of the nation's unskilled workers. 
 Is the movement of goods, capital -- even whole factories -- destroying America's blue-collar middle class? Have free traders made a Faustian bargain, exchanging well-paid manufacturing jobs for a cornucopia of fresher vegetables and cheaper blue jeans?
 
Misplaced Blame
 Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader and a key player in the battle over the deal with Mexico, fears the worst: "How are Americans to compete with workers making 50 cents an hour?" he asked. And his worries are echoed by Gov. Bill Clinton, who seems inclined to go with the free-trade flow, but vows to invest billions in training and technology to restore American workers' productivity edge.
But economists of diverse political stripes, including many alarmed by the growing wage gap, think opponents of free trade in general and the open border with Mexico in particular have misplaced the blame. They argue that while the explosion in trade and international capital movements is likely contributing to the blue-collar squeeze, other factors -- notably technological change -- have been far more significant.
Most important, perhaps, they see no practical alternative to open trade. "The protectionist cure is no cure at all," said Alan Deardorff of the University of Michigan: "The people you want to help are helped least."
While traditional theory does indeed suggest that open trade must come at the expense of the productive resources that are relatively abundant abroad -- unskilled workers -- those who have looked for evidence have never come up with the smoking gun. In fact, during the two decades of rapid trade growth following World War II the gap between blue- and white-collar wages remained very narrow by historical standards.
Economists still assume that, on balance, open trade destroys more unskilled jobs in the United States than it creates. But most agree with Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that the net effect is close to a wash. "Even factories producing super-computers need janitors," he said.
What, then, does explain the blue-collar plunge of the 1980's? Lawrence Katz of Harvard is not ready to write off foreign trade entirely. Mr. Katz, along with George Borjas at the University of California at San Diego and Richard Freeman of Harvard, blames the import explosion for a fifth of the increasing wage gap between high school and college graduates in the early 1980's.
But Mr. Katz notes that since the mid-1980's, exports have grown far faster than imports. Thus, paradoxically, foreign trade has served as a modest engine of blue-collar employment growth in recent years and has probably slowed the decline in wages. The explanation for the current bleak income prospects of unskilled workers, it seems, lies elsewhere.
In research just published in the American Economic Review, John Bound and George Johnson of the University of Michigan point to technological change, which they believe is largely responsible for replacing unskilled labor with machines and educated minds. And Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University offers what he calls the "rolling stone" theory.
 
Rolling Stones, Gathering Zilch
 Mr. Bhagwati notes that blue-collar workers uniquely depend on work experience and seniority to supplement earning power. But he believes that rapid changes in the location and product mix of corporations, along with their increasing reluctance to hang onto employees in hard times, are limiting workers' opportunities.
Rex Hardesty, information director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., takes all this ivory tower theorizing with a grain of salt. "If we were importing academics from Japan instead of autos," he said, "they would think differently about trade."
And Mr. Hardesty does strike a sensitive chord: Even if some workers are gaining from trade, one could hardly blame unions for defending those reduced to slathering special sauce on the sesame seed buns. But here, too, there is less to the protectionist case than meets the eye.
Mr. Deardorff and his Michigan colleague John Haveman compared poverty rates in industries (and nearby communities) that have secured protection with poverty rates elsewhere. And they found that high-wage industries in relatively wealthy places were far more successful in building barriers to imports. Washington, it seems, blesses the children who already have their own.
Workers and their companies represent only one side of the income equation; protection also affects living standards by raising consumer prices. Thus the only way to tell whether protection tilts income toward rich or poor is to account for both.
 
Higher Wages, Steeper Prices
 The classic study in this vein, on the textile and apparel industry, is now five years old. But its author, William Cline of the Institute for International Economics, does not think much has changed.
On the one side, protection raises the wages of the industry's workers, most of whom are relatively poor. On the other, it increases the cost of clothing for all the poor. And it generates profits for company owners.
Mr. Cline found that every income class lost: Much of the benefit from quotas actually went to foreign producers, who reaped a price windfall from the restriction on competition. But some Americans lost more than others: The bottom fifth lost 3.6 percent of their incomes while the top fifth lost just 0.3 percent.
Carla A. Hills, America's chief trade negotiator, says the overall loss from protection is a modest 1 percent of national income. But Ms. Hills's economists estimate that protection lowers the purchasing power of the poorest families by a whopping 23 percent.
Protectionism, in the words of Mr. Katz, "is a loser." What, then, should Washington be doing?
Mr. Bhagwati suggests subsidizing the working poor. But the long-term fix -- the one more likely to win popular favor -- is to add to the skills, and thus the earning power, of workers at the bottom.

PUB-DATE: August 16, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 2060 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Weary and Feeling the Presidency's Weight

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
His aides see it sometimes around his eyes, an expression of weariness that was not there before.
The Peter Pan President who seemed to grow younger and bouncier during the first years of his Administration has faced health problems and staff problems and political problems, and he has finally felt the weight of the office he once wore so lightly.
 
Gleaming, for a Moment
 When George Bush put his old Texas pal, James A. Baker 3d, in charge of the future this week, he recovered some of his gleam -- at least momentarily. The President laughingly defended himself to his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, for wearing white socks to a press conference with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. He returned to his favorite rituals, poking fun at his straight man, Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and trading spicy jokes with Mr. Baker. 
 "Obviously, a burden was lifted," Mr. Scowcroft said. "He seemed more lighthearted."
And yet, when Mr. Bush came into the White House senior staff meeting on Thursday morning to make the announcement that Mr. Baker would again be his political alter ego, he looked more somber than excited.
The 68-year-old politician who hates handlers had stumbled so badly that he had to give himself up to handlers for another major resynthesizing job. George Bush is, in many ways, right back where he was four years ago.
He must give the speech of his life at the Republican convention. He must defend his choice of Dan Quayle as Vice President. He must try to win over suspicious conservatives with the help of a prime-time blessing by Ronald Reagan. He had to plead with Mr. Baker, again, to save his chaotic campaign and now, again, has to put up with headlines that proclaim "Baker to the rescue." And he has to begin explaining all over again who he is, what he stands for, and where he wants to take the country.
Now comes the test: Is the problem that the President has not been getting out an effective message, as Bush loyalists claim? Or is the problem the reality of Mr. Bush's record, as Clinton strategists argue?
The President's new masterminds will try to make the public forget the large chunks of the Bush Presidency that were static, muddled and inconsistent. Instead, they will once again portray Mr. Bush as a man with iron principles, staunch ideology and a coherent framework for governing the country.
Everyone knows it will not be easy.
"George is kind of like Houdini at this point," said the President's brother, Jonathan Bush, an investment banker who has come to the convention as a delegate from New York. "They've shackled him. They've locked the trunk. They've wrapped eight chains around the trunk and you think they have him in there for good. But he'll get out."
Despite Mr. Bush's odd passivity so far this year, his friends cling to their faith that Mr. Bush is at his most dangerous at just such moments, when he is trapped and starts fighting with the ferocity of the timid schoolboy cornered by the class bully.
"George Bush has an internal gyroscope system that has never failed him, at every point when he was underestimated by somebody," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, a Bush confidant. "I would hate to be in the fourth quarter of any contest, in the last hours of the day, if he were behind with a chance to prevail, because he reaches down and pulls up something from down deep in his gut and his eyes sparkle and he gets that smile on his face and here he comes."
After eight years sutured to President Reagan, Mr. Bush wanted to be himself, indulging his butterfly attention span and his patchwork political philosophy. The result was an "in-box" Presidency, taking problems as they came in, offering a series of results rather than a consistent program with a clear philosophy.
 
'It's Crazy Out There'
 Those close to George Bush say that he has felt frustrated, angry and confused at the criticism he has received from all sides in the last few months. If many Americans are befuddled by the President's passivity on the domestic front, Mr. Bush is befuddled by what he sees as the fickleness of the public and the press, and the "screwy climate" in the country.
Jonathan Bush came to the airport to meet his brother when he came to New York recently for a campaign appearance and the President fretted, "It's crazy out there."
Upset by defections in his own party, the former Navy pilot urges audiences to be loyal by using the analogy of his wing man in World War II. Speaking to a group of House Republicans and a group of businessmen in recent private meetings, he said he was tired of Republicans "peeling off," and that this was a time to "stick," not "cut and run."
"When I was down in the water, the wing man was there to protect me, not to do something else," he chastised the Republican lawmakers.
The last year has represented a rejection that is very painful for a man who never took criticism easily and who, despite all his protestations that he pays no attention to polls, loved his high poll numbers.
Six months ago, he began telling friends that the race would be ugly and painful, and that he was not looking forward to it.
"He knew what was coming; he said, 'I'll be ready,' " Senator Simpson recalled. "I said, 'You're going to have to hang by your thumbs for 10 months.' These Democrats want it so bad, they are lusting so bad, their bodies are twitching with wanting the White House."
Republicans close to Mr. Bush, who had begun to despair and panic, were thrilled and relieved in recent weeks to see him turn up the volume.
Representative Jerry Lewis of California, a longtime Bush supporter, recalled a recent meeting with Republican House members at the Capitol where the President waved his arms and pounded the podium so hard that one of his Presidential seal cuff links flew off.
An elated Mr. Lewis picked it up off the floor after the meeting and plans to frame the fragment as a memento of the moment in 1992 when he saw the President engage in the battle.
"He has a strong feeling that if anybody goes from third place to a 30-point lead in one week, as Clinton did, there are anomalies built in there that we don't understand," said Marlin Fitzwater. "It's not real. He doesn't think 40 percent of the population changes its mind in four days."
 
Regretting His Choices
 His closest advisers paint a picture of a President who regrets that, again and again, he went against his own instincts and gave in to the advice of strategists: agreeing to raise taxes as part of the 1990 budget deal; agreeing to do nothing to revive the economy after his advisers told him last year that it would be a shallow recession, succumbing to his political team's panic after the upset of Dick Thornburgh, the Republican candidate who lost to Harris Wofford in the Senate race in Pennsylvania in 1991, and allowing himself to be talked into recasting his trip to Japan in January into a domestic mission in search of "jobs, jobs, jobs."
Part of the problem, the advisers say, is that Mr. Bush is bored by domestic affairs, and had always intended to maintain the status quo on the domestic side, doing only enough to develop a re-election agenda.
"He is less sure of himself on things so complicated as the budget agreement," said one member of Mr. Bush's inner circle.
But while all of Mr. Bush's boosters talk about how he has been ill served with bad advice, their explanations raise the question: Why does he keep people around him long after he has been hurt by their advice, and why can't he simply follow his own best judgment, as he did during the Persian Gulf war? Mr. Bush is the President, after all.
His advisers say that the problem is that Mr. Bush hates dismissing people and hangs on too long, hoping that things will shake out. Long after most of his advisers urged him to replace his obstreperous chief of staff, John H. Sununu, Mr. Bush kept the man who had been instrumental in helping him win the New Hampshire primary.
Once Samuel K. Skinner was in place as chief of staff, Mr. Bush rejected the early bad reviews on Mr. Skinner's performance because he could not believe he would have to get out the ax again so soon. Just so, he has refused to give in to conservative demands that he remove Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and his budget czar, Richard G. Darman -- even though his confidants say he feels that he erred by following their counsel on taxes and the economy.
"He gets weighted down by personnel problems," Mr. Scowcroft said. "If there's anything he hates, it's what he's been doing recently. It just tears him apart to have people he likes fighting with each other and to have staffers he feels he has to change."
 
Battling With His Health
 On top of everything else, those close to the President believe that he has had mood changes as his doctor, Burton Lee, has tried to adjust the dosage on his medication for a thyroid problem.
In the last year, since doctors discovered the thyroid problem, he has complained from time to time that he is tired, which he never did before. And friends and aides have noticed that on occasion he does not have as much energy and that his eyes lose their shine.
Although there has been much speculation that the President was sick or sulking, given his sluggish reaction to months of Democratic and Republican broadsides, those who know him well are not surprised that he only recently seemed to come alive in the race. Mr. Bush firmly believes that no one tunes in to a campaign until the fall.
The late John G. Tower, the Texas lawmaker who watched Mr. Bush from the beginning of his political career, used to explain his friend this way: "George Bush is only good if he can go into the fourth quarter with two minutes left and kick the winning field goal or catch the final pass."
 
Repairing a 'Hideous Mosaic'
 Senior Bush advisers say that they need to do a complete reconstruction of the President's image and the Reagan coalition during next week's convention and the fall campaign so that the Bush agenda is no longer, as one Bush associate calls it, "a hideous mosaic that leaves all constituencies dissatisfied."
"We literally have to do in three and half months what the White House should have done in three and a half years," said one top adviser.
The President's son and political adviser, George W. Bush, said that he and his father believe that Mr. Clinton has too little stature and too much baggage to prevail in the end. "Clinton came out of the gate at 100 miles an hour, but he's got a long way to go and he's out of breath," said the Texas businessman, who has backed his father's stubborn insistence on waiting until the convention to begin fighting back or explaining his agenda for the country.
Echoing his parents' view, the younger Bush complains that Mr. Clinton is being "coddled" by reporters.
Senator Simpson agreed, saying that baby boomer reporters are giving the baby boomer ticket a free ride. "Bill Clinton and Al Gore speak in a kind of code that appeals to people their age, stuff about Elvis and the kind of music they play," he said. "The code is designed to throw off some of the old goats."
And Marlin Fitzwater sat at his desk one day last week comparing news magazine coverage of Mr. Bush and the Democrats and complaining: "The incredible thing is after four years the media is not willing to give the President credit for anything. It's just like it was four years ago."
But Mr. Bush is not panicking about his re-election, those close to him agree. Even through a dark period of calls for abdication from some in his own party, a demoralized staff and chilling poll numbers, the President has remained confident that Americans are "fair," as he puts it, and that they will eventually come back around to his view: that he has been a good President who deserves a second term.
"He has taken all this with relative equanimity in this sense: When the polls were up at 65 and 70 percent he told everybody else and kept telling himself that it isn't going to last," Mr. Scowcroft said.
"When it didn't, I think he was not so crestfallen as he might otherwise have been. But the long honeymoon he got also gave him the feeling that fundamentally the American people responded to him and liked him, therefore his troubles were recoverable."
