HEADLINE: At UConn, Costs Squeeze The Students

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn., Aug. 12

 BODY:
The fall semester is more than two weeks away, but Karen Poulin is spending her summer working 48-hour weeks as a clerk at the University of Connecticut Co-op to help pay tuition and other college costs that have more than doubled in just five years.
"I can't make it without working," said the 20-year-old health-education major from Vernon, Conn. "It's costing over $10,000 a year to go here." 
 Ms. Poulin is among thousands of students attending state universities, not only in Connecticut but throughout the Northeast and the nation, who are struggling to pay soaring college costs that are a painfully visible symbol of the financial crisis buffeting American public higher education.
 
Rising Costs, Reduced Services
 Although the roughly $10,000 a year for tuition, room and board and other fees at schools like the University of Connecticut, the State University of New York and Rutgers may be a bargain compared with private colleges charging more than twice as much, to many middle-class and poorer families it seems like a betrayal of the historic premise of state universities as affordable, democratic institutions.
The increases at these once thriving and once inexpensive schools have come in the wake of budget cuts imposed by desperately straitened state governments in the last three or four years, but many students and educators said that now the cumulative impact has become overwhelming.
In addition to increasing tuition, public universities have had to cut faculty and other staff; reduce services; trim enrollment, and eliminate classes and even entire majors and departments. Among students and professors, morale is low, and for administrators, the modus operandi has become one of "ongoing crisis management," said Wilbur Jones, the University of Connecticut's vice president for finance and administration.
 
Bringing It Home
 The effects have been particularly acute for UConn, which has been a haven for students unable to afford or get into Ivy League and other private New England colleges. Perhaps best known for its winning basketball team, the university has long struggled to improve its status as a research university. UConn is also the alma mater for many of Connecticut's state legislators, who have nonetheless had to slash the state's contributions by $47.5 million over the last four years. For this academic year, the state's appropriation was $125.6 million for the university's $320 million budget, a cut of $13.8 million.
As a result, the university has eliminated almost 600 workers -- or 13 percent of its staff -- including about 175 faculty members, through early retirement and layoffs during the last three years, while enrollment at Storrs and at five branch campuses has remained about 24,000. Tuition and fees for state residents have jumped to $3,902, from $2,293, since 1988, while room-and-board costs have escalated to $4,880, from $2,790.
The university also tapped $6.7 million of the $22 million in its financial reserves. "If they're a rainy-day fund," said the university president, Harry J. Hartley, "we've never had a rainier day in my 20 years here." Officials say the hemorrhaging has stopped, and Mr. Hartley persuaded the Legislature this spring to restore $5 million it had cut.
But a 10 percent tuition increase is already planned for next fall, and -- more ominously -- a committee charged with finding up to $23 million in additional savings is to recommend this fall eliminating or consolidating departments or programs.
The squeeze has particularly hit students whose parents earn from about $30,000 to about $70,000 a year. They are generally ineligible for financial aid but still find it hard to afford up to $50,000 for a public education.
 
Not Poor Enough
 "They essentially told me, 'Don't even try for financial aid unless you live in a shack,' " said Ms. Poulin, whose father is an engineering aide at Pratt & Whitney and whose mother is a teacher's aide.
Seeing her brother, like many other students, deeply in debt, she said that in retrospect, "Maybe I should have gone to a community college." To pay for college, she said that many friends have joined the Army or National Guard. And given the bleak prospects for jobs after graduation, she said that if she can afford it, she plans to go to graduate school "to not go out into the business world."
Christine Frydenborg, a 22-year-old who graduated this spring, said, "A lot of students have had to go back to the branches, to save the $5,000 in room and board."
For students, it has not only meant higher costs but classes that are larger and ever more difficult to get into.
"I spent three hours waiting for someone to drop out so I could enroll in an English class," said Jennifer Franchere, a 20-year-old business major. "They canceled half the sections of a Shakespeare class, and, in lecture classes, people are sitting on the floors."
 
The Five-Year Diploma
 This, in turn, has made it harder for students to earn their degrees in four years, as they have been forced to reduce their course loads to work and have had to put off enrolling in perennially filled classes.
"If there are shortages of classes that are either university requirements or requirements for a major, it can force students into a fifth year," said George Ferencz, a fifth-year undergraduate who is editor of the student newspaper here, The Daily Campus. "We're getting every indication that the situation isn't improving and that there will be more cuts. Students are not optimistic."
Neither are faculty members.
Ed Kostiner, chairman of the chemistry department, said his department is "down from 30 to 25 faculty positions, and we're told we can only recruit two people," and recruiting can only begin a year from now. Other ravaged departments, he said, include English, which has lost eight professors, and physics and psychology, which are each down six professors. To cope, departments plan to rely more on part-time instructors.
"The biggest impact is yet to be felt, because the early retirements just came this spring," said Jerome Smith, a professor emeritus of psychology. "When you lose faculty, you lose coverage of some classes. But you also lose scholarly activity, which means a decline in the university's reputation, which is ultimately what a university is."
 
No Comfort Elsewhere
 The problems confronting the University of Connecticut are anything but singular among state schools.
"All public, four-year universities, with some limited exceptions, like Utah and Alaska, are under the worst fiscal stress since the Great Depression," said C. Peter Magrath, the president of the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges, which includes 150 of the largest public research universities and historically black land-grant colleges.
Indeed, the list of casualties is a veritable roll call of the states, with the worst damage occurring in the last two years: In California, fees for state residents have jumped by more than 60 percent. The hard-hit University of Massachusetts at Amherst, just 60 miles north of Storrs, has sustained cuts in state funds topping 30 percent, and the state universities of Maryland and Virginia have taken hits of 17 percent and 15 percent, respectively, in state aid.
At Ohio State, tuition went up 10 percent this year, and 300 jobs and three academic departments were eliminated. Other tuition increases this year ranged from 16 percent at Florida A & M to 33 percent at Oregon State.
The huge State University of New York system sustained a $60 million budget cut in its $3.5 billion budget this year, forcing about 1,150 jobs to be cut and forcing tuition for state residents to be raised for the fourth time in two years, to $2,650 this fall, from $1,350 in 1990.
In New Jersey, the president of Rutgers, Francis L. Lawrence, grimly told the State Board of Higher Education: "Since 1989, Rutgers has absorbed more than $100 million in annual salary shortfalls and base appropriation cuts. As a result, the university has had to freeze, downgrade, reallocate or eliminate the equivalent of 1,100 positions out of 6,900." Since then, $21 million in cuts for this fall will mean another 132 lost jobs, and a tuition increase for state residents to $3,254 -- nearly one-third more than in 1988.
Particularly troubling is that the proportion of their budgets paid by state governments has been rapidly declining, forcing schools to raise revenues from tuition, fund-raising and private industry.
"A lot of people are enormously concerned we're going to privatize the public sector," Mr. Magrath said.
In California, where the state's share of the university system's budget has tumbled to 30 percent in 1991, from 70 percent in 1980, the president of the system, David P. Gardner, said, "The University of California and California State University can no longer be considered as state-funded institutions, but rather as state-assisted institutions."
The same trends have been at work in the Northeast, where New York State's share of the SUNY budget has tumbled to 41 percent this year, from 60 percent in 1979-80; New Jersey's share of Rutgers's budget has dropped to 42 percent in 1990-91, from 51 percent in 1980-81, and in Connecticut, the state's proportion has fallen to 38 percent in the last four years, from 54.4 percent.
Mr. Hartley recognizes that his university is competing for scarce public dollars that increasingly go to entitlement programs with mandated yearly increases. But he is also quick to point out that Connecticut only spends 6 percent of its budget on higher education -- half the national average for states -- and emphasizes that "the university has a long, albeit not well-publicized, history of contribution to the state's economic progress."
Nonetheless, to compensate for lost state aid, the university has done aggressive fund-raising and is wooing "industrial partners," like United Technologies Corporation, which finances a research program at the university, Mr. Hartley said. It has also, thus far unsuccessfully, tried to develop an industrial park. But an inescapable consequence, he acknowledged, is to "shift the burden from the state to students."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Campaign to Slow Down During G.O.P. Convention

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURG, Calif. Aug. 15

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's frantic pace will slow significantly next week as the Republicans take center stage for their week of self-congratulation. But it is clear that the Republicans began stealing the march on the Democrat last week.
President Bush's campaign commandeered the airwaves and news pages with seemingly contradictory statements on abortion, attacks on Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, pronouncements on "sleaze" journalism and, finally, the political reinstatement of James A. Baker 3d. 
 The Democratic challenger had originally planned to mount a vigorous counter-campaign while the Republicans were meeting in Houston, with at least one media-attracting event a day that would draw off some of the attention.
But Mr. Clinton's strategists have now scaled back and plan to spend the bulk of the week in Little Rock. Mr. Clinton is scheduled to return home late tonight, take Sunday off and devote Monday to state government business. The campaign still has tentative plans for a few public events, including an Arkansas birthday party for the Governor and a news conference or two to respond to news from the Republican convention.
But Mr. Clinton is saving his major efforts next week for the day after the convention ends, with addresses scheduled for Friday to the National Association of Black Journalists and the Detroit Economic Club, both in Michigan.
The Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Al Gore, will then join Mr. Clinton for a two-day bus tour that will stop in Cleveland, Erie, Pa., and Buffalo.
Mr. Clinton has already begun priming his oratorical pump for the Republican attacks he anticipates next week. Tracking his words over several days, it is almost possible to hear his defensive gears grinding into action.
"This crowd in Washington," Mr. Clinton told reporters in Concorde last night, "they believe they own the White House. They don't think the people own it. They think it's theirs. And they've kept it for a generation by dividing the people, by terrifying the people, by convincing the people their opponents are aliens from outer space somewhere. And that's what they're going to do this time. That's all they know how to do."
Mr. Clinton's message is clearly a coordinated one. During the past few days, his top strategists have appeared repeatedly on television shows hammering home the same message, hoping they can raise doubts about the Republican ticket before the red-white-and-blue hoopla begins in Houston on Monday.
"We've handled everything they've thrown at us so far," Mr. Clinton said, with a measure of pride.
But most campaigns would prefer to be hurling rather than receiving. The Clinton forces were filled with glee when Barbara Bush indirectly scolded the Republican national chairman, Richard N. Bond, for criticizing Hillary Clinton, but they were caught off guard by the First Lady's tart dig at Mr. Clinton when she observed that the Democratic nominee "never said he didn't have a fling."
Sometimes, Mr. Clinton's reaction borders on outright irritation, as occurred yesterday when several anti-abortion protesters tried to shout him down at the Stockton, Calif., airport, where he was addressing about 100 people.
"Look at what the Republicans are doing," he said. "These people have come out here to demonstrate against me today. They've got a Republican platform that says they want a constitutional amendment to ban abortion, and then they have the President and the Vice President and the First Lady say they're pro-choice. Which side are they on?"
Still, the Clinton camp seems resigned that it will be on the sidelines for a few days, waiting to see if Mr. Clinton's post-convention public opinion lead will be erased by the Republicans' effort this week.
And, for the moment, Mr. Clinton is trying out his new lines off stage.
"I'm not about to let them do to this campaign what they've been doing for a generation.," he said. "It has hurt America terribly, all their sort of negative personal attacks, their divisive tactics. It's been bad for our country.
"It got them in the White House, but it hurt America," he said.

HEADLINE: JAPAN MINISTERS VISIT WAR SHRINE

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Defying a recent high court ruling, almost the entire Cabinet observed the anniversary of Japan's surrender in World War II by worshiping today at the Yasukuni shrine, a Shinto institution once regarded as the soul of Japanese militarism.
Government ministers and some Prime Ministers have made sporadic appearances at the Yasukuni shrine, which is dedicated to the souls of Japan's war dead, but the visits this year struck a particularly nationalistic note, coming so close to the court ruling on July 30. The Osaka High Court ruled that Yasuhiro Nakasone's 1985 appearance at the shrine, the first official visit by a postwar Prime Minister, violated the constitutional separation between religion and the state. 
 Apparently in an effort to avoid angering the Chinese and other Asian neighbors, who tend to criticize any signs of militarism in Japan, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa did not visit the shrine today, the 47th anniversary of Japan's surrender. He was quoted as saying he intended to go soon.
But 15 of the 20 Cabinet members worshiped at the traditional wooden edifice near the Imperial Palace moat in central Tokyo, as scores of old soldiers in uniform and legions of young rightists marched in the searing heat, vowed devotion to the Emperor and, after a moment of silence to pray for the war dead, shouted "Banzai!" to celebrate the Emperor's reign.
 
Big Role in 1930's
 The Shinto shrine has played an important role in Japanese politics. In the 1930's, when militarists rose to power, it became the center of a Government-sanctioned cult that helped instill a fanatical spirit among the military.
A military museum on the grounds of the shrine recalls that spirit vividly, with flags and letters painted in blood and several displays venerating the suicide units that used planes, speed boats and one-man submarines as human bombs throughout the war.
Most of the Cabinet members who visited today followed the traditional practice of declaring their visits private, and thus unofficial, an ambiguous device that has been followed for years to try to avoid criticism. But one, Health and Welfare Minister Tokuo Yamashita, defiantly insisted that his visit was official and that he did not feel bound by the high court ruling. (The Government's official memorial for the 3.1 million Japanese who died in the war was nonreligious and was attended by the Emperor, the Empress and the Prime Minister.)
Jiro Inoue, a lawyer who headed the group that had challenged Mr. Nakasone's appearance in 1985, said: "I am really angry at this behavior. In the United States when there is a difference in constitutional interpretation, the courts have the authority to uphold their decisions. But these visits just ignore what the high court said."
 
Compensation Rejected
 The ruling did not grant the compensation demanded by the citizens' group that filed the suit. But it did suggest in vague language that because the Yasukuni shrine had been such an important religious institution before the war, an official visit there probably violated the separation of religion and the state mandated by the postwar Constitution.
After the war, Shintoism lost its state support and the Yasukuni shrine became a private institution. But rightists, who make up a small yet very influential pressure group, continually urge ministers to make official visits. The governing Liberal Democratic Party often trades a certain number of unofficial visits for right-wing support on other issues.
That appears to have been the case on this occasion. A planned visit to China in October by Emperor Akihito has been bitterly debated. Some rightists oppose the visit out of concern that the Emperor will be forced to apologize for Japan's wartime aggression.
It has been reported that this year's visits to the shrine were part of a deal to win right-wing support for the trip, which the Government supports to strengthen its ties with a country that is rapidly growing in economic importance.
 
Clinging to Old View
 "These visits dignify the idea of dying for the Emperor," Mr. Inoue said.
But it was clear from the throngs who attended today's ceremony at the shrine that at least some still cling to the old view.
"We're proud of what we did in the war, and this is a festive occasion," said Mitsuo Okada, a veteran in his junior naval officer's uniform, alongside four dozen former colleagues happily posing for snapshots.
A plaque in the museum before some mementos of the 6,000 who died in wartime suicide missions captured the feeling. It praised their sacrifice, adding, "This spirit has laid the groundwork for the peace and prosperity of our nation today and in the future."
The plaque was installed in 1985.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
California Budget Fight May Help the Governor

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 15

 BODY:
Were those crocodile tears that Gov. Pete Wilson shed when he begged off "regretfully" from the Republican National Convention in Houston because of intractable budget negotiations in the California Capitol?
And was Mr. Wilson really as impatient for settlement with the legislative leaders as he claimed each day at terse news briefings when he reported a smidgen of progress or none at all while the nation's most populous state lumbered through its seventh week without a spending plan? 
 As the stalemate lengthens and tempers fray here, more and more lawmakers and political analysts are wondering aloud what the Republican Governor might gain from this sluggish process, which has tarnished the state's reputation, cost it millions of dollars in interest and put a financial squeeze on state workers, vendors and health-care providers who are being paid with i.o.u.'s or not at all.
There is widespread agreement here among both allies and opponents of Mr. Wilson that this week's continued impasse was a blessing in disguise for the moderate Republican Governor because it gave him the perfect excuse to skip the Republican convention.
 
Longer Could Be Better
 But an even longer stalemate may serve the Governor's political purposes as well, many Democrats say. Mr. Wilson does not run for re-election until 1994 and thus has lots of time to recover from the embarrassment of this chaotic budget season and his plummeting poll ratings, especially if he wins legislative changes that would make it easier to enact spending plans in 1993 and 1994.
The November election, meanwhile, could be a graveyard for incumbent lawmakers whose constituents have watched the dithering over the budget with dismay. And their sour reaction to democracy in action could improve the prospects of a ballot initiative sponsored by Mr. Wilson that would give the Governor broad budgetary powers, including the ability to dock the pay of lawmakers and declare a fiscal emergency if the budget is not completed on schedule.
By saying thanks but no, thanks, Mr. Wilson enjoyed the compliment of a prime-time speaking invitation but avoided the potential minefields that awaited him in the Astrodome.
 
Avoiding Abortion Collision
 By staying home, the Governor avoided a collision between his support of abortion rights and the hard-line Republican platform that calls for a constitutional amendment banning abortion, missed sharing the podium with a highly unpopular President and also took cover from jibes and queries about the reversal of fortunes in this once blessed and booming state.
Dan Schnur, the Governor's director of communications, acknowledged that the "abortion thing could get sticky," but he otherwise hewed to the line that Mr. Wilson had been eager to attend the convention and might indeed address the delegates on a television linkup from Sacramento.
Others, however, saw Houston as a no-win situation for Mr. Wilson. "It goes beyond the issue of choice," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School. "As bad off as Wilson is, he doesn't need to be joined at the hip with Bush."
And Merv Field, the director of the Field Poll, tried to imagine the speech Mr. Wilson might deliver and could not quite come up with a workable text.
"An upbeat speech would not have washed," Mr. Field said. "He couldn't talk about the national administration, because they're in terrible shape. And the state administration -- there isn't a single problem that has gotten any better and most have gotten worse. This is no loss to him not to have to say, 'I'm the Governor of the great State of California, which in many ways has lost its luster.' "
 
Grudging Admiration
 Assemblyman Richard E. Floyd, a sharp-tongued Democrat from the Los Angeles area, grudgingly admired Mr. Wilson's deft exit from the hornet's nest in Houston and called him the "toughest-brawling politician since Lyndon Baines Johnson."
"Who the hell wants to stand up on public TV with Quayle, Mrs. Quayle, Bush, Mrs. Bush and maybe even Pat Buchanan?" Mr. Floyd asked with a loud guffaw. "He gets to pass up that ugly dance by saying the equivalent of 'I have to take care of my poor ailing mother at home.' Then he keeps the gown in plastic in the closet and can wear it to dance on the graves of the remains of his political party."
Mr. Floyd is one of many lawmakers who see Mr. Wilson's ballot initiative gaining ground "the tougher it gets around here and the more impotent the state government seems."
The same conditions could spell doom for the sitting legislators, most of them Democrats. "The Governor doesn't want to settle it yet," said Assemblyman Lloyd Connelly, a Sacramento Democrat. "He's concluded it's in his best interest to get closer to the election and increase the likelihood the incumbents are removed."
Mr. Connelly said he had seen specific instances in which Mr. Wilson had stalled the process. Twice this week, he said, he was negotiating fine points of compromise with a Republican counterpart in a situation where the two would normally be expected to reach an accord. "He apologized to me and said he was specifically instructed not to reach agreement," Mr. Connelly said. "Ultimately, you can't buy a car from a guy who doesn't want to sell it to you."
Mr. Schnur denied that Mr. Wilson was stalling and said that "no political adviser on earth" would recommend a bogged-down budget as a path to popularity.
But Mr. Schnur noted that the Governor had "unique leverage" to win painful budget changes this year because the lawmakers, in the wake of redistricting, faced hard elections, credible opponents and voters who would ask hard questions about why it had taken so long to get a budget.
 
'We Can Afford to Wait'
 "We want a budget, but we can afford to wait," Mr. Schnur said. "The time pressure is more intense on them because they have to go home and run."
Mr. Wilson's goal seems to be to absorb all the budget pain on this go-round so he can look better in 1993, a strategy that could run aground if the economy does not right itself.
"He's so low in the polls that he can't deteriorate much further," Mr. Connelly said of the Governor, who had a 20 percent approval rating in a recent Field Poll. "The best course is to get it done now in a way that will make the next one look easy so he can redeem himself."
A clear example of that strategy is the education cuts that Mr. Wilson is proposing. He wants local school districts to return to the state $1.1 billion that the districts were paid last year beyond what they were entitled to under Proposition 98, which guarantees 40 percent of the general fund to education. By taking back that $1.1 billion, the Governor not only saves that amount this year but lowers the baseline so school spending climbs less steeply in the future.
That strategy set the state school chief howling. "It all has to do with next year," said Bill Honig, the superintendent of public instruction. "The Governor doesn't want to be at risk, and it's not fair to make the kids pay for that."
A Democratic legislative budget writer said that halting such "pyramiding transactions" was Mr. Wilson's "only chance of not having problems next year." The budget writer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that if Mr. Wilson had fiscal problems again in 1993 he was "dead meat," but that if he sailed through the next budget cycle, voters would flock back to his side.

HEADLINE: Tainted Water Forces Hardship on Pawtucket, R.I.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 15

 BODY:
For almost two weeks, the taps here have been spewing bacteria-fouled water, forcing residents to buy bottled water or go to fire stations for free water.
State health officials urged residents to boil tap water or use bottled varieties on Aug. 3 after tests disclosed the presence of fecal coliform, or E. coli bacteria, found in human waste. 
 Officials of the Pawtucket Water Supply Board said they believed that the bacteria entered the lines during installation of 13,000 feet of new pipes. The work may have dislodged bacteria-laden sediment from the bottom of the old pipes, some of which were more than 100 years old. The city's water comes from the Scituate Reservoir.
E. coli bacteria can cause diarrhea, nausea, headaches, fatigue and jaundice, state health officials said. Infants are considered to be at greatest risk.
 
Dim Hope for Quick Solution
 On Thursday, Gov. Bruce Sundlun signed an executive order declaring a state of emergency in this city of 72,000 people and the neighboring towns of Central Falls and Cumberland. A day earlier, he had asked for economic disaster relief from the Federal Small Business Administration.
While city crews have been flushing out water mains and adding chlorine and acid to the system in efforts to get rid of the bacteria, the restrictions could be in effect for a month, said Peter Kerwin, a community affairs aide.
Assistant Fire Chief Robert Forsher said officials were delivering bottled water to disabled residents free of charge.
The emergency has been a boon to retailers who sell bottled water and entrepreneurs like Lewis Watkins, 23 years old, who was selling T-shirts outside City Hall last week. His shirts show a disgruntled family carrying jugs of water with the caption "Pawtucket Water Buffaloes."
"I wanted to do something to get people laughing, something positive," Mr. Watkins said.
There have been plenty of negatives. After complaints were received about some retailers, Mayor Robert E. Metivier warned that price gougers trying to take advantage of the shortage would be prosecuted.
Donations of water from distributors of beer, soft drinks and bottled spring water from outside the city have helped ease the emergency at nursing homes and other health-care centers.
Memorial Hospital, the area's largest medical center, has been drawing from its own emergency 8,000-gallon storage tank.
Debra Lafreniere, 33, carrying her daily ration of two gallons from a fire station, said of the situation: "It stinks. 'I'm having to pick up water all the time, and I don't have a car."

HEADLINE: Jobless Man Wins $1 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 15

 BODY:
An unemployed Saddle Brook man won $1,238,852 yesterday at a slot machine in Caesars Hotel and Casino.
Gabriel Mayo, 58 years old, had been playing the Fabulous 50's machine, which costs 50 cents a chance, for about three minutes before he hit the jackpot. Mr. Mayo was paying $1.50 for each pull and spent less than $20 before he won. 
 "This is a miracle," said Mr. Mayo, who was a machine mechanic until the plant where he worked closed last spring. "I've worked hard during my life, and now I can spend the rest of it enjoying my family."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Needs Convention to Get Campaign Going

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Republicans began assembling here today for a nominating convention of extraordinary importance to the Bush Presidency. If the President's strategists have their way, this event will begin the redefinition of their candidate and the choice at the heart of this election.
Republican officials struck a note of determined optimism today as they readied the balloons and rituals for Monday's opening session, but the underlying anxiety was palpable. "George Bush has said all along that his campaign began with this convention," said Craig Fuller, the chairman of the convention. "We're going to prove it this week." 
 Most Republican experts acknowledge that Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee, has had considerable success, so far, in presenting this election as a stark choice in economically troubled times: Change versus the status quo, a Democratic Presidency chock-full of domestic policy proposals or a Republican Presidency with little to say about the problems at home.
 
The Republican View
 Bush strategists hope to use this convention, and the two months that follow, to persuade voters that they have another choice: A second Bush Administration hot off its successes abroad, now ready to "target America" with a host of moderate to conservative reforms, or a return to the tired, failed, bureaucratic solutions of Democratic orthodoxy.
The White House has been working on new proposals intended to stimulate the economy and Mr. Bush suggested in an interview with Time magazine this weekend that such measures were imminent. There was a wave of rumors about the possiblity of new tax-cut proposals, fed, in part, by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, who like many conservatives is a staunch advocate of that approach.
Mr. Bush told Time that his decision to break his 1988 campaign pledge of "no new taxes" and embrace the budget deal of 1990 was a mistake. "I'll be making some proposals regarding the economy that I'm not going to discuss now that I think will take care of it," he said.
Still, the content of Mr. Bush's acceptance speech, which he was working on at Camp David today and will deliver Thursday night, was a closely held secret. Four years ago Mr. Bush used his acceptance speech to mount a powerful comeback against Michael S. Dukakis.
This time, however, Mr. Bush enters the convention with a much greater deficit in the public opinion polls, nearly 20 percentage points in some surveys released this week, and with a far bleaker national mood.
For eight months, Bush strategists have struggled to retrofit Mr. Bush, a President consumed with foreign policy, for a country consumed with the economy and other domestic concerns. Now, with the President fully focused on the campaign, with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at his side, and with a scant 80 days before the election, they feel they have their best, most crucial shot.
 
Campaign Map
 Mr. Baker's speech last week announcing his return to the White House is widely viewed as, in the words of one Bush campaign official, "a Rand McNally" for the coming weeks. It was an unapologetic accounting of the past four years and the Administration's focus on foreign policy, arguing that the United States had a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to help free millions of people and reduce the threat of nuclear war. Now, Mr. Baker asserted, it was time to "target America."
For all of that, the White House has seemed preoccupied with foreign affairs even as its top officials plotted a domestic political course as the convention neared. In the last few days, the White House has announced an airlift of food and supplies to famine-stricken Somalia, and has prepared for a confrontation with Iraq over United Nations inspections of its military facilities.
Bush campaign aides say it is still unclear how much Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker will rely on major new domestic proposals, and how much they will simply repackage what they have already outlined. Conservatives yearn for an aggressive economic plan.
Mr. Kemp said on CNN's "Evans and Novak" today that he believed the Administration was clearly moving toward new tax-cut proposals, although he said this was based on intuition rather than information. "It seems to me that it is now clear that the President, particularly since the Baker speech, wants to outline a bold and audacious vision of America in the next four years," Mr. Kemp said.
 
Ideological Contrast
 A senior Administration official said today, "During the course of the campaign I wouldn't be surprised if there's new things proposed." But, the official said, "you don't define the differences simply in terms of who has a long list of new programs."
In fact, the contrast they seek with Mr. Clinton is philosophical and ideological. James Cicconi, issues director for the Bush campaign, describes Mr. Clinton as having a "back to the future" approach; the Bush campaign has already begun casting Mr. Clinton's proposals on education, health care and the economy as excessively bureaucratic and based on massive taxing and spending.
One Republican strategist close to the Administration said it was time to make Mr. Clinton "defend the left-most element of his party."
Still, the Republicans continued to have a few ideological divisions of their own as they assembled here today -- principally over the issue of abortion, after a week that saw the party's platform committee retain an implacably anti-abortion line. Mr. Fuller told reporters today that he did not expect any speeches on behalf of abortion rights at the convention next week.
Bush strategists hope for a unified convention that raises doubts about Mr. Clinton, reminds Americans of Mr. Bush's accomplishments, and persuades them that the President does, in fact, have an aggressive domestic policy plan for his second term.
Mr. Bush has a formidable travel schedule in the weeks that follow, intended to capitalize on his expected "bounce" out of the convention. His strategists acknowledge that he still has work to do to shore up his standing in the South and in Texas.
"We may have to pay a little more attention to some of them because you've got an all-Southern Baptist ticket," said Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign. "But the President through four years has run six to eight points better in the South than nationally, so I feel as soon as we get our momentum back, we'll be in fine shape in the region."
 
Southern Strategy
 Mr. Bush's first post-convention swing will focus on the South, "tamping it down early," as Mr. Black puts it.
Campaign officials are particularly sensitive to the situation in Texas, where a poll last week showed Mr. Bush, an adopted son, lagging behind Mr. Clinton. With California considered an uphill battle for the Republicans, it is essential that they be assured of carrying Florida and Texas. Still, Bush campaign officials say they remain confident that Mr. Clinton can be presented in Texas as far too liberal.
Mr. Bush will then move quickly into Illinois, Connecticut, New Jersey, Illinois, Michigan and Kentucky.
Mr. Bush's travel schedule represents the focus expected from both campaigns on the border states, which are more competitive this year because of the Southern Democratic ticket, and the industrial Midwest, which is historically a battleground.
Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman, said that the Bush campaign was not writing off California, despite a poll that showed Mr. Clinton more than 30 points ahead there. "We think, in the last analysis, California, as it's been for the past 25 years, will be very close."
Mr. Teeter added that he remained confident that the comparison between the candidates would ultimately mean a Bush victory. "If you stand George Bush up, with a bright light on him, and say here's exactly who he is in terms of qualifications, values, positions, and you stand Bill Clinton up, with no window dressing on either one, we win."

HEADLINE: A First Job Fades as the Paper Route Grows Up

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Eventually the newspaper strike that is afflicting the Pittsburgh area will be settled. Some of the teamsters who walked off the job in May will return to their jobs as truck drivers, and some presumably won't. But some people who have been idled know already that they have lost their jobs for good, like Bobby Griska, who is 14 years old.
Bobby is a paperboy, one of 4,300 young door-to-door carriers who delivered The Pittsburgh Press and The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. Under the newspapers' plan for more efficient home delivery, all 4,300 young carriers have been dismissed. They will be replaced by far fewer adults who can cover longer routes by flinging the papers onto lawns from car windows. 
 The Pittsburgh papers are following the lead of most big-city dailies, which, faced with declining readership and dwindling advertising revenues, are saving wherever they can. "We can't stay in business trying to stay with a tradition that has outlived its usefulness," said Randall Notter, a spokesman for The Press.
 
Disney, Perot, Buffett
 Through the years, no institution has stirred the entrepreneurial juices of young Americans as much as delivering newspapers. Benjamin Franklin, so the legend goes, hustled his brother James's New England Courant around Boston. Businessmen like Walt Disney, Ross Perot and Warren Buffett started out delivering papers. Even today, many parents say it is an irreplaceable tool for teaching responsibility, money management and people skills.
Retracing his old route, Bobby pointed to a house on Brierly Lane. The woman there, he said, wanted the Sunday comics and living sections delivered on Saturday evening, when Bobby received them. Only one family, who live in a big yellow house on Brierly, never tipped him. What about his other customers? "I don't ask for a tip," he said. "They just give it to me."
Along with baby-sitting, acting and family farming, having a paper route is one of a very few regular jobs that the Federal Government exempts from the child labor laws. Some youngsters around Pittsburgh started out at 8 years old, six years before the laws permit them to try other jobs. Because parents get involved, cases of abuse and exploitation have been rare.
 
The Realities of Business
 For Bobby, a paper route with about 50 customers meant 6 1/4 cents for each daily paper he delivered, 20 1/4 cents for each Sunday paper. With the tips, he earned $25 to $40 a week.
But merciless realities of business and economics have intruded. The International Association of Circulation Managers says that from 1980 to 1990, the number of newspaper carriers plunged from 912,534 to 551,356, while the number of papers printed each day stayed the same, about 62 million. For carriers under 18, the decline was even sharper, from 823,746, or 90 percent of all carriers, to 362,470, or 66 percent.
Joseph Forsee, head of the association, said a decline in the number of evening newspapers, which children can deliver right after school, accounts for much of the business youngsters have lost.
But another factor, a strong one in Pittsburgh, is the growth in publishers' use of adult carriers, many of whom cannot find other jobs. Without school to face, they can rise earlier than children to deliver morning papers, which have absorbed the circulation that evening papers have lost.
 
The Realities of Population
 In addition, Mr. Notter said, young carriers have become harder to find. The nation's birth rate has plunged since the 60's; because of that and people moving away, he said, Pittsburgh had 40 percent fewer people between the ages of 12 and 17 in 1990 than in 1980.
Finally, in some cities, though rarely in Pittsburgh, parents' fears about crime have made them reluctant to send 10-year-olds out alone.
For reasons like these, the number of adult carriers, concentrated in big cities and their suburbs, jumped in the 1980's by 100,000, to 188,886. These are troubling trends to families here who believe in the discipline of working a regular newspaper route.
Glenn D. Joyce was a newspaper boy, and all five of his children -- three boys and two girls -- delivered papers. Four went on to graduate from Carnegie Mellon University, and the fifth is a senior there.
"The discipline sure helped," said Mr. Joyce's wife, Marie, "and it gave them a nest egg to start college. You learn how to work for a living. It makes you do something when you have to do it. It expanded them socially. They had grumpy people. They had the weirdos. There were high tippers. There were low tippers. There was the guy who complained if his paper had a single raindrop on it."
 
The Rewards of Money
 Before the strike, George and Susan Kenyon, who live in the suburb of Monroeville, had set their children on a course like that of the Joyce children. Kathy, the eldest, is going to college in Indiana in the fall. With her father out of a job and her mother working part time, the money she saved from her newspaper job will pay for most of her first year. Carrie, 16, and Buffy, 15, shared a route delivering The Press. Susie, 13, had a morning route delivering The Post-Gazette, and Bobby, 11, had his own route delivering the afternoon Press.
"They buy almost all their own clothes," Mrs. Kenyon said. "They don't realize that that's not the norm."
The youngest, Bobby, did not fully share his parents' enthusiasm for the job. "There are things you want to do, but you have to walk out and go do papers," he complained. "I've been bit by the same dog three times, same leg." But he recognizes the rewards of his toil. He and Susie recently flew to Miami, a trip paid for with savings from delivering newspapers.
 
Far Fewer Depots
 The Press, which is owned by the E. W. Scripps chain, also prints and distributes the separately owned Post-Gazette, the morning paper. Until the strike started, The Press's delivery system was built on the 605 members of Teamsters Local 211 -- drivers who dropped bundles of papers at 10,000 locations a day, mostly in front of carriers' homes, and route managers who recruited and supervised the carriers.
To cut costs, The Press intends to replace the curbside deliveries with just 30 depots to which far fewer drivers will bring the papers. Instead of boys and girls, about 1,300 self-employed adults will pick up the papers at the depots and deliver them over much longer routes from their cars. Although the Press never said flatly that children could not hold the jobs, it is requiring carriers to have "a dependable insured vehicle."
Local 211 called the strike on May 17, when The Press tried to open its first two depots. The president of the local, Joseph A. Molinero, says the union cannot hope to stop the company's plan, but he wants to slow the pace. He also seeks better severance arrangements for the more than 200 teamsters who would probably be laid off right after a settlement, some 250 fewer than the company originally wanted to lay off.
 
A Cheaper, Adult System
 It appears cheaper to build a system on adult, nonunion, independent carriers earning little more than $12,000 a year than on young carriers and on teamsters, who receive an average of $43,000, not including benefits. And with the demise of Pittsburgh's heavy industry, The Press has found plenty of adults who are willing to take jobs once done by children.
But however much sympathy the union has been drumming up for the young carriers, no one is going to the mat over their jobs.
Local 211 and officials of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. who are here lending a hand say they have tried to induce management to help. They have asked that those who can walk to the new depots be given routes, and that disabled children with routes be allowed to keep them.
The union has also sponsored demonstrations by carriers and their parents to turn subscribers and advertisers against the company's plan.
 
Its Own Jobs First
 But inevitably the union is putting the jobs of its own members first, and a settlement is unlikely to save any of the carriers' jobs. "We don't have anything for them," Mr. Notter of The Press said.
Some young carriers, like LeVar Fairrior, 12, hang around the strike headquarters in downtown Pittsburgh doing volunteer work, even though there is nothing in it for them. LeVar, an honor student, has lost a coveted route in an apartment building delivering 23 copies of The Press weekdays and 49 on Sundays.
Of the $20 to $25 he earned each week, he said, he saved $10 and spent the rest on ice cream and pizza. Now, he said: "I baby-sit for my sister's daughter. She's 6 months. And I do things for my mom." He said his mother, who is divorced, gives him $10 a week for helping her.
Some people here say management could arrive at a better balance of all the competing needs. Edmund Ayoub, an adjunct professor of economics at Duquesne University here who was a chief economist for the United Steelworkers union, feels that way. "I think there is something wrong in doing away with a system in which young people are encouraged to be self-reliant and independent," he said.

HEADLINE: Nonstop, Year-Round Casino Approval Stuns Monitors

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 15

 BODY:
On a midweek morning at an hour when the sun is just starting to break over the Boardwalk, Joann Loucka stood before a dollar slot machine, barking words of encouragement to her best friend, Sophia Nicolan.
"Hurry up before the machine gets cold," Mrs. Loucka said. 
 For the last 16 hours, almost from the moment they arrived by car from Ohio, the women had been pumping coins into slot machines on the cavernous Taj Mahal Casino floor.
"We came in yesterday at 2 o'clock and we haven't been to bed yet," said Mrs. Loucka. "When are we going to bed, I can't tell you."
A month after the state Casino Control Commission approved round-the-clock gambling at this seaside resort's 12 casinos, neither champions nor critics have had the time to gauge its real impact. But the bill that allowed 24-hour gambling, which Gov. Jim Florio signed on May 16, was the most drastic easing of regulations on the state's gambling industry since 1976, when voters approved casino gambling in Atlantic City.
 
Conditions Originally Strict
 Fearing the possibilities of organized crime and an increase in compulsive gambling, the Legislature initially placed strict conditions on the casinos, including limiting their hours to 10 A.M. to 4 A.M. on weekdays and 10 A.M. to 6 A.M. on weekends.
A year ago, the Legislature authorized a test of 24-hour gambling on weekends and holidays, and in May gave the commission the authority to allow permanent nonstop gambling as it saw fit. After twice balking at round-the-clock gambling, a month ago the Commission bowed to pressure from the casinos, business groups and politicians and allowed it all year long. The only stipulation was that the casinos had to make quarterly reports on its impact.
The Commission's open-ended decision angered a sponsor of the 24-hour gambling legislation, Assemblyman Monroe Jay Lustbader of Short Hills, who said on Friday that he would introduce legislation next month that would restrict 24-hour gambling to certain times of the year, as he intended his original bill to do.
"I consider the Casino Commission's action an abuse of the last legislation and illegal," Mr. Lustbader said. "There was always a certain reluctance to grant round-the-clock gambling indefinitely because there was a feeling that there has to be a break in those hours to give the people a chance psychologically to cool off to avoid people losing the rent money in a froth.
 
Casinos Got 'the Whole Pie'
 "All I was trying to do was to work out a compromise with my legislation between those who wanted 24-hour gambling and those who were opposed to it," he said. "But it seems the casino industry walked away with the whole pie."
Mr. Lustbader said his new bill would authorize 24-hour gambling up to five days in a row plus weekends and holidays, but never exceeding 12 consecutive days.
The debate over 24-hour gambling is as old as legalized gambling itself in this seaside town.
"This has been a 14-year effort to convince the state of New Jersey since they have entertained this industry, then they have to let it be an industry," said Thomas D. Carver, president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, the legislative lobbying and policy organization for the Atlantic City gambling industry.
Along with nonstop play at the slot machines and at a dozen or so table games now offered, Atlantic City casino operators would like to add table poker, sports betting and keno, a gambling game resembling bingo.
"It's like saying we're a baseball team but we only have two outfielders," said Mr. Carver.
 
Longing Looks at Nevada
 Atlantic City's casinos have looked longingly at Nevada, with its much less restrictive gambling laws.
An 8 percent New Jersey tax on the casinos' gross gambling profits funnels nearly $250 million a year into the treasury. By law, the money is used for programs for the elderly.
Proponents of 24-hour gambling say the extended hours will add about 1,200 jobs, $20 million in taxes and about $100 million to the 12 casinos' annual $3.3 billion grosses.
The casinos have amassed statewide political influence well beyond the traditional group of legislators from southern New Jersey who led the fight 16 years ago for gambling.
Despite what Mr. Carver describes as restrictions "to prevent us from running at full speed," Atlantic City's East Coast casino monopoly helped make it one of the top tourist draws in the nation -- 30 million visitors a year, many arriving on tour buses for four-hour gambling sprees.
 
Twilighters Follow After Bus People
 The bus people, as they are known to casino workers, have yet to find a niche in the new early hours, leaving the sparsely populated floors to another breed of players called the twilighters.
"I personally like them better; they know what they are doing," said Anthony Fama, over breakfast in an employee cafeteria at the Taj Mahal during one of his 15-minute breaks from the roulette wheel he spins.
"No mama and papa bus people," he said as he returned to the casino floor to continue a shift that began at 4 A.M. and would end at noon.
For Mr. Fama, 33, and the 75,000 other employees of Atlantic City's gambling industry, the additional hours mean an added sense of job security in a business that has been linked inexorably to the whims of the economy and to seasonal tourism.
Also, Atlantic City's lucrative monopoly is swiftly eroding with the advent of casino gambling on an Indian reservation in Connecticut and as other states consider legalized gambling to help close budget gaps.
Miles away in Trenton, in a cluttered office wallpapered with newspaper clippings, letters and telephone lists, Arnold Wexler, executive director of the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, gives the opposing argument to all that the casinos would envision.
"Twenty-four-hour casino gaming will contribute to compulsive gambling," Mr. Wexler says.
Under state law, the casinos finance the council's $500,000 annual budget through the fines they pay. And they are required to display the compulsive gambling emergency phone number -- (800) GAMBLER -- throughout their gambling halls, on slot machines and in all their literature along with the slogan: "Bet with your head, not over it."
Mr. Carver said that with the start of 24-hour gambling, the casinos had begun a plan in which a compulsive gambler would sign a statement acknowledging his problem and would then be barred from betting.
A recovering compulsive gambler himself, Mr. Wexler bases his prediction on his own experiences and the rise in emergency calls in the short time since nonstop gambling began.
"You never know what you are going to hear," he says.
Almost on cue, a telephone on his desk rings, and the caller begins the conversation with what Mr. Wexler says is a familiar refrain.
"I think I have a gambling problem," says the man, who in keeping with the council's policy cannot be identified by name.
"I don't want my wife to know nothing," says the man, who identifies himself as a 54-year-old retiree. "I just had the worst streak of my whole life. I lost about $7,000."
Mr. Wexler leafs through a sheaf of papers to find a Gamblers Anonymous meeting place and date closest to the caller's Pennsylvania home.
"I know exactly what you mean," Mr. Wexler says as he tries to comfort the now-sobbing caller, "I've been there, baby."

At left is Joann Loucka, Ms. Nicolan's friend from Cleveland. A casino security guard monitored the transaction. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Year After Coup, Gorbachev Grumps, Rues and Ruminates

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The man who had the most to lose -- and lost almost everything -- after last August's attempted coup was President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
One year later, the former President of a country that no longer exists is now the head of the International Foundation of Socio-Economic and Political Research, which is housed in a vast complex that was built as a higher party school for foreign Communist leaders. 
 Since his final fall from power last Dec. 25, when the Soviet Union was officially declared dead, Mr. Gorbachev has struggled valiantly to keep himself visible and politically viable.
He has traveled abroad -- to Germany, the United States and Japan -- cashing in on his appeal to foreign audiences. But at home, he has been kept on the sidelines, scorned by his old enemy, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, and ignored by an unsympathetic population.
 
Grumbling in Print
 Mr. Gorbachev, now 61 years old, appears regularly in the pages of the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda where he worries out loud about the course taken by the Yeltsin Government and continues to mourn the demise of the old Soviet Union.
Although some members of the conspiracy have since claimed that Mr. Gorbachev himself had been preparing to declare a state of emergency in the Soviet Union last summer, he has vehemently denied giving the conspirators any encouragement.
"Above all, they were striking a blow against the reform process," he said in a recent interview. "Before you stands the President whom they locked up and seized power from, taking over his functions by coercion."
Looking back, Mr. Gorbachev recently admitted that he had blundered when, upon his release from his villa in the Crimea, he did not go immediately to lay flowers at the place where three young men were killed in the early hours of Aug. 21, as the army tanks began their retreat from Moscow.
"Of course, I should have done that," Mr. Gorbachev told Moscow Ogonyok, a weekly. "I can't find an explanation. Probably, it was the shock of the situation I found myself in."

HEADLINE: More on Reaganomics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Time to Get Back to Reaganomics" (Forum, July 26), Edwin S. Rubenstein derides both the Congressional Budget Office's data as being "seriously flawed," and Massachusetts Institute of Technology Prof. Paul Krugman's analysis of income growth based on that data, which showed that "the wealthiest 1 percent of American families received 60 percent of total income growth during the 1980's." 
 According to Mr. Rubenstein, the C.B.O. estimated "the average income of the top 1 percent of families increased from $289,743 (in 1990 dollars) in 1977, to $548,970 in 1990, a 94.2 percent rise. Capital gains, up 171 percent, was allegedly the fastest-growing source of income . . . but the budget office failed to adjust capital gains for inflation."
Mr. Rubenstein then demonstrates the isolated "logic" of the financial elite he champions: "someone who bought an asset for $50,000 in 1977 and sold it for $100,000 in 1990 had a capital gain of $50,000, even though -- adjusted for inflation -- the asset really sold for less than its purchase price."
Interesting.
Internal Revenue Service data show that after a decade of Reaganomics, 85 percent of American families still earned less than $50,000 (and 94 percent less than $75,000). Therefore, to use Mr. Rubenstein's own example, because of inflation, 94 percent of American families had negative income growth. Further, I.R.S. statistics show that 93 percent of American tax filers in 1989 received zero capital gains income.
Reaganomics has been and will continue to be Robin Hood-ism in reverse, viz., thieving from the have-nots to benefit the rich.
 
STEVEN L. FORNAL
Accord, N.Y., Aug. 3

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Parties' Core Differences in Platforms

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
To a remarkable degree, the party platforms they wrote this summer define the state of the Democratic and Republican Parties and highlight the differences between them.
The Democrats, like their Presidential candidate, Bill Clinton, are seeking new ground, a footing that they hope the American people will find more comfortable than the doctrinaire liberalism that has characterized the party in the last half of this century. 
 Their platform calls it "a third way," a course between the laissez-faire capitalism of the Republicans and the welfare-state economics that the Democrats have relied on in the past. Wherever possible, the Democrats seem to have toned down their language.
"We believe in an activist Government," the platform declares, "but it must work in a different, more responsive way."
The Republican platform, by contrast, hugs the right-hand lane, taking the most conservative turn on nearly every issue. Few people here for the Republican convention seem to mind that it goes far beyond President Bush's stands on issues like abortion. The strident language seems to appeal to the party faithful.
 
Emphasizing Social Views
 "We believe in traditional family values and in the Judeo-Christian heritage," the Republicans asserted, emphasizing social views and playing down the economy for the first time in many conventions.
The platforms themselves will soon be forgotten. Even in the election campaign this fall, the candidates will stake out their own positions with little regard to the statements of principle adopted at their party conventions.
But looking back over the years, platforms have often forecast, in themes if not in words, changes in parties' direction.
That was certainly true in 1980, when diehard conservatives first gained firm control of Republican Party affairs. Some Democrats believe it is the case this year for their party, with a new emphasis on personal responsibility rather than Government handouts, on private enterprise instead of Government subsidies.
 
Positions Are Poles Apart
 On specific issues, the platforms are often poles apart.
The most striking example, of course, is abortion, where the Democratic platform supports a woman's right to abortion without exception, and the Republican one would make abortion illegal, also without exception.
But there are many other cases when the parties are just as far apart.
Democrats want a medical care system in which the Government is deeply involved. Republicans want to keep the Government out.
Republicans favor tuition subsidies for private school tuition. Democrats want to redistribute money to public schools so those in prosperous communities do not have so much more than those in poor ones.
Democrats favor gun control; Republicans are opposed. Democrats favor civil rights laws protecting homosexuals; Republicans are opposed. Democrats want to spend billions on public works projects; Republicans stress private investment. Democrats emphasize the need for child care for working parents; Republicans want to change tax rules so children can be cared for at home less expensively.
 
Differences of Principle
 But for all the differences on particular political issues, the most important differences expressed in the platform are over matters of principle.
The basic economic principle enunciated in the Republican document is that taxes should be cut across the board. Americans, the Republicans say, should be allowed "to create wealth for themselves and their communities."
The Democrats put their fundamental economic tenet this way: "People should share in society's common costs according to their ability to pay." With that in mind, the platform calls for higher taxes on the wealthy.
In the case of the environment and energy policy, the Democratic principle is that environmental protection and energy conservation need not take a back seat to economic growth. Republicans, on the other hand, hold that the environment may have to be sacrificed in some instances in the interest of a stronger economy. And their platform emphasizes energy production with no mention of conservation.
 
Division Over Government
 For the Democrats, the Government is the answer to many of the nation's problems. The party wants an "efficient, flexible and results-oriented government that improves services, expands choices and empowers citizens and communities to change our country."
For Republicans, the Government is a necessity of last resort. "Government does not have all the answers," their platform states. "But we know where to find them: in the spirit of our people."
Each platform begins with the wisdom of its party's wellspring.
The Democrats cite Thomas Jefferson who believed, the platform states: "We should overthrow our own government every 20 years to renew our freedom and keep pace with a changing world."
The Republicans quote Abraham Lincoln: "In all that people can individually do as well for themselves, Government ought not to interfere."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Compare and Contrast: Quotes From the Platforms"
 
THE 1980's
 Repbulicans: We launched an era of growth and prosperity such as the world had never seen. . . . During the 1980's and into the present decade, the U.S. economy once again became the engine of global growth.
 Democrats: We need to rebuild America by abandoning the something-for-nothing ethic of the last decade. . . . It is wrong to borrow on ourselves, leaving our children to pay our debts.
 
THE ECONOMY
 Republicans: Inflation has fallen to its lowest level in 30 years. Interest rates dropped 15 percentage points. Productivity has sharply risen. Exports are booming. Despite a global downturn in late 1990, real economic growth resumed last year and has continued for five consecutive quarters. With low interest rates and low inflation, the American economy is poised for stronger growth through the rest of the 1990's.
 Democrats: America is on the wrong track. The American people are hurting. The American dream of expanding opportunity has faded. Middle-class families are working hard, playing by the rules, but still falling behind. Poverty has exploded.
 
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
 Republicans: Never in this century has the United States enjoyed such security from foreign enemies. With President Bush leading the free world, the Soviet empire has collapsed. . . . Eastern Europe is liberated. Germany is peacefully united. The former Soviet armies are returning home. Nuclear arsenals are being cut to fractions of their former size. A democratically elected Russian president sits in the Kremlin. Ukraine, Armenia and the Baltic states take their rightful place among the family of nations. Israel and all of its Arab neighbors talk face to face for the first time. Nicaragua and Panama celebrate democracy.
 Democrats: During the past four years, we have seen the corrosive effect of foreign policies that are rooted in the past, divorced from our values, fearful of change and unable to meet its challenges. Under President Bush, crises have been managed rather than prevented; dictators like Saddam Hussein have been wooed rather than deterred; aggression by the Serbian regime against its neighbors in what was Yugoslavia has been met by American timidity rather than toughness; human rights abusers have been rewarded, not challenged.
 
 ROLE OF GOVERNMENT
 Republicans: We believe government has a legitimate role to play in our national life, but government must never dominate that life. . . . The Democrats argue that government must constantly override the market. Republicans regard the worst market failure as the failure to have a market.
 Democrats: We believe in an activist government, but it must work in a different, more responsive way. . . . We believe in . . . the power of market forces. But economic growth will not come without a national economic strategy.
 
PUBLIC WORKS
 Republicans: The latest Democrat scam is to raise taxes for 'investment' -- a code word for more government spending. A Republican Congress will foster investment where it does the most good, by individuals within the private sector.
 Democrats: The only way to lay the foundation for renewed American prosperity is to spur both public and private investment . . . We will rebuild America by investing more in transportation, environmental technologies, defense conversion and a national information network.
 
ABORTION
 Republicans: We believe the unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed. We therefore reaffirm our support for a human life amendment to the Constitution, and we endorse legislation to make clear that the Fourteenth Amendment's protections apply to unborn children. We oppose using public revenues for abortion and will not fund organizations which advocate it. We commend those who provide alternatives to abortion by meeting the needs of mothers and offering adoption services. We reaffirm our support for appointment of judges who respect traditional family values and the sanctity of innocent human life.
 Democrats: Democrats stand behind the right of every woman to choose, consistent with Roe v. Wade, regardless of ability to pay, and support a national law to protect that right. It is a fundamental constitutional liberty that individual Americans -- not government -- can best take responsibility for making the most difficult and intensely personal decisions regarding reproduction. The goal of our nation must be to make abortion less necessary, not more difficult or dangerous. We pledge to support contraceptive research, family planning, comprehensive family life education and policies that support healthy childbearing and enable parents to care most effectively for their children.
 
EDUCATION
 Republicans: The President has shown unprecedented leadership for he most important education goal of all: helping middle and low income families enjoy the same choice of schools -- public, private or religious -- that families with more resources already have.
 Democrats: We deplore the Bush Administration's efforts to bankrupt the public schools system . . . through private school vouchers. . . . We deplore the savage inequalities among public schools across the land.
 
HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS
 Republicans: We oppose efforts by the Democratic Party to include sexual preference as a protected minority receiving preferential status under civil rights statutes at the Federal, state and local level.
 Democrats: Democrats will continue to lead the fight to ensure that no Americans suffer discrimination or deprivation of rights on the basis of . . . sexual orientation or other characteristics irrelevant to ability.
 
ARTS
 Republicans: We . . . condemn the use of public funds to subsidize obscenity and blasphemy masquerading as art. . . . No artist has an inherent right to claim taxpayer support for his or her private vision of art if that vision mocks the moral and spiritual basis on which our society is founded.
 Democrats: We believe in public support for the arts . . . that is free from political manipulation and firmly rooted in the First Amendment's freedom of expression guarantee.
 
ENVIRONMENT
 Republicans: We have taught the world three vital lessons: First, environmental progress is integrally related to economic advancement. Second, economic growth generates the capital to pay for environment gains. Third, private ownership and economic freedom are the best security against environmental degradation.
 Democrats: We will protect our old-growth forests, preserve critical habitats, provide a genuine 'no net loss' policy on wetlands, conserve the critical resources of soil, water and air, oppose new offshore oil drilling and mineral exploration and production in our nation's many environmentally critical areas and address ocean pollution by reducing oil and toxic waste spills at sea.
 
GUN CONTROL
 Republicans: Republicans defend the constitutional right to keep and bear arms. We call for stiff mandatory sentences for those who use firearms in a crime. We note that those who seek to disarm citizens in their homes are the same liberals who tried to disarm our nation during the cold war.
 Democrats: We support a reasonable waiting period to permit background checks for the purchases of handguns, as well as assault weapons controls to ban the possession, sale, importation and manufacture of the most deadly assault weapons. . . . We will work for . . . stronger sentences for criminals who use guns.
 
HEALTH
Republicans: Republicans believe government control of health care is irresponsible and ineffective. We believe health care choices should remain in the hands of the people, not government bureaucrats.
 Democrats: All Americans should have universal access to quality, affordable health care -- not as a privilege but as a right.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
At Play In the Fields Of the Vinca

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn.

 BODY:
ON a hill here behind a padlocked gate and electrified fences, Prof. Ronald Parker, a plant breeder, hides his world-famous vinca test fields. "I must be cautious," he says. "I've had people try to bribe my research crews to tell them where these fields are. You're the only one who's been in the vinca fields this year."
It is not that the vinca is exotic. On the contrary. The University of Connecticut professor's genius lies in his ability to develop a colorful flowering annual that is perfect for your typical idiot suburban gardener. No need to water vincas. They love heat. Deer and bugs hate them. 
 Every seed company president in America has tried to get into Professor Parker's vinca fields. Instead he makes these millionaire executives sit in his office, bringing them a single flower from a few plants. "If they saw the whole plant, they'd have an insight into how many flowers I'm getting per plant. It gives away too much."
When he started breeding vincas 16 years ago, they came in white. Because of his painstaking work mating species from all over the world, vincas now flower in every shade of pink, purple and orange. In the last two years he has won four All-America Selections awards, the Pulitzers of plant breeding, for vincas like Pretty in Pink. And he is not through, not by a long shot.
"We have a red coming out that is so incredible -- yes it's all right, you can print this -- it will be so demanded. No one's ever seen a red vinca." He does not keep the reds here. "Oh no. They're so valuable I keep them secure in another state."
He is a driven, methodical man, as you must be when you devote your life to isolating desirable genetic variables like overlapping petals. At work by 7, he goes out for lunch at noon: soup and milk in the no-smoking section. He is a devout Mormon. At age 56, he works out daily. In growing season he acknowledges not being the easiest guy to live with, ("My family does not expect a happy person.") To make sure there are no mixups, he and two assistants do all the planting: 35,000 sprouts during a few weeks in spring. He is so harried, rushing between class and fields, there are days he plants in white shirt and tie. ("And I can do it without getting my shirt dirty.")
Long ago he could have worked for the big seed companies at twice the salary, but he stays in academia for the intellectual freedom to breed as he pleases. "Plant breeding is nothing but unadulterated sex and I love it." He has a gift for looking at a scraggly vinca species and spotting one characteristic -- like big flowers -- that is worth extracting. He can then spend years mating the scraggly one to various short, shapely species, finally producing a big-flowered, short, shapely vinca. "The big breakthroughs are unguessable. Often the children don't look like either parent."
Among his current projects is developing a blue vinca. "I only found the key to blues last year after years of trying. I don't know if anybody else knows the key to blues. I don't ask because I don't want anybody to ask me."
When people say, "Why vincas?" he answers, "That's easy." In 1976 he spent months in libraries in search of a hardy flower that hadn't reached its potential. You could drop a boiling elephant on a vinca and it would survive, but it wasn't colorful or nicely shaped.
Now it is.
Anyone who questions the economic value of this doesn't know the story of impatiens, another high-performance, low-maintenance annual with flower, foliage and shape like the vinca. The impatiens is shade-loving and there are many who feel the vinca is about to become its sun-loving counterpart. Big deal? The impatiens now accounts for 45 percent of all summer annuals sold.
In recent years vincas (technically catharanthus) have gone from 3 percent to about 13 percent of the market. Professor Parker's vinca patents earn UConn good money; he is one of the top royalty producers here.
The reason is obvious. You spend an hour planting vincas and impatiens Memorial Day weekend, you don't do another thing, they make colorful, lush borders; and when friends from the city visit, they marvel at how you found time to watch the entire Olympics on three cable stations.
In a few weeks Professor Parker begins a sabbatical to assess new projects. He believes there is great hunger for more shade-loving varieties and thinks much can still be done with impatiens, which he has started breeding. "There are no blue impatiens, no yellows. Your eye feels their absence." He paused in his tour. "We all have our objectives. One of mine before I die is to see a bed of yellow impatiens. I'm working on it. I thought I cracked it last month -- yes, it's O.K. to print that."
