SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1735 words

HEADLINE: The Latest in Buzzwords: Mailed From America

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS; Andree Brooks, based in Westport, Conn., writes regularly on financial and family topics.

 BODY:
After celebrating morning mass at the Good Shepherd Church near his modest brick flat in Morecambe, a seaside resort in Lancashire, England, the Rev. Michael J. Smith eagerly watches for a little green van that more and more often is pulling up to his front door.
The van signals the arrival of yet another product he has ordered by mail from the United States. Since he first saw an advertisement for mail-order shopping direct from the United States in a computer magazine about two years ago, Father Smith reckons he has spent more than $4,000, mostly on computer software. 
 Move over Coca-Cola, Disney, blue jeans, Hollywood and all those other tempting slices of Americana that have captivated foreigners. The newest overseas obsessions among consumers like Father Smith are the value and new ease of international shopping offered by mail-order companies like L. L. Bean, Austad's, the Sharper Image and Lands' End.
While many of the better-known companies have always had the occasional foreign order come in, the volume of that business until recently did not warrant special marketing efforts. But such recent innovations as inexpensive facsimile machines, international toll-free calling, freer use of credit cards and speedier air-courier delivery -- not to mention a glutted, recession-hit home market -- have all led to rising interest in American mail-order operations overseas.
Drawn by efficient service and a variety of products unmatched by their local merchants, foreign shoppers in record numbers are phoning, faxing and mailing orders for everything from clothing to electronic gear to golf equipment. Indeed, the typical wee-hours customer is no longer an American insomniac, but perhaps a morning shopper from Europe.
Father Smith said much of the software he has bought cost half of what it would locally, even taking into account the overseas shipping charges, import duties and value-added tax. He just puts it all on his Mastercard, letting the banks worry about the currency exchange.
"And there's so much to choose from," he said in a telephone interview. Then he chuckled, "I also do it for the fun. I'd never phoned outside the country before. But at first I tried just because it was free. I asked them whether I was really speaking to someone in Arizona and what time of day it was. Now we talk about all sort of things. Did you know they have flash floods in that part of America? Worse rain than in Lancashire."
Express Technology Inc. of Scottsdale, Ariz., which Father Smith often calls, sells products only to overseas shoppers. It says it grossed $100,000 from foreign callers in a single week in July, a record for the five-year-old computer software company.
Two years ago, L. L. Bean, the venerable bit of Americana based in Freeport, Me., organized an international department aimed at pampering a new source of customers. Last year, the gross from overseas was $38 million, 6 percent of total sales. Compare that to $2 million in 1986.
Overseas sales by Bose Express Music of Framingham, Mass., a division of the Bose Corporation, which lists a wide variety of compact disks and tapes in its 300-page catalogue, are running at $1.5 million annually compared with $100,000 two years ago. Such sales now represent 7 percent of all sales. Its paid listing in Compuserve, the worldwide electronic information network for computer users, has been the source of many of these customers, especially from Japan, said Robert Hurley, Bose Express's general manager.
The Sharper Image of San Francisco, which offers unusual electronic gear and other items, says it now deals with some 7,000 overseas customers annually from its regular catalogue, compared with a handful a decade ago. "It's a nice piece of business," said Sydney Klevatt, the company's senior vice president for marketing. Moreover, he said, the average overseas order is about $400 compared with $150 for a domestic one.
Austad's, the golfing-equipment company based in Sioux Falls, S.D., estimates that foreign mail-order sales now total 3 percent of its total revenues, compared with a fraction of that five years ago. Fax orders roll in from Saudi Arabia, South America, South Africa, Britain and Sweden. Sales to the golf-crazy Japanese rose 88 percent between 1991 and 1992, the company says.
Lands' End, after watching overseas business increasingly trickle in all by itself, created a special catalogue for the British market last fall in its first overt plunge into international waters.
Indeed, the phenomenon has attracted its own entrepreneurs. Consider Richard McBrien, from East Dulwich, just south of London. Familiar with such shopping from his 1980's student days at Yale University and the State University of New York at Buffalo, the 34-year-old writer and actor privately published a how-to book in Britain in June called "Buying Direct From the U.S.A."
Distributed exclusively by mail order, of course, Mr. McBrien's first print run of 100 books sold out in two weeks at 12.95 each, about $25. It is now in its third printing (total: 900 copies), he said, having sold everywhere from Spain to New Zealand.
Mr. McBrien practices what he preaches. He wrote the book with the help of a modem and software bought mail order from MicroWarehouse Inc., of Lakewood, N.J. He regularly faxes orders for hard-to-find replacement parts for his Karmann Ghia, an old Volkswagen sports model, from House of Ghia in Albany, Ore.
Perhaps the most aggressive approach has been taken by R.R. Donnelley & Sons of Chicago, the printing company that supplies dozens of American mail-order houses. Concerned about recessionary cutbacks and peaking domestic demand, Donnelley last fall offered the mail-order companies the chance to reach 50,000 Japanese households with an experimental showcase of American mail-order products.
In one catalogue, written in Japanese, it provided a sampling of the products of six companies together with information on how to send for each company's full catalogue.
G. Jack Haney, Donnelley's vice president for international direct marketing, said the results were encouraging enough to send a second mailing in May. A third is planned for distribution in Japan, Britain and Mexico at year's end.
Despite such efforts, there has been criticism from overseas that American mail-order houses in general are not doing enough to woo foreign customers.
"Too many American companies think we don't know what mail order is all about in Europe," said Peter Rosenwald, a former New Yorker living in London who is an international direct marketing consultant. "They're still not comfortable with the idea of the global market and how to act on it."
Even with the success of foreign sales by some companies today, only a handful offer international toll-free calling or special services for foreigners. Even Austad's limits its international toll-free lines to calls from Canada and Britain. "The orders didn't warrant the cost" of expansion elsewhere, said David Austad, the president. A.T.&T. estimates that 400 five-minute calls a month into Austad's Sioux Falls, S.D., headquarters from Japan would cost about $3,000.
To be sure, countries like Britain and Germany already had thriving mail-order houses of their own. But with the long-term decline of the value of the dollar, such local houses cannot compete right now with the bargains available direct from the United States.
In fact, the few American companies, like the Sharper Image and Lands' End, that have made deals with foreign licensees or have gone to the expense of starting foreign-language editions of their catalogues are not bragging about the results of those extra efforts.
As pointed out last month in The Financial Times of London, a man's cotton Oxford shirt listed in the British version of the Lands' End catalogue for 25.50 plus 2.95 for postage, about $55, could be ordered from the regular American catalogue for $23.50 -- even after adding duty, tax and shipping, a 25 percent saving.
David Zentmyer, Lands' End vice president for corporate ventures, defended the higher British-catalogue price by explaining how much more it cost the company to print a separate edition and establish a local branch to work with customers.
What he overlooks is the cachet that also comes with being able to brag about an overseas purchase.
Geoff Godfrey, vice president of marketing for Express Technology Inc., said his order takers had been hounded lately by "a group of guys calling from a pub in Leeds." The men, regular customers, seem to have fun showing off their secret of ordering hard-to-find software from the United States at any hour from a British public telephone.
 
 
TAKING ORDERS IN JAPANESE
 About five years ago, a Dutch tourist walked into Richard Gnant's store in Phoenix and bought his entire stock of 10 laptop computers. The tourist explained that he could easily recoup the cost of his trip by reselling them at a profit to friends back home.
That set Mr. Gnant to thinking that there was clearly an untapped overseas market for mail-order goods at American prices. So he reorganized his computer software and equipment company into Express Technology, a mail-order house that sells only to overseas shoppers.
"I didn't think you needed to spend a quarter of a million dollars opening an office overseas anymore," Mr. Gnant said. "Not with the new international 800 lines and the fax." Instead, he planned to pass along his lower operating costs in the form of savings to his customers.
Mr. Gnant also customized his operations. He hired order-takers who speak Spanish, German, French and Japanese and put most of them on duty from 2 A.M. to 9 A.M., his company's busiest hours.
He arranged for international toll-free calling and figured out how to remove the hassle of calculating duties and taxes from his customers. He worked out mailing arrangements with United Parcel Service, Airborne Express and DHL Worldwide Express. And he ran advertisements in computer magazines in Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Scandinavia and Latin America.
At first customers would call with "great trepridation in their voices," he said. But once they realized that the company stood by its guarantees, even refunding return postage costs for defective products, the hesitation disappeared.
By 1991, the company's sales reached $4.5 million.

HEADLINE: AUGUST 9-15: The Recession's Effects;
New York City Now Has 1 Million on Welfare

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
For the first time since the economic crisis of the 1970's, the number of New Yorkers on welfare last month rose above 1 million people -- almost one out of every seven city residents.
City officials blamed the sluggish economy for the 22 percent increase in the number of people on welfare since Mayor David N. Dinkins took office in January 1990. The number rose from 823,691 then to 1,005,210 last month. Of those now on welfare, 529,949 are children. 
 A survey of new welfare applicants conducted by the state Department of Social Services backed up the Dinkins Administration's claim. In June 1991, two-thirds of the people applying for Aid to Families with Dependent Children or Home Relief had worked in the prior year or were employed but earning very little. But the recession in New York City has lasted so long -- since the spring of 1989 -- that large numbers of unemployed workers have used up their unemployment benefits, forcing them onto welfare.
Other factors that account for the surge in welfare recipients included growing number of people with AIDS, addicts in drug treatment programs and impoverished immigrants, city officials said.

LENGTH: 501 words

HEADLINE: Campaign Mode

 BODY:
Rewind to 1988 and humid New Orleans. George Bush trails a Democratic governor. His prospects are uncertain; the shadow of Ronald Reagan looms large. Mr. Bush makes a surprisingly good speech, jumps ahead and stays ahead during a relentless, unedifying campaign.
Fast forward to 1992 and Houston, another hot, humid Southern city. The same George Bush again trails his opponent, again a Democratic governor, this time by a wider margin. His record is mixed, his message unclear, his party divided. The economy is shaky, the public restless. And Bill Clinton, learning from Michael Dukakis's 1988 paralysis, has plunged into a far more energetic campaign. 
 Can the President, starting with another knockout acceptance speech, do it again? Many Republicans seem convinced that their convention, which opens tomorrow, is make-or-break time. It's surely important: Mr. Bush could definitely use a "bounce." But that puts too much weight on a made-for-television spectacle.
Conventions define themes and bridge competing views. And this convention could give definition to Mr. Bush, something he sorely needs. But conventions don't win elections. What this week truly marks is the beginning of the real battle, of what Mr. Bush likes to call the "campaign mode."
If one thing is clear about the race so far it is the public's vacillation. Remember March 1991? Mr. Bush's postwar approval rating was an astounding 88 percent. It's now about 30 percent. Bill Clinton wouldn't be riding his bus down America's blue highways if he had let the polls decide his fate. In late May, with Mr. Bush still comfortably ahead, USA Today awarded Mr. Clinton one state -- his own, with six electoral votes. By mid-July, according to the American Research Group, Mr. Clinton seemed a cinch. He led in 31 states. Mr. Bush led in only one, with three electoral votes.
So the pendulum swings. Bill Clinton never tires of warning that it could easily swing back.
The Houston convention will be a theme-a-night affair, and Republican planners will put Mr. Bush's best foot forward right away. Monday's theme is "America's Spirit in the World." It will showcase Mr. Bush in the role he likes best and in which he has arguably enjoyed his best moments -- Commander in Chief and world leader. That role would certainly be spotlighted if the U.S. carries through on reported plans to confront Saddam Hussein this week.
But what's most troubling voters isn't foreign policy but domestic drift, unemployment, the loss of competitive edge. When asked why he hasn't converted success abroad into progress at home, Mr. Bush recites, without passion or priorities, a list of proposals -- and blames Congress.
George Bush left New Orleans four years ago as the custodian of the Reagan revolution, albeit with a "kinder, gentler" face, and got by with a shallow campaign in part because the country was feeling pretty good about itself.
That feeling, like Mr. Reagan, is history. This convention is solely Mr. Bush's.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 3; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: EQUALITY'S HURDLES - A Special Report;
Too Few Changes Since Campanis

BYLINE: The following article is based on reporting by Claire Smith, Gerald Eskenazi and William C. Rhoden and was written by Ms. Smith.

 BODY:
The comments came on national television, on the opening day of the baseball season, and when they spilled forth from Al Campanis on April 6, 1987, it was as if baseball, and all professional sports, for that matter, had been hit by a cataclysmic earthquake.
Campanis, then the general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was asked by Ted Koppel on "Nightline" why so few blacks attained executive positions in baseball. He answered: 
 "I don't believe it's prejudice. I truly believe they may not have some of the necessities to be, let's say, a field manager or perhaps a general manager."
Campanis was eventually let go by the Dodgers, but his words made front-page news of the battle for increased hiring being waged by members of minority groups.
"Someone from in the inner circle had let out what we had known all along," said Frank Robinson, a Hall of Fame outfielder and the first black manager in the major leagues. "That attitude had been something we had been trying to tell people about, that these things were going on, that these thoughts existed. Now the rest of the world heard it from someone who made decisions to hire or not to hire."
More than five years later, however, minority hiring remains a complex and provocative issue, and executives in professional baseball, football and basketball are still measuring their progress in inches. Those waging the battle -- blacks, Hispanic people, Asians and whites -- are too often frustrated with systems and mindsets that still reflect the words of Campanis more than anyone who has tried to prove him wrong.
"Based on the records of the organizations, I don't think that we have been able to break through yet," said Robinson, now an assistant general manager with the Baltimore Orioles. "And I think that is evidenced by how many major league managers have been hired since Campanis and how few minorities have even been given a chance."
Executives in pro football, baseball and basketball all point to initiatives that have aided minority hiring, but the commissioners acknowledge frustration over their inability to guide individual clubs in their hiring practice. They also caution against having the issue slip behind other priorities and losing the urgency necessary to implement significant change.
Since Campanis, the 28 major league teams have hired 48 managers, only 6 of whom have been members of minority groups. Other numbers reflect both the gains and obstacles experienced by blacks trying to break through the door of limited opportunity:
*There are three black managers, the most ever, in the majors: Cito Gaston of Toronto, Felipe Alou of Montreal and Hal McRae of Kansas City. But the percentage of minority representation in all major league nonplayer, on-field jobs (including managers, coaches, trainers, scouts and instructors) was 19 percent at the end of the 1991 season, the same as the year before and down 1 percent from 1989, the peak year since such statistics started being compiled in 1988.
In the front office, members of minority groups accounted for 16 percent of employees in 1991, up from 2 percent in 1987. But the game has employed only one black general manager in its history, Bill Lucas of Atlanta in the late 1970's and among the 28 teams, there are now only 3 assistant general managers, including Robinson, who are black. Among players, 17 percent are black and 15 percent Hispanic.
*There are 66 black coaches -- head coaches or assistants -- on the 28 teams in the National Football League, up from 14 in 1980 and 44 in 1987. Still, in a league in which 60 percent of the players are black, there are only two black head coaches -- Art Shell of the Raiders and Dennis Green with the Vikings -- and three black coordinators, the position that is often a training ground for the top spot.
Over all, the number of minority-group members employed leaguewide, including coaches, front-office employees and league officials, increased from 182 in 1987 to 234 in 1991, increasing from 10 to 15 percent of the total.
*The National Basketball Association had been the only major sport with a black serving as managing general partner of a team -- Peter Bynoe of Denver -- until Bynoe sold his remaining share of the team last week. Four teams have black general managers. Of a total of 79 vice presidents league-wide, five are black.
Yet the league has come under increased scrutiny of late because it has actually seen a reverse trend at the head-coaching level. In 1987, the 23 teams then had four black coaches; but today, with four more teams, there are only two black coaches, and the last 13 coaches to be hired have all been white.
 
Commissioners And Unheeded Calls
 To many, such numbers represent more than slow progress. They represent a blatant refusal on the part of the clubs to heed the call of their own commissioners to improve employment practices.
"The numbers just aren't there," said Charles Grantham, executive director of the N.B.A. Players Association, "and it sends a very clear message to the active black player that if his intention is to continue in this business, there will be a different set of criteria in evaluating him for these positions."
The hiring issue has caught the attention of at least one member of Congress.
"I personally feel that Congressional oversight is necessary to strengthen the hand of the commissioners of the major sports leagues since the owners have historically been the drawback to progress," said Representative Donald M. Payne, a Democrat from Newark, who is black. Until such legislative action occurs, however, the bulk of the pressure must come from the commissioners, Robinson said. It has, to some degree, in all three sports. Members of minority groups make up 28 percent of the staff of the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, and blacks hold two of the eight cabinet-level positions: director of market development (Len Coleman) and director of minor-league relations (Jimmie Lee Solomon).
Vincent's record and efforts have been praised by even those who have been most critical of baseball's record: Bill White, the National League president, and the Orioles' Robinson.
That does not mean that blacks are without despair or complaint. "I think when Campanis spoke, the public outcry and the press attention made the National League do something," said White, the highest-ranking black in professional sports. "They made a statement by hiring me. But the pressure ebbs and flows, the public moves on to other things -- Roe v. Wade, Gore and Clinton, the Chicago Cubs injunction -- or whatever. After a while, all is forgotten."
In addressing the National Urban League conference in San Diego last month, Vincent said: "Here we are, 17 years after Frank Robinson became the first black manager in the major leagues, and today, in 1992, we have only three minority managers in the major leagues, only three black assistant general managers in the major leagues and not one black manager in the minor leagues. That is unacceptable."
The problem, Vincent concedes, is that a combination of other concerns -- tough economic times, the pending labor strife, turf warfare among owners -- has caused equal employment goals to fall far down the list of priorities of the clubs.
But Vincent points out that cannot be allowed to happen, not only because of the moral obligation, but also because of economic realities. "Although about 18 to 20 percent of the players are black, only 5 percent of the fans are black," Vincent said. "Now, in a world where nonwhite minorities are an increasing part of the American population, that means that baseball is selling itself primarily to a shrinking part of the market. To me, as a businessman, that's a losing proposition. And no one in baseball likes losing."
Thus baseball is striving to become more understanding of and involved in black society. Vincent recently announced the underwriting of a health care system for the approximately 135 surviving members of the Negro Leagues. And Major League Baseball is now the official sponsor of the National Urban League's annual youth conference, its $50,000 contribution underwriting the cost of the spinoff affair in San Diego.
Clifford Alexander, who runs a Washington-based consulting firm that heads up baseball's drive to improve its hiring methods, believes vigilance is absolutely necessary. He said: "What is the key is will baseball continue to seek to be better in this arena? The evidence that I have is that it will. Part of what we do is prod them. And we're going to continue to do that."
 
A Wake-Up Call To Join Battle
 David Cornwell was contemplating whether to accept a position with the N.F.L. when Campanis made his comments. A New York-based lawyer, Cornwell was being interviewed for a position as director of the league's equal opportunity program. He was leaning against making the move until Campanis spoke. "It was a wake-up call," said Cornwell. "I had a fire in my belly. My mandate? To make a difference."
Cornwell said one of his main concerns while working with the league was what he considered an institutional racist approach to hiring.
"You always used to see press releases that someone was looking for 'qualified' minorities -- as if that was the exception," said Cornwell, who worked for the N.F.L. until last March before leaving to join the sports agent Leigh Steinberg. "So I tried to get people like Pete Rozelle involved in fund-raising causes, internship programs, get them exposed to various aspects of minority life in different situations."
Unfortunately for members of minority groups, the clubs don't seem to be nearly as driven as commissioners in this area.
In baseball, over a dozen openings at the managerial level last year resulted in the hiring of one black manager and the interviewing of only two other black candidates, Don Baylor and Chris Chambliss. "You can make the numbers look any way you want, but the fact is that the commissioner has limited powers when it comes to making clubs look closer at their hiring," Baylor said.
Neither Frank Robinson nor either of the game's other two black assistant general managers were interviewed when a plethora of general-managing jobs also became available last year. Because so few black candidates are even interviewed for such jobs, blacks have had to find nontraditional routes to advancement. Reggie Williams, general manager of the New York/New Jersey Knights of the World League, illustrates this point.
Williams, a Dartmouth graduate and former Cincinnati Bengal as well as a onetime member of the Cincinnati City Council, wanted to continue his career in football in N.F.L. management. "But there were no ready opportunities in the N.F.L.," he said. "The Cincinnati Bengals have a policy that you have to learn elsewhere. They have no one in the front office who is a person of color." Williams did ask the Bengals to make an exception, to take a chance. "They graciously declined," he said.
The World League did not decline. And Williams is now running a professional franchise. Still, he cannot help wondering just how successful he could have been in the N.F.L. if he had not been swept away before he ever got a chance to get started.
Williams's problem points to the rough spots that the other sports still seek to smooth out when it comes to hiring. Payne, while stating that baseball still too often recycles white managers and overlooks black candidates, said that "the other pro sports, proportionately, do even worse."
Payne points to the Bengals' hiring of David Shula, who had recently been demoted as an assistant coach by the Dallas Cowboys. Shula was selected as head coach over Jim Anderson, a 43-year-old black assistant coach who directed Cincinnati's running game for eight seasons.
 
Rose-Colored Glasses at N.B.A.?
 The N.B.A. has traditionally been credited with better success in hiring blacks, but Alexander, a hiring consultant for major league baseball, believes much of it is the result of better public relations. "David Stern has been better and more capable of selling his league in this arena," Alexander said. "But I think there has been a lot of smoke and mirrors."
Alexander, who is black, makes that claim even though the N.B.A.'s population is 75 percent black and the league is made up of a core of extremely popular black athletes, perhaps the most popular team-sports stars in the country, if not the world.
Why the charge? "Because of the popularity of the players, people have gone from there to reach the improper conclusion that when it comes hiring in front offices you get a picture of full equity and it isn't there," Alexander said. "The N.B.A. has done a much poorer job of utilizing its source of supply than baseball."
An annual report by Northeastern University, compiled by Richard E. Lapchick of the university's Center for the Study of Sport in Society, also echoed those sentiments. "If the hiring trends in the N.B.A. continue through the 1992-93 season," Lapchick wrote, "there will be no 'shield of comfort' left for the N.B.A."
But, Lapchick added, "it is doubtful, based on his record, that Commissioner Stern will allow this to happen."
To Stern, the fact that the 13 most recently hired head coaches are white is no cause for hand wringing. "I don't think you can take a snapshot at a given time and make long-term judgments," he said. "If you look at the number of head coaches and assistant coaches and general managers and people in positions of leadership in the league, the lawyers, the accountants and others, there's been no backsliding at all."
Although the N.B.A. has no formal affirmative action policy, Stern believes it doesn't need one simply because its well-known role as an equal opportunity employer has been good for business by opening up "an extraordinary talent pool.
One of the league's five black general managers, Wayne Embry, the executive vice president of the Cleveland Cavaliers, does believe that there has been a regression in the drive for minority hiring, but he places the blame less with Stern or the individual owners than with the policy and guidance coming from Washington.
"Look at society," he said. "What we are in the N.B.A. reflects where the country has gone. I think there has been a general regression since the 1980's because of the political leadership."
By contrast, Embry, who became the N.B.A.'s first black general manager when he was chosen by the Milwaukee Bucks in 1972, had nothing but praise for Stern's commitment to equal opportunity.
"You've got to single out the N.B.A." he said. "It's been more aggressive in its hiring practices than the other leagues."
Stern, Vincent and Commissioner Paul Tagliabue of the N.F.L. know that the sport takes its biggest hits when it goes through a period like basketball just has, when the visible positions of manager and general manager open up in bunches, with very little positive results for blacks.
"Sure, that's what the public will always focus on, which is fair enough," said Steve Greenberg, Vincent's deputy commissioner. "We have at least identified a means to address the situation with managers. We have a three-to-five year focus on minor league hirings, to build a feeder system."
 
N.F.L.'s Low Grades But an 'E' for Effort
 The National Football League, is also frantically trying to find the magic key to doors that stubbornly remain closed. "You must set yourself some goals and then you must go out and look for people," Tagliabue said. "I found out people don't fall in your lap. I asked Vernon Jordan to put me in touch with black doctors. I got in touch with black judges."
Lapchick, in his report, has credited Tagliabue's administrative record, pointing to four hires of import within his office, including Harold Henderson, executive vice president for labor relations, and Leo Miles, a supervisor of officials. Still, while receiving kudos for effort, the N.F.L. receives just a C+ over all from Lapchick, and a D- in management hiring.
The solution to fixing the league's image and its problems certainly begins at the coaching level, many believe. That may also be the most difficult area to crack. For years, the league has cried that it gets its coaches from the college ranks, and that the top colleges don't produce minority coaches. Currently, there isn't one black coach in Division I-A. "If colleges would push harder, it would put more people in the pipeline," Tagliabue said.
The other pool often tapped for head coaches is the ranks of assistants, an area where blacks also often feel excluded. "It's a very fraternal thing," Bill Walsh, the former coach of the San Francisco 49ers and now coach at Stanford University, said in trying to describe the traditional mind-set of picking staffs. "You end up calling friends, and the typical coach hasn't been exposed to many black coaches."
The N.F.L., acknowledging flaws in its feeder systems, some years ago established a program to bring coaches from black colleges to training camps. But some of the traditionally black schools had their own troubles grooming black coaches.
The N.F.L. has since done away with that program and adopted a model created five years ago -- the year of Campanis -- by Walsh.
Walsh asked coaches to send him their academic background and a statement on goals if they wished to join his program and spend the entire preseason with the 49ers. "The first year I had a dozen applications," Walsh said. "By the end of the second year there were 50 responses."
Although unofficial in status, the concept worked. Both of the coaches who were picked from the Walsh program in 1987 found employment in the N.F.L. the next year. By 1988, half the N.F.L. teams had adopted Walsh's plan; now 26 of 28 have the program (the holdouts: the Giants and the Bengals).
It can also be said that the N.F.L. efforts may also be stymied by conservatism. The sport, treated in part like rocket science and religion, often requires of its applicants a dedication tantamount to signed loyalty oaths as well as proof of proper collegiate breeding that only a handful of schools can provide.
Work ethics, like necessities, will probably always be questioned in one form or another. Only when sports can guarantee that such questions are no longer attached to any particular race or ethnic group will the legacy of Al Campanis finally be allowed to die.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Robinson says the breakthrough on minority hiring has yet to come. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Mets May Not Officially Be One of the Worst Bargains Ever, but It's Close

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The August onslaught of physical mayhem committed against the Mets or by the Mets against themselves has shattered any thoughts that the disappointing team had of staging a last-lap sprint toward the National League East championship. It will also most likely prevent the Mets from finishing first in the salary standing and becoming only the second team to do that with a losing record.
Injuries to Bobby Bonilla, Howard Johnson, Bret Saberhagen, Dave Magadan and Willie Randolph in the first 12 days of this month forced the Mets to summon a platoon of players from the minor leagues, and their low salaries have reduced the team's average salary. 
 On opening day, the Mets had a 26-player payroll (including one player on the disabled list) of $44.5 million for an average of $1,711,615. The four roster moves they made on Friday left the Mets with a payroll of 33 players (8 on the disabled list) of $47.9 million for an average of $1,451,676.
The opening-day Mets average was No. 1 in the major leagues; the team's current average is third, behind Toronto's $1,576,970 and Boston's $1,465,853. The official 1992 average salaries will be based on players who are on rosters and the disabled list on Aug. 31.
With so much attention and considerable question focused on astronomical payrolls, a team could find it embarrassing, not to say devastating, to finish with the highest average salary and a record whose victories fall short of its losses.
The Blue Jays, barring radical roster changes, most likely will finish atop the salary standing. Their economic largesse should be rewarded with at least a division championship. But if Bonilla, Johnson and Saberhagen heal in time to be active again in two weeks, allowing the Mets to return three of their low-priced players to the minors, they could sneak to the top.
Then, assuming they don't win 30 of their last 48 games and finish over .500, the Mets could join the 1986 Atlanta Braves as the only teams to finish a season with the highest payroll and a losing record.
The Players Association began computing average team salaries in 1978. In 14 years, the Yankees have had the highest average eight times (including seven of the first eight), Oakland twice (the last two years) and the Braves, the Mets, Kansas City and California once each.
Five times the team with the No. 1 average salary finished first in its division. The salary leader has finished second three times, third twice, fourth twice and fifth once. All of those teams compiled winning records.
Then there were the '86 Braves.
Featuring such players as Dale Murphy, Bruce Sutter and Bob Horner, those Braves finished last with a 72-89 record and an average salary of $657,657.
A record average that lasted until the 1988 Yankees broke it, the figure was inflated by Murphy's $1,825,000, $1.8 million for Horner, $1,729,167 for Sutter, $1.5 million for Ken Griffey (known now but not then as Sr. because Jr. was still in high school), $1.37 million for Doyle Alexander and $1 million for Ted Simmons, who as the Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager wishes he could sign Barry Bonds for that salary.
Despite the lucrative pay, the Braves couldn't produce. Sutter epitomized the Braves' problems. Signed a year earlier to a six-year, $10 million contract, the relief pitcher had had off-season shoulder surgery, then encountered additional rotator-cuff problems early in the season and had to quit after making only 16 appearances in the first season in 10 years that he hadn't accumulated at least 20 saves. His career was virtually over.
During that season, the Braves were only a game and a half from first on July 3 with a 41-37 record, but over the rest of the season, they staggered to a 31-52 record and finished 23 1/2 games from the top.
Six years later, the lushly paid Mets are headed in the same direction.
 
Braves' Double Play?
 Tom Glavine, leading the majors with 18 victories, is in strong position to repeat as the winner of the Cy Young Award as the best pitcher in the National League. Terry Pendleton, his teammate with the Braves, is a legitimate contender for the most valuable player award, which he won last year. If they should both repeat, it would mark the first time in either league that the same players won the awards in two successive seasons.
In two instances, different players from the same team won the awards in successive seasons.
In 1962, Don Drysdale and Maury Wills of Los Angeles won the awards, and their teammate, Sandy Koufax, grabbed both awards the next season. Rollie Fingers of Milwaukee won both awards in 1981, and his teammates, Pete Vuckovich and Robin Yount, were winners the next year.
 
Marlins' Triple Play?
 If all of the reports are to be believed, the Florida Marlins will select an unprotected Danny Tartabull in the expansion draft, sign Andre Dawson as a free agent and get Jose Canseco in a trade.
All three sluggers have longtime Miami connections -- Tartabull and Dawson were born and raised there, Canseco grew up there -- and speculation has all three being available after the season.
It says that the Yankees will not place Tartabull on their 15-man protected list, gambling that the Marlins won't want to pick up his expensive contract; that the Cubs will let Dawson go as a free agent and that the Athletics will trade Canseco to get rid of his contract and his questionable attitude.
Carl Barger, the Marlins' president, laughed at the thought of acquiring all three stars. But he didn't say the Marlins would automatically shun high-priced players.
"A lot of what we do will depend on the options other teams give us," Barger said. "If they choose to leave their high-priced talent exposed, we could do some things that would surprise people. That's not our present intention. Our intention is to build with young players. But we're also not going to expand a team's 15-man protected list to 30. We're not going to send out a message that they can leave their high-priced players unprotected because we're not going to take them."
 
A Fielder Too Tall
 Gary Sheffield of San Diego woke up yesterday leading two-thirds of the Triple Crown categories. He was hitting .343, 6 points better than John Kruk of Philadelphia; he had 83 runs batted in, the same number as Darren Daulton of Philadelphia, and he had hit 25 home runs, two fewer than his teammate, Fred McGriff.
All three of his numbers might have been higher (.344, 86, 26) if Bip Roberts, Cincinnati's left fielder, hadn't been ejected from the game Friday night. Roberts was thrown out for arguing a play at first base, and minutes later, his rookie replacement, Cesar Hernandez, leaped at the left-field fence and, with his glove above the fence, snared what would have been a three-run home run. Hernandez is 6 feet tall. Roberts, five inches shorter, might not have reached the ball.
 
A Bridge Too Far
 If the Giants are permitted to move from San Francisco to St. Petersburg, Fla., the Oakland Athletics will have the Bay Area to themselves. They should benefit by gaining more lucrative television and radio contracts with the airwaves all to themselves -- negotiations are in progress for new contracts -- but contrary to popular view, they won't necessarily gain at the gate.
When the Giants and the Dodgers left New York 35 years ago, the Yankees did not benefit by having the fans of the departed teams flock to Yankee Stadium. In the seven years before the move, the Yankees averaged 1,581,687 a season; in the seven years following the move, they averaged 1,494,811. The Yankees won six pennants in each seven-season span.
For most Giants fans, crossing over to the east side of the bay to see a baseball game would be like Dodger fans traveling from Brooklyn to the Bronx in the late 1950's and early 60's. It didn't happen.
 
He's Only Human
 The Athletics, doing a remarkable job in overcoming various forms of adversity, experienced culture shock in the last week. In the space of five games, Dennis Eckersley squandered a save opportunity in one game and walked two batters in another.
Before he relinquished the lead to Kansas City, Eckersley had succeeded in holding leads 36 times in 36 save situations this season. Four days later, after having walked five batters in 55 1/3 innings over 47 games, Eckersley walked Lance Johnson and Joey Cora of the Chicago White Sox. He would plead guilty, but with an explanation. The walk to Johnson was intentional.
Discussing the Athletics' uncharacteristically mediocre pitching, General Manager Sandy Alderson said: "We've gotten very good pitching and lousy pitching for periods of time. When we're good, we're very good, and when we're lousy, we're very lousy." Then he added: "Eckersley has to make a huge difference. We win every game he pitches, and no one else can say that."

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: When Doctors Say Yes and Insurers No

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
A few months ago, Dr. Steven Nissen, a cardiologist at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, was called in to consult in the puzzling case of a 44-year-old woman. Her chest felt tight at times, but she did not have the pain that signals the clogged arteries of heart disease. Hospitalized several times for the discomfort, she was discharged each time when tests showed nothing wrong.
Then Dr. Nissen had an idea: a new, little-used test called intravascular ultrasound that would let him see inside the woman's arteries. Like something out of the film "Fantastic Voyage," the test involves threading through the blood vessels a catheter with the equivalent of a tiny movie camera at the tip. 
 "We put the probe in there," Dr. Nissen said, "and sure enough, there was soft cholesterol-laden plaque all up and down the artery," indicating serious clogging.
The other doctors in the room, who were about to send the woman home with no treatment, were shocked. They prescribed two powerful cholesterol-lowering drugs and a strict low-fat diet to try to induce the plaque to regress. The hope is to prevent a disabling or fatal heart attack, keep the woman at work and eliminate enormous hospital bills.
Intravascular ultrasound "could be the most important change in the way we evaluate patients with coronary disease in the last 30 years," said Dr. Jeffrey Isner, chief of cardiovascular research at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Boston. Other cardiologists agree. They say it shows the inside of a patient's blood vessels with detail so fine, and images so pure, that the only thing comparable is to split open the blood vessels at autopsy and look at them.
But development and use of the new device has languished, doctors and manufacturers say, falling victim to the nation's struggle to control medical costs. The bill for each intravascular ultrasound is expected to be several thousand dollars. Insurance companies are beginning to refuse to pay for such expensive tests and treatments unless it can be proved with clinical data that they are more effective for a particular class of patient than are the existing methods. And their costs must be justified, by improvement in the patient and also sometimes by elimination of the need for other costly treatments.
 
Who Will Pay?
 The catch, cardiologists and manufacturers say, is that the only way to prove intravascular ultrasound is clinically and cost effective is to use it a lot. And the only way that will happen is if insurers pay for it.
Health care experts say that the story of intravascular ultrasound illustrates a growing obstacle to the development of medical technology. For years, the country has relied on health insurance to pay for the diffusion of new technologies that saved or improved lives and oh, by the way, turned a pretty profit for doctors, hospitals and medical-equipment manufacturers and the investors who financed them. When that source is cut off, there seems nowhere else to turn.
The problem, many experts say, is that in the name of cost containment Americans may be slowing progress toward medical advances -- even ones that might ultimately save on health costs by detecting disease at an early stage, curing it at a lower cost or preventing it.
"What you see here in this case, what's being complained about, is the beginnings of mechanisms of controlling a process that never was controlled," said Dr. Norman Daniels, a health care researcher at Tufts University. "In the past, you could always just go ahead and run with this ball as far as you could and see if it was worth carrying. And if it wasn't, so what? You could always get reimbursement."
Insurers say they are in a bind. Expensive technologies account for 40 percent of annual increases in health insurance premiums, said Dr. John Cova, director of medical technology assessment for the Health Insurance Association of America, which represents many insurance companies. "We have fewer and fewer health care dollars to spend each year and more and more to spend them on," he said. "We can no longer afford to support the diffusion of new technology through health care coverage."
Intravascular ultrasound is far from the only treatment running into resistance from insurers. (See box.)
Dr. Michael Strauss, the president of Health Technology Associates, a consulting firm in Washington, said the new insurance climate has a chilling effect on investors who finance small companies. "If it takes five, six or seven years to get payment, most companies can't hold out that long," he said. "We have retainer agreements with lots of venture capitalists, and about once a week we get a call asking what is the likelihood of payment" on a new method or device.
A 1991 survey of executives at medical-product and service companies found that 45 percent of those at companies with sales exceeding $51 million thought that the new resistance by insurers, which also includes bargaining down the price they pay for various treatments, was hurting their stock price and financing prospects. The figure rose to 81 percent at the smallest companies (sales under $5 million). A third of the company presidents in the survey, by the consulting firm Biomedical Business International of Santa Ana, Calif., said cuts in insurance coverage would reduce revenues by as much as 5 percent; almost half said the drop would be 6 percent to 25 percent.
Not too long ago, insurers routinely paid for devices and medical procedures that had Food and Drug Administration approval. And devices like that used for intravascular ultrasound are usually approved quite quickly by the F.D.A. Unlike drugs, for which manufacturers have to prove safety and efficacy, devices need only be substantially equivalent to other devices on the market.
 
Bring in the Experts
 But F.D.A. approval is "not enough anymore," Dr. Strauss said. The Health Insurance Association of America helps its members decide whether to pay for new technologies by convening panels of experts to discuss them. Dr. Cova said he brings together four or five advocates of a technology and four or five who challenge it. An expert deemed neutral leads the panel, and transcripts are sent to the 300 commercial insurers in the group. The medical director at each insurer then decides whether to recommend reimbursement.
Dr. Cova said the insurance association also passes its findings on to the Government for its own health programs, including Medicare and Medicaid. The Government assesses technology through the tiny Office of Health Technology Assessment. And like the private insurers, the Government has increasingly balked at paying for certain things.
The field of cardiology, in which the intravascular ultrasound is a potential player, illustrates the way medical technology, with all its benefits and costs, has proliferated. Thirty years ago, a patient with chest discomfort who went to the doctor would typically come away with nitroglycerin pills that temporarily relieve chest pain. The cost was usually minimal. Then again, a lot of patients later died of heart attacks.
In the 1960's came the wide use of angiography, in which a dye is injected into the arteries and an X-ray is taken, showing constrictions. The test, improved since then, costs insurers about $1,500, says the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
By the 1970's, surgeons were practicing coronary bypass surgery, in which blood is shunted around a blocked artery. Such surgery typically costs $40,000 today.
Now, diagnostic tests also include an echocardiogram, measuring heart movement, at about $450, and a scintillation test, measuring blood flow to the heart, at $400.
An intravascular ultrasound would cost insurers about $3,000 to $4,000, said Melissa Sabino, vice president of the Wilkerson Group, a New York health care consulting company. This includes about $2,000 to $3,000 for the hospital and about $1,000 for the cardiologist administering the 10-minute test. And that charge might come on top of the cost of the angiogram tried beforehand.
Such procedures have proved lucrative for the specialists who perform them; these doctors "have increased their income quite a bit recently," Ms. Sabino said, by doing more procedures and charging more.
In an intravascular ultrasound, doctors thread a thin catheter into the blood vessels. At the tip of the catheter is a minuscule device that bounces sound waves off the artery walls. A special ultrasound machine picks up the signals and produces detailed pictures.
The technique helps cardiologists determine whether the artery-clogging plaque is hard or soft. This allows doctors to more rationally consider a variety of options, including whether to do a bypass, to try to squash the plaque against the vessel wall by inflating a tiny balloon within the artery, or to try to vaporize the plaque with a laser.
In addition, cardiologists say, intravascular ultrasound allows them to learn, for the first time, whether a person has a uniform, and dangerous, buildup of plaque, as Dr. Nissen's patient did, or merely narrow blood vessels. Tests like angiography sometimes miss the plaque because they look for areas of artery constriction. The plaque buildup in Dr. Nissen's patient was so uniform, narrowing the artery so smoothly, that it appeared the artery was simply of slightly small bore.
Some patients who have undergone intravascular ultrasound in the few hospitals that offer it were spared bypass surgery, saving tens of thousands of dollars, when doctors learned that they were fine. Others, like the woman Dr. Nissen saw, had huge pile-ups of plaque, although some patients, like the woman, could not benefit from surgery because there was no specific constriction.
If intravascular ultrasound had come on the scene just a few years earlier, cardiologists say, it would have spread quickly. Now, with no insurance payments, just a few medical centers offer it. Only large medical centers, like the Cleveland Clinic and Duke University Medical School, are willing to absorb its costs, taking a loss or paying for it through research grants. A few places, like Tufts University, say they have found creative ways to slip in the cost, unnoticed, on insurance bills.
 
Companies Give Up
 The new resistance from insurers has left medical-equipment manufacturers dangling, said Steven Speil, director of payment and health care delivery at the Health Industry Manufacturers Association. "Payers say, 'Give us more information on what it can do.' But you can't generate more data absent reimbursement," he said. Mr. Speil said a growing number of companies are giving up on new technologies.
The medical-equipment industry offers great potential for profitability once a device gains wide use. Ms. Sabino said gross profit would typically be around 60 percent for machines like ultrasound devices, and about 80 percent for catheters.
The ultrasound machines that make intravascular images sell for $75,000 to $100,000. The catheters, which cannot be reused, sell for $400 to $800.
The ultrasound machines and catheters are being made mostly by small companies, including Intertherapy in Irvine, Calif., Endosonics in Pleasanton, Calif., and Cardiovascular Imaging Systems in Sunnyvale, Calif. But last month, Hewlett-Packard announced that it would start making the machines as well, teaming up with Boston Scientific, a Watertown, Mass., manufacturer of catheters.
Doctors say they are especially saddened by the slow development of intravascular ultrasound when they compare it with other technologies that gained a foothold because insurers paid for them. For example, balloon angioplasty, introduced in the early 1980's to clear arteries by inflating a tiny balloon, spread rapidly and is now more widely used than bypass surgery. Yet only now are clinical trials under way to see which provides better long-term results.
An expensive diagnostic method, magnetic resonance imaging, also slipped in under the old rules.
Dr. Cova said that if manufacturers are so set on intravascular ultrasound, they should "take some of the millions of dollars that they are spending on marketing and advertising and fund a neutral party that would assess that technology."
But Dr. Daniels of Tufts said that would not be so easy. It is hard enough, he said, to do a good cost assessment of an established technology, but nearly impossible to do one for an embryonic technology.
Another possibility is for doctors and manufacturers to jointly perform clinical trials that could show the intravascular ultrasound saves money by improving diagnoses.
But the studies would take years, and the handful of companies that make the special catheters and ultrasound machines are mostly small start-up companies, with limited cash to pay for clinical trials. In the past, trials were not done at all or they were done by the Government.
Dr. Isner of St. Elizabeth's said he and others like the intravascular ultrasound so much that they considered doing the studies themselves. But "it's not that easy," he said.
"Maybe," he said, "the fact that no one has gone to the trouble reflects our past experience that it is not necessary to go to that trouble. Maybe now we are living in an era where if we feel strongly enough about something like this, we have to do it."
 
TREATMENTS SPURNED
 Intravascular ultrasound is not the only medical treatment facing demands from insurers for more proof of effectiveness. All told, hundreds of products aimed at anywhere from 10,000 to a million patients have met resistance, said Peggy Pargoff, president of Biomedical Business International, a consulting firm in Santa Ana, Calif.
For example, devices called lithotripters, which are widely used to pulverize kidney stones, could not get insurance coverage for smashing gallstones because they were judged to be not as effective as techniques like removing the gall bladder.
Dr. John Cova, director of medical technology assessment for the Health Insurance Association of America, said that despite the enormous investment in positron emission tomography, the imaging technique known as a PET scan, most insurers won't pay for it. In a recent assessment by his organization, experts concluded that PET scans of the heart were not much better than conventional imaging yet "cost twice as much."
Dr. Cova said insurers are also denying payment for a type of gynecological surgery that employs two teams of surgeons and a laparoscope to do vaginal hysterectomies. "They don't have any data showing it's more effective and it costs four or five times as much."
In other cases, new techniques have slipped through the insurance net. A popular new method of gall bladder surgery, through a slit in the abdomen with a laparoscope, has been covered by insurers. Yet there were no clinical data on its effectiveness or on how it compared with traditional gall bladder surgery, said Dr. Michael Strauss, president of Health Technology Associates, a Washington consulting firm. The reason it is covered, he explained, is that doctors can bill for it as a gall bladder removal -- they did not need a new insurance code -- even though the procedure takes less time and should be less expensive.
 
IN SEARCH OF A COMPROMISE
 No one denies that health insurance companies have a legitimate complaint when they say they cannot go on paying for every new technology that lights up a doctor's eye. But some experts question the new demands by insurers that manufacturers prove the worth of their devices. They propose alternative solutions that, they say, would give promising new methods more of a fighting chance.
The Health Industry Manufacturers Association favors what it calls conditional coverage: the insurance industry would pay for limited use of a new technology in settings like selected medical centers where data on its effectiveness could be generated.
Such a system "would help us all," said Steven Speil, director of payment and health care delivery for the association. "It puts at least a temporary lid on the technology, so we don't have the consequences the insurers fear -- a technology out of control. And the manufacturers, the doctors and the clinics get paid."
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association has begun financing such studies for bone marrow transplants in breast-cancer patients.
Dr. Steven Nissen, a cardiologist at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, said he would like to see the Government pay for studies on the effectiveness of promising technologies and a national panel of experts to evaluate which ones merit reimbursement. If a new method passed this scrutiny, he said, its overuse should be prevented by requiring "certificates of need," issued by the Government, that would limit the number of centers at which the technology would be available.
Dr. Norman Daniels of Tufts University said more research must be done on how best to assess a technology. Now, he said, only a minimal effort is under way to develop better ways to determine how clinically and cost effective new medical methods are. Too often, he said, "it's just guesstimating." And that, experts said, can lead to capricious decisions that hobble methods that could save lives and dollars while letting fancy devices with no clear advantages into the marketplace.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 23, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about new medical technology and what insurers are willing to pay for it inaccurately described a billing practice at Tufts University. While other hospitals have found ways to be partly reimbursed for cardiovascular ultrasound, the main teaching hospital at Tufts, New England Medical Center, says it gets no such reimbursement.

HEADLINE: Finally, Vietnamization

BYLINE: By Kevin Cooney; Kevin Cooney has covered Asian news for the past six years and is currently the Bangkok bureau chief for Reuters.

 BODY:

AFTER THE WAR WAS OVER
Hanoi and Saigon.
By Neil Sheehan.
131 pp. New York:
Random House. $17. 
 IN 1989 Neil Sheehan, a former correspondent in Vietnam for United Press International and The New York Times, returned to the scenes of his youth, of his generation's war and of the reportage that became his life's work. "After the War Was Over" is the result of that journey. This political travelogue deals with the question that occurs so easily to all who visit Vietnam now, but that American leaders of the 1960's apparently could not begin to formulate: "Why in the name of God had we bombed a country as poor as this?"
The poverty, exacerbated by American bombing and now partly maintained by the postwar American economic embargo, is everywhere present in this work, from rat-infested hotel rooms to a filthy Hanoi hospital where the life of a child was lost for lack of an antibiotic readily available at American drugstores.
The Vietnamese Mr. Sheehan interviewed are presented as people as forgiving as they were fierce. As examples of dedication to the common good, they are sharply at odds with the current conception of "Communist" as a synonym for "corrupt."
The most interesting of them is Nguyen Van Linh, who in 1989 was the general secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party. He is a man who survived 12 years in a French prison, 30 years of war and a decade of political infighting to push his country toward economic liberalization and away from the grayness imposed by his Stalinist comrades.
Mr. Linh, whose Communism is based more on "Les Miserables" than on "Das Kapital," achieved a degree of reform, he told Mr. Sheehan, by applying the lessons learned in the jungle fighting Americans. "My comrades and I could not afford to be subjective in our conclusions," he said. "Had we been subjective, we would immediately have been crushed by reality. So I continued to think according to that pattern when I shifted to peaceful restructuring." Mr. Sheehan contrasts this with the illusions on which John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson based their war policy, primarily the belief that Ho Chi Minh and his associates, heirs to a thousand-year tradition of anti-Chinese nationalism, were pawns of the Chinese.
"After the War Was Over" serves as an afterword to the author's Pulitzer Prize-winning "Bright Shining Lie" and will probably be most appreciated by readers of that book. Mr. Sheehan revisits the battlegrounds of the war and finds them filled with optimistic people, along with the "American grass" that the Vietnamese believe was deliberately seeded by the United States to provide a combustible material for additional waves of napalm.
To his surprise, Mr. Sheehan discovers an absence of animosity toward the United States. In a country now finally, truly undergoing Vietnamization, buildings are kept in readiness for the return of American officials.
As a Hanoi doctor said of the 19th-century microscope still used at his hospital, "After the War Was Over" helps us "see a little better than with our eyes."
 
 
 
WAITING FOR THE RATS
 "The Hotel Metropole . . . was 'le dernier salon ou l'on cause,' the last really fashionable place in Hanoi," [Bernard] Fall had written of his Hanoi of the 1950's. . . . When I walked up the front steps . . . past Grecian columns of peeling white paint, and pushed on the revolving door at the entrance, it turned grudgingly. The explanation was not in the heaviness of the once-handsome door: almost everything in Hanoi has been running down since 1939. The spindle on which the revolving door turned was worn out. Decades of guests coming and going, grinding grit underfoot, had also created dips in the marble of the entrance steps and the floor of the lobby. We went up to the room assigned to us on the third floor. It was large and held two old wooden beds with mosquito netting. . . . Because I had stayed in rooms like it elsewhere in Asia during my young reportorial years, I could almost see the rats, even though I knew they probably would not come out until after dark. (An Australian friend stayed at the [Metropole] with his son and daughter while we were in Hanoi. His son lost a large part of a sock to the rats one night, and his daughter was afraid to get out of bed to take a bath because the rats made so much noise gamboling about the room.) -- From "After the War Was Over."

HEADLINE: Office Space Still Plentiful Despite Bright Signs

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHEN the subject is office space, the good news locally is that many small and medium-size companies are leaving Manhattan and relocating their operations in Westchester. But the bad news is that the flurry of activity is not strong enough to turn the market around.
"Bluntly put, there is still a tremendous amount of office space to be absorbed before it will be fair to say that the county has turned the corner," said John Rostenberg, president of the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a commercial brokerage with offices in Purchase and Stamford. 
 "Prospects look slim for a rebound of the office market this year," he said. "One of the reasons for that prognosis is that the Westchester market is closely tied to the activity of the mid-Manhattan market. And right now, the difference in rental rates between mid-Manhattan and Westchester have narrowed, making us less competitive. The large company move-outs that landlords in the county were hoping for are not occurring. The large companies are staying right where they are, in Manhattan."
In order to attract prime tenants from New York City to Westchester for Class A space, Mr. Rostenberg said, a margin of about $10 a square foot for space is needed.
 
A Record Vacancy Rate
 "Although 100,000 square feet of Class A space in Westchester can now be had for under $20 a foot, compared with $30 a foot five years ago, Class A space in New York City has dropped to $25 a foot, which makes it not as attractive to move to Westchester as it was when the spread was significantly greater," he said.
A just-released report from Mr. Rostenberg's office found that corporate consolidation and new vacancies continued to hamper recovery for the Westchester office market during the first half of the year. The countywide vacancy rate of 21.9 percent at the end of June was up from 18.5 percent in 1991. Hardest hit was downtown White Plains, with a record vacancy rate of 27 percent.
Major changes, namely the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's vacating 180,000 square feet of space and a consolidation by Prodigy Services, has left the downtown area with 387,000 square feet vacant. The failure of the Dollar Dry Dock Bank also returned a sizable block of space to the market.
 
Some Positive Notes
 But Prodigy's recent announcement that it had signed a renewal lease for 340,000 square feet, the entire building at 445 Hamilton Avenue, is an encouraging sign for the downtown market.
"Also on the positive side, 10 Bank Street, a building with easy access to the train station, is doing well," Mr. Rostenberg said. "Right now, 10 Bank Street is the most active building in Westchester."
That building is a 12-story, 219,000-square-foot granite and glass structure, built in 1990 and owned by Homart Development Company of Chicago, part of the Sears Roebuck group of companies.
R. Perry Neilson Jr., the development director for Homart, said plans for the building, which is Homart's first project in the Northeast, were developed during the boom years of the late 1980's.
"We were then correctly responding to the forces of supply and demand," Mr. Neilson said. "In our surveys we showed that downtown White Plains had the lowest vacancy rate in the country at that time. But by December 1989, when the building came onstream and our first and largest tenants, the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, moved in, the recession was already on us."
Mr. Neilson said Homart decided on a marketing plan, going after the Manhattan market. By implementing an aggressive advertising and marketing campaign, which included posters in commuter train cars and ads in Metro-North schedules, the building attracted attention from prospective tenants.
 
Transplanted Tenants
 "We stressed the quality of the building and its proximity to Manhattan, which is only a 3-minute walk to the station and a 34-minute commute," Mr. Neilson said.
Just how successful were their efforts? More than half of the 23 tenants are transplants from Manhattan, Mr. Neilson said.
"We have lawyers who want to be near the courthouse and Manhattan at the same time," Mr. Neilson said. "We have small companies whose owners live in Westchester and like the ease of commuting by car. And we have a good mix of small- to medium-size businesses that come from Manhattan, including trucking companies and security firms."
The tenants get inducements like improvement allowances and rental concessions, "but I believe the big selling point in the 90's will be service," Mr. Neilson said. "A key element in renting space today is running harder than the competition to provide such things as 24-hour security, a resident manager who is an on-the-spot trouble-shooter and making sure that the computerized buildings we have today run efficiently."
Thirty-five percent, or 75,000 square feet, at 10 Bank Street is still vacant.
 
Concessions Being Offered
 At Cushman & Wakefield, the region's largest commercial brokerage, William E. Hartman, the associate who handles Westchester transactions, said: "Although the first three months of the year were especially tough with numerous properties, namely the Schulman Realty Group's buildings taken over by lenders, in the long run, changes in ownership will be beneficial to tenants. Because the new owners are financially stable, they have the wherewithal to make a long-term commitment to the market."
He gave as an example Gateway Towers, the 560,000-square-foot building in downtown White Plains, built by James Pappas and now owned by the Cigna Corporation of Hartford.
"When former lenders like Cigna become owners they can be more responsive to the market," Mr. Hartman said. "The new owners of the 22 properties that formerly belonged to the Schulman Realty Group also have the resources now to make concessions to tenants."
Both Mr. Hartman and Carl Austin, head of Austin Corporate Properties in Tarrytown, said the glut of office space and the decline in rents has a silver lining.
"This is the time to lock in 10-year leases because we're at the bottom of the market now," Mr. Hartman said. "Tenants who hold leases written in 1986 and '87 are paying over $30 a foot for space that can now be negotiated for $19 to $20 a foot. And there is nothing on line because there is no new construction going on in the county at present."
 
A Chance to Move Up
 Mr. Austin added: "It's a market of opportunity for tenants who are eager to step up from Class B space to Class A space. The climate is right for companies who want to relocate outside of New York City."
The county's largest lease so far this year, the 78,000 square feet taken by J.W.P. Inc. in the Royal Executive Park in Rye Brook, has helped reduce available space in the eastern part of the county, Mr. Austin said.
He added that H. Hoenig & Company, a brokerage firm, recently transferred an entire office from Third Avenue in midtown Manhattan to Royal Executive Park.
In other Westchester markets, the Route 119 corridor saw the vacancy rate fall slightly from six months ago. Although International Business Machines made a major recommitment with renewal and expansion at the Tarrytown Corporate Center, American Ultramar vacated about 50,000 square feet of subleased space in the Christiania Building, Mr. Rostenberg said.
In southern Westchester, there was little significant leasing during the first six months of the year. The vacancy rate was 15.3 percent, up slightly from 14.2 percent the previous year.
In the northern Westchester office market, which includes Mount Pleasant and Mount Kisco, more than 86,000 square feet was absorbed during the first half of the year. The vacancy rate in that market fell from 25.6 percent six months ago to 23.3 percent at the end of June.
