SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1832 words

HEADLINE: Burden of Commuter Smog Falls on Employers

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT employers must now start thinking about how their employees get to work, as much as how hard they work. This is because an updated and revised version of a 1970 Federal law, whose provisions are being phased in throughout this decade, makes large companies in areas as polluted as Connecticut responsible for curbing the pollution associated with commuting.
A draft plan prepared by the state Department of Transportation calls for large employers to consider such measures as sharing the cost of van-pooling and mass transit with commuters, providing preferential parking for car poolers and permitting flexible work hours to encourage car pooling. Although there has been much criticism of Federal delays in developing regulations needed to meet the goals of the new legislation known as the Clean Air Act of 1990, the Transportation Department, trade groups and planning agencies are joining together to help companies prepare to meet the letter of the law. 
 "This could really change business, because it makes them responsible for something that we've always taken for granted as being a personal decision -- how we get to work," said William H. Messner, a planning director for the Transportation Department. "It could even result in significant social changes, if employers adopt things like four-day work weeks and telecommuting to reduce pollution."
Under the original Clean Air Act adopted in 1970, only so-called smokestack industries were held accountable for pollution. But air experts estimate that 70 percent of the smog in Connecticut comes from automobile tailpipes. So, in areas like Fairfield County, classified as severely polluted, any company with more than 100 employees will have to develop a policy to reduce the number of commuter trips. .
"Companies that have never had to think about the Clean Air Act before, now they're going to have to start paying attention," said Joseph M. Ercolano, vice president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association. Under the new law, compliance is based on commuting, he said, "and every business has commuters."
 
More Comprehensive Than Old Act
 Although the Federal act affects only large businesses, it could change the way all commuters think, said Liz E. Navarro, director of sales for Metro Pool, a transportation management company based in Stamford.
"We want to say, 'You, Mr. Corporation, you fix this problem,' but what can happen is the corporations become trendsetters, and things will get done," Ms. Navarro said. "It does spread, and that is, of course, what it's meant to do."
The revised Clean Air Act, signed into law Nov. 15, 1990, is far more comprehensive than its predecessor, and the impact on commuting is one way it is expected to make itself felt in Connecticut. The act seeks to reduce toxic emissions into the air by as much as 90 percent.
The 1990 legislation is almost 800 pages long, compared with 65 pages for the 1970 version. It regulates 189 chemicals, up from 7, and where the 1970 act regulated any company putting more than 100 tons of pollutants into the air each year, the 1990 act governs a company emitting 25 tons, or 10 tons of any one pollutant. In 1970, violations of the act were misdemeanors; the 1990 legislation makes many violations felonies, with fines as high as $1 million.
The legislation puts new restrictions on chemicals that cause acid rain, that damage the protective ozone layer or that create smog. Industry estimates it will cost the nation's businesses $51 billion a year to comply with the 1990 provisions. Government analysts put the cost lower, at $25 billion to $35 billion.
But advocates say there could still be a net savings. The American Lung Association estimates that there will be 1,750 to 3,000 fewer deaths each year from pollution if the air is clean and that health care costs will decrease $40 billion to $50 billion a year. Damage to buildings will diminish, and the productivity of farm and forest land should be enhanced as acid rain is brought under control. The expanded Clean Air Act could even spur the creation of a new environmental engineering industry and prop up the price of corn if farmers use it to make alcohol, a cleaner-burning fuel than gasoline.
 
Deadlines for State Improvement
 The state was divided into two areas for the purposes of the act. Fairfield County is classified as "severely polluted," which means it will be under tighter restrictions than the rest of the state, which is classified as "seriously polluted." Air quality in Fairfield County must be improved to healthy levels by the year 2007; in the rest of the state, by 1999.
Joseph A. Belanger, the state Department of Environmental Protection director of planning for implementing the Clean Air Act, said people might be surprised at some of the measures that would go into effect to meet those goals.
Lawn mowers might have to be controlled because they contribute as much as 5 percent of the hydrocarbons that cause smog. Power boats, and even back yard barbecues, might have to be regulated.
 
'A Regional Problem'
 Mr. Belanger said the state's rules, in many instances, went beyond what was required at the Federal level. For instance, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency will require that only cleaner burning gasoline be sold in Fairfield and Hartford Counties by 1996. Connecticut extends that requirement to include the entire state.
"We're sort of out in front in this area, and we hope the Federal government adopts our position as it develops its own regulations," Mr. Belanger said. "Pollution is a regional problem, and it will do Connecticut no good to have rigorous policies if neighboring states don't."
Some business groups think provisions of the Federal legislation go too far, and could strangle economic development. Because of restrictions in seriously or severely polluted areas -- which covers the entire state -- companies now must go through an extensive review for permits to put in new or expanded operations. In order to receive a permit to emit chemicals at one site, a business will have to reduce pollution at other plants, or "buy" pollution credits from plants that are reducing pollution, said Richard A. Miller, a staff attorney for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
 
U.S. Rejects Petition
 The state argued that eastern Connecticut, which has cleaner air, should be classified only as moderately polluted, which would have allowed some economic development to take place without meeting the strict new pollution control requirements, Mr. Miller said. The Federal government rejected the petition.
The designation, Mr. Miller said, "wasn't necessarily based on science as much as it was based on a feeling there should be uniformity in such a small state. I think the Clean Air Act went a little too far in that it didn't look at some of these issues completely fairly."
In Fairfield County to obtain a permit to emit 100 tons of material a year, a company would have to cut back 130 tons somewhere else; in the rest of the state, by 120 tons.
"That's going to cause a real backlog at D.E.P., and that may mean some businesses will go to a state where they can get a permit faster and be up and running sooner," Mr. Miller said.
 
Enforcement Challenged
 Environmentalists, however, take the opposite view. Michael Stern, a staff attorney for the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, said he was particularly concerned about the pollutant that was of greatest concern in Connecticut: smog, or ozone.
"I think it could have been stricter about ozone," Mr. Stern said. The act sets up regional ozone transport commissions that will review each state's progress in meeting reduction efforts. If one state is not meeting goals, the other states report the violation to the Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Stern asserted that the commissions should have had the power to take action themselves.
"Every one of these steps you add allows someone to put more political pressure on the process," he said.
In addition, he said, while the Clean Air Act sets many new requirements for business, it affords a liberal timetable -- businesses do not have to show any results for two to four years -- and there are no penalties for businesses that do not meet their goals. They simply have to submit a new commuter trip reduction plan.
"The act is real short on enforcement in many respects," Mr. Stern said.
Mr. Messner of the Transportation Department said it was a balancing act. "You don't want to make employers in Connecticut non-competitive because the burden is too onerous, and you don't want to compromise your health standards," he said.
 
Timetables Required
 The most widely felt impact of the legislation, however, will be on commuting. The state Department of Economic Development estimates there are 2,200 businesses in Connecticut with more than 100 employees, with more than 25 percent of them in 7 of the state's 169 towns: Hartford (156); Stamford (109); Bridgeport (88); New Haven (85); Waterbury (77); Danbury (60), and Norwalk (59).
The Transportation Department has a draft known as the State Implementation Plan for the Clean Air Act, with a final copy scheduled to be ready by Nov. 1, Mr. Messner said. Early next year large companies will get copies of the plan, and a timetable for submitting their own programs to increase average vehicle occupancy to at least 25 percent over the area's average.
Transit planners hope that as the provisions of the law go into effect over the next couple of years, more people will be encouraged to take advantage of systems that are already in place. Bea Friedman, a spokeswoman for Metro Pool, said her company's new shuttle system in Greenwich ran between the trains and major employers, with a capacity of more than 300 people, but is used by only about 60 people each day.
"We'd like to be able to say before long that we have 200 riders," Ms. Friedman said. "And I think that can be achieved, but we have to get the employers behind it."
 
Uncrowded Shuttle
 Peter S. Smichenko, a property manager for Hines Interests Ltd., which operates a 225,000-square-foot office complex on High Ridge Road in Stamford, said a shuttle to the railroad station was offered to tenants. Although only 15 or 20 people use it each day, of the 500 people working at the complex, he said he expected use to climb as employers came under the pressure of the Clean Air Act.
"Even now, it's a very important service to the people who use it," Mr. Smichenko said. "It's their only way to get to work."
Ms. Navarra, of Metro Pool, said many businesses knew what would be required of them under the Clean Air Act, but they also knew they had some time to comply.
"There will be some companies, probably a lot of companies, that will wait until the last minute," Ms. Navarra said. "We need to remind people that this is coming, that it has to be done, so start now."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1174 words

HEADLINE: George Bush, Prisoner of the Crazies

BYLINE: By Garry Wills; Garry Wills, adjunct professor of history at Northwestern University, is author, most recently, of "Lincoln at Gettysburg."

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
St. Augustine, when he decided to dragoon reluctant people into the Christian camp, used a scriptural tag taken from the parable about the man whose guests did not come to his wedding feast: Coge intrare -- "Force them to come in" (Luke 14.23). The Republicans have called a love fest in Houston, to which some are loath to come. Their motto seems to be: Obsecra ut intrent -- "Beg them to come in."
People who have defied the President, called him weak or traitorous -- even branded him a tool of Satan -- are now being cajoled, asked not only to attend but to speak from the party's podium of honor. The platform committee renounces as "recessionary" the President's tax rise. A President in a strong position would not let his own party indirectly censure him. He certainly would not let minor Republican figures criticize him with impunity. But what is George Bush to do? He cannot ban people from a feast that so many do not want to attend in any case. 
 A third of the Republicans in Congress have announced their intention not to be in Houston. Republican candidates around the country are staying home to conduct their own campaigns. George Bush, who seems to attract hard luck these days, is being given a wide berth by people uneasy about their own elections. The President is reduced to papering the house, even if he has to do it with those who have ridiculed or humiliated him. Many of these critics come from the right wing of Mr. Bush's party, the hard core he needs most now and is servicing most strenuously.
Pat Buchanan began this year challenging the President's manhood -- the kind of attack Mr. Bush deeply resents. Mr. Buchanan said the President was afraid to debate him, that he could run but he could not hide, that he was unable to defend his vacillating record. That would be enough, with most partisans, to consign Mr. Buchanan to official oblivion.
Consider the other party's attitude to a member who challenged its candidate. Asked if Hamilton Jordan could return to the Democratic fold, James Carville, Bill Clinton's campaign manager, answered that he would not succor Mr. Jordan even if his heart were on fire and it could be doused by the simplest of irrigations.
But clearly the most astounding speaker in Houston is Pat Robertson. Mr. Robertson published a book this year ("The New World Order") arguing that the President's gulf war, his proudest achievement, was part of a diabolic plot to destroy America. By submitting to the U.N. and calling the world to its banner, President Bush was proclaiming the New World Order of the Antichrist. Near the original site of Babylon, the United Nations was raising a new Tower of Babel to challenge God's supremacy.
Mr. Bush thus completed a series of actions by organizations he has belonged to -- the Council on Foreign Relations, the Trilateral Commission, the C.I.A. -- pawns of the devil, all of them. Yet the President's party must now give this nuttiness a forum, as if Mr. Bush were crying: "Hit me again! Hit me again!" If the President will not defend his New World Order, what will he stand by?
This is not the first time the Republicans have cowered before their own right wing at convention time; but nothing like so large a set of concessions has been extracted before this.
In 1976, Gerald Ford caved in to the right wing's denunciation of detente by hiding Henry Kissinger through most of the convention and letting language critical of the Administration's foreign policy slip into the platform. John Sears was using these pressure points to promote a challenge from Ronald Reagan. Mr. Ford had to yield because there was some threat remaining of a stampede toward another candidate.
But President Bush is unchallenged, now, for the nomination, and he still grovels. He has not one official whose role he must play down or apologize for, but many. Richard Darman is denounced for the economic plan he foisted on the President, and Nicholas Brady for carrying out that plan. William Reilly, the E.P.A. Administrator, is denounced for protecting the environment at the cost of business immunities promoted by Vice President Dan Quayle. Robert Mosbacher is denounced for conferring with gays. Even Jim Baker, called in as a savior, is a dreaded "moderate" to the right, the marshaler of forces to the New World Order in the gulf.
In the past, the so-called social issues, which are really moral and religious issues, could be treated as secondary by Republican campaign managers, since the economy was the main concern of the party -- an economy called bad under Democrats in 1980, considered good under Republicans in 1984 and 1988.
That issue has crumbled beneath this President. The deficit is the Republicans' baby, nurtured to its present size by Reaganomics. All the promises of "supply side" policy -- increased saving and investment, reduced debts, new jobs -- sound empty.
This leaves Mr. Bush more than ever dependent on people who will oppose abortion, support school prayer and denounce homosexuals, no matter what happens to the economy. The President felt the ire of these people when he not only signed into law the "hate crimes" bill but invited gay activists to the signing. The Southern Baptist Convention retaliated by disinviting him from a speech he had been scheduled to give that body.
Mr. Bush has been actively courting this constituency ever since -- by, for instance, not only maintaining but strengthening his opposition to abortion, as one can see from the Administration's work for the "gag rule" against abortion counseling at federally supported clinics.
The man in charge of that policy is William R. Archer 3d of the Health and Human Services Department, a man who not only criticized the Roe v. Wade decision on abortion but the Griswold decision on the sale of contraceptives. Mr. Archer, a self-proclaimed celibate, is such an advocate of abstinence as the best way of controlling AIDS, teen pregnancy, and abortion that he told a clinic worker he regretted his own indulgence in sex six years earlier.
The crazies are in charge. The fringe has taken over. The social issues were a source of strength to the Republicans when they seemed to be supporting the mainstream moral concerns of most Americans. These Americans believe in God, prayer and the Bible, and they are uncomfortable with those who oppose any or all of those things -- as Democrats, absurdly, seemed to be doing in 1988.
But these morally concerned Americans do not want the AIDS menace to go unchecked while Pat Buchanan calls it the homosexuals' punishment, while Republicans oppose safety measures like the distribution of condoms and clean needles. These are not people who read the Book of Revelation as condemning the New World Order. They are not wild-eyed figures from the fringe that Mr. Bush is now reduced to courting. No wonder the Republicans must beg people to come into their shrinking tent. The fringe on that tent's entrance is forbidding, and the tent is becoming mainly fringe.

PUB-DATE: August 16, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 20; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1108 words

HEADLINE: CULTURAL VIEW;
Inside the Political Mimic's Fun-House Mirror

BYLINE: By Anna Deavere Smith; Anna Deavere Smith will appear this afternoon in a final performance at the Joseph Papp Public Theater of her one-woman show, "Fires in the Mirror," in which she plays 27 people she interviewed about the 1991 Crown Heights racial violence in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
To the artist, what is more dangerous: the possibility of giving offense or the refusal to look and to see? When the rest of us have turned our attention to other matters, the impressionists, the parodists, the comics, are still watching. Historically, their vigilance is what has kept them on the outskirts of society.
In our own time, Dana Carvey's impressions of President Bush on "Saturday Night Live" won him an invitation to the White House. On another occasion the President's speechwriters asked Mr. Carvey to talk to them about the President's mannerisms. 
 A videotape of the comedian Jim Morris performing Bush impersonations at the Ford Theater in Washington is intercut with shots of the President and his wife in the audience obviously enjoying the joke.
Authority likes to see itself imitated, followed. But impersonation is not the same as a mirror image or a videotape. For the health of a society, it should not be; it should, in fact, be authority turned upside down. Mimics study authority while standing on their hands. They wear respectable clothing -- designer jeans in their real lives and business suits while portraying politicians. But underneath is the spirit of Harlequin and his multicolors and a view of the world that is inverted. The public takes this reflection and uses it as a key. The mimic has opened up a new way of seeing.
In Shakespeare's "King Lear," the Fool is referred to by Goneril, the King's daughter, as his "all licensed Fool." The character can say things that would send others to prison or their graves. The Fool also serves as a mirror of Lear. Will the King recognize himself, the play asks. Every fool's mirror throws back a fun-house reflection that in some ways is truer than the more flattering real mirror image would be.
"I'm not concerned about politics for the good reasons," said the "Saturday Night Live" writer and performer Al Franken in a recent conversation. "I'm interested for the bad reasons. I'm interested for the horse race. It's fun to watch these people savage each other and lie."
In this society, comedians don't get executed for their political commentary, but a comic can't go where the audience is not willing to follow. Joy Behar remembers that when she performed Reagan jokes in the 80's, nobody laughed. "Even in New York, the Reagan material was not working. People were still making money and they didn't like seeing him trashed. Then it became clear unemployment was rising and it opened up."
"You couldn't get a joke off of Bush when he was Vice President because he had been the head of the C.I.A.," Ms. Behar said. "Today, Quayle has been a boon to comedy."
Which Presidential candidate is more lampoonable? "Clinton is younger," she said. "You can take more shots at a younger person."
When Comedy Central, the cable network, covered the Democratic National Convention last month in New York, what fascinated was the degree to which real politicians were cajoled into participating in their "foolishness." As Ms. Behar, Mr. Franken and other comics worked the convention floor, interviewing candidates and delegates on "Indecision '92," one wondered what encourages politicians to speak with fools. Might it be that some of these office-holders see the limit of the real glass mirror; see it and seek the notion of a human mirror, even if deflation comes with the bargain. When jesters sat at the side of kings, a relationship of interdependence developed with the two often meeting in the hallway of distorted mirrors. The mingling of politicians with select fools today may be a sign that a more fluid relationship between the two is being sought.
But it may also mean that this is a time for outsiders, said Mary Salter, vice president of current programs and production for the Comedy Central network. "With the rise of Perot, you saw that the country was open for something from the outside. People are looking for alternatives."
About the Republican National Convention, which opens tomorrow in Houston, Ms. Salter said her team is optimistic, convinced that the delegates want to be perceived as having senses of humor.
Although some comics are licensed fools, particularly those who have the sanction of celebrity, other social commentators, the rap artists, have clearly not been "all licensed." Perhaps they never set out to be. And it's doubtful that any of them are eager to cavort with the king. But they are eager to challenge the king. Their words are listened to. No physical shtick, no MTV cinematography keeps the word from coming through loud and clear. And, as has been seen this summer in the cases of Sister Souljah and Ice-T, the words have been taken seriously. To some they are cutting and on the money, to others, fearsome and divisive.
"Race is a tricky one," Ms. Salter said. "The whole point is it should be talked about. And we should talk about it, because when you can laugh about something together, you can talk about it."
So what is more dangerous: the possibility of giving offense or the refusal to look and to see? Eddie Murphy has done an impression of Jesse Jackson in which the mimicry is technically brilliant. As Mr. Jackson, he stops speaking and continues his thought in a soul tune with a three-man backup group. Would a white comic get away with combining these two motifs -- a powerful black political figure and Motown? Or would this be considered racial stereotyping? Would some consider Mr. Murphy himself to have crossed over the line of what is acceptable? Or is it rather that parts of our society are considered sacred until the fool shows us the upside-down view?
What if the President had an impressionist on staff who held him accountable? The political figure performs himself or herself every day, and that performance grows and changes like actors' performances grow and change the more they learn about the text, the circumstances and the audience.
If there were a house mimic -- an all-licensed Fool for 1992 -- would the individual necessarily be of the same race, gender and political sensibility as the President? Could that even be, if the person were meant, as the Roman satirists were, to keep the emperor in check?
Who would be the perfect Fool for our time? A time in which we are divided, challenged, in some quarters hushed, in others licensed. Who could speak to all our fragments, for all our fragments, while revealing to those in power their own denials, without the risk of metaphoric execution? Before we even answer that question we must ask: Does our society breed the kinds of fools who take the risks to show us more than we can see?

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: August 17, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: PARTY IN THE SPOTLIGHT: THE OVERVIEW;
Fractured G.O.P. Meets as Public Voices Disfavor

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Battered by political events and months of disorganization in President Bush's re-election drive, Republicans assembled here today for their national convention in a mood of striking uncertainty for a party that has held the White House for the last 12 years.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll outlines the daunting task of political rehabilitation that faces them. Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee, retains a 17-point lead over Mr. Bush. Perhaps more important, the vast majority of American voters said there needed to be "real change" in the way things are going in this country, according to this survey.
 
Candidate for Change
 Only 15 percent said that re-electing Mr. Bush would bring that change, compared with 63 percent who saw that possibility under a Clinton Presidency. 
 Mr. Bush's strategists acknowledge that, whatever the reason, they have failed to convince the American people that the President has a plan and a vision to mend the economy; only 23 percent of the voters in the Times/CBS News Poll said he had offered specific ideas to reverse the downturn, while 48 percent said Mr. Clinton did. "That's what we're going to start curing here this week," said Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, underscoring the stakes of the next four days.
The nationwide telephone poll of 1,022 registered voters was conducted Tuesday through Friday and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
'I Know It, I Feel It'
 The campaign sent Mr. Bush forth this weekend on an extraordinary media blitz: from Time and Newsweek to the ABC News program "This Week." He confessed error, notably on breaking his "no new taxes" pledge. He blamed Congress for blocking his domestic programs. And, clearly trying to soften the impact of months of Democratic attacks, he told the American people that he understood their "hurting."
"I know it, I feel it, we pray about it," he told David Brinkley.
Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle are expected to arrive here on Monday, the opening day of the convention at the Houston Astrodome, but Mr. Bush set a feisty tone when he spoke by satellite hookup this afternoon to a group of supporters there. "Together, we really are going to close the gap," the President said. "We've got a good program; the people do not know it. And when we get through with this convention you've worked so hard for, they will."
Within his Administration and the party at large, the debate continued over what new economic measures the President should embrace, and when. Republicans presented the case both for and against new tax cuts on the Sunday talk shows, while others predicted a simple re-packaging of existing Administration proposals.
The abortion issue also continued to roil the party, with a billboard supporting abortion rights at the entrance to the convention center telling all who passed that 71 percent of Republicans support their cause. The Republican national chairman, Richard N. Bond, in an appearance this morning on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," tried to signal tolerance for differing views even as he defended the anti-abortion stance of the President and the party's new platform.
 
Jittery Convention
 "I don't think," Mr. Bond said, "that George Bush will abandon his pro-life stand, but I think we've all got to take this in perspective, which is, abortion is one 150th of the Republican Party platform."
But supporters of abortion rights vowed to keep up the fight. "I think we ought to do whatever it takes, whatever is necessary to remove this very contentious issue from the current platform," Senator John Seymour of California said tonight. "I know it's uphill, but we have to try."
It all made for a jittery scene as the 2,210 Republican delegates gathered for a convention that only a year ago was expected to be a rollicking coronation for the commander of Operation Desert Storm.
"Republicans haven't had a chance to make their case yet, and we've been getting bashed for weeks," said Kay Bailey Hutchinson, the Texas State Treasurer and a devoted Bush supporter. "It's our turn now."
Joe Duffel, a Republican leader in Contra Costa County, Calif., said simply, "Bush has got to come down here and announce some measures that are going to pep up the economy, because if the economy stays at the same level between now and November, he will not win."
 
Polls and the Party Spirit
 Delegates could take the edge off their anxiety at a full schedule of parties organized by the Houston Host Committee, from elegant soirees in the mansions on River Oaks Boulevard to rodeos out on the prairie beyond the suburbs. Fireworks lit the skies over Galveston Bay, greeters swarmed around arriving passengers at the airport, and cabdrivers chatted up their passengers about the virtues of Houston.
But the business at hand was deadly serious. The New York Times/CBS News Poll showed that Mr. Clinton, who received an enormous gain in the polls after his convention last month, remained well ahead of the President, 52 percent to 35 percent. While Mr. Clinton's overall lead dropped 7 percentage points, as expected as the Democratic convention receded, his support actually rose among some important groups: young people, middle-income ($30,000 to $50,000) voters, Midwesterners and Catholics.
If history is any guide, Mr. Bush will go a long way toward narrowing this race over the next four days; the burst of national attention around a nominating convention almost always produces a significant "convention bounce" in the polls.
Mr. Bush retains several strengths he can play to in the coming months, which will be highlighted in this week's convention program. For example, 58 percent said he could "deal wisely with a difficult international crisis," compared with 28 percent who expressed that confidence in Mr. Clinton. And Mr. Bush has a small edge over Mr. Clinton in being trusted to deal with problems that confront a President, a quality that his strategists argue is decisive in a Presidential election.
But the glow is clearly off Mr. Bush's conduct of the war in the Persian Gulf. When asked, "if you could change one thing George Bush did during his Presidency, what would it be?" the Gulf War was most frequently volunteered; it was cited by a fifth. And when voters were asked about the way Mr. Bush was now handling relations with Iraq, only 40 percent approved, while 48 percent disapproved.
 
Thumbs Down on Economy
 The poll underscores, however, what Mr. Bush's strategists are achingly aware of: The public is rendering a devastating verdict on the Bush economic record. Only 14 percent of American adults approve of the way Mr. Bush is handling the nation's economy, the lowest economic rating of his term, as low as any faced by President Jimmy Carter.
The survey also suggests that the political mood has shifted sharply since 1988, when the economy was still healthy and Mr. Bush was able to run on a promise of only modest shifts in the course set by President Ronald Reagan. For example, Mr. Reagan is now viewed unfavorably by more people than view him favorably. And the retrospective approval rating on his Presidency is now about the same as the retrospective on Mr. Carter's.
This suggests that turning the convention spotlight on Mr. Reagan on Monday night may not be entirely helpful to his party.
On the positive side, Barbara Bush remains an enormous asset to the Republicans: 74 percent have a positive opinion of her, and only 5 percent do not.
 
Comparing Parties
 There were, however, several other ominous notes in this poll for the Republicans: Fifty-seven percent of the voters now say they have a favorable opinion of the Democratic Party, compared with 47 percent who said they viewed the Republicans favorably. The Democrats also have an advantage on the Congressional level, in a year when an unusually high number of open seats are at stake: 45 percent said they would vote for the Democratic candidate for the House if the election were held today, while 35 percent said the Republicans.
Moreover, despite Republican attempts to capitalize on "family values" the two parties are tied in the public's mind on that issue. Thirty-six percent said Republicans would be better at "upholding traditional family values," while 37 percent said the Democrats would.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton has succeeded in getting a plurality of voters to consider him a moderate.
There was no surer sign of the altered political landscape than the voters' own handicapping of the race: Fifty-two percent now predict that Mr. Clinton will win in November, and 36 percent predict Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Helps Homeless Find an Exit

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
More than a decade after New York City started grappling with a surge in homelessness, a program by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to combine police enforcement with treatment has cleared out the authority's midtown bus terminal and started to wear away the building's image as a grim example of the link between bureaucratic failure and human pathos.
Only eight months after the program's start, social workers for Operation Alternative have handled 6,000 referrals for mental illness, drug and alcohol abuse and abject poverty. 
 They have also raised a tentative hope that the city's slow-moving bureaucracies may finally have started sketching out answers that move beyond the sweeps and crackdowns that typified early efforts, which were attacked as cruel and ineffective.
Advocates for the homeless give the Port Authority's approach grudging praise and complain only that the program should be better financed and integrated into a citywide plan. They argue, and public transportation officials increasingly agree, that long-term solutions will benefit both the homeless who live in public transit areas and the passengers who use them.
The benefits for the 185,000 people who pass through the terminal each day are clear. Once a nagging reminder of the city's social and economic ills, the terminal no longer represents a grim gantlet for bus passengers dodging beggars, drunks, thieves and destitute drug addicts. Hallways and corners that once were littered with the crouched and covered forms of up to 400 or 500 homeless people are now both empty and clean.
Officials with the Port Authority link that change to a sharp drop in crime. In the program's first seven months, reports of robberies in the terminal dropped by 39 percent compared with the same period last year. Reports of pickpockets were down by 41 percent and of assaults, by nearly one-fourth.
"Eight months ago when I came here," said Capt. William G. Cafaro, who supervises police operations at the Port Authority, "the big complaint was the homeless. Now, it is smoking."
The police report a similar though less dramatic drop in crime in the vicinity. In the Midtown South precinct that includes the Port Authority Bus Terminal, robberies declined by more than 15 percent in the first four months of this year compared with the same period last year. Grand larceny and assaults declined by 6.4 percent and 7.9 percent respectively.
When the police encounter someone who is homeless in the corridors, they tell the person to move along but also ask if he or she wants treatment or shelter. Many homeless people return to the streets, but some accept the offer and are escorted to an office on the ground floor.
 
Finally, Options
 There, social workers from the Manhattan Bowery Corporation and the Partnership for the Homeless, working under a contract with the Port Authority, direct homeless people to places to sleep, eat and recover from everything from heat exhaustion to multiple addictions seven days a week. "What this program has allowed us to do," said Janis M. Beitzer, the terminal's manager, "is to separate out different cases. The tendency is really to lump everyone together."
Still, seen against a broader background, the Port Authority's project is like a pea inside a bucket, a small glimpse of success in a deep well of failure. The sidewalk along Ninth Avenue is crowded with people living in boxes and eking out a bare existence. So are surrounding streets.
Summer is the slowest season for shelters. But most are full. A nearby Manhattan Bowery Corporation shelter and one run in the Bronx by the Partnership for the Homeless, which handle Port Authority referrals, are packed to capacity. Winter will surely make matters worse.
And with unemployment up and Federal financing for social projects already cut and facing further reductions, the problem continues to grow. Mary Brosnahan, the executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, says that her group, which sets up regular food lines at various sites around the city, is feeding twice as many people as it did just six months ago, even at the Port Authority. At one food line in Harlem, there are now 50 children under 13 who depend on the nightly meals. And because the demands on that group have expanded suddenly in recent months, the meals have been cut back.
 
A Call for Compassion
 Critics say that public programs that stress evicting the homeless from such havens as bus terminals and train stations are the cruelest of all. "You shouldn't get tough on the issue, you should get smart," said Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union and a longtime advocate for the homeless. "The city needs to develop a comprehensive plan to finally, once and for all, get beyond this terrible problem. We've been dealing with this for 12 years, and I don't see the light at the end of the tunnel."
No comprehensive program is in place. Yet the Port Authority's effort is one positive sign. "The Port Authority is one of the most progressive of the groups," said Ms. Brosnahan. "We just want to push them to be more progressive."
Operation Alternative's roughly $500,000 budget is barely one-thirtieth of the $15 million allocated to the Port Authority Bus Terminal police. And it constitutes less than 1 percent of the Port Authority Bus Terminal's annual $54 million budget. Mr. Siegel called the budget "insufficient," and said the city should commit at least $5 million toward a broad approach that would integrate housing with job training and treatment.
Advocates for the homeless said last week that the two groups hired by the Port Authority have been one factor in the program's success. They tended to criticize an older program, initiated in 1991 by the Metropolitan Transit Authority. Though that program, too, uses social workers to convince homeless people to get help, advocates said the M.T.A.'s follow-through is insufficient.
"Maybe they cleared up their problem," Mr. Siegel said of M.T.A. directors' claims that the number of homeless in the subways has dropped to about 700 to 1,000 from about 3,000 to 5,000 in the late 1980's. "But they dumped it onto the rest of the city."
 
Convincing the Homeless
 Bernard Cohen, director of the M.T.A.'s department of policy and planning, defended the M.T.A. program and stressed that it, too, contains a treatment component. During a tour of Grand Central Terminal with social workers last week, he said, he was told about a man who had lived there for four years. The social workers said they had just convinced the man to buy a ticket on Metro-North to go to a treatment center outside the city.
"I said, 'How do you know he got on the train?' " said Mr. Cohen. "So we walked over to the platform and, sure enough, he poked his head out and started chatting."
Wendy Feuer, the M.T.A.'s director for transit and facility design and one of the organizers of the program for the homeless, said she believed it was still evolving. "We are getting more sophisticated at handling these things," she said. But she pointed out that some people are harder to reach than others. "It's as though it's the last six miles of a marathon, when you really have to do hard work."
It took 10 years and a heart full of failure before Tony, 24, finally sought help and stayed with it. Last March 16, on the second day of a cold snap that covered Manhattan with a clear blue sky but left thermometers drifting between 17 degrees and a high that barely cleared the freezing mark, he wandered into the Port Authority Terminal to ask for help.
"I knew I had to stop or die," said Tony, who asked that only his first name be used to protect his family. He described a life of homelessness and drug abuse. "It got to the point where someone would want to kill me, someone including the police."
Shifting on a metal chair and recounting his years on the streets, Tony said his troubles started at 13 when a cousin invited him to help sell heroin and cocaine on the streets of Harlem. For three years, he took his pay in fancy clothes. Then, on his 16th birthday, he got a shoe box stuffed with $16,000. He also got a message: His cousin told him that from that day forward, Tony would be in business for himself.
Within a year, the cousin was dead and Tony's life started unraveling. In quick sequence he was shot, stabbed and attacked with a baseball bat. His drug use increased; his luck ran out.
Several times he quit taking drugs. Always he went back. By March, he knew he was near some personal end point, a moment when he had to change. He had heard that the Port Authority's program worked.
 
Help for Some, Not All
 Today, Tony still lives in a shelter run by the Manhattan Bowery Corporation. But he is off drugs, is working on his high-school equivalency diploma and has a paying job working every night with homeless people who, like him, wander in to seek the program's help.
Not everyone wants it. Last week, as a driving rain pelted rush-hour commuters, Mary Jane Manley and Lewis Terry sat on 41st Street, under the second-story link between the terminal's two buildings and shared a cigarette. Ms. Manley was drinking Thunderbird. Mr. Terry was sipping from a large bottle of beer inside a paper bag.
They passed the cigarette back and forth and said they had heard about the program. Mr. Terry said he did not go because he was a Vietnam veteran and would go to a Veterans Administration hospital if he needed help. Ms. Manley fished into a pocket for a letter of referral to the Port Authority's program.
"I want to go," she said. "I want to get myself back together again. Maybe this weekend. Maybe I'll go in there this weekend." Then she excused herself and her friend. They were busy drinking and talking. There were still a few drags in their cigarette. Ms. Manley tucked her referral letter away again. The center, she knew, would be open another day.

HEADLINE: LOOKING TO THE FUTURE: LOOKING AHEAD;
While in Houston to Help Bush, Many Have Eyes on 1996

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Squadrons of political aides will be tensely watching their candidate this week to make certain he gets the biggest possible boost from the Republican National Convention.
But many of them will have their eye not on George Bush but on one of the Republicans already angling for a run at the Presidency in 1996. And as crucial as the convention is to Mr. Bush, it is almost as important to the others -- Vice President Dan Quayle, Patrick J. Buchanan and Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, to name just a few. 
 At times, jockeying for the 1996 race has overshadowed Mr. Bush's own campaign, and it might have been a central attraction in Houston this week had the convention turned out to the coronation ceremony that Mr. Bush had wanted. But with the President's re-election prospects shaky, the White House quietly passed the word that lobbying for 1996 should be done discreetly.
"We want to see less of that this year than you did in 1984, simply because we're in a tough race," a senior campaign official said. "In 1984, when Reagan was way ahead and everyone thought he would win big, people could get a little more aggressive about wining and dining and buttonholing and campaigning. We're fighting for our lives, everyone knows it, and we want to keep our eyes on that. If people can get exposure through their role in supporting Bush, more power to them."
 
Creating a Vacuum
 These concerns have tamped down the 1996 electioneering somewhat, but not entirely. After all, the jockeying over the next race was driven to large extent by Mr. Bush's own political problems.
His record-low poll ratings and his failure to project a strong ideology created a vacuum into which the 1996 contenders eagerly rushed. Their fight is, in part, over who will lead the party's conservative wing, which does not consider Mr. Bush a member. Indeed, a few conservatives concluded months ago that their cause might better be served if Mr. Bush lost.
This sort of split has not been erased by the show of unity the Republicans are putting on here, and the candidates for 1996 are looking for ways to gain even a slight edge. Mr. Kemp has been reminding everyone who will listen that he told Mr. Bush to back a tax cut, so if the President does something like that in his acceptance speech, the Housing Secretary can claim credit for inspiring it. If Mr. Bush does not, Mr. Kemp has made his point.
That kind of talk is just the sort of exposure that the crop of 1996 contenders is after. Many of them have had little or no introduction to the country as a whole. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that Mr. Kemp's favorable rating, 21 percent, is two and a half times his unfavorable, 8 percent. But 71 percent said they were undecided or did not know enough about him.
 
Limelight for Others
 The Republicans have gone out of their way to make sure most of the 1996 candidates get a moment in the limelight, if only to avoid having them fight among themselves and distract attention from Mr. Bush.
Two notable exceptions are James A. Baker 3d, who has to remain in the background because he is still technically Secretary of State and has not officially taken over the campaign yet, and Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who begged off from the convention, citing his state's economic problems.
No matter. If Mr. Wilson remains mired in budget deficits and tax increases in California, no amount of speech-making at the convention is going to save him. Mr. Baker is going to get all the attention he wants -- and probably a lot more -- in the fall campaign.
No Republican has announced his candidacy for 1996, although Mr. Buchanan, who ran in the early Republican primaries this year, has left the door wide open. But the list of likely contenders is widely known in Washington and the face of the future of the Republican Party is white, male and conservative.
Mr. Quayle, Mr. Baker, Mr. Kemp, Mr. Buchanan, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney are most frequently mentioned for the A list. Some conservatives would put William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary and anti-drug chief, in that group as well.
 
Robertson Included
 Republican strategists say the Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who ran in 1988, should never be counted out. He will be a host of a "God and Country" rally on Monday and he is on the list of convention speakers.
The B list includes Governor Wilson of California, Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts and Pete du Pont, the former Delaware Governor who made a marginal showing in the 1988 Republican nominating race and is now using his political organization -- the Committee for Republican Leadership -- as a national platform.
There is the long-shot list -- Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin and Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina -- and the wish list. "The front-runner for the Republican nomination in 1996 won't be at the Republican convention," said Kenneth M. Duberstein, the former White House Chief of Staff. "He's too busy at the Pentagon. He's Colin Powell."
Mr. Quayle, who has the natural advantage of his office if he chooses to run in 1996, will have the highest profile here of any of the 1996 candidates: some two dozen public appearances and a major speech on Thursday night.
But Mr. Quayle also has the most at stake, given his seemingly unerasable unfavorable ratings (50 percent in the latest New York Times/CBS poll). The Vice President and his aides see the convention as one of two pivotal moments this year for him to "reintroduce" himself to the public. The other will be the Vice-Presidential debate with Senator Al Gore.
"The Vice President's staff was very envious of the way Gore was reintroduced at the Democratic convention," a senior official said. "It was very well handled and Quayle is hoping to do the same thing. His last time at a convention was pretty rotten."
 
Quayle's Reintroduction
 But Mr. Quayle comes to Houston after witnessing his worst nightmare come to life: While Gov. Bill Clinton presents Mr. Gore as virtually a co-President, Mr. Bush is putting forward his own dynamic duo -- with Mr. Baker, a rival who has disdained the Vice President, as the other half.
For his big moment, the Vice President is preparing what one aide called "a personal and defiant speech that will address substantive issues," in the context, as the aide put it: "This is what I stand for. People have tried to attack me for it. And I'm not backing down."
Mr. Gramm will get a lot of attention -- at the biggest social event of the week, the "Red, White and Boots" reception on Monday night, which is in his honor, and by giving the keynote speech on Tuesday night. He also has the opportunity for plenty of politicking as head of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee.
Mr. Buchanan, whose insurgent candidacy in the early primaries first threw the President's campaign off stride, will also speak. But the Bush team has tucked him into the program late on Monday evening, and made sure he would be overshadowed by a subsequent speaker, Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Cheney will be here, as "spouse of" Lynn Cheney, the head of the National Endowment for the Humanities. She will speak. He will not. But his supporters do not want his name forgotten. "Put him on the list," said one Cheney associate. What about Republicans who say Mr. Cheney is not interested in the Presidency, or would not run because of his history of heart problems? "Never mind that," the associate said. "Put him on the list."
 
'Bennett Is the Real Comer'
 Mr. Bennett has a featured spot on the program: putting Mr. Quayle's name into nomination. But he has infuriated the Bush team by making criticism of the President into a cottage industry, which delights conservatives.
"Bennett is the real comer," said Burton Yale Pines, chairman of the National Center for Policy Research, a conservative organization. "He's put more distance between him and this President than any of the other leading contenders. Bennett is going to be running for 1996 one day after this election is over."
Mr. Kemp has been credited with pushing Mr. Bush into a more active position on urban issues since the Los Angeles riots, giving himself new prominence along the way.
His outspoken views, often critical of the President at least by implication, have won him fans on the right. But they have made him enemies as well, including Mr. Baker, who, according to numerous published reports, blames Mr. Kemp for leaking accounts of a meeting at which the Secretary of State reportedly dismissed American Jews' concerns about the Administration's Israel policy with an obscenity.
"Jack Kemp is finally sitting in the circle with the big boys," Mr. Duberstein said. "The only problem is, he's in the middle, they're all armed, and they're firing inward."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Re-examining Bonds' Rally
New Questions Arise About Underpinnings

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The sharp fall in bond prices on Thursday raised doubts in the markets about the future of the rally that had carried the yield on the 30-year bond to its lowest level in five and a half years.
And those doubts, in turn, are making investors think about what has actually been driving this rally and what can upset it, even though bond prices rebounded on Friday. 
 Many analysts have thought that growing confidence about low and stable inflation could push bond prices to new highs and consequently push interest rates and yields to new lows. And, it appears, many traders and investors were not paying attention to the Presidential campaign and the ever-menacing Federal budget deficit. But last week's one-day slump may have changed that.
 
Era of Lower Rates
 While inflation is coming down -- as both the Consumer and Producer Price Indexes reaffirmed last week -- it is not yet clear to some analysts that the country is moving into a new era of lower inflation expectations, the kind that could push the yield on the long bond below 7 percent or lower. Such levels have not been seen in 20 years.
"I wonder if the markets have considered the longer-term outlook for inflation in a political sense?" said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "Will the political system allow a long-term attack on inflation? I have a feeling that in the business community, especially in manufacturing, that the cure is becoming worse than the disease; they feel that a little bit of inflation is not so bad, and it's better than no orders."
It may be that the more powerful force behind the rally is a seemingly unshakable consensus among investors and traders that the economy will continue to grow only sluggishly this year and into 1993. Because it is the usually strong growth at the beginning of a recovery that ignites inflationary concerns and prompts an increase in short-term interest rates, the absence of that possibility is making inflation less worrisome.
In addition, it may be that much of the rally reflects the search for higher yields because short-term interest rates have dropped so sharply in the last year. A year ago, the three-year note was auctioned at a yield of 6.92 percent. This week, that average yield fell to 4.69 percent.
In this case, the good news on inflation has not so much changed investors' minds as given them some comfort as they buy longer maturities once considered too risky.
In either case, however, it appears from the sharp move in the bond market on Thursday that it is easy to upset the confidence of the market.
 
Response to Baker
 The decline of more than a point in the price of the long bond on Thursday was, in part, because of investors' response to remarks by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d as he officially announced his resignation to become President Bush's chief of staff and guiding light of the re-election campaign.
The report by one news service carried the headline: "Baker says lower tax rates should be fundamental to campaign." That was quickly interpreted as a threat to the bond market because it could mean there would be tax cuts to stimulate the economy and even less concern about the growing Federal deficit.
While the market also fell because it had just come too far too fast, the reaction to Mr. Baker's comments shows that politics and the deficit can quickly re-enter the investor consciousness. This may mean that the economic program of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic nominee for President, will come under closer scrutiny.
The prospect of a Democratic victory in November and the plan to stimulate the economy that Mr. Clinton promises could quickly unsettle the market. Some unsuspected signals of strength in the economy could also worry investors. Or just a renewed focus on the Government's record budget deficit could cause a case of the jitters.
 
Taking Some Profits
 In light of all the possibilities, Glenn E. Murphy, the chief investment officer of Travelers Asset Management International, is being cautious, though his expectation of a 2 percent inflation rate is below the rate of 3 to 3.5 percent now.
Last August, Mr. Murphy began heavy buying of 30-year Treasury bonds. At that time, he began to believe that inflation in the United States would fall sharply and stay low for some time -- the best of news for long-term bond investors.
But he still thinks a real change in expectations has not set in yet. "I think people are grudgingly working their way down the inflation curve," he said, "but it's only grudgingly."
He is now taking some of his profits on the long bond because he thinks that in the short term the bond market has moved ahead of itself. "The market is discounting more good news than is in the market, so I would be cautious," he said.
Whether the rally is over, is hard to answer. "The market is overextended, but interest rates are still on a downward trend," Mr. Murphy said.
Many traders said the market was due for a correction because it had risen so fast. But a correction does not mean a rally is over. The strong rebound in the market on Friday, which brought the yield on the long bond back down to the five-and-a-half-year low of 7.31 percent it reached Wednesday, means investors have not deserted.
The economic data released Friday, including the four-tenths of a percent increase in industrial production last month, after a four-tenths of a percent decline in June, still paints a picture of slow growth and declining inflation.
 
Bad News for President
 But if the rally is over, even just temporarily, that will be bad for the economy and bad for President Bush. It has been the relatively high level of long-term interest rates that has made it much harder for the Federal Reserve, despite its sharp cutting of short-term interest rates, to restart the economy. It is a problem that the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, has repeatedly complained about.
"I think long bonds have to come down more to reflect less inflation expectations and if you want the American economy to really get going," said Henry Kaufman of Henry Kaufman & Company.
For that reason, no matter what Mr. Baker meant to say about economic policy and the Presidential campaign last week, he may be trying to reassure the investors in the bond market that they have nothing to worry about.

HEADLINE: No Action Is Expected On Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Most monetary specialists believe that the Federal Reserve, ever-mindful of its reputation for independence, will shun further cuts in interest rates when its policy-making Open Market Committee meets on Tuesday for the first time in seven weeks.
New action that could reduce the lending rate for overnight banks loans and eventually even the discount rate is considered highly unlikely during the Republican National Convention, despite a recovery that is among the weakest on record. 
 By a quirk of the calendar, the central bank appears to face the same obstacle posed at its meeting of June 30-July 1, which took place just after President Bush specifically urged another round of rate cuts.
 
Stand Against Inflation
 No matter how it weighs the economic evidence, which has been decidedly mixed of late, the Fed cannot afford to give the impression of bowing to pressure from the Bush Administration in the election campaign, analysts say. Creating such an impression would almost certainly be counterproductive, arousing fears about the Fed's commitment to fight inflation and thereby raising the long-term banking rates so crucial to the home-building and capital investment essential to recovery.
"They'll be concerned about reducing interest rates in the proximity of the convention," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities Company International and a strong advocate of more monetary stimulus.
Still, analysts said, the deliberations of this 19-member committee -- 12 of them voting at any given time -- could lead to a rate cut in the weeks ahead, most likely around Labor Day if August employment statistics show private payrolls grew by, say, less than 50,000. The jobs survey was taken last week, but the results will not be released until Sept. 4.
Other recent figures seem to point toward monetary easing, though not conclusively. Retail sales were reported up five-tenths of a percent in July, but a June gain of that amount was revised to show a loss. And an increase in industrial production was confined entirely to utilities and mining; manufacturing was flat.
"The economy's just muddling along -- there's no catalyst," said Alan C. Lerner, senior money market analyst at Bankers Trust.
At the same time, inflation appears virtually nonexistent. Prices at the consumer and producer levels edged up only one-tenth of a percent in July.
Yet various Fed officials are said to be worried that the score of interest rate cuts in the last two years might have put too much stimulus in the pipeline, and therefore they might resist adding further stimulus. Despite earlier easing, money-supply growth continues to lag.
On the Federal Reserve Board, whose seven members form a voting majority on the Open Market Committee, the cautious camp in general consists of those appointed by President Ronald Reagan. President Bush's three appointees are considered more receptive to further cuts.
The board is responsible for setting the Fed's discount rate, the rate the central bank charges financial institutions for loans. The other main tool of monetary policy, the market-based Federal funds rate for overnight loans among banks, is strongly influenced by the committee, which advises the Fed's trading desk about how scarce or how available it should seek to make bank reserves.
One thing that no doubt pleases the Fed is that long-term rates have declined significantly since the Open Market Committee's midyear meeting -- to about 7 3/8 percent from 7 3/4.
But this cuts both ways in terms of decision making, contended Jeremy A. Gluck, monetary specialist for Mitsubishi Bank in New York. He said policy makers could consider this either as a significant stimulus that might make further action unnecessary or as a vote of confidence in the Fed's anti-inflation commitment that could make further action possible.
Another factor in what might be decided this week, though probably not a controlling one, is the dollar's weakness. Recent central bank support for the dollar seems to argue against further rate cuts, which make the currency even less attractive, but analysts also note that a weak dollar aids exports, which have been slipping.
With no immediate rate changes likely to result from the Tuesday meeting, speculation will tend to center on the committee's directive to its securities trading desk in New York. At the May 19 meeting, the directive shifted to a neutral stance from one biased toward easing.
The directive adopted at the June 30-July 1 meeting -- the Fed cut rates sharply on July 2 in the wake of very poor employment data announced that morning -- will be exceptionally interesting when published on Friday, analysts said. It should provide insight on the extent to which the Fed foresaw the June jobs figures.
 
Shows Some Growth
 As for Tuesday's session, analysts say that the majority opinion at the Fed is probably impressed by the fact that the economy, however sputtering, has at least expanded a bit for five straight quarters. Thus, the majority view may be that further measures can be deferred.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Hachette Set To Give Elle A Makeover

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Gilles Bensimon, the 48-year-old creative director of Elle, is surprisingly blunt about the fashion magazine's recent troubles. "Elle got to be boring," he said quietly in a heavy French accent, leaning back in a black leather sofa at Hachette Magazines' headquarters in Manhattan. "Our articles are going to be more deep."
That is quite an indictment coming from a man who has worked at Elle since it burst on the American scene in 1985 by being spunkier than Vogue, putting high fashion with street fashion and emphasizing faces rather than outfit-clad figures. 
 But if earnings and crucial newsstand sales are any indication, Mr. Bensimon knows what he is talking about. Profits of the American version of Hachette S.A.'s popular French magazine have skidded since 1989.
David Pecker, president of Hachette Magazines, said profits dropped to $10.5 million last year from more than $16 million in 1989. Revenues fell 10 percent, to $72 million from $80 million.
 
Bad Timing
 That puts a squeeze on Hachette, since Elle is the company's flagship publication and a leading money maker, along with Woman's Day, Car and Driver and Road & Track.
And the timing of Elle's slide could not be worse. On Aug. 25, the Hearst Corporation is scheduled to introduce an updated Harper's Bazaar, younger and hipper and homing in on Elle's territory. And of course, Vogue, published by Conde Nast, still dominates the market.
In response, Elle is diversifying, including more-conservative fashion coverage. It has undertaken an aggressive effort to lift newsstand sales, and it is widening the range of articles it publishes.
Elle swept on the scene in November 1985 with a slew of young, healthy, devil-may-care models. They were often photographed close up, with more emphasis on their faces and accessories than on the traditional outfits that were the standard fare of Vogue and Harper's Bazaar. Colors were hot. There was the pink section, the yellow section, the red section.
Or as Mr. Bensimon said: "Before we had visual shock. Now slowly we want to be more realistic." For example, the September issue carried an article on abortion, the kind of article that might not have appeared in earlier issues.
By 1989, Elle's circulation had soared 37 percent, to 826,000, from 600,775 at the end of 1986, challenging Vogue's dominance in the field, with a circulation of 1.2 million. Meanwhile, Harper's Bazaar, facing problems of its own, represented little threat.
In 1989, 60 percent of Elle's circulation came from newsstand sales, which are significantly more profitable than costly subscription sales and a key indicator of reader enthusiasm. And the magazine ran 2,321 ad pages that year.
The architect of Elle's at-first immensely popular editorial approach was Regiz Paniez, a Frenchman who had been associated with Hachette for many years. Mr. Paniez was on vacation and could not be reached for comment.
But readers can be as fickle about fashion magazines as they are about fashion. No sooner had the magazine peaked than ad pages began to slide and newsstand sales dived.
 
Recession, and Predictability
 The decline stemmed partly from the recession. Advertising in Elle fell 28 percent between 1989 and 1991, to 1,764 pages. In the same period, Vogue's dropped 24 percent. But Vogue lost almost no newsstand sales, while Elle's have fallen a sharp 40 percent. Newsstand sales now account for 41 percent of Elle's total circulation.
There were bright spots. Leo Scullin, a magazine consultant, noted that subscription sales had offset the drop in newsstand sales, so that while Vogue's circulation is flat, Elle's is up 10 percent from 1989, at 916,000, although mailing costs make subscriptions less profitable.
But the key problem for Elle, critics said, was its failure to change as competitors began emulating its innovations. Critics say the magazine became too predictable in trying to shock its readers, and its novelty wore off.
In 1988, Vogue hired Anna Wintour as editor. She immediately signaled her determination to make Vogue irreverent by putting on the cover a model in a $10,000 jewel-encrusted T-shirt and blue jeans.
The war had begun. There is no franchise on jeans and jewels or bright pink. If Elle could shock and mix and match, so could Vogue.
Mirabella, too, joined the fray. Though it attracted an older reader, Mirabella hurt Elle at the checkout counters, Mr. Pecker of Hachette says.
Such inroads dealt a cruel blow to Hachette, which has started 19 editions of Elle worldwide.
 
'We Have to Change'
 It also shocked Hachette's profits here, where Elle's contribution is critical. Woman's Day made about $25 million a year in the mid-1980's, while Car and Driver and Road & Track, now the two most profitable publications, earned close to $20 million each, Mr. Pecker said. At its peak, Elle, where editorial costs are higher than at the car publications, was still hugely profitable.
"We have to change," said Mr. Bensimon, who acts confident that Elle can regain lost ground. He said that in Vogue, "there are too many women in Versace and Chanel, young, rich and sophisticated, very dressed, lots of gold and shiny fashion."
And he added: "I admire Anna Wintour. Vogue is like a charming pretty woman, a pretty charming woman with money. When I open Vogue, I smell money. It is women who spend money with clothes and are not afraid to wear two gold Rolexes, perhaps."
Elle's new direction is perhaps reflected in his strikingly conservative September issue, with the model Claudia Schiffer in black, gray and white on the cover. "Sometimes you want to be more gray and beige, not show off at all," Mr. Bensimon said. "We are looking for a balance."
Elle is trying. It is spending aggressively on its crucial September issue, with promotions at newsstands across the country. And Mr. Paniez and others are making more of an effort to get around New York and rub shoulders with designers and advertisers.
But competition is tough.
Harper's parent, Hearst, is investing heavily in Bazaar, hoping to recoup readers it has lost. Advertising pages in the October issue of Bazaar are up while Elle's are down.
 
'We Flex a Little Muscle'
 "We did not even know the top people at Elle," one leading advertiser said. "They are not just visible or accessible, the way Vogue and Bazaar are. The book is the major thing, but when a publisher calls, all that massaging pays off."
And he added: "Advertisers expect editorial support. You can only expect what is fair. If we don't feel we are getting our fair share, then we flex a little muscle."
Several executives close to Elle said morale was low, partly because turnover among editorial employees was heavy.
In response, Mr. Bensimon said, "We haven't found a strong team, and we need that."
His decision to hire as fashion editor Tierney Gifford, former fashion director at the retailer J. Crew, is a nod to the importance of the American market.
And some in the magazine industry speculate that the publisher, Gail Stone, who joined the magazine in December 1991 after 18 years at Modern Bride, will be replaced by Douglas Johnson, former publisher at Vanity Fair, who is now a Hachette consultant. Mr. Pecker denied the rumors.
"They are changing" one editor said. "But it is going very, very slowly."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
Buyers Seek Distress Sales as Newspaper Prices Stay Low

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
THOUGH few newspapers are being bought and sold these days, prospective buyers with cash in hand are sensing that some real bargains are available from sellers who need -- not merely want -- to sell.
Make no mistake. The vast majority of prospective sellers will not settle for the prices that newspapers currently bring and are hoping that an improved economy will restore newspaper prices to the glory days of the late 1980's. 
 Gerald D. Reilly, a newspaper broker, noted that three papers in New England -- he declined to identify them -- had recently been offered for sale and then withdrawn when the offers proved disappointing.
But in a few situations, sellers have little choice, such as when estate taxes after an owner's death make selling a virtual necessity. And it is these must-sell situations, especially in reasonably prosperous markets, that are attracting plenty of interest from newspaper entrepreneurs.
For instance, one head of a private newspaper chain who spoke on condition of anonymity said he was quietly raising an equity fund to take advantage of such distress sales.
"When somebody needs to sell, they're glad to see you," he said, noting that in the late 1980's, prospective buyers had to plead for a chance to bid.
In a sense, an ad in the Aug. 1 issue of Editor & Publisher, the industry's weekly trade magazine, reflected all aspects of today's complex market for newspapers and similar publications like the free "shoppers."
The ad, which covered about a third of a page, was placed by Dirks, Van Essen & Associates, a newspaper broker, to announce the sale July 1 of the Mason City (Iowa) Shopper, a weekly free publication with circulation of 30,000, to Lee Enterprises Inc., which owns the newspaper in Mason City. The shopper was sold by Darwin Oordt, who owns six other shoppers in the region through his company, Shopper Enterprises, based in Blue Earth, Minn.
The ad clearly reflected just how hard times are for newspaper brokers if such a modest transaction was heralded with such fanfare.
In 1989, Dirks, Van Essen published an identically sized ad promoting the sale of three small papers in South Carolina for nearly $75 million. By contrast, the Mason City Shopper deal, in which no price was given, was relatively small potatoes.
But Owen Van Essen, a partner in the firm, said Mr. Oordt was able to get a "full price" from Lee because Lee was removing a competitor. And he said Mr. Oordt was motivated to sell Mason City to enhance his ability to buy other properties, presumably at considerably less than full price.
Mr. Oordt did not respond to calls seeking comment.
 
Reward for Enterprise
Investigative journalism is being de-emphasized at some news organizations, where budget constraints and a shift to softer coverage have created new priorities.
But this year, two foundations are offering big cash prizes for investigative reporting, hoping to encourage more of it.
The Pope Foundation in New York City will award three annual $15,000 prizes for investigative work produced during the last three years.
And the Goldsmith-Greenfield Foundation of Sarasota, Fla., has endowed the Goldsmith Awards Program, which includes an annual prize of $25,000 for investigative reporting during the last year. The Goldsmith Awards are administered by the Joan Shorenstein Barone Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
The Pope Foundation was founded in 1949 by Generoso Pope, the late publisher of Il Progresso Italo-Americano, a New York Italian weekly aimed at immigrants like Mr. Pope, who made most of his fortune from tugboats and construction.
One of his sons, who bore his name and has since died, was the longtime owner of The National Enquirer but was not involved in the Pope Foundation. Rather, the foundation is administered by two other sons, who steered most of its grants to education.
But last year, Catherine Pope, the founder's granddaughter and the foundation's program director, persuaded the family that investigative journalism needed a boost.
Ms. Pope, who has a background in advertising, said that she had decided to push for the prize after listening to friends in network television complain that budgets were being cut in investigative-reporting units.
Similarly, Marina C. McCarthy, administrator of the Goldsmith Awards, said that their prize sprang from a conviction by the Goldsmith-Greenfield Foundation that the foundation's sponsor, the late Berda Goldsmith, would have wanted it that way.
"Her heroes were Woodward and Bernstein," Ms. McCarthy said.
 
Big Plans, and Jail
For nearly a decade, one of the most mysterious figures hovering at the edge of the nation's newspaper industry has been Peter Wirs.
But Mr. Wirs's long and fruitless effort to break into the newspaper business in a big way has finally landed him in jail, in York, Pa.
Mr. Wirs first appeared in the mid-1980's, when he declared that his Philadelphia-based company would acquire United Press International. But he had no money and no financing.
In U.P.I. and other ventures, he would use his obvious intelligence, persuasive tongue, and ability to write long, impressive business plans to form tenuous alliances with major companies like New York Telephone. He would then use their resources to pursue deals that never happened.
When the two daily papers in York said in 1989 that they wanted to form a joint operating arrangement, merging production and business operations, Mr. Wirs arrived in York declaring he would start two new papers.
Many in the town welcomed the idea, and Mr. Wirs contracted with a company to prepare a sophisticated direct-mail solicitation to sell advance subscriptions to his new papers.
Glenn S. Coffey, deputy prosecutor of York County, said Mr. Wirs then wrote a bad check for $25,000 and was found guilty at a trial. He had already pleaded guilty to writing a bad check for $4,911 to an airplane charter company and had been sentenced to 23 months' probation.
When Mr. Wirs did not appear at his sentencing hearing, he was declared a fugitive.
