HEADLINE: PACT ON GARBAGE IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration and the leadership of the City Council have agreed to go ahead with construction of a $550 million incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and at the same time accelerate New York City's recycling program.
The two elements are at the core of a compromise to deal with the city's growing problem of garbage disposal -- a subject that has caused a long and bitter debate. 
 With the city's last landfill nearing capacity, most neighborhood and environmental groups have opposed more incineration and demanded more recycling. The agreement would increase recycling, but in conjunction with building the incinerator, which city and state garbage experts say is necessary for New York City to handle all its trash.
 
Significant Revisions
 The compromise still faces a review by the full City Council next week and may yet undergo significant revisions. Only last month, a majority of the Council members opposed another plan that also included building the incinerator but contained a far slower timetable on increasing recycling.
Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said through a spokesman yesterday that the deal with the Mayor could resolve the long dispute. To get the incinerator built, the city has agreed to introduce citywide curbside recycling programs by the fall of 1993, one year earlier than planned. The city will also close two smaller incinerators it had planned to renovate, and it will export the toxic ash from the Navy Yard instead of dumping it on Staten Island.
It is too early to gauge the costs of the agreement. By eliminating instead of renovating incinerators Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and Maspeth, Queens, the city will save $200 million. But by accelerating the recycling program, which will mean building new plants throughout the city to separate and process plastics, glass, paper and newsprint, the city may spend as much as it saves or more.
 
Awaiting Council Action
 Many opponents of the new incinerator emphasized yesterday that the compromise plan did not yet have the blessing of the full Council.
In fact, the Council's most important voice on environmental matters, Stanley E. Michaels, who is chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee, did not participate in the negotiations. He has been on vacation in Australia. Only a month ago, he stood on the steps of City Hall and declared that without major revisions, the Sanitation Department's plan for the city's garbage would never pass.
But the lobbying since then has been as fierce as at any time in the decade since the project was first proposed. The city is required by state law to produce a waste management plan and the state Environmental Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, has been harsh in his warnings to council members -- both in public and private -- about what would happen if it ignores the city's looming garbage problems.
"I am not going to state a position on whether or not the incinerator should be built," Mr. Jorling said in an interview last month, in part because he cannot encourage or discourage a plant that he will have to approve. "But clearly the city of New York is going to need every avenue open to it if it wants to manage its waste properly."
 
Solid Waste Capital
 In 1989 Mr. Dinkins campaigned against immediate construction of the incinerator. In the past two years, however, he has become a quiet, yet firm, supporter of the plant.
No city generates more waste each day than New York. Currently, the city recycles less than 10 percent of its residential waste and burns slightly more than 10 percent of its 28,000 daily tons refuse. Almost all the remainder is taken to the world's largest landfill, Fresh Kills on Staten Island. But the landfill's life will end within 10 to 20 years, and Congress now permits states to prevent the export of garbage. The only options left to the city are to burn or recycle its trash.
Here and elsewhere across the country, recycling has been seen as ecologically friendly, and incinerators have rapidly become an avenue that is almost impossible to pursue. They are hated by many local residents who detest the way they look and fear the pollutants they spew into the atmosphere. Although the Navy Yard would be constructed as one of the nation's most advanced such plants, which many experts say pose few if any health threats, not many area residents have been eager to see it built.
Rabbi David Niederman, head of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, the neighborhood where the Navy Yard is located, vowed last night to continue the group's six-year opposition to the incinerator.
 
Doubts About Incinerator
 "No matter what compromise the City Council and the Mayor will agree on, we will make sure that a health hazard like this incinerator will not be built," he said. "This is not a done deal at all. It's a done plan, but not a done deal."
Many environmentalists yesterday continued to question the value of building a new incinerator.
"We have always said that recycling has to work first before we would be able to examine the possibility of any new incinerator," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council, and a leader of the effort to increase the paltry rate of recycling in the city.
Mr. Goldstein and other opponents of the Navy Yard incinerator have long contended that as long as the city can spend hundreds of millions of dollars to burn its garbage it would not be making recycling its first priority. "We don't have any of the details about how much recycling they are talking about or how it will be introduced. What we do know is that this would get the nose under the tent for a giant network of garbage burning incinerators in New York."
 
Political Will
 But city officials disagree. They concede that recycling in the city has failed so far largely because there has never been the money or political will to make it work. But they say that once curbside recycling spreads throughout the city it will be easier to direct education and information programs that work.
'We have been trying so hard to develop a plan that responds to the concerns we heard at the hearings," said Andrew Lynn, the Sanitation Department's assistant commissioner for the new Solid Waste Management Plan. At hearings throughout the city this spring, two facts became clear: New Yorkers want more recycling, and they want to burn less garbage.
"We are going on line as quickly as we can with as much as we can," he said. "And we have the highest hopes for the recycling program."

HEADLINE: New York Reviving Quota Regulations For Minority Firms

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Armed with a new study that shows minority-owned businesses still get a relatively small share of state contracts, New York State is resurrecting a program that requires contractors to reserve a certain proportion of state work for companies headed by women and members of minority groups, state officials said.
In effect, the state is returning to a program it suspended in 1989 after the United States Supreme Court ruled that a similar program in Virginia violated the constitutional rights of white contractors to equal protection under the law. The court left open the possibility that local governments could restore the programs if they compiled evidence of discrimination.
 
Voluntary Compliance
 New York State officials say the new study demonstrates a pattern of discrimination based on statistics. It also includes the testimony of minority contractors who say they are excluded from the process. 
 The Supreme Court ruling, in City of Richmond v. Croson, voided a local law that mandated 30 percent of the value of all city construction contracts go to companies owned by women and members of minority groups. It has forced a string of local governments to dismantle such programs.
Since the ruling, New York State has asked contractors to voluntarily abide by its goals, which vary from agency to agency. But a result, according to the study, has been that the amount of contracts going to women and minority-group members dropped sharply.
Under New York's resurrected program, all contracts will still go to the lowest responsible bidder without regard to race or sex. But the prime contractors will be required to insure that a slice of the contract goes to minority- and female-owned companies. If the contractor fails to comply, the state can cancel the contract.
For instance, the State Parks Department asks contractors to try to give 12 percent of its subcontracting to minority-owned companies and 5 percent to female-owned companies, but it cannot punish them for not doing so. Those goals will become mandatory again once the regulations are put in place, state Economic Development officials said.
Many details of the system are yet to be worked out. State officials denied that the program amounted to a quota system but they said that when the new regulations are published in three weeks, each state agency will begin requiring contractors to channel a percentage of the work to minority- and female-owned companies. Those percentages will be decided ultimately by the state Economic Development Corporation based on how many minority- and female-owned companies are available in any given field. Such companies are defined as ones in which women or members of minority groups have a controlling interest and exercise independent control over all business decisions.
The rules will apply to about $4.8 billion worth of contracts that the state solicits competitive bids for every year, from bridge repairs, to highway construction, to printing contracts, to hospital supplies.
New York is one of about 65 cities, counties and states that have finished or are conducting exhaustive studies to justify restoring their programs. Last February, New York City released a similar study when Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a broad policy initiative to insure that a fifth of city contracts go to minority-owned companies.
Minority-owned business groups praised the state's decision yesterday, saying the studies spawned by the Croson decision had revealed widespread inequities. "It's the only way minorities will be given a fair opportunity to participate," said Anthony W. Robinson, president of the Minority Business Enterprise Legal Defense and Education Fund in Washington.
Harriet R. Michel, president of the National Minority Suppliers Development Council, said it was sad the state had to do an expensive study just to ratify what officials believed was necessary three years ago.
"Now they are going back to square one to do what they did voluntarily in the first place," Ms. Michel said. "It's nuts."
Contractors said they doubted the study would withstand the legal challenges that would surely come from white contractors. Michael Kennedy, special counsel for the Association of General Contractors of America, said the Supreme Court ruling set up an "extremely high standard" similar to the standard applied since the 1940's to strike down programs that discriminate against members of minority groups.
"Whether any of these studies will stand up to legal scrutiny, no one knows," Mr. Kennedy said. "It's my view that the Supreme Court did not intend the Croson case to provide grounds on how a jurisdiction could justify one of these programs."
The Supreme Court ruling placed a heavy burden on the local government to prove minority-owned businesses had been discriminated against, saying such programs could only be justified if they served the "compelling state interest" of redressing "identified discrimination."
New York State officials believe they have amassed enough evidence of discrimination to stave off legal challenges under the Croson decision.
The study, which will be released Wednesday, shows that while businesses owned by members of minority groups and women make up nearly 25 percent of the bidders on state contracts, they get 7.9 percent of the $4.8 billion the state spends each year. The premise of the study is that the amount of money that goes to minority businesses in a particular field should be comparable to the proportion of the minority businesses in that field.
Some contractors questioned yesterday whether the statistics were valid. It was unclear, they said, whether the study took into account the size of companies bidding, their qualifications and the number of minority-owned companies bidding on the same contracts.
The study analyzed all state contracts for construction, goods and services in fiscal years 1990 and 1991, and includes the following findings:
*Female-owned businesses received only 19 percent of the contract dollars that state officials said they should receive given their numbers. Black businesses received 32 cents on the dollar and Hispanic businesses garnered about 36 cents.
*Only 1.2 percent of state contracts were awarded directly to minority-owned businesses and 1 percent went to companies headed by women. The majority of the contracts to such companies were subcontracts.
*In hearings held throughout the state, about 250 witnesses testified to problems ranging from discrimination in getting credit to racial discrimination by Government officials. "The testimony was compelling and even chilling in revealing the depth and malice of that discrimination," the report said.
In the fall of 1989 and spring of 1990, when the regulations were mandatory, 7.7 percent of state contract dollars went to minority business enterprises and 4.4 to women. In the following budget year, when the goals became voluntary, those levels dropped to 5.5 percent for members of minority groups, and 2.4 percent for women.

HEADLINE: Cambodia Pact Founders on Attacks and Distrust

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Nearly a year after the United Nations brokered a peace accord intended to end Cambodia's decades of bloodshed and terror, the settlement is under threat of collapse because of the refusal of the Khmer Rouge to disarm their tens of thousands of rebel soldiers.
Some diplomats and Cambodians remain hopeful that the Maoist-inspired Khmer Rouge will begin at least a partial disarmament in time for elections next spring, but no one can be certain of the intentions of the secretive group. 
 In Phnom Penh, which has become a chaotic boom town with the arrival of more than 18,000 United Nations peacekeeping troops and civilian workers, there is a debate over what should be done if the Khmer Rouge remain obstinate and do not disarm. The alternatives include using armed United Nations troops to force the Khmer Rouge to cooperate.
The Khmer Rouge controlled the government in the 1970's and directed a "peasant revolution," a radical restructuring of Cambodian society. Estimates of the number of Cambodians who died range from hundreds of thousands to more than one million.
One of four warring factions that signed the peace accord, the Khmer Rouge have issued a set of demands intended to strengthen their hand in the elections and to dismantle the current Vietnamese-installed Government.
During a visit to Phnom Penh this month, the United States representative to the United Nations, Edward J. Perkins, said in an interview that "I'm more hopeful than not hopeful" about the prospects for peace. "Of course," he added, "I don't know what is on the mind of the Khmer Rouge."
Diplomats say any grounds for hope lies in the expectation that the Khmer Rouge will determine, on the basis of a cold calcuation of the facts and nothing else, that they must return to the peace process and begin to demobilize. According to this reasoning, Khmer Rouge leaders would otherwise risk being abandoned by their remaining allies, most importantly the Chinese Government and the Thai military, and giving up whatever international legitimacy they have secured through the peace settlement.
Even if the current stalemate is resolved with the Khmer Rouge, however, diplomats and many Cambodians agree that the peace process is almost certain to bog down again and again as the Khmer Rouge and other factions demand new concessions.
It is impossible to find anyone here who believes that the guerrillas of the Khmer Rouge will ever simply lay down their arms and disappear into the jungle, even if their leaders do agree to rejoin the peace process this year.
 
A Sense of Relief
 Despite so many dire predictions about Cambodia's future, the presence of the large United Nations force has produced in many Cambodians a sense of relief, even of opportunity, that they had never experienced.
There have been repeated cease-fire violations in recent months by the Khmer Rouge, including shooting attacks on United Nations helicopters flying over their territory, but military observers describe the Cambodian countryside as generally peaceful.
Taking advantage of what many acknowledge could be only an intermission in the civil war, foreign investors and wealthy Cambodians have created the fastest-growing if most chaotic and speculative economy in Southeast Asia.
Even as most of its residents continue to live in utter poverty, Phnom Penh, like provincial capitals elsewhere in Cambodia, is now one big construction site, with hotels, restaurants and office buildings under construction or renovation.
For a visitor who knows of Phnom Penh only as the city from which the Khmer Rouge directed their campaign to return Cambodia to "Year Zero," the effect of a downtown stroll can be jarring.
Newsstands have begun selling fresh copies of glossy Western magazines, and there are two new English-language newspapers in the capital, The Phnom Penh Post and The Cambodia Times. Stores are stocked with yogurt and cheese from Thailand and crisp red apples from Washington State.
Singaporean investors can be found thrashing out business deals over espresso in a pricey new French bistro that picked up and moved here, staff and all, from Bangkok, Thailand.
The owners of Cambodia's new international airline have enough confidence in the future that they have leased an American jet and hired an experienced Icelandic crew. The phones are working properly for the first time in years.
The question bedeviling diplomats, foreign business people and many Cambodians is: Can the United Nations pull out of Cambodia on schedule next year, even if the Khmer Rouge agree to return to the peace process?
The United Nations, it is feared, will be marooned here. Without the presence of the peacekeeping force, many here argue, the hard-won peace will collapse as Cambodians, many of whom have known only battle or genocidal terror in their lifetimes, find themselves unable to manage a government.
Sawn Van Thay, a 39-year-old tailor whose shop is just off Achar Mean Boulevard, the capital's congested central thoroughfare, offers a hope common among Cambodians: He wants the United Nations to remain here for years.
"It must be here for 15, maybe 20 years, so we can raise and educate a generation of children who will capable of running a government," he said, his seamstress turning from her work to nod, frantically, in agreement.
 
Fear of War's Return
 "The Khmer Rouge killed all the people who had education," he said. "If the United Nations soldiers leave, we will go back to squabbling and then to war. The United Nations must stay many, many years."
That, United Nations officials insist, will not happen, especially with the Security Council now contemplating additional responsibilities in what used to be Yugoslavia.
"We are not here to solve all the problems of Cambodia," said Yasushi Akashi, the Japanese-born diplomat who is in charge of the United Nations operation in Cambodia, vowing that peacekeeping troops will not have a "perpetual presence" here.
He hedged, however, when asked whether the peacekeeping forces would be able to leave on schedule after elections next year.
"I will raise questions on the part of my colleagues in New York whatever answer I give you, so please excuse me," he said. "I hope so," is the best response that he can give for now.
The Khmer Rouge are taking part in the peace settlement hammered out by the United Nations. The nominal leader of the group is Khieu Samphan, a French-educated Cambodian economist, who is believed by diplomats to answer to Pol Pot, the shadowy founder of the Khmer Rouge.
Mr. Pol Pot, whose real name is Saloth Sar, has been in hiding for most of his adult life. He is said to move between Thailand and western Cambodia.
Unlike the army of the Vietnamese-installed Government and the other two rebel groups involved in the peace accord, the Khmer Rouge have so far refused to put down their arms and place their soldiers in United Nations-supervised camps, a process that was supposed to begin in June.
Khmer Rouge officials have said their troops will not disarm until more authority is taken away from the central Government and given to a neutral interim body and until there is proof that all Vietnamese troops have left Cambodia. The Vietnamese ousted the Khmer Rouge in an invasion that began in December 1978
 
Council Led by Sihanouk
 The neutral body, the Supreme National Council, is made up of representatives of all four factions in the peace settlement and is led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the nation's former monarch and its newly restored head of state.
One of Prince Sihanouk's sons, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, leads one of the other two rebel factions. The smallest faction, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, is directed by former Prime Minister Son Sann.
The United Nations says that it has already done what it can to satisfy the demands of the Khmer Rouge.
Diplomats observing the peace process say they are heartened that China and Thailand, longtime patrons of the Khmer Rouge, have publicly demanded that the Khmer Rouge disarm. In an effort to exert pressure on the Khmer Rouge to cooperate with United Nations peacekeepers in Cambodia, a high-ranking Chinese official reportedly held a rare meeting in Bangkok last week with Mr. Pol Pot.
There is also excitement in diplomatic circles over reports of a consistent flow of deserters from the Khmer Rouge in recent weeks.
Still the Khmer Rouge appear to have remarkable staying power, thanks to vast stocks of weapons and to its control over gem-mining and logging areas near Cambodia's Western border. The gems and lumber produce tens of millions of dollars a year for the Khmer Rouge, most of it funneled through Thai businessmen who seem to care little about their Government's public efforts to isolate the rebels.
The peacekeeping operation in Cambodia is the largest in the history of the United Nations, with a budget approaching $2 billion and a staff drawn from more than 100 nations. There are about 15,100 soldiers, 2,100 police officers and 1,000 civilians.
 
A Comforting Sight
 Across the Cambodian countryside, the sight of United Nations soldiers and the blue United Nations flag has become familiar, and comforting, to many Cambodians.
"When they see us now, they always smile and welcome us," said Cpl. Salim Zakaria, a 25-year-old Malaysian policeman who now walks the beat in Phnom Penh.
Yet the arrival of the United Nations has plainly not been all good news to all Cambodians. The presence of so many free-spending foreigners -- many civilian United Nations workers have a living allowance well in excess of $100 a day -- has aggravated Cambodia's already serious inflation problem.
Although there is no sign of the starvation that once afflicted Cambodia, international relief organizations say malnutrition is a constant concern.
The price of rice, the staple of the diet, has more than doubled over the last year, to 55 cents a pound, equivalent to a day's wages for much of the population, which is about seven million.
 
Potato Shortages in capital
 There have been reports of potato shortages in Phnom Penh as foreigners buy up the crop for their own meals. Families of beggars wait patiently outside many of Phnom Penh's sparkling new restaurants and hotels.
"The foreigners complain about the prices of the food, but they always pay them," said Un Chanphalla, who runs a vegetable stand in Cambodia's central market. "The poor are not so lucky. They must go without."
While foreign businessmen are swarming into Phnom Penh, most of their investments are made in services industries -- banking, restaurants, hotels and the like -- and seem designed more to make a quick return on capital than to contribute to the economic development of Cambodia.
To a degree that startles many Cambodians, the United Nations is now administering much of the central Government, filling key posts at the Defense and Foreign Ministries, and in the national police.
Prime Minister Hun Sen and his deputies, installed by Vietnam after its 1978 invasion, remain in place, although increasingly they must work alongside United Nations officials, a requirement of the peace settlement.
 
A Daunting Assignment
 "The United Nations has never done anything like this before," said Gerard Porcell, an administrative-law judge from France who was recruited by the United Nations for a daunting assignment -- administering the Cambodian Government in advance of the election. "We cannot look over everyone's shoulder, but we are attempting to have control."
Although diplomats had feared that the Hun Sen Government would refuse to give up authority in sensitive ministries, Mr. Porcell has few public complaints of lack of cooperation by the Government, although in some ministries there was little left for the United Nations to run.
Outraged by corruption and by inadequate pay, experienced Government workers by the hundreds have fled for private business in recent months, leaving the Government to crumble from within.
"In some ministries, we have found almost nothing -- empty rooms," Mr. Porcell said, shaking his head. "That was true especially in the Ministry of Defense. There we found many empty rooms, many spiders and cobwebs."

HEADLINE: Dow Dips 4.05, to 3,324.89, in Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in light summer trading as investors took a cautious view ahead of the Republican convention.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.05 points, to 3,324.89. But advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by a ratio of 9 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Volume on the Big Board was a low 152.8 million shares, down from 166.8 million in the Friday session.
Stocks were influenced somewhat by pessimism in the bond market over the potential for a bigger Federal deficit. Bond prices tumbled yesterday on fears that President Bush would have to act -- possibly during the convention in Houston -- to bolster the economy through a tax cut or lower interest rates, which would increase the deficit.
"It's hard to see him doing something dramatic that wouldn't affect the deficit, at least on a short-term basis," said Jeffrey Tabak, a principal in the firm of Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company.
Another bearish sign for stocks, Mr. Tabak said, was a high ratio of purchases of "call" options to buy securities at specific prices to "put" options to sell them, indicating that traders expect a market decline.
Some analysts expected stocks to get a lift from the start of the Republican convention. Investors generally favor Republican administrations, and disdain change. But the market was cautious because of Mr. Bush's continued weak standing in polls.
"The markets feel better when the guy in charge is strongly supported," said Richard Hoey, economist at the Dreyfus Corporation.
Airline stocks helped support the Dow average, influenced by a favorable article in Barron's magazine predicting the sector was ready for a rally. UAL gained 2, to 109 1/4; USAir rose 1/2, to 13 1/4, and Delta Air Lines gained 3/8, to 51 7/8.
Global Marine led the Big Board's most-active list, rising 1/8, to 2 1/4.
Among other actively traded issues on the New York Stock Exchange, Lowe's fell 5/8, to 18. The stock tumbled 4 3/8 on Friday after the retail chain reported earnings below analysts' expectations.
Citicorp, which said late Friday that it had to restate second-quarter earnings downward, fell 3/8, to 18 1/2.
On the Nasdaq market, Systemix tumbled 9 1/4, to 23 3/4, or 28 percent, after a Merrill Lynch analyst lowered his rating for the biotechnology company.
Also on the Nasdaq, American Biodyne rose 3 3/4, to 19 3/4, after announcing it will be acquired by Medco Containment Services in a $121 million stock deal. Medco fell 2, to 28 1/2.
The Big Board's composite index rose 0.54, to 231.60. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.12, to 386.94. The Nasdaq index fell 0.71, to 572.47.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Defense Department plans to cut money for Sematech, a Government-computer industry consortium formed to regain American competitiveness in making computer chips, which is achieving most of its goals, the G.A.O. said. [D1.]
 
Companies
Pfizer Inc. plans to sell a majority interest in its specialty minerals unit, which provided 5 percent of Pfizer's $6.95 billion in 1991 revenues, in a public stock offering. [D5.]
Wang Laboratories class B shares lost more than half of their value, falling 87.5 cents, to 75 cents, in heavy trading, as rumors swirled that Wang might file for bankruptcy soon. [D4.]
Kmart earnings rose only 3.1 percent, and Tiffany's tumbled 45.8 percent, but Toys 'R' Us had a 39.7 percent rise. [D4.]
I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck plan a joint venture to manage computer networks both for the giant retailer and customers. [D4.]
Phar-Mor filed for bankruptcy protection and sued its auditor, Coopers & Lybrand. The discount drug chain has accused two former executives of massive fraud. [D5.]
Chrysler appeared close to wrapping up a $6.8 billion loan agreement, which is crucial to its revitalization. Only one of 152 banks, an unidentified one, was still declining to sign. [D5.]
Home Depot plans to open a Recycling Depot in a joint venture with the British waste management concern Attwoods P.L.C. [D4.]
Humana Inc. laid off 400 administrative employees because of low volume at its hospitals and health plans. [D4.]
Ambase said Kohlberg & Company had decided against leading a $200 million rescue of Ambase's troubled Carteret Savings Bank, based in Morristown, N.J. [D4.]
 
International
Some Japanese companies are asking that rice be imported. The previously unthinkable position is being taken because Japan, which has resisted international calls to open its market to rice imports has a shortage that is driving up costs for makers of rice crackers, miso, sake and other foods, pitting them against Japanese rice farmers. [D1.]
The Export-Import Bank of the United States plans to take over the operations of a private contractor. The FCIA Management Company issues Federal insurance policies that protect exporters against losses if a foreign customer refuses to pay for goods. [D2.]
 
 Markets
Stock prices were mixed in light trading as market participants took a cautious view ahead of the Republican convention. The Dow Jones average fell 4.05 points to 3,324.89, but advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by a ratio of 9 to 7. [D6.]
The bond market fell as investors waited to see what kind of economic program the Republicans would outline. The Tennessee Valley Authority issued $700 million in new 30-year bonds. [D13.]
Copper futures settled sharply higher on technical factors and concern about Poland's deteriorating labor situation. [D14.] The dollar fell slightly. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
The Islanders' new managers are hailing "the new ice age" in a marketing campaign that treats the troubled hockey team like a floundering consumer product. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
The pharmaceutical industry is girding for attacks on the drug labeling practices of many multinational companies in Latin America, Africa and Asia. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [D2.]
Interest rate futures have made a huge difference in the way financial markets function and perhaps in the way that the Government manages the Federal debt. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: PARTY IN THE SPOTLIGHT: ON STAGE;
A Few Words, Texas-Style, Before 'the Rubber Hits the Road'

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
This Republican National Convention being deep in the heart of Texas, speakers on the first night of the party's nominating session were trying to outdo each other with clever, folksy metaphors and sayings.
Just about everyone tried their hand at it, even the delegates. One of the delegates loyal to Patrick J. Buchanan, Bill Dearing, a 28-year-old lawyer from Tennessee, said Mr. Buchanan's rivals for the mantle of conservative leadership had "sold out like a bunch of kennel-fed dogs." 
 But the clear master of the evening was Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, who has turned pungent soundbites into a cottage industry.
"This week," he said, "is where the rubber hits the road for our party."
Barely pausing to draw a breath, Mr. Simpson proclaimed that the Republicans would "blow away all this warm hazy stuff of summer with the cool crisp winds of fall" and the Democrats will "disappear like squash vines in the winter time."
And when the Republicans talk about Gov. Bill Clinton's draft record, Mr. Simpson said, the Democrats will "holler like a gut-shot panther."
 
Quick to Compare Military Records
 Indeed, Mr. Clinton's draft record seemed to be a favorite subject of the evening. Mr. Bush has said he wants his campaign to avoid the "sleaze" business, but tonight's speeches suggested that he draws the line at his opponent's family life. Other subjects, like the draft, are fair game.
The aim, apparently, was to remind the delegates that Mr. Clinton had joined an R.O.T.C. program and gone to study in England to remove himself from the draft, while Mr. Bush flew a Navy torpedo-bomber in World War II.
"When Mr. Clinton's turn came in Vietnam, he sat up in a dormitory in Oxford, England, and figured out how to dodge the draft," Mr. Buchanan said.
Mr. Simpson was even more direct. "We'll be talking about a man who quit school to go to fight for his country and a man who went to school to avoid fighting for it," he hollered.
It seemed that about the only politician here who was not talking about Mr. Clinton's draft record was Vice President Dan Quayle, who has had his own problems with the issue.
 
A Republican Version Of Ann Richards
 Every convention, it seems, needs a colorful woman from Texas to run it. In New York, at the Democratic National Convention, it was Ann W. Richards, the Governor of Texas, who was voted temporary chairwoman of the gathering and said some pithy and not very flattering things about George Bush and Dan Quayle.
In Houston, Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Texas Treasurer, is also the temporary chairman. Her mission, it seemed, was the same as Ms. Richards's, only in reverse.
Suggesting that Mr. Clinton had unrealistic views of the economy and just about everything else, she proclaimed: "You know something? I think he really did inhale."
At times, Ms. Hutchison seemed to be almost consciously imitating Ms. Richards, who tormented Mr. Bush in 1988 by quipping that he was born "with a silver foot in his mouth." She used the same oratorical cadence, held her head high and stiff, just like the silver-haired Ms. Richards, and tried to turn her Democratic colleague's own words on her.
"Poor Ann, she can't help it -- she was born with silver roots in her hair," said Ms. Hutchison, who has tinted blond hair.
 
Buchanan Supporters Keep an Eye on 1996
 Mr. Buchanan declared in his speech tonight that the "the primaries are over" and that he was behind Mr. Bush "all the way to a great comeback victory in November."
His loyalists on the convention floor, who call themselves "The Buchanan Brigade," made it clear that Nov. 3, Election Day, is where the unity ends.
Tonight they proclaimed Mr. Buchanan the early leader in the fight for the next Republican Presidential nomination that turns in large part on the party's right wing.
Vice President Dan Quayle, they insisted, is no competition. Mr. Buchanan is "more of a leader than Dan Quayle," said Lester Firstenberger, 29, a lawyer from Nashville.
His fellow delegate, Bill Dearing, said two other conservatives, William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary, and Jack F. Kemp Jr., the Housing Secretary, had "sold out."

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Excerpts Of Address By Reagan To G.O.P.

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by former President Ronald Reagan to the Republican National Convention last night as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.
To hear them talk, you'd never know that the nightmare of nuclear annihilation has been lifted from our sleep. You'd never know that our standard of living remains the highest in the world. You'd never know that our air is cleaner than it was 20 years ago. You'd never know that we remain the one nation the rest of the world looks to for leadership. 
 It wasn't always this way. We mustn't forget -- even if they would like to -- the very different America that existed just 12 years ago; an America with 21 percent interest rates and back-to-back years of double-digit inflation; an America where mortgage payments doubled, paychecks plunged, and motorists sat in gas lines; an America whose leaders told us it was our own fault; that ours was a future of scarcity and sacrifice; and that what we really needed was another good dose of government control and higher taxes.
It wasn't so long ago that the world was a far more dangerous place as well. It was a world where aggressive Soviet communism was on the rise and American strength was in decline. It was a world where our children came of age under the threat of nuclear holocaust. It was a world where our leaders told us that standing up to aggressors was dangerous, that American might and determination were somehow obstacles to peace.
But we stood tall and proclaimed that communism was destined for the ash heap of history. We never heard so much ridicule from our liberal friends. The only thing that got them more upset was two simple words: "Evil Empire."
But we knew then what the liberal Democrat leaders just couldn't figure out: the sky would not fall if America restored her strength and resolve. The sky would not fall if an American President spoke the truth. The only thing that would fall was the Berlin Wall.
WINNING THE COLD WAR -- I heard those speakers at that other convention saying "we won the cold war" -- and I couldn't help wondering, just who exactly do they mean by "we"? And to top it off, to top it off, they even tried to portray themselves as sharing the same fundamental values of our party.
But they truly don't understand is principles so eloquently stated by Abraham Lincoln: "You cannot strengthen the weak by weakening the strong. You cannot help the wage-earner by pulling down the wage-payer. You cannot help the poor by destroying the rich. You cannot help men permanently by doing for them what they could and should do for themselves."
If we, if we ever, if we ever hear the Democrats quoting that passage by Lincoln and acting like they mean it, then, my friends, we will know that the opposition has really changed.
Until then, when we see all that rhetorical smoke billowing out from the Democrats, well, ladies and gentlemen, I'd follow the example of their nominee: don't inhale.
All right, all right. Just listen to me. This fellow they have nominated claims he's the new Thomas Jefferson. Well, let me tell you something -- I knew Thomas Jefferson. He was a friend of mine, and Governor, you're no Thomas Jefferson.

 	 	 		. ..	 	BEST DAYS AHEAD -- America remains what Emerson called her 150 years ago, "the country of tomorrow." What a wonderful description and how true. And yet tomorrow might never have happened had we lacked the courage in the 1980's to chart a course of strength and honor.
All the more reason no one should underestimate the importance of this campaign and what the outcome will mean. The stakes are high. The Presidency is serious business. We cannot afford to take a chance.
We need a man of serious purpose, unmatched experience, knowledge and ability. A man who understands government, who understands our country and who understands the world. A man who has been at a table with Gorbachev and Yeltsin. A man whose performance as commander-in-chief of the bravest and most effective fighting force in history left the world in awe and the people of Kuwait free of foreign tyranny. Yes, yes, yes. Four more years. A man who has devoted more than half of his life to serving his country. A man of decency, integrity and honor.
And tonight I come to tell you that I -- warmly, genuinely, wholeheartedly support the re-election of George Bush as president of the United States.
All right. O.K. All right. We know President Bush. By his own admission, he is a quiet man, not a showman. He is a trustworthy and levelheaded leader who is respected around the world. His is a steady hand on the tiller through the choppy waters of the 90's, which is exactly what we need.
We need George Bush!

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Biosys's Pest Killers Go Underground

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Like the products it nurtures, wormlike nematodes that survive by invading insects that live in the soil, Biosys Inc. plans to flourish in a niche.
Biosys is content to let other biotechnology companies pursue the more than $4 billion spent worldwide each year on synthetic chemicals and biological agents to fight insects above the ground, where nematodes quickly perish. A big slice of the $1.8 billion spent to control soil-dwelling pests would do fine, thank you, at least as a start. 
 "The opportunities are explosive," said Paul D. Dick, national sales manager for the nine-year-old company, which is based in an industrial park here at the northern edge of Silicon Valley.
Like other agricultural biotech companies, Biosys has some trends in its favor. As some of the most effective and long-lasting synthetic chemicals have been outlawed for environmental reasons during the last 20 years, farmers have become eager to use biological pesticides along with the chemicals that remain.
Biosys has something else: a patented production technique that is cutting the cost of these hard-to-cultivate creatures enough to make them competitive for the first time in treating several agricultural crops. It has developed a process to grow nematodes with bacteria in a liquid broth of nutrients resembling those found in insect prey. That is expected to transform a cottage industry, which has served ecologically conscious gardeners and small organic farmers, into a big business.
"The fermentation technology is like the difference between hand-weaving fabric and making it in a modern textile mill," said Venkat S. Sohoni, Biosys's president and chief executive. "We used to raise 2 billion nematodes a week. Now we make 3.5 trillion."
Production at such levels, which the company began to achieve early this year, is necessary, since it can take concentrations of several billion nematodes an acre to control many soil-dwelling pests.
 
Costs Remain High
 At the moment, nematodes are still expensive, but they are proving useful in some circumstances. Cranberry growers in Washington state, for example, have been using nematodes in increasing numbers for four years at a cost of $300 an acre. Most use them only at times in the growing season when no chemicals are allowed or when black vine weevils threaten to overwhelm the chemicals, according to Bob Hitt, chairman of the Washington Cranberry Growers Alliance.
Mint growers have found nematodes more economical than chemicals, because they require fewer applications, Biosys says.
Biosys's nematodes have no impact on humans, plants, or beneficial soil-dwellers like earthworms, but they come armed with a type of bacterium that makes them deadly predators for a variety of insect pests like weevils, grubs and the larvae of a number of insects that live most of their lives above ground. The nematode penetrates the insect, releases the bacteria that kills its host, and starts breeding. After several generations inside the corpse, the food supply is exhausted and more than 100,000 hungry juvenile nematodes burst out looking for new hosts.
Biosys's next challenge, which has to be met crop by crop, region by region, is to prove that nematodes are as effective as the chemicals that remain. "The safety advantage is a good reason to charge a premium, but it's not good enough to introduce the product," said Ramon Georgis, Biosys's director of field development.
Analysts expect sales of nematodes to push Biosys into the black by the end of next year. The company lost $2 million on revenues of $1.9 million in the first six months of this year. By 1996, earnings ought to exceed $9 million and sales should be nearing $50 million, according to Allen H. Cohen, an analyst at Kemper Securities Group Inc., the Chicago brokerage firm that co-managed the first public offering of Biosys shares in March.
 Biosys's lineup of revenue-producing products already includes the Biosafe insecticides for the consumer lawn care and garden market, sold by the Ortho division of Chevron; a professional lawn and plant care line marketed by Ciba-Geigy of Switzerland, and products for citrus, cranberry, artichoke and mint growers sold directly by Biosys.
 
Production Arrangement
 Biosys's commercial and technical success allowed the company to leverage its patented fermentation process into an exclusive manufacturing agreement with the Archer Daniels Midland Company, the nation's largest fermenter of biological products. Under the new arrangement, Biosys becomes, in effect, the gatekeeper for any other biotech firms that would also like to use Archer Daniels's state-of-the-art operations.
"It's a unique relationship," said R. Patrick Simms, Biosys's vice president of manufacturing. "We can enter contracts to scale up manufacturing for other firms, and it gives us something to trade for marketing resources or a share of new products. It allows A.D.M. to get more business without really getting involved in projects too small to really interest them, and without having people from lots of companies at their facility."
Archer Daniels executives say they have been impressed by Biosys's technical skills and by the work of Biosys employees transplanted to the Decatur, Ill., fermenting complex when production began this year.
"The successful installation and start-up of bulk nematode production exceeded our expectations," Mark Whitacre, president of Archer Daniels's Bioproducts Division, said early this month as part of an announcement expanding the partnership.
Some of the industry's most experienced analysts, like George Dahlman of Piper Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis, say they have a hard time imagining the new arrangement adding much to Biosys's prospects or Archer Daniels's business. "There's lots of fermenting capacity out there, so other start-ups would not be willing to give Biosys much to get into A.D.M.," Mr. Dahlman said.
But nematodes alone should keep Biosys busy. There are many families of the creatures. Although some are pests that cause diseases in humans, animals or plants, the Environmental Protection Agency has decided there is no need to regulate the families that Biosys has concentrated on, Steinernema and Heterorhabditid.
 
Rivals' Approach
 So far, all of Biosys's products are based on strains of Steinernema. Some potential rivals, like Ecogen Inc., which recently acquired Bioenterprises, an Australian nematode producer, say they are focusing on Heterorhabditids. "We have heard that they are more active hunters, at least against things like grubs that don't move a lot," said John McIntyre, vice president of commercial development at Ecogen, which is based in Langhorne, Pa.
Ecogen hopes to have its own fermentation process running in three years. One concern: it looks as if Heterorhabditids do not stand up well to such mass production.
To survive, nematodes need both moisture and protection from the ultraviolet rays in sunlight. They are also sensitive to temperature extremes. Farmers have to be more careful about when they apply nematodes than chemicals if they want to get the maximum benefit.
In the long run, scientists are likely to attempt to use genetic engineering to make beneficial nematodes tougher and more versatile. But genetically altered nematodes would also draw close scrutiny from regulators, so the shorter-term strategic emphasis is on testing natural strains found in soil samples. Biosys has built up a "library" of 300 strains, most of them preserved in frozen form.
 
Packaging Systems
 Biosys has also invested heavily in developing a patented process for packing nematodes in gels, along with several other packaging systems for different markets. One approach is to store them in tea-bag-like packaging on flexible plastic frames, which extends their shelf life to five months in normal temperatures. "None of the packing materials we're using were available 10 years ago," said Bruce Dunlop, manager of formulations development.
The nematodes are usually applied with standard agricultural spraying equipment after being mixed with water or, sometimes, chemicals.
Despite the nematodes' preferences for underground life, Biosys sees other opportunities. Some strains may be effective above the ground in shady places or in the controlled environment of the greenhouse. Nematode hotels in the kitchen are also a distinct possibility.
The smelliest room in the company's research department is currently the site of cockroach carnage, as test populations of roaches are exposed to different concentrations and strains of nematodes. Spared from the experiments, however, are the closest thing to the company has to mascots: Twinkie-sized roaches from Madagascar and Costa Rica that the researchers keep as pets.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Market Made In Hedger Heaven

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
RICHARD SANDOR remembers why many said interest rate futures contracts were a foolish idea. "The criticism was that interest rates don't fluctuate enough, and so who needs to hedge?"
Mr. Sandor, as much as anyone, can be deemed to be the father of interest rate futures, which have been trading for 15 years and now dominate the futures markets as perhaps the most successful financial product ever introduced. The actual birthday will be Saturday, but the Chicago Board of Trade will stage its celebration on Friday, mindful that traders value their weekends. 
 On an average day, traders now exchange futures that control $285 billion in underlying government bonds. They do so with only minimal requirements for margins and have become such an accepted part of the markets that it is hard to find a bond trader who remembers what life was like without futures.
Birthdays of products, like those of people, are usually worth noting only to those directly involved. But interest rate futures have made a huge difference in the way financial markets function and perhaps in the way that the Government operates. It is probable that the huge expansion of Federal debt could not have been managed, at least not without more strain to the system, without the ability to lay off the risk of interest rate changes. It is that ability that is the hallmark of the futures markets.
The industry believes that the existence of bond futures has minimized volatility in interest rates, and that is probably true on most days. But they have also made it much easier to quickly place huge bets on the direction of interest rates, in ways that can destabilize markets in times of stress. When a flood closed the Board of Trade earlier this year, there was little activity in the bond market.
The growth of the futures markets as financial centers -- last year the Chicago Board of Trade traded twice as many futures contracts as it traded all agriculture futures -- created a rival center for power to New York, which had dominated bond trading. Many in New York regret the missed opportunity, but Mr. Sandor, now an executive managing director at Kidder, Peabody & Company, thinks it was inevitable. It takes an outsider, he argues, "to cause structural change in any industry," simply because the insiders see no need to risk big changes.
The fact that futures markets now vie for dominance in the trading of bonds, as well as in stocks through similar stock index futures, has created a system of competitive regulation that the financial industry has sometimes been able to use to its benefit in resisting regulation it considers to be heavy-handed. The cash market in bonds is partly regulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and partly by the Treasury. But the futures are regulated by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a group that was originally founded to keep watch on agricultural futures.
The C.F.T.C., in turn, is watched over by the House and Senate Agriculture Committees, which are dominated by farm-state representatives who seek such committee seats largely to protect one farm program or another. And it is those legislators who are now trying to sort out a bitter battle in which the futures markets are trying to put limits on the trading of interest-rate swaps, which provide a competitive way to hedge against the risks of changing interest rates.
In theory, an interest rate future is simple. A contract requires the seller to deliver, on a particular date, $100,000 in 8 percent, 30-year Treasury bonds, or an equivalent value of a similar bond issue. In fact, few bonds are ever delivered as a result of the contracts. Instead, those who buy contracts sell them before they expire.
The beauty of such futures contracts is that for a small margin -- $2,025 now controls $100,000 in bonds -- a trader can offset the risk to a portfolio of a sharp rise, or fall, in interest rates. Without such a hedging technique's being available, it would be extremely dangerous for Wall Street firms to buy huge quantities of government bonds at auctions, or to underwrite large corporate bond issues. A big rise in rates could wipe out such a firm, as the value of the bonds being held came tumbling down.
While Mr. Sandor, an academic turned Wall Street official, gets the credit for proposing interest rate futures, it is Paul A. Volcker who should probably be praised for convincing traders that they were absolutely necessary, simply by showing that bond prices could be unbelievably volatile. The "Saturday night massacre" of Oct. 6, 1979, sent bond prices tumbling as Mr. Volcker, then chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, signaled he meant to get inflation under control, whatever the cost.
That move came just after underwriters led by Salomon Brothers had bought $1 billion in bonds from I.B.M. and caused the value of the bonds to plunge by more than $60 million. But Salomon had used Treasury futures to hedge, a fact that impressed Wall Street. Of course, other traders, many of them speculators, had suffered the losses, just as they would have profited had interest rates fallen.
That helped to set off the huge rise in volume. It nearly quadrupled in 1979, then tripled in 1980, to almost $26 billion a day. And that was less than a tenth of the peak reached in 1990. Now there are numerous other interest rate futures, as well as growing markets in options on such futures.
The fact that volume seems to have peaked in 1990 and is running about 5 percent lower now, does not bother Mr. Sandor. "This is a market that is driven by hedgers," he said, and with interest rates having fallen steadily in recent months, there are fewer who think they need to spend the money to hedge. "When you get an upturn in the economy and a perception that interest rates have bottomed, you'll see a lot more hedging."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
AGREEING TO PROCEED ON INCINERATOR
The Dinkins administration and the leadership of the City Council have agreed to go ahead with construction of a $550 million incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard while at the same time increasing New York City's troubled recycling program. Those are the central elements of a compromise plan to deal with the city's growing problem of garbage disposal -- a subject that has caused a long and bitter debate. A1.
 
A NEW PLACE TO HOLD COURT
Faced with a shortage of court space in Brooklyn so severe that one magistrate holds hearings in a press room, the Federal Government is planning to move the courthouse to the two landmark post office buildings in downtown Brooklyn and build a 415-foot tower there. B3.
 
30 FEET OF STEAM AND TROUBLE
A 30-foot-high plume of contaminated steam billowing from an underground pipe in Manhattan exposed 12 people on East 33d Street to asbestos, dumped asbestos on the fronts of several buildings and forced the closing of Fifth Avenue near the Empire State Building for much of the day. B3.
 
AN ARREST AND AN INQUIRY
A top police official directed the department's Internal Affairs Division to investigate the circumstances surrounding the arrest last week of a Brooklyn van driver who suffered an injury while in police custody. B3.
 
REGION
 
FIGHTING BIAS IN BUSINESS
Armed with a new study that shows minority-owned businesses still get a relatively small share of state contracts, New York State is returning to a system of requiring contractors to reserve a certain proportion of state work for companies headed by women and minorities, state officials said. In effect, the state is returning to a program it suspended in 1989 after the Supreme Court ruled that a similar program in Virginia violated the constitutional rights of white contractors to equal protection under the law. A1.
 
CRACKDOWN ON WASTE INDUSTRY
Charging that a reputed Mafia leader has dominated the private garbage-collection industry on Long Island for many years, Federal prosecutors are trying to bar him from the industry. The prosecutors, who described Salvatore Avellino Jr. as a leader of the Lucchese crime family, are asking the court to block him from participating in any activities "connected with the collection, transportation or disposal of solid waste." B5.
 
A MAN OF (HIDDEN) INFLUENCE
Mort Pye has arguably wielded more sustained influence in New Jersey affairs over the last quarter-century than any other person, public or private. But his name would not be recognized by the average reader of the newspaper he has edited since 1957, The Star-Ledger. But as a tub-thumper for New Jersey and -- not incidentally -- The Star- Ledger, he has had few peers. B5.

HEADLINE: An Affirmative-Action Plan For Birmingham Is Upheld

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
After more than a decade of litigation, a Federal district judge has upheld an affirmative action plan for the City of Birmingham, Ala., including numerical hiring goals that were attacked by the Reagan Administration and by white city employees.
The Birmingham case, one of the nation's most celebrated courtroom tests of affirmative action, involves firefighters, police officers and other city employees. It has attracted attention around the country and has already been reviewed once by the United States Supreme Court. The High Court ruling in 1989, which allowed the reopening of job bias cases in a number of cities, was considered a major setback by civil rights advocates. 
 Judge Sam C. Pointer Jr., chief judge of the Federal District Court in Birmingham, said the city's affirmative action plan was legally justified in view of the exclusion of blacks from city jobs in the past. In a ruling on Friday, he concluded that the plan "did not unnecessarily trammel the rights of whites" and did not violate their constitutional rights.
 
Appeal Is Planned
 Raymond P. Fitzpatrick Jr., a lawyer for white city employees who are plaintiffs in the case, said today that they would appeal Judge Pointer's decision.
Richard T. Seymour, a lawyer for black employees of the Birmingham fire and police departments, said the latest decision "will give encouragement to many employers, public and private, to continue their affirmative action plans."
Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. of Birmingham welcomed the decision. "I hope that it will help hasten the end of this fight over reverse discrimination in the City of Birmingham," the Mayor said in an interview.
The Bush Administration says it supports affirmative action in principle. But it has often opposed enforcement of numerical goals for the hiring and promotion of blacks, Hispanic people and women, arguing that such goals tend to become rigid quotas.
Administration officials had no immediate comment on the ruling in Birmingham. "We are not commenting at this time," said Amy J. Casner, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department.
 
Origin of Case
 The Birmingham case began in 1975, when the Justice Department sued the city, charging that there was a pervasive "pattern and practice" of illegal job discrimination against blacks and women. After a long trial, the Justice Department helped negotiate a consent decree, which set up an extensive plan of affirmative action, including numerical goals for the hiring and promotion of women.
Under the original decree, for example, one black firefighter was to be promoted for each white who won promotion to lieutenant in the Birmingham Fire Department. The decree stipulated that all the people selected for such promotions must be qualified for their new jobs.
The Justice Department signed the decree in May 1981, but it later challenged actions taken by the city under the decree. Then in 1984, the department sided with white city employees who said their rights had been violated by the preferences given to blacks.
Mr. Arrington, a black who has been Mayor since 1979, strongly supports the affirmative action plan. "This city was once steeped in discrimination," he said today. "If affirmative action can't prevail here, it can't prevail anywhere in America. The strongest case you can make for affirmative action based on past racial discrimination is the one you can make in Birmingham, because of its history."
 
Justices Order Trial
 Judge Pointer's decision upholding the Birmingham plan reflects his assessment of evidence presented to him at a trial in October 1991. The trial was required by a Supreme Court decision in June 1989. The High Court said that white city employees had not had an adequate opportunity to present their objections to the consent decree at a trial held by Judge Pointer in 1985.
Robert D. Joffe, a lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York who represented black city employees in Birmingham, hailed Judge Pointer's decision as "a great victory for affirmative action."
"This case demonstrates that affirmative action can be constitutional and justified when the remedy is narrowly tailored" to correct the effects of discrimination, Mr. Joffe said.
In his latest ruling, Judge Pointer said the adoption of numerical goals for promoting blacks in Birmingham was justified by statistical evidence showing "underrepresentation of blacks in traditionally segregated job categories."
Judge Pointer approved the consent decree in 1981, and in his new ruling he rejected the arguments of white city employees who challenged the decree as too broad a remedy. "The decree is limited and tailored to the relief necessary to overcome the employment effects of past discrimination by the city," said the judge, who was appointed by President Richard M. Nixon in 1970.
 
Effect of Ruling
 Mr. Joffe said that "affirmative action was coming to be accepted as an appropriate remedy" in Birmingham when the Justice Department and some white city employees attacked the consent decree in the early 1980's. "They kept this matter festering for 11 years," he said. The effect of Judge Pointer's new decision is to uphold actions taken under the 1981 decree.
Mr. Fitzpatrick, the lawyer for white city employees, said today: "We are disappointed that Judge Pointer did not rule in our favor, but we are not surprised because he has never ruled for us before. The quotas in the consent decree and, more important, the manner in which they were implemented violate the constitutional rights of the white firefighters to equal protection of the laws."

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICAN PLATFORM
ISSUES: ABORTION;
G.O.P. Avoids an Open Debate on Abortion

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The Bush campaign managed to avoid an open debate on the abortion issue at the Republican convention today by appealing to the loyalty of leaders of pivotal state delegations who themselves favor abortion rights.
Polls of delegates show that only a few favor the rigid position on abortion taken in the party's platform, and the Bush camp took pains to place some distance between the President and the platform. 
 Torie Clarke, the campaign spokeswoman, said her colleagues had worked to prevent an abortion debate on the convention floor because "we wanted to get the convention off on the right foot." And she stressed what has become a theme of the Bush camp -- that "people can be pro-choice and pro-Bush."
As a consequence of appeals from the Bush campaign, Gov. Pete Wilson of California and former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, among others, persuaded the delegates from their states who are unhappy with the platform that a televised debate over abortion would hurt President Bush and help his Democratic opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
 
'Immense' White House Pressure
 "It was just a standard kind of whip action," said Charles Black, a senior political adviser who represented the President's interests in the platform debate.
The abortion rights forces tried to keep delegates in line, but were outgunned by the strength of the Bush organization. "The pressure from the White House has been immense," said Nancy Sternoff, executive director of the National Republican Coalition for Choice.
Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said few delegates were willing "to buck the hierarchy of the party."
The abortion plank advocates a constitutional amendment that would outlaw abortion in virtually all circumstances. It would not allow abortions when pregnancies were caused by rape or incest, exceptions favored by Mr. Bush.
The entire platform was adopted without amendment by voice vote this afternoon. Under the party's rules, a floor discussion of a platform plank could have taken place only if a majority of the members of the delegations of six states signed statements saying they opposed the plank.
The leaders of the movement opposed to the abortion section, Govs. William F. Weld of Massachusetts and John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, said today that they gave up their fight after only four delegations sided with them. Those were the ones from Maine, Massachusetts, New Mexico and the Virgin Islands.
The abortion rights forces fell six signatures short in New Jersey and two in Vermont. No vote was taken in California after Governor Wilson's appeal, although a majority of the delegates were said to favor a right to abortion at least in some circumstances.
A CBS News poll of delegates found that only 7 percent favored a law that would, as the platform states, permit abortions "under no circumstances." But the only support for abortion rights in convention speeches today came from Senator John Seymour of California, who, according to statewide polls, is running behind his Democratic opponent, former Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco, in a race in which abortion is an important issue.
Senator Seymour began his five-minute speech this way: "I'm pro-choice, I'm pro-family and I'm pro-jobs. To say I'm entirely happy with our party platform would be untrue. I, for one, believe it should be changed. However, there is much, much more in our party platform that unites us than divides us."
That was his only mention of the issue.
But down on the floor, some delegates said they were disappointed by the direction the party was taking. "We should be moving to the center, not to the right," said Maureen Ogden, a State Representative from New Jersey. "You don't win elections when you move to one extreme or the other."
The New Jersey delegation would probably have voted against the abortion plank had not former Governor Kean given a strong speech against such a stand at a delegation meeting Sunday night. Delegates quoted Mr. Kean as saying that he would "vote his conscience" if he thought the platform could be changed, but that such a battle was fruitless and would only hurt Mr. Bush's re-election chances.
Governor Wilson made the same point to the delegates from California in a speech from Sacramento transmitted here by satellite. "By promoting a fight that cannot be won," he said, "you risk creating rancor and division."
Phil Moore, a California delegate, said the Governor's speech "made us realize the importance of the issue."
Republicans were not alone in trying to keep disagreement on the abortion issue under wraps. At their convention in New York last month, the Democrats did not allow any speakers who objected to their party's line against any legal restrictions on abortions.
And there was no evidence here that disagreement over abortion would cause delegates to abandon their party. Reciting the lesson of the day, Governor Weld declared, "You can very rationally and easily conclude, as I do, that you can be pro-choice and pro-Bush because of the importance of re-electing the President on the grounds of economic, tax and spending issues and foreign policy."
