HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICAN PLATFORM;
Excerpts From the Republican Party's Platform: A New Call for Unity

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the platform adopted by the Republican National Convention.
 
PREAMBLE
 Abraham Lincoln, our first Republican President, expressed the philosophy that inspires Republicans to this day: "The legitimate object of Government is to do for a community of people whatever they need to have done, but cannot do at all, or cannot so well do, for themselves in their separate and individual capacities. But in all that people can individually do as well for themselves, Government ought not to interfere."

 	 	 		. . .	 	America had its rendezvous with destiny in 1980. Faced with crisis at home and abroad, Americans turned to Republican leadership in the White House. Presidents Reagan and Bush turned our Nation away from the path of over-taxation, hyper-regulation, and mega-government. Instead, we moved in a new direction. We cut taxes, reduced red tape, put people above bureaucracy. And so we vanquished the idea of the almighty state as the supervisor of our daily lives. In choosing hope over fear, Americans raised a beacon, reminding the world that we are a shining city on a hill, the last best hope for man on earth.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We believe in a President who represents the national interest, not just the aggregation of well-connected special interests; a President who brings unity to the American purpose. . . .
 
UNITING OUR FAMILY
 
 . . . Our greatness starts at home -- literally. So Republicans believe government should strengthen families, not replace them. Today, more than ever, the traditional family is under assault. We believe our laws should reflect what makes our Nation prosperous and wholesome: faith in God, hard work, service to others, and limited government.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Family: The Home of Freedom
 THE RIGHTS OF THE FAMILY -- . . . Republicans trust parents and believe they, not courts and lawyers, know what is best for their children. That is why we will work to insure that the Congress and the States shall enact no law abridging the rights of the family formed by blood, marriage, adoption, or legal custody -- rights which are anterior and superior to those of government. Republicans oppose and resist the efforts of the Democrat Party to redefine the traditional American family.

 	 	 		. . .	 	CARING FOR CHILDREN -- George Bush secured the American family's most important victory of the last four years: his child care bill. . . .
The demands of employment and commuting often make it hard for parents to spend time with their children. Republicans advocate maximum flexibility in working and child care arrangements so that families can make the most of their schedules. We support pro-family policies: job sharing, telecommuting, compressed work weeks, parental leave negotiated between employer and employees, and flextime.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Achieving Educational Excellence
 The Republican strategy is based on sound principle. Parents have the right to choose the best school for their children. Schools should teach right from wrong. Schools should reinforce parental authority, not replace it. We should increase flexibility from Federal regulation. We should explore a new generation of break-the-mold New American Schools. Standards and assessments should be raised, not reduced to a lowest common denominator. Communities should be empowered to find what works. The pursuit of excellence in education is a fundamental goal. Good teachers should be rewarded for teaching well. Alterative certification can bring desperately needed new people into the teaching profession.

 	 	 		. . .	 	America must remain neutral toward particular religions, but we must not remain neutral toward religion itself or the values religion supports. Mindful of our country's Judeo-Christian heritage and rich religious pluralism, we support the right of students to engage in voluntary prayer in schools and the right of the community to do so at commencements or other occasions. We will strongly enforce the law guaranteeing equal access to school facilities. We also advocate recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in schools as a reminder of the principles that sustain us as one Nation under God. . . .
 
For Healthier Families
 PROMOTE HEALTH, PREVENT DISEASE, REFORM HEALTH CARE -- . . . Republicans believe government control of health care is irresponsible and ineffective. We believe health care choices should remain in the hands of the people, not government bureaucrats. This issue truly represents a fundamental difference between the two parties.

 	 	 		. . .	 	AIDS -- The H.I.V./AIDS epidemic has exploded over the past decade into a crisis of tragic proportions. In our country, AIDS has already claimed more than 150,000 lives, and as many as one million more Americans may have been infected with the virus.
Epidemics have, throughout history, challenged governments, which have too often been powerless to combat them. Science -- and human wisdom -- have advanced, however, and we have met this crisis not only with a massive commitment of resources but also with a personal determination on the part of the President. That commitment and leadership will continue.

 	 	 		. . .	 	PROMOTING CULTURAL VALUES -- . . . Elements within the media, the entertainment industry, academia, and the Democrat Party are waging a guerrilla war against American values. They deny personal responsibility, disparage traditional morality, denigrate religion, and promote hostility toward the family's way of life. Children, the members of our society most vulnerable to cultural influences, are barraged with violence and promiscuity, encouraging reckless and irresponsible behavior. This undermines the authority of parents, the ones most responsible for passing on to their offspring a sense of right and wrong. The lesson our Party draws is important -- that all of us, individuals and corporations alike, have a responsibility to reflect the values we expect our fellow citizens to exhibit.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We oppose any legislation or law which legally recognizes same-sex marriages and allows such couples to adopt children or provide foster care. . . .
Government has a responsibility, as well, to insure that it promotes the common moral values that bind us together as a Nation. We therefore condemn the use of public funds to subsidize obscenity and blasphemy masquerading as art. The fine arts, including those with public support, can certainly enrich our society. However, no artist has an inherent right to claim taxpayer support for his or her private vision of art if that vision mocks the moral and spiritual basis on which our society is founded. We believe a free market in art -- with neither suppression nor favoritism by government -- is the best way to foster the cultural revival our country needs.
 
Individual Rights, Good Homes and Safe Streets


 	 	 		. . .	 	REBUILDING THE DREAM -- . . . In the tradition of Lincoln, President Bush has replicated the American dream of home-ownership. For first-time home buyers, he has proposed a $5,000 tax credit. For lower-income families, he has worked to restore opportunity through HOPE, his initiative to help tenants now dependent on federal aid to buy their own homes; Mortgage Revenue Bonds, to assist more than 1.9 million families to buy a first home; Low Income Housing Tax Credits, already producing more than 420,000 decent apartments at affordable prices; and HOME, a partnership among all levels of government to help low-income families secure better housing. . . .
ENDING DEPENDENCY -- . . . Today's welfare system is anti-work and anti-marriage. It taxes families to subsidize illegitimacy. It rewards unethical behavior and penalizes initiative. It cannot be merely tinkered with by Congress; it must be recreated by states and localities. Republican Governors and legislators in several states have already launched dramatic reforms, especially with workfare and learnfare. Welfare can no longer be a check in the mail with no responsibility.

 	 	 		. . .	 	SAFE HOMES AND STREETS -- . . . The Republican Party is committed to a drug-free America. During the last twelve years, we have radically reversed the Democrats' attitude of tolerance toward narcotics, vastly increased Federal operations against drugs, cleaned up the military, and launched mandatory testing for employees in various fields, including White House personnel. As a result, overall drug abuse is falling. We urge that states and communities emphasize anti-drug education by police officers and others in schools to educate young children to the dangers of the drug culture. Dope is no longer trendy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	NEW MEMBERS OF THE AMERICAN FAMILY -- Our Nation of immigrants continues to welcome those seeking a better life. This reflects our past, when some newcomers fled intolerance; some sought prosperity; some came as slaves. All suffered and sacrificed but hoped their children would have a better life. All searched for a shared vision -- and found one in America. Today we are stronger for our diversity.
Illegal entry into the United States, on the other hand, threatens the social compact on which immigration is based. That IS, the Nation accepts immigrants and is enriched by their determination and values. Illegal immigration, on the other hand, undermines the integrity of border communities and already crowded urban neighborhoods. We will build on the already announced strengthening of the Border Patrol to better coordinate interdiction of illegal entrants through greater cross-border cooperation. . . .
INDIVIDUAL RIGHTS -- The protection of individual rights is the foundation for opportunity and security.
The Republican Party is unique in this regard. Since its inception, it has respected every person, even when that proposition was not universally popular. Today, as in the day of Lincoln, we insist that no American's rights are negotiable.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We believe the unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed. We therefore reaffirm our support for a human life amendment to the Constitution, and we endorse legislation to make clear that the Fourteenth Amendment's protections apply to unborn children.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
UNITING OUR COUNTRY
 KEEPING WHAT YOU EARN -- The test of economic policy is whether it promotes economic growth and expands job opportunities. Lower taxes and an expanding economy depend on long term, consistent restraint in the growth of federal spending. . . .
The simple truth for the American people is this: The only safeguard between themselves and Democrat tax increases is the use of the veto by George Bush and enough Republican votes in Congress to sustain it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We will cut the capital gains tax rate to 15 percent -- zero in enterprise zones -- and index it so government cannot profit from inflation by taxing phantom capital gains, literally stealing from savings and pensions.

 	 	 		. . .	 	LIBERATION THROUGH DEREGULATION -- . . . We support President Bush's freeze on new regulations. We applaud his Competitiveness Council, under Vice President Quayle, for fighting the regulatory mania, saving the public $20 billion with its initial 90-day moratorium on new regulations and billions more under the current 120-day freeze.

 	 	 		. . .	 	JOB CREATION AND SMALL BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES -- . . . To create jobs and keep small business growing, the Republican Party supports increased access to capital for business expansion, exporting, long term investment, opportunity capital for the disadvantaged, and capital to bring new products and new technology to the market.
The Republican Party enthusiastically encourages the passage of Federal enterprise zones. Enterprise zones have been effective programs for promoting growth in urban and rural America. Republicans believe that the concept of enterprise zones is based on unyielding faith in the entrepreneurial spirit of all Americans. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Reforming Government and the Legal System
 CLEANING UP THE IMPERIAL CONGRESS. -- The Democrats have controlled the House of Representatives for 38 years -- five years longer than Castro has held Cuba. They have held the Senate for 32 of those 38. Their entrenched power has produced a Congress arrogant, out of touch . . . . Republicans want to change all that. We reaffirm our support for a constitutional amendment to limit the number of terms House Members and Senators may serve.

 	 	 		. . .	 	MANAGING GOVERNMENT IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST -- . . . We deplore the blatant political bias of the government-sponsored radio and television networks. It is especially outrageous that taxpayers are now forced to underwrite this biased broadcasting through the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB). We call for sweeping reform of CPB .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Our Land, Food, and Resources
 AGRICULTURE -- The Republican Party is the home of the farmer, rancher, and forester. We have long championed their right to pursue growth, efficiency, and competitiveness through market incentives, diversification, and personal ingenuity. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	We value our Nation's real wetlands habitat and the diversity of our native animal and plant life. We oppose, however, bureaucratic harassment of farm, ranch, and timber families under statutes regarding endangered species and wetlands.

 	 	 		. . .	 	PUBLIC LANDS -- . . . We believe that recreation, forestry, ranching, mining, oil and gas exploration, and production on our public lands can be conducted in a way compatible with their conservation. The United States has some of the richest mineral resources in the world. Our public lands should not be arbitrarily locked up and put off limits to responsible uses.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
UNITING OUR WORLD
 Building on the legacy of Ronald Reagan, George Bush saw the chance to sweep away decadent Communism. He was the first Western leader to declare his determination to fashion "a Europe whole and free." . . .
Yet now that we have won the Cold War, we must also win the peace. We must not repeat the mistake of the past by throwing away victory through complacency. A new world beckons, unlike any we have ever known, filled with uncertainties. Old passions have re-emerged. New democracies struggle to decide their destiny. Nations are torn asunder. Migrants and refugees strain the social fabric of continents. Tyrants work to build nuclear, chemical, and even biological weapons to threaten us and our neighbors. Drug trafficking and terrorism, often linked, menace Americans at home and abroad. . . .
PROVEN LEADERSHIP -- George Bush has been the most important architect of Western aspirations and designs for the challenging world we are now entering. . . .
The test of international leadership is on the field, not in a playbook. The Oval Office is no place for on-the job training -- not in carrying out the Presidential duty to protect and defend our Nation, not in managing the arsenal of the supreme nuclear power. There are those who talk and those who perform. George Bush has clearly performed for America, making the right calls in a series of tough decisions that helped transform the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

COMPANY: REPUBLICAN PARTY REPUBLICAN PARTY (93%);

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Fall as Convention Opens

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market fell yesterday as investors waited to see what kind of economic program the Republicans would outline at their convention in Houston.
But the pause in the market, with the resulting rise in yields, has not discouraged big borrowers from continuing to lower their interest costs by recalling old debt at higher rates and issuing new notes or bonds at much lower rates. Even with the decline yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond is still lower than it was in Janaury. 
 The Tennessee Valley Authority made such a move yesterday, issuing $700 million in new 30-year bonds that together with earlier refinancings has lowered the utility's annual borrowing costs by $200 million.
After comments by James A. Baker 3d, the incoming chief of staff, helped undermine the bond market on Thursday, traders said they were paying more attention to the impact of the election, especially during this convention week. There has been talk of President Bush proposing some kind of tax cut to help stimulate the economy, a proposal that has some investors worried because it could signal a rise in the record Federal budget deficit.
Analysts said that the decline in bond and note prices, which saw the 30-year bond down almost half a point, was also a continuation of the correction after a rally in the bond market that pushed up prices and reduced yields on the 30-year bond to five-and-a-half-year lows.
 
Eyes on Meeting of the Fed
 Eyes were also on the meeting this week of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, which could cut short-term interest rates again soon. Some analysts do not expect the committee to act during the Republican convention. But there is a growing feeling that the Fed, given the steady diet or recent sluggish economic data, will act again by the fall.
It is, however, hard to gauge what the Fed will do. And it is almost equally hard to keep track of the feelings in the market about whether the Fed will ease again or not. Lately a new Fed easing, like the half of a percentage point reduction in the Federal funds rate and the discount rate on July 2,, has been greeted by conclusions that it would be the last cut the Fed would make. Then as new economic data came out showing the the economy was still barely growing, the mood among traders and investors would swing back toward the belief that the Fed would have to act again.
"We're likely to have one more easing, if just for political and psychological reasons," said Thomas Synnott, chief economist at the U.S. Trust Company of New York. "But I don't think it will help very much," he added, because he expects only a quarter of a percentage point cut in the target Federal funds rate, which is now at 3.25 percent.
In late trading in the secondary market, the 7.25 percent, 30-year bond was offered at 98 25/32, down 15/32 to yield 7.35 percent, compared with 7.31 percent on Friday.
The 6.375 percent 10-year note was off 7/32, to yield 6.52 percent, compared with 6.5 percent at the end of last week. But the 5.5 percent five-year note was unchanged to yield 5.49 percent.
In the weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the discount rate fell for the second consecutive week, a reflection of the growing expectation of another easing by the Fed. The average discount rate for the three-month bill of 3.10 percent was the lowest since Feb. 14, 1972. And the average yield of 3.18 percent for the six-month bill was the lowest since July 1, 1963.
In the municipal market prices were off sharply and yields rose. the average yield of The Bond Buyer Index of major municipal securities was up to 6.22 percent from 6.20 percent. One executive at a firm involved in the municipal market said that the prices were falling because a lot of Wall Street firms had bought much of the new municipal issues in recent weeks and were having trouble moving them on to retail or institutional investors. "These have to be priced more attractively," he said, especially because there is another $4 billion to $5 billion of new municipal issues expected this week.
 
Concern Over Situation in Iraq
 In the Treasury market, some traders said there was also concern yesterday that the United States would have to take some retaliatory action against Iraq, which could lead to a jump in oil prices. President Bush, in an interview on the Cable News Network, said, as he has many times recently, that he would not let President Saddam Hussein of Iraq renege on agreements involving the destruction of the country's major weapons of war.
"I think he's just trying to thumb his nose at the rest of the world and he's not going to get away with it," the President said.
But traders thought the convention and just the need for a market correction had more to do with the decline yesterday.
If one thinks about it, it seems a little odd that investors and dealers are just now focusing on the Republican National Convention in Houston and the effect any economic stimulus program might have on the economy and the bond market.
Analysts and investors have known for a long time that the convention was this week and that a sluggish economy would prompt an economic stimulus program by the Democrats, if the Democratic nominee, Bill Clinton, wins, and possibly by the Republicans.
Although this is the case, in the bond market, as in other markets, like foreign exchange, the focus of investors tends at times to be single minded. And until Mr. Baker spoke last week the focus was on slow economic growth, low inflation and the growing conviciton that both these eoconomic developments were so positive for the bond market that they would push the yield on the 30-year bond as low as 7 percent by the end of the year.
Now, after the rally paused last week, the attention of investors has been distracted enough to make them worry about the convention and what it might tell them.
But that does not mean the rally cannot resume again if the news is not bad. In fact, the bond rally of July paused during the Democratic Naitonal Convention because of the surge of Mr. Clinton in the polls. But it resumed the next week, even as Mr. Clinton's popularity seemed to grow.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
2-Party Democracy Comes Screaming to Nassau

BYLINE: By Diana Jean Schemo

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I.

 BODY:
TALL wood panels line the grand meeting room of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors, suggesting an air of seriousness. But it is only a suggestion, for democracy here carries its share of theater, if not circus.
Consider the morning George Glasel, an 83-year-old with cancer, hijacked a standing-room-only crowd from matters of sludge to the threshold of wonder. 
 Mr. Glasel took the microphone just as homeowners from Cedar Creek and Bay Park -- incensed that the county was considering another sludge treatment plant in their neighborhoods -- faced down the muscular men from the trades unions, so disgusted at the dearth of jobs that they appeared eager to build anything, no matter how noxious.
"The last time I spoke to you was two months ago, and I was bald," Mr. Glasel began, reminding the audience of his illness.
"But sometimes, from a terrible tragedy something wonderful happens. Look at me now." He lowered his head to show the supervisors gray shoots sprouting from his scalp. Then he looked up, eyes alight with awe.
"Isn't it wonderful that we live in an age when a doctor can prescribe something to make an 83-year-old man grow hair?" The rancorous room -- taken aback as much by Mr. Glasel's testimony as by its unexpectedness -- fell silent.
Thus unfolds two-party democracy in Nassau County, long ruled by a Republican Party machine of legendary patronage and power. The election of three Democratic supervisors last year to a board of six, along with a recession that drained 91,000 jobs from Long Island, have renewed scrutiny in one of America's richest counties.
To be sure, people have always had the right to speak up at public meetings here and did so, often noisily, over certain issues, such as day care. But one-party government usually meant staid meetings at which supervisors announced decisions worked out in private.
Now, as Nassau gropes toward something approximating open government, its Board of Supervisors meetings have become a stage for the anger, the innocence and the mayhem of people newly preoccupied with the workings of government.
And for a brief and delightful moment, order is taking a back seat.
Even by the colorful standards of the day, last week's Board of Supervisor's meeting was raucous. At issue was a strange resolution to seek bids for freeze drying sludge at waste-treatment plants on the South Shore. The supervisors promised residents the county would just collect the bids, as required under a Federal consent decree to stop ocean dumping, while it sought a poorer county upstate to take Nassau's refuse.
The issue may well have begged for high drama and hyperbole.
Alan Baron, the first speaker from Cedar Creek, set the tone when he described the county's plans as duplicitous, and compared them with Nazi death camps, where "people marched through gates on which was written 'Freedom Through Work' on their way to the gas chambers."
Even the walls seemed to groan at the comparison.
If the meeting began with a list of speakers, it was quickly ignored. Neighborhood leaders and union men took the microphone at random, each speaker drawing taunts from the other side. They wheedled, ranted, intoned and, in a bind, insulted public officials and one another.
"No wonder people want change," Joseph Tortora from the Electrical Workers Union, said. "How long before we take responsibililty for our own garbage?" Mr. Tortora said Long Island had become the laughingstock of America when a barge of its trash floated endlessly at sea, turned away wherever it tried to land.
One out of work construction worker, said he, too, was troubled by the unusually high rate of breast cancer on Long Island.
"Married, I have three daughters," he began. "Between my wife and my three daughters that's four breasts." The spectators giggled and looked at one another, as the burly worker counted on his fingers. "Eight breasts. That's why I'm out of work, I guess."
After suggestions that the only way Nassau County could avoid a sludge problem were if everyone would stop going to the bathroom, the man ended with an image that made many wonder if the meetings were not sinking to a dangerous low.
"Let's not ship our sludge upstate," he said. "It will only run downhill and kill us later."
The meetings traditionally begin at 10:30 A.M. and usually end discreetly at lunch time, but last week's went on until 5:30 P.M.and adjourned inconclusively.
By then, the Democratic Supervisor from Oyster Bay, Lewis J. Yevoli, was so revolted that he scolded the audience for its "backtalk and screaming across the aisles."
"I have attended a lot of meetings, and I have never seen anything like this." he said. "I have never seen anything like this in my entire life." But then again, Nassau County hasn't seen two-party democracy in a long time either.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Nassau County gropes toward something approximating open government, its Board of Supervisors meetings have become a stage for anger, innocence and mayhem from people preoccupied with the workings of government. Peter Bonziglia, left, and Frank Abrami argued last week. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
With Just One Bank Holdout, Chrysler Loan Appears Near

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 17

 BODY:
With only one of 152 banks still declining to sign a $6.8 billion loan agreement, the Chrysler Corporation appeared to be very close today to wrapping up the arrangement, which is crucial to its revitalization.
An executive with the auto maker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, declined to identify the lone holdout bank. In recent weeks, Chrysler solicited the help of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, to persuade German central bankers to use their influence on German banks that were holding out. 
 All of the banks belong to a consortium that has been lending to Chrysler for about four years. The interest rate and charges on the new agreement are significantly higher than in the old one, reflecting perceptions that the company poses a higher risk because of the recession and its fragile financial condition.
 
Deadline Is This Week
 Still, Chrysler officials have been confident that the agreement will be completed by the end of the week. Officially, the company declined to comment on the negotiations.
If the agreement, which stipulates unanimous participation among the lenders, is not complete by the end-of-the-week deadline, the auto maker and its lead banks, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Swiss Bank Corporation, could be forced to start negotiations all over.
The $6.8 billion loan replaces a loan of equal size to the Chrysler Financial Corporation that comes due in March and April. The money is used to finance retail vehicle purchases and dealers' wholesale inventory. Negotiating such loans has been routine in the past, but the process has been clouded by Chrysler's thin financial resources and regulatory pressure on banks.
 
Big Pension Obligation
 Among the big question marks on Chrysler's books is a $4 billion unfunded liability for employees' pensions. The auto maker asserts that an array of new models and higher demand for vehicles will allow it to pay off the liability over 10 years and to finance multibillion-dollar new-product programs.
Low ratings on Chrysler's debt securities by ratings agencies have made it prohibitively expensive for the company to raise money in the public markets. Several American banks initially resisted participation in the loan because they had changed their lending strategy to one that avoids large nationwide lending syndicates. But the pressure to join the Chrysler syndicate has been heavy because the fate of the company could be at stake.
The First Fidelity Bancorporation, a large banking company in New Jersey, said it would not comment on reports that it was the bank holding up Chrysler's financing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Dips in Slow Trading As Investors Await Signals

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell slightly against most currencies yesterday in slow trading as investors watched for signals from the Republican National Convention. Gold prices rose.
"It was just sort of a no-man's land in the dollar markets, where no one knows what's going to happen" at the convention," said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager at the Bank of New York Company. 
 In New York the dollar closed at 125.70 Japanese yen, down from 126.00 yen late Friday. In Tokyo the dollar closed at 126.25 yen, up 0.22 yen from Friday's close. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 125.72 yen.
The dollar rose in early European trading in anticipation that the German central bank would push interest rates lower, Mr. Ryan said. But dollar traders started selling off when ticker reports said a member of the German Bundesbank had commented that rates would not fall soon.
Higher interest rates in the United States and lower foreign yields would give investors incentive to buy more dollars.
In Europe the dollar rose to 1.4760 marks, from 1.4683 late Friday. But in New York the dollar closed at 1.4640 German marks, down from 1.4650 late Friday.
Traders are watching the convention closely for any signals on the direction of the American economy, which could affect interest rates, and on global tensions.
President Bush said yesterday that the United States had the right to "use force if necessary" to compel President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to comply with international inspection weapons demands and said President Hussein "is not going to get away" with defying the world.
Prospects of military action in the Middle East would be likely to move the dollar higher. It is seen as a safe haven for investors in times of global uncertainty.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rising Polish Labor Unrest Sends Copper Up Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures settled sharply higher yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange on technical factors and concern about the deteriorating labor situation in Poland.
The continuing strike at Poland's state copper producer Komginat Gorniczo Hutniczy Miedzi has increased expectations that the company will declare that it cannot meet export commitments because of conditions beyond its control. 
 Copper prices opened weakly, falling 70 points on concern over continued weakness in the world economy. But prices moved higher in a surge of commodity fund and commission-house buying, with the September contract settling 4.10 cents higher at $1.1540 a pound, a three-week high.
Giving a boost to copper was news of increased labor unrest in Poland, with the strike at the state producer spreading to other industries, including transportation, said Bernard Savaiko, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc.
"K.G.H.M. has been on strike since July 20," he said. "The market was looking for an early end, but no solution is in sight."
 
Coffee Tumbles
 Coffee futures fell on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on selling pressure from Central American and Brazilian producers.
September coffee fell 2.25 cents, to 48.25 cents a pound.
Melissa Trout, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said there was little new to influence the market. She said the coffee crop was the largest in 30 years, depressing the market.
Grain and soybean futures were higher in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The surge in prices was influenced by the release Friday of the National Weather Service's 30-day forecast, said Jerry Gidel, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago.
The forecast calls for normal to below normal temperatures through mid-September and normal to above-normal rainfall.
The unsettled relationship between Iraq and the United Nations gave a boost to crude oil and related energy futures traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
September light sweet crude oil was 17 cents higher at $21.45 a barrel; September heating oil was 0.45 cent higher at 59.35 cents a gallon; September unleaded gasoline was 0.78 cent higher at 61.58 cents a gallon; September natural gas was 7 cents lower at $1.762 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Livestock and meat futures were lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, under pressure from weak cash prices and expectations for reduced demand.
August live cattle were 0.60 cent lower at 73.95 cents a pound; August feeder cattle were 0.35 cent lower at 84.92 cents a pound; August live hogs were 0.38 cent lower at 44.07 cents a pound, and August frozen pork bellies were 0.55 cent lower at 38.40 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Kmart's Net Up by 3.1%; Tiffany Falls

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Reflecting weak confidence among bargain hunters and affluent shoppers alike, the Kmart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer, behind Wal-Mart Stores Inc., reported a limp 3.1 percent increase in second-quarter earnings yesterday, and Tiffany & Company reported a 45.8 percent plunge in profits.
But Toys "R" Us, which sells more than 25 percent of the stuffed animals, video games, dolls and other toys sold in America, defied the depressing trend in retail earnings in the second quarter, when its profits skyrocketed 39.7 percent. 
 Following are details of the retailers' profits:
 
Kmart

Kmart, which operates Kmart discount stores as well as several specialty retail chains, said its earnings rose to $168 million, or 37 cents a share, from $163 million, or 40 cents a share, during the similar period last year. Earnings per share were diluted by the greater number of shares outstanding at the end of this year's second quarter.
Sales increased 8.8 percent, to $9.14 billion, from $8.40 billion in the second quarter of 1991.
Wall Street analyst's estimates of Kmart's second-quarter earnings ranged from 37 cents a share to 42 cents a share, with a mean of 40 cents a share, according to Bloomberg Business News.
Joseph E. Antonini, chairman and chief executive of Kmart, said cautious spending patterns and colder than normal weather that stymied sales of apparel and gardening equipment had hampered the company's performance.
Kmart's strongest sales came in July, when the weather was warmer, but July typically is a highly promotional month, used by retailers to clear out spring and summer merchandise. Consequently, the company's profit margins in the second quarter slipped 1 percent, to 23.9 percent of sales.
Some analysts were concerned by the faltering pace of sales and profits from Kmart's PACE Membership Warehouse stores, which contributed 2 percent of the company's overall profits in 1991. Although PACE did better than its competitors in the warehouse industry, with a 10.9 percent increase in sales at stores open at least one year, its sales were still below plan in the second quarter, Mr. Antonini said.
 
Tiffany
 Tiffany's net income dived to $3.9 million, or 25 cents a share, from $7.2 million, or 46 cents a share, in 1991, which was worse than most analysts had expected. Sales for the quarter that ended July 31 rose to $120.8 million from $119.4 million a year earlier.
William R. Chaney, Tiffany's chairman, said the company continued to struggle against weak economic and retail conditions. Its costs also increased 11.5 percent as it continues a major expansion of stores throughout the United States.
Tiffany's United States operations, which had flat sales in the second quarter, were hit by a declining number of tourists, who account for a large portion of the volume of the company's stores. And internationally, the company's performance was hampered by declining sales to Mitsukoshi, the exclusive Japanese department store chain that sells Tiffany merchandise in Japan.
Given the luxury goods it sells, Tiffany needs a bigger improvement in the economy than most retailers to experience sales growth, analysts said.
"Over all, the outlook for the company is not very favorable when you combine the sluggish outlook for the U.S. economy with the severe downturn in the Japanese consumer markets," said Peter J. Caruso, a retail analyst with Merrill Lynch.
 
Toys "R" Us
 Toys "R" Us lifted its profits to $32.7 million, or 11 cents a share, during the quarter that ended Aug. 1, from $23.4 million, or 8 cents a share, last year. Sales grew 18 percent, to $1.3 billion.
Analysts' estimates of the company's second-quarter earnings ranged from 9 cents a share to 12 cents a share, according to Bloomberg Business News.
Charles Lazarus, chairman and chief executive of Toys "R" Us, said the outstanding growth in earnings reflected greater sales of classic toys like board games and baby dolls, which give the company higher profit margins and require less advertising and promotion than "hot" toys like video games. He said the company benefited from strong sales in its European stores and improving sales in its Canadian stores.

HEADLINE: American Chestnut Could Still Win Its Battle

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
PLANT pathologists hope they are on their way to one of their greatest victories, the resurrection of the magnificent American chestnut tree, a cousin of the oak and by some estimates far more beautiful.
The chestnut was long one of the dominant and most economically important hardwood trees on the Eastern Seaboard, its range extending from Maine to Alabama and west to the Mississippi. The chestnut grew quickly and flourished in thin, rocky soil that was inhospitable to many other trees, and its wood was exceptionally resistant to rot. 
 The tree's straight, imposing trunk proved an excellent source of timber, its chestnuts were harvested to feed livestock and produce flour, and its bark and wood provided abundant amounts of tannin, a chemical used to tan leather. Through the 18th and 19th centuries, entire industries and towns centered on the chestnut tree, particularly in Appalachia.
But in 1904, botanists at the Bronx Zoo in New York discovered that trees they had imported from the Far East were infected with chestnut blight, a bright orange fungus that kills trees by girdling the trunk and cutting off nutrients and water. The American chestnut tree had no resistance to the foreign pest and quickly succumbed.
 
A Way to Fight Back
 Dispersed by rain, insects and humans, the blight spread an estimated 25 miles per year up and down the coast. In less than 50 years, several billion mature chestnut trees had perished, and so, too, had the businesses that relied on them.
"It was the greatest ecological tragedy in recorded history," said Dr. William L. MacDonald, a chestnut expert at West Virginia University in Morgantown.
Now researchers may have created a way of battling the blight. It turns out that some surviving chestnut trees in the Midwest, as well as in Europe, are infected with a far less virulent strain of the blight. Analyzing the innocuous fungus, scientists have learned that it is itself afflicted by a pathogen, a type of virus called a double-stranded RNA virus, that somehow inhibits the fungus's growth and keeps it from killing a tree.
An attempt to use the natural form of the virus to control the blight does not appear to be feasible on a large scale, however, because the natural virus must be spread among the fungi by so-called vegetative fusing, and many strains of the blight are incompatible and will refuse to fuse.
To circumvent the problem, Dr. Gil H. Choi and Dr. Donald L. Nuss of the Roche Institute of Molecular Biology have fashioned a DNA version of the RNA virus and have prompted the DNA copy to integrate into the fungus chromosomes. In its new configuration, the virus can spread from one fungus to another by sexual reproduction involving two fungal cells, a far more assured event than vegetative fusion. Hence, there is no barrier to the virus's eventual dispersion throughout the entire population of blight because it crowds out the less virulent form genetically.
The scientists hope to expose chestnuts to the less virulent strain of fungus, essentially inoculating them by giving them a less harmless blight that will dominate over the virulent strain. In theory, chestnuts could be restored where they had once thrived.
Young sprouts of the trees cover the forest floors of many Eastern states and await only a break in the cover of other, taller hardwood trees, say by fire or lumbering, to begin growing toward the heavens. Right now, the trees would be killed by blight as they matured. But if the new, less virulent blight were released into the environment, the trees may be able to reach their former majesty.
The scientists at Roche anticipate that it will take three to five years to win permission to release the genetically altered fungus in even a small bit of forest.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In 1904, it was found that chestnut trees from the Far East were infected with a blight that killed American trees like these, photographed in the Great Smoky Mountains before the blight. Today, researchers have discovered a less virulent strain that may preserve young chestnuts. (The Museum of North Idaho)

HEADLINE: Astronomy's New Era Is Born in Poverty

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
DESPITE America's historical and continuing lead in inventing new types of telescopes and other advanced instruments, astronomers charge that the failure of the Federal Government to provide dependable financial support has put American astronomy at a serious disadvantage in the competition with its counterparts in Europe and Japan.
Federal financing has flagged, they say, just as a stream of new telescopes and telescope-enhancing devices are ready to be exploited. Scientists expect the instruments to mark a new era of astronomy, vastly improving the ability of ground-based telescopes to peer through the distorting veil of the earth's atmosphere and increasing human understanding of the cosmos. Yet some American astronomers, including senior professionals as well as young postdoctoral researchers, are even leaving this country for better professional opportunities in Europe. 
 Paradoxically, the United States plans to build some of the largest and most advanced telescopes in the world. Designers hope to embellish them with devices that were originally invented and developed for such Defense Department programs as spy satellites and Strategic Defense Initiative weapons. But reduced Federal commitments to astronomy have made some of these projects uncertain at best.
Despite its importance and popular appeal, astronomy functions on a shoestring budget, compared with other fields of science. The National Optical Astronomy Observatories had a budget of $28.8 million for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30; that money had to cover the operation of two major observatories in the United States and one in Chile.
Dr. Sidney C. Wolff, director of N.O.A.O., said that since 1984, financing for the agency, the Government's main vehicle for optical astronomy research, had actually declined by 15 percent when inflation was taken into account and that the prospects for the coming year were even worse. "Between 20 and 40 staff members are likely to have to be dropped," she said, "and while the European observatories can count on funding three or four years in advance, we have to live from year to year.
"We realize the need for big cuts in Federal spending, but it seems to me we've already paid more than our share," Dr. Wolff said.
The agency operates Kitt Peak Observatory in Arizona, the National Solar Observatory in New Mexico and the Cerro Tololo Interamerican Observatory in Chile. It also hopes to carry out a major new telescope project called Gemini, a joint project by the United States, Canada and Britain, who later enlisted Chile and Australia as junior contributors. But Australia may not be able to commit its share by the deadline of Oct. 1, so Congress may simply cut off the money for the project.
Financial and management problems for American astronomy are mounting just as an international race for leadership in astronomy is reaching full stride. Dr. Riccardo Giacconi, the chief scientist for the Hubble Space Telescope, charges that poor management of the America's space and astronomy programs has hobbled efforts to compete with European science.
Dr. Giacconi himself, a founder of X-ray astronomy and the current director of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, will soon join the brain drain. In January, Dr. Giacconi, an Italian-born American, will become the director of Europe's eight-nation astronomical consortium, the European Southern Observatory, and will concentrate on completing Europe's Very Large Telescope, the largest ground-based telescope project ever undertaken.
A wealth of new inventions and technologies, most of them developed in the United States, promises to bring about a revolution in astronomy. In principle, that should give the United States a strong competitive edge in its race with Europe and Japan. But, concurring in Dr. Giacconi's gloomy assessment, many American astronomers say that this nation's scientific institutions seem to be incapable of exploiting the discoveries and inventions of its own scientists and engineers to best advantage.
"We have very poor management," Dr. Giacconi said in an interview."We just don't seem able to exploit our intellectual and technological resources.
 
Reversing the Tide
 "Take my own particular field, X-ray astronomy," he said. "We Americans founded the field and were the world leaders in X-ray astronomy. But it's come to the point where everything new in the field is either Japanese or German. It's not that we didn't spend the money. It's just that we spent it wrong, we spent it poorly."
In past generations, the flow of astronomical talent was mainly from Europe to the United States. Some of the best-known American astronomers, including the Dutch-born discoverer of quasars, Dr. Maarten Schmidt of the California Institute of Technology, immigrated to the United States at a time "when American astronomy was at its zenith and the observation possibilities were mainly in this country," Dr. Giacconi said. "But that situation is no longer true. The pull on astronomers is in the other direction," he added.
Another astronomer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "The situation is reaching a crisis. The astronomical programs in this country, which are small potatoes compared with the proposed space station and the Superconducting Supercollider, are in danger of starving."
That assessment is supported by Dr. Roger Angel, a British astronomer at the University of Arizona's Steward Observatory. While Dr. Angel does not plan to return to Europe, he said significant numbers of American astronomers had already left. Among them is Dr. Jacques M. Beckers, a Dutch-born astronomer, who left a senior position as a planner of federally financed American telescopes to join the team building Europe's mighty V.L.T.
Another recent emigre from the American astronomical community is Dr. Steven Beckwith, formerly a prominent astronomer at Cornell University, who has joined Germany's Max Planck Institute of Astrophysics. According to Dr. Angel, American postdoctoral astronomy students who are unable to find jobs in the United States are also drifting to Europe. "One of my own postdocs, a very capable young astronomer, has left to join Dr. Beckwith in Germany," Dr. Angel said.
Why should the American taxpayer care where American astronomers choose to reside, as long as they do good work? Does it matter to astronomers where they work, provided they have access to the best possible tools of the trade?
"It does," Dr. Angel said. "I feel terrible about this trend. Astronomy was the first physical science in which America became preeminent. That happened in the 19th century at a time when Europeans led in almost all other fields of science, including chemistry. In the early 20th century, Europe was blazing trails in chemistry, relativity theory, quantum mechanics and many other sciences, but the United States could still claim to be first in astronomy, and it remained preeminent for a century. It really hurts to see Europe taking that lead away."
 
Waiting for Opportunity
 American astronomers using international telescopes are at another disadvantage. The observation time customarily allotted to an astronomer depends partly on his or her nationality; the higher the proportion of financing contributed by the astronomer's nation, the more time the scientist gets to use the telescope. The United States contributes little or nothing to most European telescopes, except for some jointly built observatories on United States soil.
Dr. Angel said excellence in astronomy was perceived by many as an attribute of national prestige.
"I served on the panel that looked into the optical error in the mirror of the Hubble Space Telescope," he said. "As an astronomer I had worried about the Hubble's gigantic cost, something like $2 billion. But on that panel I heard something really telling: that if the Hubble had worked as it was supposed to, the $2 billion would have been well worth the price for United States public relations alone, showing that we could still carry off a technological triumph brilliantly. As it turned out, of course, the public relations part of it backfired."
After the Hubble Space Telescope was launched in 1990, the scientists using it discovered that its heart, the concave mirror that collects and focuses light from the stars, had the wrong shape. Although the Hubble has proved much more scientifically productive than pessimists at first feared, the telescope will not operate as it was intended unless a space shuttle mission planned for next year installs corrective optics, similar in principle to eyeglasses.
The race for better telescopes has two aspects: making telescopes bigger and making them better.
From the time it was inaugurated in 1948 until the present, the largest operating American telescope has been the 200-inch-diameter instrument at Palomar, Calif. Nevertheless, the smaller telescopes built since Palomar have improved immensely, mainly because of an American invention called the charge-coupled device. C.C.D.'s were invented at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in the late 1960's and were first put to use mainly in military hardware, like night-vision devices and spy satellites.
It was not until 1975 that scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and the University of Arizona demonstrated the devices' potential use in astronomical telescopes. Their main advantage over both photographic emulsions and vidicon television cameras is that C.C.D.'s can capture the very faintest light, of any wavelength, and generate a precisely amplified electronic record that can be viewed on a video screen. The human eye, a remarkably efficient light detector, registers only about 1 percent of the photons of light it encounters, while a C.C.D. chip converts up to 90 percent of the incident photons into electronic counterparts.
 
Telescopes Get Stronger
 When C.C.D. detectors replaced conventional photographic plates in most astronomical telescopes during the 1980's, the telescopes' light-gathering power increased enormously, almost as if their mirrors had been enlarged to many times their actual sizes. Important discoveries ensued, yielding insights into the nature of quasars, the formation of galaxies and the large-scale structure of the universe. America's costly but wonderful C.C.D.'s opened a golden decade of astronomical discovery, in which modified telescopes rather than new ones were the tools.
By the end of the 1980's, the benefits of the C.C.D. had been exploited to the maximum, so still greater light-gathering power was needed to push farther into the unknown. The only way to achieve this was by building larger telescopes, and the race to do that is now in full swing.
But bigger telescopes mean much bigger technological problems. A major problem for a traditional reflecting telescope is the effect of turbulent air inside an observatory dome and inside the open structure of the telescope itself. To compensate for this, new telescopes are being made as short as possible to fit inside small, well-ventilated domes. That, of course, means using mirrors with much great curvatures than the conventional kinds.
Dr. Angel has devised an approach to making such mirrors. The Angel system uses a rotating electric furnace about the size and speed of a carnival carousel. Chunks of optical glass imported from Japan are loaded on the furnace's turntable mold; as the temperature rises toward the melting point of glass, the platform is set to spinning at a precisely controlled speed. When the glass is fully liquefied, centrifugal force pulls it away from the center toward the edge, resulting in a smooth, concave surface very close to the ultimate shape of the mirror.
A competing mirror system will be used in Europe's V.L.T., the telescope that Dr. Giacconi will be directing. That system depends on computer-controlled mechanical devices pushing and pulling the back of each mirror to maintain its perfect optical shape. The four "meniscus mirrors," eight meters (26 feet) in diameter, being cast for the V.L.T. are much thinner and more flexible than conventional telescope mirrors. The system needed to keep them in shape while the telescope is tracking a celestial object is extremely complex.
The new Keck Telescope's 10-meter (33-foot) mirror, made of 36 independently mounted segments, is also kept in shape by active optics; astronomers have high hopes for this American giant.
If N.O.A.O. secures the needed financing, the agency hopes to build Gemini, a project involving two telescopes, each with an eight-meter mirror, in Hawaii and Chile. Although financing for the second telescope remains uncertain, if the project goes forward, Dr. Angel's spin-casting carousel may make the mirrors.
Despite the ingenious technology that has become available for advanced astronomical telescopes, "America will only remain competitive in astronomy if its managers resolve to back the science with consistent funding and wisely planned programs," Dr. Giacconi said. "As it is, American astronomy is only about on a par with that of Italy. That makes me proud, as an Italian-American, but I'd like to see us do better."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Riccardo Giacconi, Hubble Space Telescope chief scientist -- He says poor management of America's space and astronomy programs has hobbled efforts to compete with European science. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) (pg. C8)

HEADLINE: The Republicans: Unchanged

 BODY:
The platform that the Republican Convention adopted yesterday in Houston rings with partisan passion, but as a document to promote President Bush's campaign for re-election it lands with a disappointing thud.
Americans everywhere are grumbling over economic stagnation and long for new ideas. This platform supplies a ritualistic roster of old ones -- dogma that's not only tired but also discredited. By comparison, the 1992 Democratic program floats, lighter than air, on some utopian assumptions about growth. But at least it's a program. 
 Just how much the public wants action is dramatically documented in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Does the country need real change? An astounding 92 percent of the public answered "yes." Would electing Bill Clinton bring about real change? Fully 63 percent answered "yes." Would re-electing President Bush bring about real change? A mere 15 percent said "yes."
So what bold ideas does the platform advance? None. The Republicans proclaim their enduring devotion to a balanced budget amendment. They call for reneging on the 1990 Congressional budget agreement to hold down the deficit. They embrace deregulation so eagerly that they almost claim credit for President Carter's monumental oil and gas deregulation. And they embrace supply-side economics with a zeal that erases the memory of the huge Reagan-Bush deficits.
Underlying all the platform's economic proposals are two convictions: that tax hikes, for whatever purpose, hurt the economy; and that private investment is productive while public spending is inherently wasteful.
The Republicans surely have a strong argument that the proposals for public investments advocated by the Democrats could easily turn into euphemisms for old-fashioned pork if President Bush were not on hand with vigilant vetoes.
But the Republicans drive their argument out the window.
The test for investment is not whether it is private or public but whether it is productive. In truth, studies show that public investments -- wisely selected -- make substantial contributions to economic growth. Public investments in highways, fiber-optic telecommunications and training for disadvantaged workers can boost productivity more than equal amounts of private investment. The platform takes the cramped view that taxpayers see no benefit in helping educate other people's children; but most Americans aren't that shortsighted.
The platform writers have not seen a tax cut they don't like, a tax hike they don't despise. Mr. Clinton's proposed hike in payroll taxes to finance worker training is automatically wrong; yet tax giveaways to upper-income families or real estate investors are presumed to promote productivity.
The Republican platform rehearses the G.O.P.'s greatest hits. That may placate conservatives. But it will do little, in this financially fearful time, to address most Americans' fears.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Classical Music in Review

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:

Bonhoeffer Tribute
Union Theological Seminary
Last year, the Union Theological Seminary commissioned three composers to write works in honor of Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the German theologian and resistance figure who was executed in 1945 after participating in a plot to assassinate Hitler. On Sunday afternoon in the seminary's James Memorial Chapel, the three works were given their world premieres under the collective title "Altar Triptych for Bonhoeffer."
The concert celebrated Bonhoeffer both as a symbol of moral fortitude and for his connections with the seminary. He studied there in the early 1930's and returned briefly in 1939, before deciding that it was his responsibility to work in Germany. There he took the dangerous position that "only those who cry out for the Jews may also sing Gregorian chant." Now the seminary is raising $2 million to endow a Bonhoeffer Chair in Theology and Ethics. 
 The commissions were carefully ecumenical: Herman Berlinski, a Jewish composer who was born in Leipzig and has lived in the United States since 1941, provided the first panel, "Das Gebet Bonhoeffers" ("Bonhoffer's Prayer"). Heinz Werner Zimmermann, a Protestant organist who works in Frankfurt, composed the central panel, "Neujahrslied" ("New Year's Song"). And the concluding piece, "Cross and Freedom: Cantata for All Time," was composed by Robert M. Helmschrott, a Catholic organist from Munich.
The composers drew their texts mostly from the Bible and from Bonhoeffer's letters and poetry. All were sung in German, except for a quotation from Auden's "Friday's Child" in Mr. Helmschrott's work.
Mr. Berlinski's work reflected on Bonhoeffer's prison thoughts, his hope to be reconciled with his fiancee, and his prayers for salvation, both his own and the world's. Verses were presented by alternating groups. A soprano was accompanied by a flute and a celesta, a baritone by a cello and light percussion, the choir by the organ. Mr. Berlinski's writing is graceful, attractive, sometimes harmonically tense, and remarkably economical: the contrasts in spirit between the vocal and instrumental lines gave an impression of resolved tensions and emotional depth.
Mr. Zimmermann's piece, a straightforward choral setting of Bonhoeffer's poem "Von guten Machten" ("Powers of Good") with a Faure-like gentleness, is a serene centerpiece. And Mr. Helmschrott's four-movement cantata, the most expansive and colorfully scored of the works, also had the greatest intensity and drama.
The works were performed by members of the Dresden Chamber Choir, the Handel Choir of Baltimore, the Shir Chadash Chorale of Washington, and the Mount Vernon Chamber Orchestra. Hans-Christoph Rademann, the director of the Dresden group, conducted, and also led his choir in ravishing performances of works by Schutz, Bach and Brahms. There were also short compositions by Mr. Berlinski and by Mr. Helm schrott, for which the composers served as organist.

HEADLINE: A Profitable Insurer Gets Respect

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
While other large multiline insurance companies continue to stagger from real estate losses and weak markets, M. R. Greenberg's tightly run international empire, American International Group, last month reported results so characteristically positive that Wall Street once again greeted them with a yawn. Many analysts take for granted that A.I.G., under Mr. Greenberg, its chairman and chief executive, is the smartest and most successful large insurance company in America.
But on Wall Street, Mr. Greenberg is also something of a terror. 
 So formidable is his presence in the small community of insurance industry analysts and investment bankers that in a dozen recent interviews all but one insisted on not being quoted by name when discussing Mr. Greenberg, including those who had only positive things to say.
 Many said they feared that A.I.G.'s 67-year-old chairman might take offense at the slightest criticism. One wrong step, they said, and Mr. Greenberg would direct a blast at their bosses, or they would be cut off from Mr. Greenberg and A.I.G. as a valuable source of industry information and analysis.
Although analysts stressed that the company would receive excellent reviews in any case, they said that Mr. Greenberg had managed to make them hesitant to be the first publicly to question A.I.G. and its prospects for the future.
"His grasp of the industry and where it is going seems almost omniscient," said Myron Picoult, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "But, yes, he can be very intimidating."
Indeed, few challenge Mr. Greenberg's recent decisions to enlarge the company's presence in areas that the industry considers unpromising and unprofitable. With little fanfare, for example, A.I.G. has been slowly increasing its involvement in personal automobile insurance in the last year by investing in a company that specializes in inner-city auto claims. And Mr. Greenberg says he expects a major push in this decade into the life insurance business in the United States, which he avoided in the glory years of the 1970's and 1980's
"If you ask what is today's global financial powerhouse, I'd argue it's not American Express, it's not Citibank, it's A.I.G.," said Michael Frinquelli, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. "This is a big company but when you look at the piece of the market they control worldwide it is tiny. There is still a lot of room for growth."
Perhaps analysts' confidence stems from the fact that since Mr. Greenberg took charge 24 years ago, A.I.G. has outshone other American insurers by keeping down costs with an iron discipline and spotting niches for growth where no one else saw them. A.I.G. has concentrated on strict underwriting and finding sometimes obscure market niches like insurance covering kidnappings and ransoms, oil rigs, and directors' and officers' liabilities.
Profits have grown from $17.2 million in 1968 to $1.5 billion in 1991 on revenues of nearly $17 billion. The stock of A.I.G. has risen mightily in the last decade, up more than four times its 1981 level. But the share price has been meandering in a range of $72 to $101 for the last 18 months.
Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the shares closed at $97.125, down 37.5 cents. As of January of this year Mr. Greenberg owned 4.7 million shares, or 2.2 percent of the stock.
Visitors to Mr. Greenberg's office on Pine Street in the financial district of Manhattan are confronted with one of New York's world-class power walls: there are five photos of President Bush with A.I.G.'s chairman, four Ronald Reagans, two Henry Kissingers, one Jimmy Carter, one Gerald Ford, a Corazon Aquino, a Ferdinand Marcos and a Deng Xiaoping. There is also an autographed Harry S. Truman.
On the afternoon of a recent interview, Mr. Greenberg allowed a visitor several minutes to take in his office before he entered, a short, trim man with a gentle voice and a disarming smile. Asked about his effect on analysts, Mr. Greenberg responded with a quizzical shrug: "What can I tell you about what goes on in people's heads?"
 
Overseas Roots
 A.I.G., whose roots go back to a tiny insurance office established in Shanghai, China, in 1919, is now the pre-eminent underwriter of big-ticket commercial insurance in the United States and the only American insurance company with nearly half its business overseas. The company has ridden the growth of foreign economies, particularly in Asia, something that other American insurers have generally lacked the desire or expertise to do.
Last quarter, earnings from A.I.G.'s mostly international life insurance business surged 16 percent, supported in particular by growth in Southeast Asia and Japan. In Malaysia and Thailand, for example, life insurance earnings grew 39 and 24 percent, respectively. The multiline carriers like Aetna, Travelers and Cigna, meanwhile, continued to report bad news as a result of the real estate investments in their domestic life insurance businesses.
A.I.G.'s Financial Services, which includes worldwide investment banking, asset management and airplane leasing, showed a 65.6 percent increase in pretax operating income, compared with the corresponding period last year.
In the weak property-casualty business, where companies are suffering from seemingly endless low prices caused by competition in commercial liability lines, A.I.G.'s operating income was down 3 percent in the quarter compared with last year. But its performance in that area remained stronger than that of most competitors, in large part because it kept its operating expenses at 20 percent, about 10 percentage points below the industry average.
 
Assertive Personality
 Mr. Greenberg's persona seems to define the company, from the advertisements in national magazines like The Atlantic and Newsweek that rail against the nation's policies on litigation and environmental waste (issues that are critical to the company's future) to sharp-tongued telephone calls that his executives can expect to receive on any day of the week, from anywhere in the world. Mr. Greenberg refuses to join insurance trade organizations and occasionally makes cracks about the low average intelligence of others in the industry.
On Wall Street, many analysts say that Mr. Greenberg, a United States Army Ranger in World War II, can attack with a forcefulness that is highly unusual in the traditionally soft-spoken industry.
They point to the case of Michael A. Smith, a Shearson Lehman analyst who in February 1990 wrote some mildly critical comments about TransAtlantic Holdings, a reinsurance company that did business with A.I.G. and in which A.I.G. had a 41 percent stake.
A.I.G.'s protests included a vehement letter from Mr. Greenberg to Shearson's chief operating officer, Howard L. Clark Jr. Less than a month later, Shearson, in a highly unusual move, put out another report summarizing and quoting Mr. Greenberg's objections without offering any additional commentary.
"We spoke with him," Mr. Greenberg said of Mr. Smith, "and said we think this is wrong, and he refused to make a change until we spoke to his boss about a change."
Mr. Smith said that Shearson's second report was not a retraction and that his superiors had put no pressure on him to alter his conclusions.
In another case, in 1990, Public Citizen, the Washington-based consumer group associated with Ralph Nader, published a report questioning the solvency of A.I.G. and four other insurers -- a report that was criticized by many experts. But it was Mr. Greenberg alone among industry executives who held a news conference to protest; hired Floyd Abrams, a prominent First Amendment lawyer, and threatened to sue. Public Citizen soon issued a news release saying it did not, in fact, mean to say that A.I.G. could become insolvent.
"There are very few people who have the stomach to cross him," one prominent analyst said. "He has the memory of an elephant and there is the fear that he will make it difficult for you to do business with him again."
Sitting in his paneled office, Mr. Greenberg asserted that he was simply aggressive in correcting errors about A.I.G. "I suppose," he said, "we are very passionate about what we believe in."
The great unknowns on the company's future are the outcome of toxic- waste cleanup litigation, which could result in hundreds of billions of dollars in unpredicted costs to insurers like A.I.G., and the matter of who will take over after Mr. Greenberg retires.
Mr. Greenberg, as he often has in the past, declined to say who his successor might be or when he would retire, although he has hinted that his retirement is not imminent. He also said it was impossible to estimate how high the cost of environmental cleanups could eventually be for the company. It is a subject, he acknowledged, "I think about when I go to sleep; I think about when I wake up."
Mr. Greenberg said that the company for the first time sees great opportunities in the domestic life insurance business. Until now, the business has made up only 1 percent to 5 percent of its life insurance operating income, but Mr. Greenberg has assembled a team to expand on his belief that in the next decade it could account for more than 20 percent of A.I.G.'s life insurance operating income.
Many experts argue that the life insurance market has passed its prime because of demographic shifts like the aging of the baby boomers. But Mr. Greenberg disagrees. "You can get better margins than a few years ago because people are more interested in security than reaching for the more competitive product," he said. "Where there is a troubled field there are opportunities."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 22, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the success of American International Group misstated some of the company's results. Its new life insurance premiums grew 39 percent in Malaysia and 24 percent in Thailand last year. The figures did not represent earnings increases.

HEADLINE: Report Finds An Embattled Crown Hts.

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
With an edgy Crown Heights marking the anniversary of last summer's racially charged disturbances, a coalition of community leaders has taken a second look at the neighborhood and found a community suffering from high unemployment, AIDS, an overwhelming influx of immigrants and overtaxed city services.
The report, prepared by 40 educators, civic leaders and clergyman in an effort to examine the underlying causes of the disturbances, also called youth services in Crown Heights "grossly inadequate." A third of 235,000 residents of Crown Heights are under the age of 24. 
 The study by the Crown Heights Coalition was one of many efforts to commemorate the victims of last summer's violence in this community, where blacks and Hasidic Jews live a tense coexistence. At St. Anthony Baptist Church, several hundred people gathered last night for a memorial service for Gavin Cato, the 7-year-old boy who was killed last year when a car from the entourage of the Lubavitch Hasidic spiritual leader spun out of control and jumped a curb. The accident touched off four days of violence.
 
'It Is a Shame'
 Outside the church, vans full of police officers lined the streets, and nearby, hidden behind a park, scores of officers waited with riot gear. Inside, the Rev. Al Sharpton condemned the criminal justice system because a grand jury failed to indict the driver of the car.
"It is a shame that any child died," he said, as some in the audience shouted their agreement. "It is more than a shame when nothing is done about the death of a child."
He then led about 300 demonstrators on a peaceful candle-lighted march for four blacks to President Street, where the boy was struck and died.
Echoing complaints from last year, several marchers contended that the Hasidic community received preferential treatment from the police and the city.
The report by the Crown Heights Coalition also touched on the persistent racial divide in the community. It found that the Jewish youths it surveyed thought that police services in their community were good, while the black and Hispanic youths felt they were "very poor." The 686 youths who were questioned for that part of the study were randomly selected from local high schools.
The report did not examine the attitudes and perceptions that black and Hasidic residents have toward each other; instead it outlined the social problems of the inner-city neighborhood as a whole. The violence last summer, the 80-page report noted, "reflected the anger and alienation, aggravated over time of different communities within Crown Heights who believe their urgent social needs were being ignored."
The report, which was commissioned by Borough President Howard Golden, is to be released today at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden during an official ceremony to commemorate the victims of the violence. The trouble began on the night of Aug. 19, 1991, when a car in the motorcade of the Lubavitch spiritual leader, Rebbe Menachem M. Schneerson, jumped a curb, killing Gavin Cato, and seriously injuring his 7-year-old cousin, Angela Cato.
Three hours later, in what the authorities have called revenge, a 29-year-old Hasidic scholar, Yankel Rosenbaum, was stabbed five blocks away by a band of black youths. He died later at Kings County Hospital. For four days the Brooklyn community was engulfed in violence.
 
'No Justice, No Peace'
 The marchers last night, led by Mr. Sharpton, the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, and the Cato family, were peaceful, chanting, "No justice, no peace," and "Whose streets? Our streets," as they moved to the corner of President Street and Utica Avenue, and placed candles and a wreath near a faded red cross painted on the sidewalk to mark the spot where Gavin Cato was killed.
Scores of people lined Utica Avenue, watching the demonstration. "I can't afford to protest," said Al Johnson, 20, who said he was arrested when he participated in a march last year. "I think it's right for them to protest but they should do it in a decent way."
The lone confrontation last night occurred when a Hasidic man, Mark Cohen, waded into the demonstrators, saying he wanted to hear Mr. Sharpton. "Get out of here. Get out of here," the black demonstrators shouted at him, and he was escorted away by the police.
By 10 P.M., about 50 demonstrators remained on President Street across from a unity mural recently painted by black and Hasidic artists. They chanted approvingly when some in the group smeared white paint across all the white faces on the mural.
Last week, Rabbi Shmuel Butman, one of the Lubavitch leaders, called on Mayor David N. Dinkins to ban any demonstrations in Crown Heights during the anniversary period, but he later backed away from the request.
"We are concerned, we are very concerned," Rabbi Butman said yesterday. "Basically what we want is the right to live and for the women and children to walk in security and safety in our community."
Late yesterday afternoon, David Elnakam, who identified himself as the national director of the Jewish militant group Kahane Chai, said 50 armed members of his organization were patrolling Crown Heights.
In the year since Crown Heights erupted in violence, the Crown Heights Coalition has labored to achieve some measure of understanding between blacks in the community, and the Lubavitch Hasidim, an ultra orthodox Jewish sect that has its world headquarters on Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights.
The coalition's report found that in some parts of Crown Heights, AIDS has become the third leading cause of death, killing 511 males per 100,000, according to figures compiled in 1988. Citywide AIDS was also the third leading cause of death, but the rate of death for males was lower, at 333 per 100,000, according to Marilyn Gelber, the executive assistant to Mr. Golden.
The coalition reported that unemployment among men, in Crown Heights, according to the 1990 census, was at 13.2 percent, compared with 10.6 percent overall for Brooklyn. The study said the 22,000 immigrants who moved to Crown Heights in recent years had strained the capacity of nearly every day-care center in the community. Crown Heights's public schools are the fourth most crowded in the city.
The coalition called for creation of a New Deal-style Crown Heights Youth Corps that would employ teen-agers to work as crisis prevention counselors and in neighborhood cleanup projects. It also urged, among other points, that Crown Heights get prevention and treatment programs for AIDS; that conflict resolution programs be put in the schools; that "Safe Corridors" under extra police protection be created for students walking to neighborhood schools, and that police officers be required to live in New York City.
Rabbi Shea Hecht, the co-chairman of the coalition along with Dr. Edison O. Jackson, the president of Medgar Evers College, said the group's greatest achievement was that Hasidic and black representatives had worked together for a year and "that we were able to understand some of the difficulties of the other community."
"To make the difference on the street," he added, "will take a long time."
