HEADLINE: Sluggish Trading Ends With Dow Up 4.59

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market finished higher in sluggish trading yesterday despite losses in share prices abroad and a worse-than-expected Government economic report.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 4.59, to 3,329.48. Advancing issues outnumbered declines, 9 to 8, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Volume on the Big Board came to a moderate 171.8 million shares, up from 152.8 million in the previous session.
Share prices held up well despite negative signals from the economy and foreign stock markets, said Gordon Wilson, senior vice president with Kemper Financial Services Inc. The Commerce Department reported that housing starts in July fell 2.8 percent.
Traders apparently took their cue from rising bond prices. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond rose 3/8 point, pushing down its yield to 7.33 percent.
A few earnings reports and other corporate news moved individual stocks yesterday, but there was no apparent broad movement in the market.
The most actively traded Big Board issues included Kroger, which fell 1 7/8, to 11 5/8. Kroger, a supermarket operator, said its third-quarter results might be no better than break even.
Among other active issues, Toys "R" Us rose 1 1/2, to 38 1/2, after reporting a 61 percent jump in second-quarter earnings.
Hewlett-Packard fell 3 3/8, to 57 1/4, after reporting disappointing third-quarter earnings.
CMS Energy fell 1/4, to 15 1/2, after Oxford Energy said it was seeking Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors following a breakdown in talks with a CMS unit. Oxford also said it was unable to repay CMS loans.
Aetna Life and Casualty fell 7/81, to 43 1/8, after saying it would post a smaller-than-expected profit on the $1.4 billion sale of its American Re-Insurance Company subsidiary.
 
A Solid Earnings Gain
 In over-the-counter trading, System Software rose 2 5/8, to 26 5/8, after announcing solid third-quarter earnings.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.30, to 231.90. On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index lost 0.13, to 386.81. The Nasdaq index fell 1.60, to 570.87.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Housing starts slumped 2.8 percent in July, even though mortgage rates are at the lowest level in two decades. The Commerce Department also revised downward data for May and June, meaning housing had become a drag on the economy's lackluster recovery, instead of pacing it. [Page D1.]
How can George Bush cast off the economic albatross? Three possibilities are to pursue a supply-side approach, try Ross Perot's no-hostage approach to eradicating the budget deficit or to dust off Keynesian intervention. Peter Passell: Economic Watch. [D1.] 
 Federal prosecutors offered to delay trying Clark Clifford and Robert Altman until after they had stood trial in New York on fraud and bribery charges related to B.C.C.I. A U.S. District Judge said she would decide on Sept. 10 whether to accept their offer. [D2.]
 
International
Japan set emergency measures to halt stocks' plunge, trying to persuade big investors not to sell, but analysts called the package anemic. The Nikkei average slid 620.14 points, or 4.2 percent, to 14,309.41, its lowest level in more than six years. [A1.]
A $1 billion global telephone network is planned by BT, the British giant, but analysts see many obstacles. [D4.]
 
Companies
Wang Laboratories filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors, and plans to cut 5,000 from its work force of 13,000. Its shares lost half their value, closing at 37.5 cents on the Amex. [D1.]
Chrysler won agreement on a new $6.8 billion loan from the last of 152 banks. The new loan will assure dealers and customers of a source of financing for vehicles and remove a big uncertainty from the company's balance sheet, but at higher interest. [D1.]
American Airlines will raise fares 15 to 25 percent on transcontinental flights and on some through its big hubs. [D5.]
Air Canada announced an alliance with United Airlines that will make transfers by passengers easier. [D5.]
Three credit bureaus agreed to settle Federal charges on the release of sensitive data about people, the F.T.C. said. [D5.]
SmithKline Beecham and Marion Merrell Dow plan a partnership on nonprescription heartburn and nicotine patch drugs. [D4.]
Wasserstein, Perella insists that a talent drain of the last 18 months is no reflection on the firm's fortunes, and Robert B. McKeon, the latest, agrees. Detractors are not persuaded. [D5.]
Hewlett-Packard reported slightly lower earnings of $191 million, and its stock tumbled by $3.375 a share. [D4.] Dell Computer's net income surged 76.6 percent, sending its shares up $2.125. [D4.]
 
Markets
Stocks edged up in sluggish trading despite negative economic signals, with the Dow Jones up 4.59 to 3,329.48. [D6.] The bond market advanced modestly, as traders moved to shorter maturities, widening the spreads with the Treasury's long bond. [D14.]
Both the dollar and gold drifted downward as traders reacted to the housing news. [D15.] Cocoa futures surged, reflecting concern that an African drought would result in tight supplies. [D15.]
 
Business Technology
Japanese researchers are nearing completion of a strategic technology: an electronic English-Japanese dictionary that will allow computers to translate documents. [D5.]
Canary Wharf's mirrored surface is bouncing ghost signals that BBC engineers have not been able to exorcise. [D5.]
 
Today's Columns
The resignation of Todd Shipyards' directors' audit committee because of differences with the company's managers was but one sign of trouble at a company beset by lawsuits. Market Place. [D6.]
Arthur Ashe's lead in the fight against AIDS has attracted marketers like Aetna, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Visa U.S.A. to an all-star tennis tournament. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
3 Wishes: Ways for Bush to Prime Economy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
With unemployment seemingly stuck near 8 percent and consumers guarding their paychecks as if each would be the last, is George Bush fated to play out the election campaign as Herbert Hoover to Bill Clinton's rendition of F.D.R.?
The White House has taken pains to scotch rumors that he would announce some dramatic initiative for jump-starting the economy. And some economists hope they mean what they say, arguing that the present course is the best course for a stable, noninflationary economy. 
 But many of Mr. Bush's supporters think otherwise. While there are infinite variations on what the President might do to try to win public confidence in his economic prowess, three alternatives stand out:
 
1981 All Over Again
 Within months of entering the White House, Ronald Reagan persuaded Congress to slash taxes, setting the stage for seven years of economic growth. Only in the late 1980's, when old-fashioned Republicans ganged up with liberal Democrats to resume the tax-and-spend policies of the past, did the economy run out of gas.
That, at any rate, is how Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and other supply-siders see it. Mr. Kemp, along with six New Right members of Congress, are pressing the President to embrace the supply-side revolution as his own. This would include an across-the-board tax cut, a freeze in discretionary Government spending, radical welfare reform and a zero-inflation target for the Fed.
But the President's invitation to a supply-side party does not guarantee that anyone would attend, says Rudolph Penner, an economist at KPMG Peat Marwick. Most of the supply-side agenda would require legislation, and there is little reason to think Congress would entertain radical reforms of any sort before the election.
Indeed, much of what Mr. Kemp proposes has already been rejected by the legislators. Yet another brushoff could backfire, leaving the impression that Mr. Bush is an ineffectual leader. Or worse, a dissembling one. The President's advisers, who think the supply-siders are intellectual lightweights, would only advance supply-side initiatives that were sure to die. "Four years ago George Bush's word was his bond," said Jude Wanniski, president of Polyconomics, a consulting firm in Morristown, N.J. "Now the voters demand collateral."
Mr. Wanniski, who spearheaded the supply-siders' 1980 assault on Washington, has the collateral in mind. He believes the President could index capital gains to prices by executive order, cutting the effective tax rate with the stroke of a pen.
The effect would be striking. A share of stock purchased for $100 in 1979, for example, would be taxed only on the gain above $200, since the price level has since doubled. Milton Friedman, who teaches at Stanford's Hoover Institution, argued that the Administration had been "stupid" to pursue lower capital gains taxes when "indexing the base makes more sense economically and politically."
The obstacle, apart from Mr. Bush's innate caution, is a legal one. C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, has ruled that the President does not have the authority to index capital gains. But Lawrence Zelenak, a professor of law at the University of North Carolina, thinks a determined President could succeed in stretching his powers. "Despite the invalidity of regulatory indexing," he wrote in the May 11, 1992, issue of Tax Notes, "indexing would probably be immune from judicial challenge" because no one could make the case they had been injured by the initiative.
 
The Radical Middle
 If George Bush loses the election, goes the now-familiar refrain, it is because he could not coax back the suburbanites and blue-collar elite, sometime-Republicans who defected to Ross Perot. One way to win them over would be to adopt Mr. Perot's take-no-prisoners program for eliminating the budget deficit in five years.
But the Perot plan relied on tax increases and cuts in social entitlement spending. Thus in wooing votes from the radicalized middle, Mr. Bush might further alienate those stung by his betrayal of the read-my-lips pledge. And it would certainly anger affluent retirees who would take home less Social Security and pay more for health care. The Perot initiative "appeals to budget nerds like me," Mr. Penner said. But any plan that "asks for short-term suffering in the name of long-term gains is politically risky," he concluded.
There is also the worry that it would lengthen the recession. In the long run, a smaller deficit would free resources for private investment, lowering interest rates and presumably increasing growth. But it is hardly the medicine of choice for smoothing the business cycle. "I would be happy to wake up in five years with a 50-cent gas tax," said Robert Solow of M.I.T. But the immediate effect of Federal tax increases, he noted, would be fewer jobs and less income.
 
Born-Again Keynesianism
 "We are all Keynesians now," Richard Nixon concluded in 1971. Fiscal fine-turning is again out of fashion, at least in Republican circles. But by advocating tax cuts or spending increases, President Bush might connect with the people who count most -- voters who fear for their jobs. And by dressing it up in supply-side rhetoric he might make it palatable to the right. "Distinguishing between Keynesian and supply-side stimulus is a matter of spin and timing," said Benjamin Friedman of Harvard.
The President would not have to look far, were he so inclined. An appeal signed by 100 economists this spring called for a swift disbursal of cash to state and local governments to prevent cutbacks in construction projects. Mr. Bush might add some job-stimulating tax breaks.
The one big drawback: no direct impact before the election. "The action might not be visible for six months," Mr. Solow conceded.
Will the White House go for broke anytime soon? "They're in the grip of timidity and paralysis," Mr. Wanniski said, and they hope to increase the President's clout by tried and true means. "They'll hand off through the right tackle, " he concluded, "when they should be throwing bombs."

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Excerpts From the Remarks By Housing Secretary Kemp

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks tonight by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp at the Republican National Convention, as transcribed by Reuters.
Several months ago -- several months ago I had lunch with the former Mayor of Moscow. I asked him how he got elected. He said, "Mr. Kemp, I told all the people in state-owned housing that they should have the right to own their own home. I told them they should have the right to sell them for a profit and leave their property to their children." And then the Mayor of Moscow said, "I pledged to make downtown Moscow a free enterprise zone." I said Mr. Mayor, where did you get these radical ideas? He said, "Mr. Kemp, I got them from the 1980 Republican platform of Ronald Reagan and George Bush." 
 Ladies and gentlemen, communism didn't fall. It was pushed. It was our ideas that did the pushing and our Republican Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush that helped change the world. Now we must change America.
Our goals for this nation must be nothing less than to double the size of our economy and bring prosperity and jobs, ownership and equality of opportunity to all Americans, especially those living in our nation's pockets of poverty.
Think of what that growth would mean: more jobs, a higher living standard for the people, extraordinary opportunities for all Americans, and the resources to meet our most ambitious goals, public and private.
But make no mistake. If we are to change America, we must change the United States Congress.
We must give President Bush . . . and Vice President Quayle a Republican Congress to help get America moving again and finally wage a winning war against poverty and despair. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	My fellow Americans, the liberal Democrats just don't get it. They don't understand that you can't create more employees without first creating more employers, that you can't have capitalism without capital, and we can't expect people to defend property rights when they're denied access to property. But when people have a stake in the system, they'll not only defend their own property, they'll help their neighbor defend his property as well.
You see, you see, this is the message of Los Angeles. This is the message of every other pocket of poverty in America. We must be the party that gives all people a stake in the system, and a stake in each other. That's what the re-election of George Bush means to America. . . .
Ladies and gentlemen, this is a great cause. We've got a great team. And let me say as an old football player who played in this very stadium: we've got a great quarterback in George Bush.
And, Mr. President, give them hell Thursday night.

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Excerpts From Keynote Address by Phil Gramm

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks last night by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas at the Republican National Convention, as transcribed by The New York Times.
When you count up the number of nations liberated from Soviet tyranny -- when you total up the population freed from the Marxist yoke -- when you add up the puppet despots whose support from Moscow has now been yanked away, ours is the greatest victory in the history of freedom. 
 It was Ronald Reagan who put the Kremlin in the cross hairs but it was George Bush who pulled the trigger.
If Jimmy Carter -- if Jimmy Carter had been re-elected in 1980, if Walter Mondale had won in 1984, if Michael Dukakis had been elected President in 1988, the Berlin Wall would still be standing today. And all we marvel at in the world today would be a wishful dream. Leadership is the difference. It has changed the world, it has brought us more than peace; George Bush's leadership has brought us victory.
With this victory secured, President Bush instituted a long-term build-down in defense, saving $300 billion for deficit reduction and tax cuts for working families.
But Governor Clinton and the Democrats don't want to build down defense, they want to tear it down. If they succeed in implementing the Clinton plan, one million people now in uniform and civilian defense jobs will be thrown into the streets and defense -- and defense as a percentage of the budget will plunge below the level that existed on Dec. 7 of 1941.
We have not forgotten that the last Democrat in the White House so decimated defense that on any given day, 50 percent of our planes couldn't fly and our ships couldn't sail, because we didn't have spare parts and mechanics. So bad was pay for the military that many enlisted personnel and their families qualified for food stamps.
Under Republican leadership, we changed all that. We modernized our weapons and we recruited and have retained the finest young men and women who have ever worn the uniform of this country. And they wear that uniform all over the world tonight with a new pride and a new confidence, and we Republicans are committed to keeping it that way.
We must never -- we must never allow the Democrats to disarm America again.
There are tyrants in the world and there will be tyrants in the future. And when reason and diplomacy fail, we must have an Army and a Navy, and an Air Force, and a Marine corps that do not fail. Even in a world where the lion and the lamb are about to lie down together, we Republicans are committed to the principle that the United States of America must always be the lion.

 	 	 		. . .	 	To fight back against the drug thugs who prey off the health, happiness and lives of our children, 1,161 days ago today, the President sent Congress the nation's toughest anti-crime/anti-drug bill. It restored the Federal death penalty. Under our bill, no matter who your daddy is or how society has done you wrong, if you sell drugs to a child you're going to jail and you're going to serve every day of 10 years in a Federal penitentiary. And when you finally get out of prison, if you do it again, you're going back to prison and this time you're going back for life.
Had Congress said yes, we would have grabbed the drug thugs by the throat. But the Democrats said no.
You see, the Democrats still blame society, not criminals, for crime! And not content with just gutting the President's bill, the Democrats went on to overturn 22 Supreme Court decisions that had strengthened law enforcement, that had empowered the cop on the beat to protect law-abiding citizens. So bad was their bill that 15 state Democrat attorneys general, not to mention 16 Republicans, urged the President to veto the Democrats' "pro-criminal" bill.
America's problem today, America's problem today is not that the President's plan to energize the economy has failed. Our problem is that it has not been tried. It is not that the President did not ask for change but that the Democrats who run Congress killed those changes. The President asked for the tools to put our people back to work. The President asked for the weapons to win back our streets. And the Democrats bent them and broke them and threw them away.
To paraphrase Winston Churchill: Give us the tools and we will finish the job. Give us a Republican Congress and we will put our people back to work and we will put criminals in jail where they belong.
Democrats, Democrats and Republicans agree on one thing: We both want change. The debate is not about who is for change; it's about the direction of the change. Today America stands at the crossroads. It's time for choosing: their way of more taxing or our way of more jobs; their way of more government or our way of more opportunity.
The change Republicans want today is to stop the growth of government, to bring spending under control, to balance the budget and to cut taxes again. The change the Democrats want is to go back to the tax and spend policies they gave us in the 70's, the last time there was a Democrat in the White House.
Did you notice that at their convention in New York, the Democrats hid their Congressional leaders? Poor -- poor Speaker Tom Foley and majority leader George Mitchell were hidden so far back in the crowd that you had to press your nose right up against the TV screen and get out a magnifying glass to see them.

 	 	 		. . .	 	At the New York convention, Clinton was like a used car salesman peddling his vehicle for change. The wax job was shiny, the hubcaps sparkled, the upholstery was spotless, the paint was new. But when you look under the hood, he's peddling a model from the 1970's: a Carter mobile with the axle broken and the frame bent to the left. It was a lemon for the nation; it was a lemon for the nation in the 1970's when it sent inflation through the roof and income through the floor, and it is a lemon for America today.

HEADLINE: UNDER THE DOME: On Stage;
A 32-Year Congressman Joins The Attack on His Colleagues

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
A politician rarely does what he wants, but mostly he does what he must.
The House minority leader, Robert H. Michel, is 59 years old, and he has served in the House of Representatives for 32 years. The Democrats have controlled the House for every one of those years. But Mr. Michel, an affable man, always got along with them, and was always known as someone who took pride in the institution he has made his life's work. 
 But in a convention where criticizing Congress has become an obligatory part of the oratory, Mr. Michel did the necessary tonight, and smilingly trashed his home.
Denouncing what "38 years of misrule have done to an institution," Mr. Michel called Congress "a bloated bureaucracy," that could not "even run a branch Post Office." He went on about the disgrace of the House and for his troubles, won modest applause, and a few cheers.
 
What? Get Out of My Chair? And What's 'the Wave?'
 The floor of the Astrodome, where the delegates sit in neat rows of red chairs, is a decorous place. There is nothing at issue here -- nothing to vote on except a platform and two candidates about whom party debate is over -- and the hall is too big for the kind of crowding that helped the Democrats generate some sense of excitement.
It is left to the floor whips, well-groomed young men and women in green baseball hats, to enliven the crowd, cruising the aisles and trying to teach Republicans to act rowdy. It was an uphill job.
Most people remained seated, their emotions well under control. As Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts took to the stage, an effort was made among the Maryland and California delegates to stage a series of body "waves" as sports fans do without the aid of whips.
Even before they tried, however, there was a certain foreboding. "We're going to do a wave, but probably most folks here have never even been to a ball game," said a California delegate. "I think we're kind of nervous."
The first wave was weak and ragged. The second was considerably worse. By the fourth attempt the whips had given up.
 
The Very Thin Line Between Wit and Witlessness
 It was bound to be a problem. With 40 to 50 speakers a day all saying much the same thing -- Bill Clinton is no good and the Democrats are rotten to the core -- there must inevitably be a certain overreaching, a stepping across the line that divides oratory and inanity.
In the category of Most Cruelly Tortured Metaphor, the evening's winner was Gov. John Engler of Michigan, who, apparently driven by home-state pride, found himself in an endless string of automotive metaphors.
He began by suggesting "a look under the hood," of the President's record, went on to note that "the Clinton-Gore model is no Lincoln, it's a lemon" that had a "slick paint job" but that could "only turn left." And, he said, it had "already had a test drive in Arkansas" and done poorly.
The award for Most Awkward Observation was garnered by Commerce Secretary Barbara Hackman Franklin for claiming that Mr. Clinton's "whole vision of commerce has been shaped while on the Government payroll." Quite true, perhaps, but unfortunate for inviting comparison with Mr. Bush, who spent all but 4 of the last 28 years on the Government payroll.
A gaudy yet cheap trophy for Most Tasteless Line went to Governor Weld for a rumination that combined basic economics with basic biology: "The Democrats' taxing and spending habits remind me of that old definition of a baby: a huge appetite on one end and no sense of responsibility on the other."
An honorary Oscar went to the actor Bruce Willis, for his explanation of why he supported President Bush: "It's a big desk and I want someone who's had the experience of sitting behind it before."
The Grand Over All Overreacher Award, in a hands-down, no-contest triumph, was Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. "In any hut in any village on the planet," he said, "one world leader is loved, honored and admired above all others. Spoken in a thousand dialects, his name is George Bush."

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 3; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1173 words

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS IN HOUSTON: News Analysis;
G.O.P. Is Flirting With the Dangers of Negativism

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Richard N. Bond, the fiercely combative Republican chairman, says his party is fighting a "cultural war" with the Democrats. But there is also a cultural war taking place within the Republican ranks here, a war that pits conservatism with a snarl against conservatism with a smile.
Both are on display in the Astrodome this week, and both will probably be on display throughout the campaign. The question is, which will President Bush emphasize in his acceptance speech on Thursday night? Which will he emphasize in his campaign oratory and in his television commercials? And which, if either, will work? 
 It is hard to say. Mr. Bush is a political version of the 19th-century Yankee merchant, always genteel and mannerly in private but sometimes cunning and ruthless in business. He has said he will do whatever he needs to win re-election, and he commented when he arrived here, "I have always done better when I fight back."
 
Strategy of Divisiveness
 He has also employed, this year as four years ago, accomplished political rabbit punchers who think divisiveness often wins elections.
Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Bush's erstwhile primary opponent, epitomized the scowling face of conservatism on the convention's first day. We are America, he said in effect, and the rest of you are not. But former President Ronald Reagan, eloquent still at 81 years of age, urged his fellow Republicans to keep their eyes fixed on his metaphorical "shining city on the hill."
Today Mr. Bond conceded that "George Bush and Pat Buchanan have some differences of opinion on a lot of subjects," but he also said, "Pat Buchanan's speech was brilliant, and I think that he is now on Bill Clinton's tail." James Lake, another top Republican manager, argued that Mr. Buchanan's denunciations of homosexuals, feminists and liberals in general would give needed help to the ticket in Orange County, Calif., a Republican bastion that in years past would have long since been locked up by the party.
 
'Not Comfortable With That'
 But many in the party, equally conservative, made no secret of their displeasure at the tenor of Mr. Buchanan's speech and others like it, including one by Attorney General Dan Lungren of California this morning in which he revived the Willie Horton theme that the Republicans used against Michael S. Dukakis in 1988.
Asked how Mr. Buchanan's pitch would play in Wisconsin this fall, the state's Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, replied, "I don't think it will," grimaced and walked away.
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the most influential Republican spokesman on foreign policy on Capitol Hill, was more explicit.
"Pat's message is not a very appealing one for most Americans, and it's not a winning message," he said at a breakfast meeting with reporters. "You don't build majorities by excluding whole groups of people, and you don't have to be nasty to be conservative. I wish they'd cut it out, especially the attacks on Hillary. I'm not comfortable with that at all."
Mr. Lugar said he hoped the President and most Republican candidates would "try to make the Republican message more inclusive." Nothing would really matter, he said, unless the President offered the convention "a set of ideas that adds up to some potential for real economic change for average people, and not just broad principles and more attacks on Congress."
But the Republicans, even the conservatives, are deeply split between two approaches, each favored by one of the contenders for the party's Presidential nomination in 1996. They both spoke tonight. Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp favors tax cuts to stimulate the economy, an idea that Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who wants to balance the budget before anything else, calls "free-lunch politics."
In his speech tonight, Mr. Kemp did no lobbying for reduced taxes, but he eagerly identified himself with the Reagan approach. He said his party's purpose was "not to denounce the past, but to inspire our nation to a better future." Mr. Gramm did the same, bashing the Democrats' policies but avoiding divisive language, and pledging that "America's third century will be our greatest century."
The Republicans sent to the platform this morning and tonight a racially and ideologically diverse series of speakers, including a dozen women, with advocates and opponents of abortion rights among them.
They called the Democrats the party of April 15 and themselves the party of July 4. They described affirmative action for minorities as a snare and a delusion. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, mocked Mr. Clinton as an advocate of "taxation without hesitation."
 
Verbal Flame Throwing
 Most drew back from Buchanan-style demonization. The former White House speech writer had slashed away at Governor Clinton, picturing him as a "draft-dodger" who lacked "the moral authority to call on Americans to put their lives at risk." He had described Hillary Clinton as the standard-bearer of "radical feminism" and arch-enemy of the family.
After a daylong uproar over Mr. Buchanan's tactics, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia was one of the few who leapt into the fray at his side. Mr. Gingrich accused the Democrats of promoting "a multicultural, nihilistic hedonism that is inherently destructive of a healthy society."
On the floor, delegates held up small signs that asked, "If Hillary can't trust him, how can we?" in an allusion to the charges about the private life of the Democratic nominee. A big banner also went up picturing a marijuana leaf with the caption, "Bill Clinton's Smoking Gun."
This is a frustrated convention, unable quite to comprehend what has gone wrong after 12 years of soaring electoral success, unsure exactly what to do about it. Frustration breeds bitterness, and much of that has spilled out in attacks on Democrats, the Clintons and reporters and commentators.
Mr. Reagan was never one for bitterness or meanness of spirit, even in the heat of combat, and his sunny, optimistic spirit shone through his speech. He was partisan enough, heaping scorn on the Democrats on Capitol Hill: "the gavel-wielding chairmen, the bloated staffs, the taxers and takers and Congressional rule makers." But he emphasized his own accomplishments and George Bush's abilities, not any personal failings of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton.
 
Including the Outsiders
 The former President chose the rhetoric of inclusion, reminding delegates that "we are all equal in the eyes of God -- whether we come from poverty or wealth, whether we are Afro-American or Irish-American, Christian or Jewish, from big cities or small towns."
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., who served as political director in the Reagan White House, liked what his old boss had to say. Mr. Reagan, he said, "has saved conservatives from the perils of negativisim before, and maybe he can get us on the right course again with the positive tone of his speech."
Later in the day, it was announced that Mr. Daniels would be joining the Bush campaign team.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fell 2.8% in July

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Despite the lowest mortgage rates since the early 1970's, the pace at which builders broke ground for new homes slumped 2.8 percent in July, the second straight decline, the Commerce Department reported today.
The somewhat unexpected skid, combined with downward revisions for both May and June, meant housing was not only no longer pacing the lackluster recovery, as it had until spring, but was becoming a drag. 
 It was also another negative dose of economic news for the Bush Administration during this week of the Republican National Convention.
 
Competing Factors

 
 "We've got a tug-of-war going between lower interest rates and the factors causing the lower interest rates," said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. The weak economy and poor consumer confidence, he indicated, seemed to be prevailing.
Mr. Seiders fretted that not even tumbling rates on adjustable mortgages, which are now available at rates just over 5 percent, were providing the stimulus he had expected.
Conventional 30-year mortgages have also become more attractive, averaging 7.96 percent compared with 9.03 percent as recently as March. This is the first time 30-year rates have moved below 8 percent in almost 20 years.
Permits for home construction did rise 3.7 percent last month, today's report also showed, but analysts found little solace in this. Contrary to widespread belief, the permits figure has not proved a reliable indicator of future activity, and in any event the July increase for single-family homes was negligible.
 
An Economist's View
 "It's a little disappoining," commented David W. Berson, economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, the Government-chartered company that buys home loans. "Builders are not responding fully to lower rates and a pickup in sales."
The department reported in late July that sales of new single-family homes in June were at an annual rate of 572,000, up 7.9 percent from May.
July's starts, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, were 1.12 million, down from revised rates of 1.15 million in June and 1.20 million in May. The June decline was revised to 3.8 percent, instead of the 3.2 percent first reported.
This was the first time since January 1991 that housing starts, which have a significant ripple effect throughout the economy, have dropped for two straight months.
"The recovery in housing starts, even with falling interest rates, may be running out of gas," the United States Chamber of Commerce said.
Last month's decline in starts, which was experienced in all regions but the South, was entirely accounted for by a drop in single-family homes, to a rate of 959,000 from an even 1 million. Construction of multi-unit buildings rose a bit, as an increase of 14,000 for those with five units or more countered a decline of 5,000 for buildings with two to four units.
The overall decline was most severe in the West, where starts fell 7.7 percent, to a pace of 275,000, and in the Northeast, where the decline was 5.5 percent, to 120,000. Starts in the Midwest eased 1.5 percent, to an annual rate of 267,000.
The South's increase, to a pace of 457,000 from 455,000, amounted to four-tenths of 1 percent.
Without seasonal adjustment, the actual number of starts last month was 110,500, compared with 118,400 in June and 115,200 in May.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS IN HOUSTON: The Houston Thing;
Paging Any Blacks. Report to the Stage.

BYLINE: By Maureen Dowd and Frank Rich, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
This was diversity night at the Republican National Convention, with a eclectic parade that included a rabbi, a governor who advocates abortion rights, the former pro quarterback Roger Staubach and the only black in the Bush cabinet, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis W. Sullivan.
Despite efforts to broaden the "big tent," it has not stretched over many blacks. Convention planners had to reach back to two long-gone Bush Administration officials to balance the convention show. 
 Fred McClure, the most prominent black official in the very White House until he left to become a Dallas banker, sang the national anthem at the opening convention session Monday morning. It was his most visible moment with the President since he sang "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" a cappella at a fund-raiser for Senator Phil Gramm in the Astrodome in 1990. Condoleezza Rice, a National Security staff member who left two years ago, came from Stanford University to praise Mr. Bush's foreign policy.
Meanwhile, black delegates are in such short supply that two of the television networks had to use the same faces when searching for black audience reactions to the references to the Los Angeles riots in Ronald Reagan's speech Monday night.
In the Department of Symbolism, delegates have been fending off queries all week about a shindig on the final night at the River Oaks Country Club, one of the three clubs that the 1988 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, fleetingly resigned four years ago because of its all-white membership.
 
No Comment Yet On Strategy for '94
 The Vice President promised today that there would be "a new Dan Quayle in 1992." But it looked a lot like the old Dan Quayle from here.
Asked by Bernard Shaw of CNN if a Bush-Quayle victory this year would make him the heir apparent in 1996, the Vice President answered:
"Let us get through this week. Let us get through the debate or debates. Let us see George Bush re-elected this November. And then we'll talk about 1994."
Perhaps Jack F. Kemp, James A. Baker 3d, William J. Bennett and Patrick J. Buchanan won't be running that year.
 
Southern Belles For Safer Sex
 Lovely to look at, somewhat surreal to behold, in hoop-skirted gowns of violet, pink, blue and teal, a bevy of self-described Southern belles visited the Republican convention at mid-day, to dispense Texas hospitality and condoms.
Sashaying rather self-consciously into the Astrodome complex, the Southern Belles for Safer Sex were met with a surprisingly warm reception as they handed out the green and red prophylactics from dainty wicker baskets.
"Hi there, honey, would you like a condom?" said Tina Hester, chief belle, to the police officer at the front gate.
"Why, thank you ma'am," he said, taking two.
"Nobody is rude to a belle," Ms. Hester said with satisfaction.
The belles are members of such groups as the National Organization for Women and Planned Parenthood staging a light protest against the Republican platform's position on abortion.
Political conventioneers are so frequently accosted by pamphleteers that they tend to take what is handed to them without breaking stride. That, at least, was Michael K. Deaver's excuse.
The former Reagan White House chief of staff, who took two condoms from a belle in blue, said, when asked if he was pleased at the little bonus the day had brought, "What? What? I thought they were handing out cookies or mints." But, as he walked on, he kept the gift.
"My daughter will love this," he said, laughing.
 
Woody Allen And Family Values
 The New York tabloid headlines about Woody Allen began to provoke the family-values police among the Republican delegates today. The reviews have been somewhat less kind than those that greeted Mr. Allen's less-than-rapturously received last film, "Shadows and Fog."
"That's wacko Hollywood," said Robert K. Dornan, a California Congressman interviewed by CNN on the convention floor. "I'm a big fan. Woody, why did you do this to us?"
 
Rocking the Astrodome
 At a convention whose show business contingent is top-heavy with country music singers and faded Hollywood icons like Pat Boone and Charlton Heston, rock-and-roll, if not necessarily youth, still must be served.
Three Dog Night, a rock group best known for its 1970 hit "Mama Told Me Not to Come," gave a concert to a small but vocal crowd in the American Spirit Pavilion.
"They're making a comeback," said Torie Clarke, the Bush campaign spokeswoman. "It's retro-chic."
One rock critic has described "Mama Told Me" as a paean to "getting drunk at a party" and a "celebration of hedonism and substance abuse."
In "Wouldn't It Be Nice," his 1991 autobiography, the Beach Boys' Brian Wilson described the "ample supply of stimulants" he surveyed at the Hollywood Hills home of Danny Hutton, then and now a Three Dog Night lead singer, in the early 1970's.
Presumably the group now abides by the Republican Party Platform, which declares, "Dope is no longer trendy."
 
The Recession Hits Home
 A large sign above the Houston Shoe Hospital, at a shopping center not far from the wealthy River Oaks neighborhood, reveals the politics of pain, Republican style:
"Topsiders Resoled Here."
 
Tall and Bronze, It's the President
 At a time when the statues of Lenin and Stalin are toppling to history and Washington is still debating over a likeness of Franklin D. Roosevelt, leave it to the Texans to come up with a prime example of grandiose political art.
Within yards of a chunk of the Berlin Wall in the Astrodome Arena stands an eight-foot-tall bronze statue of the President, as cast by David Adickes, a Houston artist.
A rather young Mr. Bush, of an intedeterminate age somewhere between World War II aviator and United Nations Ambassador, seems to be caught in winds as powerful as those that swept Dorothy and Toto to Oz. Mr. Bush strides into the gale, chin up, shirtsleeves rolled up, tie whipping off his left shoulder, jacket streaming horizontally back from the right. In his left hand, he clutches a book.
The title, as if scripted by the convention's theme engineers: "The Winds of Change."
 
The Calendar Is Ticking
 The Liberal/Media Lynch Mob Department:
"I don't mind the four more years," Murray Kempton of Newsday said today. "It's the three more days that is more than I can stand."

HEADLINE: Why Haven't More Banks Failed?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Earlier this year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned that 200 banks with combined assets of more than $80 billion would fail this year. After seven months, however, only 70 banks with $20.9 billion of assets have failed, far below the rate the F.D.I.C. forecast.
But even as banking experts debate how much the slowdown stems from election-year politics and how much from the palliative effects of the lower interest rates that make even the weakest banks more profitable, the F.D.I.C. is warning that tougher new regulations that will take effect on Dec. 19 will result in a flurry of bank closings. 
 After Dec. 19, regulators must either start closing banks whose shareholder capital drops below 2 percent of assets, or provide good reasons why they are letting them stay open. A good reason, F.D.I.C. officials say, would be a viable plan for a quick merger or infusion of fresh capital.
Under current law, state and Federal regulators do not usually close banks unless they are insolvent, meaning that the value of the bank's assets, like loans and securities, is not equal to the combined total of its capital and what it owes depositors.
"The idea is to close institutions while there is at least some theoretical value left," said Robert F. Mialivich, assistant director for bank supervision at the F.D.I.C. "If you wait until the bank has zero capital, it has long been proved that it has a negative value as soon as it is closed."
The 2 percent rule, which was part of the banking legislation passed late last year, is intended to reduce the F.D.I.C.'s losses from failed banks.
William Taylor, chairman of the F.D.I.C., estimates that based on the agency's latest information a number of banks with assets of $30 billion to $45 billion will be affected by the rule changes, though he will not disclose how many.
Ferguson & Company, an Irving, Tex., consulting firm, found that 54 banks with $17.3 billion of assets failed to meet the 2 percent test, based on public reports filed by banks on March 31.
Notwithstanding the predictions for many more closings at the end of this year -- or maybe in part because of the predictions -- accusations that regulators are playing politics with bank failures remain widespread.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, is among those who suggest that banking regulators may be delaying the closing of weak banks to avoid controversy in advance of the November elections. Mr. Gonzalez said in June that the slow pace of bank closings was reminiscent of the way savings and loans were handled in 1988.
Accusations continue that regulators have been too slow to close financially shaky savings institutions. Because the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that handles failed savings and loans, has lacked the money it needs to handle large failures, some institutions have remained open longer than analysts expected.
The F.D.I.C., for its part, received an extra $30 billion from the Treasury last year for dealing with troubled banks, but it has not yet used any of that money.
Some bankers noted that a policy of early intervention, where banks are closed before they are insolvent, might not always be the least costly way for Federal regulators to handle weak banks.
"It makes a lot of sense when property values and overall conditions are deteriorating," said Charles D. Jeffrey, president of the Heritage Bank for Savings, a Holyoke, Mass., bank that has a plan for raising more capital, but is now below the 2 percent level. "But at times like now, when real estate markets have stabilized and banks are benefiting from lower interest rates, it is exactly the wrong thing to do, as far as the Federal taxpayer is concerned."
When conditions are favorable, Mr. Jeffrey said, the weakly capitalized banks might find fresh capital and survive, at no cost to the F.D.I.C. But if they are closed, he said, there is still a chance the F.D.I.C. will lose money.
Some banking experts stop short of accusing regulators of bending the rules to avoid closing banks. But they say regulators are more inclined to sit on their hands before an election.
"Neither party would seem to benefit from bank closings, and I think the regulators have recognized that," said Edward Furash, a Washington bank consultant.
Fred Finke, a deputy in the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency who is in charge of supervising the weakest national banks, acknowledged that "closings have been running a little slower than we expected." But, he added, there simply have not been as many insolvent banks as had been expected. "We are not doing anything designed to push the failures back beyond November," he said.
Mr. Taylor says it is economic factors, not politics, that have kept more weak banks alive.
"The biggest thing to slow down the pace of failures has been the decline in interest rates," Mr. Taylor said. "It has had the effect of helping some banks improve their condition in a material way, while for others it has just postponed the inevitable."
 
Fresh Inflows of Capital
 Besides the benefits of lower interest rates, Mr. Finke notes that many troubled banks have already set aside reserves for bad loans or written off the loans at a loss. And banks are not facing the same steady decline in the value of their loans as they were the past few years, he said.
Another cause of the slower-than-expected failure rate, Mr. Finke said, is that "there are more people out there who are thinking that maybe it is still possible to earn a return in banking." Just as large banks have rushed to offer stock this year, he noted, smaller banks have also found it easier to restore their financial condition by issuing more stock, in small, private transactions.
Mr. Finke said the fresh inflow of money to banking was not dramatic enough to eliminate the industry's problems, but "it could make the difference beween having 16 failures so far this year, or having 20 or 25."
Some bankers are still scrambling to increase their capital. The First City Bancorporation of Texas, a holding company in Houston that has four banks below the 2 percent capitalization level, last week announced a plan to sell small banks and raise $100 million from its shareholders and new investors. The plan, if successful, would put the company on solid financial footing.
 
Facing Up to the Problems
 Even if the F.D.I.C. or state regulators were acting cautiously because of the election, there is not much to suggest that they are denying the existence of problems -- as savings and loan regulators were doing in 1988.
Mr. Taylor, who came to the F.D.I.C. last October and whose term expires in March 1993, describes himself as a bureaucrat whose career at the Federal Reserve did not prepare him for bending to prevailing political winds.
Earlier this year, in fact, Mr. Taylor voted in favor of a sharp increase in the deposit insurance premiums banks must pay -- a sign that he was not trying to minimize the industry's problems.
Before that, Mr. Taylor pushed the F.D.I.C. to revise downward its forecasts for its own financial condition. Instead of accounting only for losses it would suffer at banks that are on the verge of failure, the agency now casts its net wider to include losses from banks that it estimates are likely to fail, even though the event is not imminent.
"I operated on the simple principle that the loses are there whether the bank gets closed today or sometime in the future," he explained.
In another indication that the F.D.I.C. is not trying to hide industry problems, early this year the agency sharply increased the amount of assets on its list of troubled banks.
Those banks, whose problems with low capital, bad loans, weak management and poor earnings are severe enough to be rated four or five on a scale in which the bottom is five, had assets of $610 billion at the end of 1991, up sharply from $487 billion three months earlier. Since the number of banks on the problem list increased only slightly -- to 1,016 from 1,005 -- analysts said the sharp increase in assets apparently reflected a decision, made since Mr. Taylor's arrival, to include one or more very large banks.
Mr. Taylor has so far withstood the temptation to issue a more rosy forecast for the industry. He noted that the benefits of lower interest rates would not last forever and that "when interest rates rise, as they surely will some day, it is going to kick out some banks" onto the list of those that regulators will close.
"Some people inside here are of the opinion that things are better," he said, "but I am not convinced yet."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Short of a Dire Forecast" shows the number of banks closed from '86-to date '92, and the assets of closed banks from '86-to date '92. (Source: F.D.I.C.) (pg. D1)

Here is a list of banks in the United States that would have failed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's new capital adequacy test if it had been applied on March 31, 1992, the latest date for which figtures are available. The new test will take effect Dec. 19.

HEADLINE: Twins Study Shows School Is Sound Investment

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Like cleaner air and safer streets, better education has become a must on every politician's wish list. But in an era of shallow pockets, when an extra dollar for schools may mean a dollar less to keep the bridges from falling down, would more spending really pay off?
Just-completed research by two Princeton econometricians confirms that it probably would -- and handsomely. More years in school, Orley Ashenfelter and Alan Kreuger conclude, may well be the key to salvaging the declining prospects of unskilled workers. 
 The new study -- unusual in that it compared data from identical twins to distinguish the impact of nature from that of nurture -- estimates that, on average, each year of education at any stage, from grade school through graduate school, adds 16 percent to an individual's lifetime earnings.
"No ordinary investment is likely to produce anything close to this return," points out John Bishop, an economist at Cornell University.
The Princeton researchers' findings could prove manna from the ivory tower for Democratic Presidential candidate Bill Clinton, who has anchored his economic program to a big Federal investment in education. "This only strengthens my conviction that Americans' standard of living is uniquely connected to skills and training," said Robert Reich, a Harvard Business School professor and a leading economic strategist for the Clinton campaign.
While earlier studies on the relationship between schooling and income have used survey data collected for other purposes, the Princeton researchers decided to start fresh with what they call a "natural experiment." They interviewed 298 people over the age of 18 who were identical twins, triplets or, in one case, quadruplets, and who were attending the Twins Day Festival in Twinsburg, Ohio, last summer.
Each twin answered a series of questions on his or her years of education as well as marital status, race, military service, parents' income, work experience, profession and union membership -- in short, anything that might have affected current earnings.
 
Cleansing Research Bias
 The same information could have been gathered with less fuss from unrelated individuals. But studying twins, Mr. Kreuger said, was uniquely useful in neutralizing suspected sources of bias that have dogged previous statistical studies.
Analysts have long worried that school attendance was closely correlated with unmeasured factors, like intelligence and social class, that were influential in determining a person's earning power later in life. Thus, estimates excluding these unmeasured factors might leave the impression that schooling was a better investment than it really was. But by looking at the differences in earnings and education between genetically identical twins who grew up together, the researchers believe this "selection bias" has largely been cleansed from the estimates.
While interviewing twins could not completely eliminate misreporting by interviewees, the researchers corrected for that potential bias by asking each twin to report on the education of the other.
This cleverly constructed experiment has yielded what many analysts regard as the most trustworthy estimate of the current return on an investment in education -- and what all regard as the most striking. If an extra year of high school or college education adds 16 percent to the average individuals' wage, a four-year college degree can be expected to increased an individual's earnings by almost two-thirds.
 
Words of Warning
 Paul Taubman, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania, cautions that the reported earnings gain attributable to schooling -- roughly twice that found in his own study of World War II veterans during the 1970's -- may be misleading. While he acknowledges that the age, education and earnings of the twins were close to national averages, Mr. Taubman worries that "there may be subtler differences" that make the sample unrepresentative of Americans in general.
Arthur Goldberger, an economist at the University of Wisconsin, focuses on another possible problem in interpreting the research. The difference in schooling between twins was the result of family choices, he notes. Thus, the Princeton results may not accurately predict the consequences of such government-mandated changes in school attendance as lengthening the school year or increasing the minimum dropout age.
It is also conceivable that the remarkably high average return on education is a transitory phenomenon, although Mr. Bishop, the Cornell economist, finds that improbable. His own research suggests that the demand for skilled workers will grow in the 1990's, not shrink. But even if the estimated 16 percent return is on the high side, many economists view the results as a potent mandate for investing in education.
Isabel Sawhill of the Urban Institute in Washington notes that the increasingly open world economy is forcing unskilled American workers to compete with their counterparts everywhere from China to Mexico, widening the income gap between America's haves and have-nots and feeding a protectionist backlash.
But the potential for hefty earnings-gains from education, she argues, implies that America need not choose between a stagnant closed economy that protects blue-collar workers and an open one that grows at the expense of the least fortunate. If virtually all Americans could acquire skills, a great majority would be likely to prosper in the global market.
 
Tuition as Tax Surcharge
 Mr. Bishop warns, however, that raising average skill levels might take a costly reorganization of the education system. He sees promise in "doing what the Germans do" (and what the Clinton campaign promises to do), tying the last years of high school for noncollege-track students to apprenticeship programs. But he is concerned that many students with college potential are being priced out of the game by rising tuition rates.
Representative Tom Petri, a Republican from Wisconsin who has led the effort in the House to restructure college loan programs, offers a more optimistic view. While he agrees that higher education is now out of the reach of many middle-income families, the double-digit return estimated by researchers suggests that "most students ought to be able to pay for college or technical training out of their future earnings."
His preferred solution would be to offer more generous Federal loans that students would repay as a percentage surcharge on their future income taxes. Those who chose low-paying occupations, or simply did not get much from the extra years spent hitting the books, would be helped along by the majority who used college as a ticket to affluence.
Mr. Ashenfelter agrees that the benefits from pooling the risks of investment in higher education offer "a classic justification for Government intervention." So, apparently, does Mr. Clinton, who has proposed college loans that could be repaid either through an income tax surcharge or through community service after graduation. Even the free-marketeers in the Bush Administration are willing to test the idea of income-contingent loans: the education bill just signed by the President includes a $500 million demonstration project.
No one is claiming that increased education is the magic bullet for curing what ails the American economy. But in Ms. Sawhill's view, the Ashenfelter-Kreuger research reveals what amounts to the next best thing. "It is the one investment", she said, "that would increase overall productivity and narrow the income gap that has been widening since the mid-1970's."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Regain Some Ground

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market rose modestly yesterday, wiping out most of Monday's losses on the 30-year bond and moving higher in other maturities. But traders and analysts are still worried about some sudden surprise from the Republican National Convention and expect the market to be volatile for the rest of the week.
The day's economic data continued to paint a picture of an economy growing slowly, which is one of the main reasons prices of notes and bonds have advanced recently. 
 The Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 2.8 percent in July, which surprised many analysts inasmuch as home mortgage rates are close to 20-year lows. The consensus forecast was for an increase of 1.7 percent.
The one possibly positive note in the housing report was that permits for new structures were up 3.7 percent last month. But a lot of those new permits were for multifamily housing, not single-family dwellings, which would give a stronger lift to the economy. Permits for single-family homes have remained basically unchanged since April.
 
Slower Sales Seen
 The Johnson Redbook report, which covers sales for department and chain stores, predicted that sales this month would decline four-tenths of a percent from July if they continued at the pace of the first two weeks of August.
But investors were only moderately lifted by the news because of jitters about the Republican convention, though White House officials have tried to indicate there will not be any big economic policy pronouncements this week, even on Thursday night when President Bush is scheduled to give his acceptance speech.
"Most of the people are still focusing on what comes out of the Republican convention," said one government bond trader. He also said that the billions of dollars in notes and bonds sold in the big quarterly Treasury auction last week were still weighing down the market.
In late trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 991/16 , up 12/32 , to yield 7.32 percent, compared with 7.35 percent on Monday.
In other maturities, the 6.375 percent 10-year note was offered at 995/16 , up 7/16 , to yield 6.47 percent, down from 6.52 percent the day before. The 5.5 percent five-year note was offered at 100 3/8, up 3/8, to yield 5.41 percent, down from 5.49 percent on Monday.
The one-year bill was trading at a discount rate of 3.20 percent, down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. The Treasury will auction $14.25 billion in new one-year bills tomorrow.
Another signal of the market's uncertainty was the widening of the differential between the yield on intermediate-term notes, like the two-year note, and longer-term securities, like the the 30-year bond.
Some investors are showing a preference for shorter-term maturities because they are less volatile. Therefore, if there is some unexpected news from the Republican convention, the prices of these securities are likely to fall less than those of the 30-year bonds.
The differential or spread between the two-year note and the 30-year bond widened on Monday by 6 basis points. And it widened again yesterday by 3 basis points.
The spread between the five-year note and the 30-year bond also increased, rising 9 basis points from Friday. Both these moves show that investors are moving from longer securities to those of shorter-terms.
Analysts said they they did not see signs of the Federal Reserve's moving to lower short-term interest rates at the meeting yesterday of its Open Market Committee. And the debate continues among economists who watch the Fed over whether the current economic data, including the housing starts figures released yesterday, will make the Fed act soon.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Fall Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
In what has become a painful weekly ritual for bank depositors, yields of bank money market accounts and those of certificates of deposit were down again in the latest period, which ended today.
According to data gathered by The Bank Rate Monitor, the greatest setback appeared to be in money market accounts, which reflect conditions in the short-term money market that find Treasury securities near historical lows. 
 The weaker the economic indicators, the greater the downward pressure on savings yields as the Government does what it can to bring along a recovery.
"Since July, when the Fed cut the discount rate and banks cut the prime, five-year certificates of deposits have dropped 50 basis points, with shorter maturities not far behind," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"What may be happening now," Mr. Heady said, "is that banks may be giving themselves room between what they pay out to depositors and what they lend out, setting the stage for another cut in the prime for sometime in September, when the Fed is expected to ease again."
 
Treasury Barometer Falling
 At the Treasury's weekly three- and six-month bill auction on Monday, rates slipped for the second straight week. The auction is regarded by many interest-rate watchers as a fairly good barometer of what banks will be paying out to their depositors in coming weeks.
The average rate on a three-month Treasury bill at auction was 3.10 percent, down 3 basis points from the previous auction, while the six-month bill fell a basis point, to 3.18 percent.
In the latest week, New York area banks, including commercial and savings institutions, reduced the average yield on a money market account by 2 basis points, to 3.03 percent, while knocking down the yield on three- and six-month certificates by 3 basis points, to 3.04 percent and 3.25 percent.
In the data for the New York commercial banks alone, the cuts were only one basis point across the board, with a money market account slipping to 2.86 percent, a three-month certificate to 2.90 percent and a six-month certificate to 3.07 percent.
It was the New York-area savings banks that moved more aggressively, cutting money markets accounts by an average 2 basis points, to 3.20 percent. Three-month certificates were down 5 basis points, to 3.19 percent, and six-month certificates were down 6 basis points, to 3.44. That compared with an average decline of 3 basis points on six-month certificates among 20 major banks nationally.
In the New York area, the largest yield adjustments were at Midlantic Banks in New Jersey, which cut its money market account by 15 basis points, to 3.10 percent, and at First Fidelity of New Jersey, which lowered its three-month certificate by 30 basis points, to 3.40 percent -- only one week after raising it by the same amount. Chase Manhattan, on the other hand, raised the yield of its six-month certificate by 25 basis points, to 2.94 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
A Market for Playing the 2 Candidates

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IOWA CITY, Aug. 18

 BODY:
All the daily claptrap of the American Presidential contest -- slogan and sleaze, spouses' spin and poll takers' posturing -- are mercifully left behind each morning when Forrest Nelson turns on the computer monitor of the Iowa Political Stock Market to watch the overnight investments of a silent minority who are putting their money where the politicians' mouths are.
There are 550 investors and $34,000 in the market this week, and the beauty of its calm traffic in buying and selling Bush and Clinton securities is that the automated investment process pares away the hustings' blather factor. 
 This morning, the Gateway 2000 computer hummed with price changes from America's lucrative soul, not the latest hyperbole bites from the Republican conventioneers in Houston. The screen's message, while multi-hued as any rally bunting, was humble: Read my blips.
"Pat Buchanan's speech didn't inspire a dollar to move," said Mr. Nelson, an economist here at the University of Iowa. He and three other economic and political faculty members invented the political stock market in 1988 and eventually saw its investors predict the results to within one-tenth of a percentage point of the actual vote -- a precision they say was six times better than the closest final opinion polls that year.
 
Pros Are Sitting Tight
 This morning, there was none of the folderol over convention "bounce" to be read into the overnight numbers because the market investors are not going to get any more excited about the Republicans' gathering in Houston than they did about the Democrats in New York last month, when President Bush, in the Iowa market, experienced none of the poll takers' 17-point boon for Bill Clinton.
As the rest of the nation is hearing melodramatic assessments of an incumbent President having to come from behind, the Iowa market shows Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton neck and neck, with the Arkansas Governor having taken a half-cent edge, or half percentage popularity point, last week.
Aficionados are trading in an all-night, seven-day market in which investments are made from cash advances and in which, incidentally, family values have no discernible value. Last month, while most political junkies were wringing or washing their hands over Ross Perot's sudden departure from the race, investors were at their computers bailing out so that Mr. Perot's price, which translates to a percentage share of popular support, dropped from 30 cents a share to half a cent in a matter of minutes.
"I did all right," said Boaz Weinstein, a high-yield specialist with a major Wall Street investment bank who has $1,000 in two accounts in the political market and plays it for a mixture of fun and his professional need to be attuned daily to politics. "I caught a CNN bulletin and got into the market about 20 seconds before Perot stock started falling off a cliff."
 
Many With Minimum Stake
 Most investors are students down toward the $5 minimum end of the investor's stake. But they are no less enthusiastic than Mr. Weinstein at their hard-money lessons, which, even at penny-ante stakes, provide markets for payoffs on the precise party sharing of the Presidential popular vote as well as on such exotic put-and-call subtleties as how far above or below half the vote total a candidate will finish.
Typically, investors buy into the market with five "unit portfolios," at a cost of $1 each, representing equal shares in Bush and Clinton stock. They are then free to buy and sell these and more endlessly. The payoff after the election will be $1 a share times the percentage of popular vote each candidate registers. This morning the market was at 50.2 cents for a Clinton share and 48.6 cents for a Bush share, with Perot investors holding die-hard paper.
"We try not to refer to this as the point-spread market," Mr. Nelson said, playing down the sort of gambling attraction that led some of the university's law professors to object on ethical grounds. He dismisses the notion that if the market ever gets too big and too active it could become just the sort of family-value issue that politicians prefer for their dire warning portfolio.
Mr. Nelson figures an active and sagacious high-roller who has $500 in the market might double his money. Mr. Weinstein hopes he might realize a 30-percent return on his $1,000 if he plays the market well. This involves sound investments on both the best and the worst President Bush can do in the vote (no better than 54 percent, no worse than 46), and churning his money wisely in response to what he considers serious political developments.
 
Insulated From Bombast
 Here in the pit, far from the madding conventions, it is possible to savor the sheer coldheartedness of the market on the American political scene, and its relative insulation from the ephemeral bombast of the great beyond.
Last winter, at the beginning of the Democrats' primary and caucus fights, Iowa's favorite son candidate, Senator Tom Harkin, came to the campus here to speak. "His stock was falling in our primary market before he got here and it kept falling while he was speaking," recalled Mr. Nelson.
The primary market is closed and the market itself will close at 3 A.M. Election Day. The market is nonprofit, with no commissions or advertising allowed, so it operates at a loss of $2,000 a month, a teaching investment absorbed thus far by the university and a National Science Foundation grant. This year the market was federally sanctioned by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as one of the oddest teaching experiments in the country.
In the Iowa market there is more risk about holding a political opinion, but also more wit. A new punter logging on for the first time can practice on a dummy market based on the 1948 Presidential race -- the "Dewey Wins" race in which President Harry S. Truman confounded all human markets.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Reporter's Notebook;
Scrambling For Time On the Air

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 18

 BODY:
Watching a Presidential campaign scramble for television air time is not a pretty picture. Gov. Bill Clinton's organization has resorted to all manner of genteel desperation to balance all the pretty red-white-and-blue pictures emanating from Houston.
Today's theme was discovery. 
 Mr. Clinton, arriving at the Statehouse to work at being a Governor for a few hours, complained that the Republicans seemed too preoccupied with the past instead of the future.
"You talk about slick," he said. "These guys have talked about how prudent they were, and they have presided over the 10 biggest deficits in American history, Reagan and Bush."
"They've brought us to the position we're in, and now they're asking for a fourth term," Mr. Clinton said, lumping Mr. Reagan's eight-year tenure with Mr. Bush's four-year one. "That's really the message of that speech last night. We want four terms. Three's not enough. And now we will discover America in our fourth term; sort of a Columbus theory of politics."
George Stephanopoulos, the campaign's communications director, who has dispensed daily dollops of campaign spin, declared: "The economy is dead in the water, and all they can do is attack Bill Clinton and attack his wife and kowtow to the far right.
"I mean, Pat Buchanan is 'Cape Fear' and Ronald Reagan is 'The Way We Were.' "
It's only a movie.
 
Hide-and-Seek Candidate

For a man who wants to be President, Bill Clinton has developed a genuine distaste for some of the universally public aspects of the job.
Last week, he dodged reporters at his hotel in Santa Monica, Calif., by taking out his Secret Service entourage for a morning run 20 minutes earlier than scheduled.
And today in Little Rock, he completely fooled the waiting camera crew, which was positioned for the daily jogging picture at the front gate of the Governor's Mansion.
For several moments frustrated network producers thought Mr. Clinton had been smuggled out of the mansion in the back seat of a sedan that had driven out virtually unnoticed. But it turned out that he had devised a more ingenious solution. He simply ran out the back way.
 
The Accent Thickens
 When Mr. Clinton travels South, it is not unusual for him to abandon his urbane ways long enough to become plain old Neighbor Bill, the Governor of Arkansas. His accent thickens, he uses the word "we" a lot and he speaks in an almost confidential tone about the problems the South has overcome. Race. Jobs. Politics.
"The other side is going to go down there to Houston, and they're going to say that Al Gore and I may have been born in Arkansas and Tennessee, but we're just a bunch of crazy wild-eyed liberals," Mr. Clinton predicted last week at a meeting of Southern state legislators.
By "we" he meant the Democratic ticket. But for his audience, which chuckled appreciatively, the pronoun crossed party lines, making all Southerners victim of the Republican slurs he described.
"They're going to say they took us to New York City in a safe and no one saw us in an incubator there for 20 years," Mr. Clinton said with folksy disdain. "And we've got crazy ideas and came home and hid them for 20 years, waiting for the opportunity to spring them on the rest of the country.
"They're going to say every speech I gave on the Fourth of July in northeast Arkansas was a deliberate attempt to conceal my radical impulses. And that we just can't wait to get into power in Washington so we can take your guns away and trample family values and raise taxes on every poor working person in America."
