HEADLINE: On the Front Lines of the War Against Misery

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Robert Brice arrived promptly for his appointment at the St. Nicholas Income Maintenance Center on West 125th Street the other morning, joining dozens of others waiting to tell their tales of hardship to a welfare worker. But before his turn came, Mr. Brice fell asleep, only to wake up two hours later to the sound of his name echoing across the huge expanse of the third-floor room.
He gathered up his envelopes stuffed with documentation of the hard times that have befallen him and wearily made his way to the desk of Terry Cowell, a welfare worker who has been seeing a lot of Robert Brices these days. 
 Last month, the number of New Yorkers on welfare broke the one million mark for the first time since the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's, a vivid statistical measure of the recession's human toll.
Almost one in seven New Yorkers is on welfare: 1,005,210 in July, a 22 percent increase since January 1990.
 
Views of Misery
 To spend a day with a worker at any of the city's 39 welfare offices is to glimpse the hues and details of the recession's misery through the eyes of those who bear the weight of so many lives on the edge.
As an eligibility specialist, Ms. Cowell reviews applications for public-assistance benefits. In the three years she has had the job, she said, the stories of hardship have become increasingly more desperate.
"Some people come in and try to tell a little fib, but you can basically tell," she said, as she filled out paperwork on her overflowing desk. "The majority of people who come in here do need it. Many more of the people coming in these days have lost their jobs. Their unemployment benefits have run out. It's not that these people who come in here don't want to work. They want to work. They just can't find anything right now. And it seems to be getting worse."
The St. Nicholas Income Maintenance Center is currently handling 11,000 welfare cases, a load that is higher than anyone can remember, said Kathryn Harper, the center's director.
Here, in this narrow four-floor office building, tucked between shoe stores and hair salons on a busy Harlem intersection where street vendors crowd the sidewalk, every weekday 60 to 75 people apply for welfare benefits or renew their applications.
 
Urgent Stories
 But the third-floor reception area, where applicants pass through the welfare processing area, is quiet and orderly, underlining the contrast between the bureaucratic strictures of the welfare system and the urgency and privacy of the stories the workers must hear.
One day recently, a radio that was on in the reception area muffled the conversations of welfare workers interviewing clients at desks only a few feet apart. Rick Nelson crooned about going to a garden party as workers asked applicants: Do you have a bank account? Do you know where your children's father is? Are you able to work? Why are you applying for public assistance?
An irate applicant at one desk was shouting for all to hear, "What do you want me to do, rob a bank? Can't you see I'm in need?" A worker quietly responded, and no one else seemed to notice.
The room is marked by an air of quiet desperation, as the waiting people clutch worn envelopes and hold tight to the stories of hardship they will tell in due time. For some, the waiting is harder than for others.
"I guess maybe it was anxiety," Mr. Brice said quietly about his nap in the reception area. "It's hard for everybody. When I woke up, I thought maybe I'd missed my turn."
Mr. Brice, who is 56 years old, has sought but has been unable to find steady work since 1987, when he was laid off from his job as a maintenance worker in a Federal building downtown.
A self-described shy man, he has been surviving on odd jobs like washing cars or cleaning windows, "nothing to brag about," he said, and with the occasional meal from his sister and her family. But now, the rent is overdue and his resources have run dry.
Stories like Mr. Brice's abound. But, first, the applicants must make their way through a bureaucratic labyrinth. When they enter the room, they approach teller-like windows, where they are handed four-page application forms and given a number to mark their turn to talk with a worker, who explains the form and what documentation they will need to support their requests for benefits. They are given appointments to return with the completed forms and necessary documentation, like rent receipts and wage stubs.
When they return for a second visit, they wait their turn to talk with eligibility specialists like Ms. Cowell, whose desks line one wall. Ms. Cowell and the others spend about an hour with each applicant, perhaps six in a day, reviewing their forms and documentation to determine the urgency of each case. Some people require immediate assistance, for example if their electrical power has been shut off for lack of payment, or if they have no money for baby formula. Others can wait until official notification of eligibility in a month or so.
Once a client is approved, he or she is assigned to another welfare worker, who becomes the client's contact with the massive system that will provide benefits of about $176 every two weeks for one person. Those employees, called undercare workers, must handle about 170 cases at once, 15 more than last year. They may get desperate telephone calls from any of them at any time.
On one wall, a worker has posted a photocopy of an article whose headline reads: "Burnout: Are You a Candidate?"
But Ms. Cowell, who is 28, said that in her three years at this office, she has not become discouraged or jaded.
"It's all in how you treat people," she said. "You might get a person who raises his voice, but I never get upset. I never raise my voice. You never get anywhere that way. Sometimes they get upset and start screaming things like, 'How come you're asking for that?' And you try to explain it to them so that they'll understand."
In the same rote style as a police officer reading an arrested person his rights, Ms. Cowell told each applicant: "I am asking you these questions to determine your eligibility. I am now going to make photocopies of your documents, and after a I return, you may ask me any questions that you have."
 
Tattered Documents
 When it was Gladys Rivera's turn, she opened several envelopes to place tattered birth certificates, rent receipts and other documents in front of Ms. Cowell. She was applying for public assistance, she said, because she had recently lost her job as a personal care aide and has two children to support.
"I did a double boo-boo," she said. "I called the elderly lady that I was caring for to tell her I couldn't come to work one day, but I didn't call my boss. And I did it twice."
"I had just recently lost my mother and I was under a lot of pressure," she said. "She had cancer and I was taking care of her."
Ms. Rivera, who is 33, said she was on public assistance once before, in 1987, and at that time was placed in one of the agency's several job-training programs. That was how she found a job as a personal care aide.
"Now I'll look for something else," she said. "Maybe something in clerical. I've been a cashier before."
Ms. Rivera didn't seem surprised that more than a million New Yorkers were on public assistance, more than at any time in 20 years.
"There are a lot of people out of work right now, and a lot of people who are homeless," she said. "But I think, why be homeless? Why be out of a job if you can work? Especially if you have children. I would prefer working, but if you need a little bit of help, you need it."
Some people have grown weary of looking for jobs that never seem to come. Roy McNair was also in to see Ms. Cowell on Friday. His 13 weeks of unemployment benefits recently ran out. He had worked in maintenance with the city's public housing for several months, but it was a seasonal job that lasted only through April.
"I've been out looking for jobs, but I can't find one," said Mr. McNair, 49. "There's no work. I'm looking for any kind of work. Makes no difference to me. Everyone says they don't have no jobs."
Robert Brice has been depending on help from his sister and her children.
"If it wasn't for my family, I don't think I would've made it," he said. "They've been very supportive. But they have families of their own. After a while you feel like excess baggage. They tell me to come by, and I say I will, but I don't."
Mr. Brice's troubles began when he was laid off in 1987, and has been unable to find another steady job. Mr. Brice suspects it is because of his age.
"I don't know what that has to do with it," said Mr. Brice, who wore jeans and a blue sweater covered with lint. "No one seems to want to take a chance on a 56-year-old. I don't know why they consider that old. I don't consider myself old. They don't say it, they just always tell you they'll let you know, and then you never hear from them."

HEADLINE: Student Credit Union Fails At University of Connecticut

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn., Aug. 18

 BODY:
The University of Connecticut's student-run credit union has been closed because of poor record-keeping, risky lending practices and a high level of loan delinquencies.
The nonprofit UConn Student Federal Credit Union, which gave extra interest to students who earned A's, was declared insolvent on Monday after it had to write off $68,000 in bad loans. It had written off only $1,000 in the previous 12 years. 
 The National Credit Union Administration forced the credit union, which has 2,000 members, into liquidation, saying a suitable manager to reorganize it could not be found.
"If somebody else wants to give it a shot they could," a university spokesman, Richard Veilleux, said today. "But the Federal people have been keeping an eye on this union since April when the delinquent and flat-out bad loans started mounting."
Regulators would not provide details on how insolvent the credit union was. Mr. Veilleux said the 13-year-old credit union has $1.1 million in assets.
 
'Just the Recession'
 "It's just the recession," Mr. Veilleux said. "All loans had to be cosigned, but the recession has been so long and so bad, not only are borrowers failing to repay, but cosigners aren't paying."
Anthony LaCreta, deputy regional director of the National Credit Union Administration, said all credit union members would get their money back and the checks would be sent in about two weeks.
The closure was prompted by long-term "mismanagement of operations" at the credit union, including the lack of documentation of loans and a lack of consistent procedures in making loans, Mr. LaCreta said.
Lewis Mandell, a professor of finance and political science, said many of his students learned the skills to be bankers by volunteering at the credit union. "It's a double loss to the university," he said.
An organization run by students that gave loans to other students was probably more vulnerable to the Northeast's recession than other credit unions, Professor Mandell said. Credit unions that are run by employers are usually more insulated from bad loans, he said.
"You hate to use the word inevitable," Professor Mandell said, "but it was almost inevitable that if you're giving loans to people who really need it, you're going to get hurt."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Declines; Gold Prices Are Also Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower against most major currencies in thin trading yesterday as investors digested news on the United States economy and tensions in the Middle East. Gold prices also fell.
Dollar traders were somewhat discouraged by news that construction of single-family homes and apartments fell 2.8 percent in July, said Richard Mahoney, vice president of foreign exchange at Citibank. 
 "Housing starts were weaker than the market expected, which keeps interest rate expectations low and naturally the dollar suffers a little bit," Mr. Mahoney said.
Tensions between the United States and Iraq also caught traders' attention yesterday, lifting the German mark against most other currencies, Mr. Mahoney said.
Political unrest abroad tends to drive investors into currencies that are considered safe havens, such as the dollar and the mark. With traders uncertain about the United States economy and in turn the dollar, they were leaning toward the mark yesterday.
In New York, the dollarcurrency fell to 1.4570 marks, from 1.4640 late Monday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.4580 German marks from 1.4625.
Government officials in Washington and Paris have threatened to enforce United Nations resolutions to ease the repression of Shiites in southern Iraq.
In New York, the British pound rose to $1.9305, from $1.9250 Monday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9295, from $1.9260 late Monday.
In New York, the dollar closed at 126.15 Japanese yen, up from 125.70 yen late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 126.18 yen, down 0.07 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 126.25 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.3055 Swiss francs, down from 1.3165; 4.9430 French francs, down from 4.9635; 1,106.00 Italian lire, down from 1,111.00, and 1.19855 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19475.
The price of gold for August delivery fell $1.10, to $335.80 a troy ounce, on the New York Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: Japan Announces Series of Steps To Try to Halt Stock Market Slide

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 19

 BODY:
With another steep drop in share prices deepening the sense of crisis in Japan's financial system, the Finance Minister announced a series of measures Tuesday aimed at halting the two-and-a-half-year stock market slide.
The action was taken after the closely watched Nikkei average of 225 stocks plunged 620.14 points on Tuesday, or 4.2 percent, to 14,309.41, its lowest level in more than six years. 
 Stocks rebounded somewhat in trading today, but brokers remained cautious. They said that sentiment had been encouraged by the measures, but that most of the buying was for technical reasons. At the close today, the Nikkei regained 341.33 points, or 2.39 percent, to 14,650.74.
After the plunge on Tuesday, the average was down 13.5 percent in one month alone, and the market's fall since the end of 1989 has wiped out about $3.1 trillion, or 63 percent, of the value of the shares traded on the exchange in Tokyo.
In his package announced Tuesday, the Finance Minister, Tsutomu Hata, sought to put pressure on big investors not to sell shares and said financial institutions would be permitted to withhold negative financial data from the public in the hope of easing worries about the system's fundamental health. He also said steps would be taken to encourage Japanese banks to make more loans.
Financial experts generally said the measures did not go far enough. The best that could be said of the package, market experts and economists said, was that it showed that top Government officials have finally awakened to the severity of the troubles afflicting Japan's stock market and banking system, and to the impact on the economy.
Most said they feared the announcement could harm the market further by sidestepping the deeper problems of the market and the economy. The measures simply add to the sense, analysts said, that the financial system is careering from crisis to crisis with the Government unable to control it.
The severity of the decline in Japan's market in some ways exceeds some of the worst stock market crashes. In the United States in the 14 months after the crash of October 1929, the Dow Jones industrial average lost nearly 50 percent of its value, and in the 1987 crash the Dow lost more than 20 percent.
While the Government maintains that the economy will expand 3.5 percent in the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, most private economists say they expect growth of less than 2 percent, in part because of the problems in the badly shaken system.
"This was perhaps the first real admission from the Finance Minister that the situation is severe and that they have to do something," said Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "But as far as the content goes, I'm not impressed."
Added Alicia Ogawa, a financial analyst at S. G. Warburg Securities (Japan): "This is a dangerous game they are playing. The only thing keeping this system together is faith in the authorities, and this announcement doesn't inspire a lot of faith."
Mr. Hata announced a generally vague package of measures with these principal features:
*Financial institutions will be asked not to sell shares on which they can still record some profit before the fiscal half-year ends on Sept. 30. The ministry has no formal power to enforce this rule.
*The ministry will lift a rule that prohibits financial institutions from paying out more than 40 percent of their profits as dividends. As profits have shrunk, the fear has been that companies either will sharply cut dividends to stay within the 40 percent rule or will sell some stock holdings to inflate profits artificially.
*Financial institutions will be given the option of not reporting stock losses for the six-month period that ends Sept. 30. Instead they will be able to wait until March 31.
*Banks, which have drastically cut the growth of new loans, are to be encouraged to make more loans and to take steps for smooth write-offs of their growing burden of bad loans. The ministry will also help banks raise fresh capital to make up for the huge losses on their stock portfolios.
This is the third rescue package the Government has announced in the last five months. The previous two were aimed at stimulating the faltering economy not just the stock market. In both instances the Government said it would increase public-works spending and the Bank of Japan lowered interest rates. And in both cases, the stock market declined afterwards.
Although there is still no sense of panic in the stock market -- Tuesday's trading volume of 170 million shares was less than one-sixth the average volume on the exchange just a few years ago -- one of the biggest changes in recent weeks has been a realization that the severity of the market's decline has been sapping strength from the overall economy.
For much of the last two and a half years Government officials and business leaders have insisted that what happens in the market has little impact on what they like to call the "real economy." Now they have begun to see the connections between the tumbling value of stocks, the severe loan-loss problems at banks and the sharp slowdown in the economy.
The bank problems are at the heart of the issue. Japanese banks own huge stock portfolios, whose value makes up about half of their total capital. The plunging value of the stock market means their capital bases have been shrinking. That reduces their ability to lend, forces them to consider selling shares and weakens an already-slowing economy by limiting the amount of fresh credit available to help companies grow.
In fact, a vicious cycle has developed. While tumbling stock prices eat into banks' capital, the slowing economy has caused a record level of corporate bankruptcies, which add to the banks' burden of bad loans. Fearful of how the banks' loan losses could harm the economy, investors have been more inclined to sell shares.

HEADLINE: UNDER THE DOME: ISSUES -- THE ECONOMY;
Bush May Promise to Keep Baker As Manager of Economic Policy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
To try to rebuild his credibility on economic matters, President Bush and his speech-writing team have discussed a proposal to have the President promise Thursday night to keep James A. Baker 3d at the White House after the election to manage economic policy, Administration officials said here today.
Mr. Baker, whose resignation as Secretary of State and appointment as Mr. Bush's chief of staff and campaign coordinator become effective Sunday, is said to be resisting the idea as gimmicky and too confining. 
 But discussion of the proposal illustrates a fundamental tactical puzzle that the White House must solve by Thursday. It needs to come up with a bold step or convincing promise of action that the President can make without reminding a national television audience that he is the man who broke the keystone pledge of his 1988 acceptance speech: "Read my lips. No new taxes."
The speech writers' deliberations also underscore the importance the President and his advisers place on finding some means of invigorating the campaign and breaking through his encrusted image as the passive guardian of the economic status quo.
 
Bad Economic News
 The need for an economic plan was given even greater urgency today after the Government announced that the pace at which builders broke ground for new homes slumped 2.8 percent in July. Combined with downward revisions for May and June, the skid meant that the housing sector not only was no longer pacing the lackluster recovery but was becoming a drag. [Page D1.]
Mr. Bush and his advisers view the Thursday night speech, in which he will accept his party's nomination for a second term, as a crucial opportunity to convince voters that he intends to deal decisively with the country's economic problems. But so far they have dismissed all suggestions for drastic new remedies for the weak economy.
As the speech has gone through one draft after another, the President, officials said, has more or less decided against proposing the kind of specific new tax cuts that have been recommended by Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and others on the Republican Party's conservative flank.
Some of the President's advisers say that having broken the promise he made on taxes at the last Republican convention, Mr. Bush could open himself to ridicule with a comparably firm statement this year. "It would be a home run or a tremendous disaster," one adviser said. "It's just too risky."
Instead, officials said that unless someone has a brainstorm, Mr. Bush intends to take a broad approach that will place him and the party on the side of reducing taxes and controlling spending without saying precisely which taxes and spending programs would be involved, other than measures he has already offered that have been blocked in Congress.
 
'Making People Trust Him'
 "The President needs to use the speech to begin the process of making people trust him again when he talks about the economy," one official said. "That's not something you can do in one night, which is one reason that the 'big idea' approach has not gotten anywhere."
Mr. Bush's past speeches dealing with the economy have been seen as duds. In his State of the Union Message in January, he said, "I mean to speak of big things."
But then he offered a laundry list of disparate proposals that seemed to many analysts to have no enthusiasm or theme. He urged Congress to "modify the passive loss rule" and to "fund our H.O.P.E. housing proposal" -- words unlikely to instill confidence.
The economy section of Thursday night's speech is being drafted primarily by Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Robert B. Zoellick, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, one of Mr. Baker's closest associates who will move with his boss to the White House.
Mr. Baker dealt with economic issues under President Ronald Reagan. He was White House chief of staff in Mr. Reagan's first term and Treasury Secretary in the second. Mr. Darman was his deputy throughout.
 
The Old and the New
 Mr. Darman was with the President at Camp David, Md., last weekend and flew here Monday with him on Air Force One. Interviewed today on the Cable News Network, he said:
"A good deal of what the President has to say will involve the old plan, because an awful lot of it makes sense and has not been enacted. But there will be some new things. But I wouldn't want to mislead you or your viewers. I think that the speech is likely to be more thematic."
Mr. Zoellick was still writing at a computer in the conference room of the Houstonian Hotel, where the President is staying, at midnight Monday.
Mr. Baker is at his ranch in Wyoming and will not arrive here until Wednesday, but he has kept in constant touch with the speech-drafting through Mr. Zoellick, aides said.
The principal speech writer is Raymond K. Price, who was Richard M. Nixon's chief speechwriter and has sporadically worked for other Republican Presidents. Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman, has been instrumental in drafting the parts of the speech not involving the economy.
Officials who have followed the drafting said the speech would deal in some detail with Mr. Bush's foreign policy successes and would try to draw distinctions between him and Republicans on the one hand and Gov. Bill Clinton and Democrats on the other.
But the economic theme is by far the most important one, the officials said, since the President and his advisers believe that is the ground on which the election will be decided.
Since early in his Presidency, Mr. Bush has received conflicting advice about the economy.
One wing of the party, represented by Mr. Kemp and others instrumental in the supply-side revolution of the Reagan years, holds that tax cuts are the key to growth. They have pressed the President to propose lower taxes and to battle Congress to win them.
 
Looking to the Deficit
 Another group that includes Mr. Darman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, maintains that the budget deficit must be brought under control first.
Mr. Bush listened to the second group two years ago, when he broke his campaign promise and struck a deficit-reduction agreement with Congress that increased taxes by more than $130 billion over five years.
Many Republicans here believe that was the beginning of the President's political fall and the source of the credibility problem he is hoping to solve with his acceptance speech Thursday night. But other politicians question that judgment, saying that if the economy were strong, Mr. Bush's broken tax promise would be disregarded.
The Brady-Darman-Boskin camp argues that the President has suffered most from what they call false Democratic charges that he generally sides with the well-to-do over ordinary Americans. These advisers say that Mr. Bush would be sure to lose a tax-cut fight with the Democratic Congress, and that in the process the portrayal of the President as the patron of fat cats would be enhanced.
Mr. Kemp has often been at odds with Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who delivered the Keynote Address on Tuesday night. Mr. Gramm, a Ph.D. economist, also advocates lower taxes but primarily stresses bringing the budget into balance. They are potential competitors for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996.
Mr. Bush's speech will embrace a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, which Mr. Gramm champions, while rejecting Mr. Kemp's call for bold new tax proposals.
In his own speech Tuesday night, which was presumably cleared by the Bush camp, Mr. Kemp did not talk about the specific tax measures he was advocating publicly here last week.
Some politicians have been urging Mr. Bush to make big changes in his economic-policy staff, but his close friendship with Mr. Brady and the leading role Mr. Darman has played in drafting the speech seem to indicate that, for the time being at least, that advice is being rejected.
In political and economic circles, there is much speculation about how Mr. Baker's transfer to the White House will affect Mr. Darman.
Martin Anderson, an economist in the Reagan Administration who met with Mr. Bush last week, said he expected Mr. Darman to lose influence because he would be relegated to being Mr. Baker's deputy, a postition he held for most of the Reagan era. But other officials said Mr. Darman's position would be enhanced because Mr. Baker was so comfortable depending on him.

HEADLINE: Out of the Toolbox, Into the Kitchen

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
IT may not be long before chefs start wearing hard hats instead of toques. Many of them are already using equipment -- electric drills, blowtorches and such -- usually associated with construction work instead of cooking.
"Yeah, the blowtorch works great," said Alfred Portale, the chef at the Gotham Bar and Grill in New York. "It's the quickest, most direct way to glaze the top of a berry gratin or a creme brulee. You don't heat up the whole dessert when you just wave the torch over the top. You've got control." 
 Chefs are always looking for better, more efficient and economical methods of turning out good food. And sometimes this search takes them to the toolbox or the plumbing-supply store.
"I love to rummage in hardware stores because I'm always coming up with something interesting to use," said Michel Richard, the chef and owner of Citrus in Los Angeles.
Sometimes even the tack shop can be a source. "We use those brushes made for grooming horses to take the scales off fish," said Robert Del Grande, the chef and owner of Cafe Annie in Houston. So does Mark Peel, the chef and an owner of Campanile in Los Angeles. So the fact that Texas is horse country has nothing to do with taking the currycomb from stable to kitchen.
Ice carving is not an everyday kitchen activity, but chefs who do the elaborate banquet centerpieces often use chain saws to cut the blocks of ice. Among the chefs whose work includes creating the shimmering tours de force are Donald Donovan of the Millenium Hotel, which opened in June in lower Manhattan. Along with chain saws, the chefs rely on electric routers for carving the ice and ordinary household irons for smoothing the edges.
David Burke, the chef and an owner of Park Avenue Cafe in Manhattan is particulary fond of outlandish tools in the kitchen. He uses an electric drill with a special hollow bit to slice the kernels off corn on the cob. "The drill bit is like a cookie cutter, exactly the diameter of the cob so as it goes down, it shaves the kernels right off," he said. "Sometimes we just use it on the ends to make natural handles on the cob."
Using a drill in this manner may be unusual, but in restaurants today, the blowtorch has become common, replacing the broiler or salamander for burnishing a variety of foods. This fall, when "Trucs of the Trade" by Frank Ball and Arlene Feltman is published by HarperCollins, home cooks who read about chefs' cooking tricks -- trucs in French -- may follow suit. In telling how to achieve a crisp layer of caramelized sugar on creme brulee the way restaurants do, Hubert Keller, the chef and owner of Fleur de Lys in San Francisco, advised, "First, go to the hardware store and buy a propane torch."
But in many instances, a special purchase is not necessary. Sometimes, everyday equipment that is simply not associated with the kitchen is used. In "More Classic Italian Cooking" (Knopf, 1978), Marcella Hazan recommended using a blow-dryer on the skin of a duck before roasting. "This is to keep the pores wide open and ease the outflow of fat while roasting," she wrote.
Duck gets somewhat different treatment at the hands of Eileen Yin-Fei Lo, who teaches and writes about Chinese cooking. She uses a bicycle pump to separate the skin from the flesh of a whole duck and also suggests using a small electric fan to dry the duck before roasting it, Peking style, to insure crispness.
Rose Levy Beranbaum, the author of books on baking, relies on dental floss to slice horizontally through delicate cake layers more effectively than with a knife. Why dental floss? Her mother is a dentist.
A number of chefs use a time-honored Italian grandmother's trick to weight a butterflied chicken as it grills or sautes: they place a clean brick on top.
Mr. Richard of Citrus has started using glass chimneys for foie gras, stuffing the cylinders and then chilling them, so that he can slice perfect rounds as he pushes out the foie gras.
Most chefs rely on needle-nose pliers to remove pin bones from fish. These tough little vertical bones remain after filleting and can easily be detected by running a hand lightly over the fish. Chefs pull them out one by one with the pliers.
Plastic squeeze bottles are also used routinely in professional kitchens for edging desserts with multicolored borders, floating a decorative flourish of cream or herb-infused oil on a bowl of soup or covering a plate with Abstract Expressionist dots and swirls of sauce.
Plastic spray bottles can mist oil over, say, thin slices of potato before baking, a method that involves using less oil than a brush, reducing the fat for the customer and the expense for the restaurant. In Mr. Burke's kitchen at Park Avenue Cafe, a commercial paint sprayer is pressed into service when an even coating of chocolate is needed on a dessert or plate.
Another of his technical improvisations is to use lengths of ordinary copper plumbing pipe in the oven. He wraps the dough for skinny baguettes in parchment and bakes them inside the pipes so they hold their shape. "I got the idea when I worked in France and saw how the French baked their tall cylindrical brioches in coffee cans," Mr. Burke said. At the same time, lacy potato gaufrettes are laid on the outside of the pipes, to crisp into graceful curves as they brown.
Not so long ago chefs used $5 stainless-steel molds, imported from France, for creating tidy little cylinders of fish tartare, salad or grains to garnish a plate. Looking for something cheaper, a number of chefs first tried small tin cans, like tunafish cans, with the tops and bottoms removed. But these did not offer a range of sizes. So now chefs head for plumbing suppliers, where they buy white PVC pipe in various diameters. They cut the pipe to make rings of the desired size, and it's easy to make 30 or 40 rings at a fraction of the price of the French ones.
John Doherty, the executive chef at the Waldorf-Astoria, prefers a scalpel from a surgical supply company to a knife for some fine cutting and trimming jobs, especially with fibrous ingredients like leeks. Some chefs also use surgical syringes to infuse flavorings into meats and other foods.
Most of the time chefs resort to unusual, nonculinary equipment because it represents some improvement over the utensils regularly found in the kitchen. But they are also not immune to displays of bravura.
In the private dining room adjacent to the glassed-in open kitchen at Park Avenue Cafe, Mr. Burke astounds diners as he buzzes ears of corn with his drill. And sometimes at charity benefits, onlookers gape as Mr. Portale of Gotham Bar and Grill and a platoon of chefs aim flaming torches at hundreds of berry gratins.
"People get a real kick out of it," he said, "and besides, it's fun."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Donald Donovan, Millenium Hotel chef, cuts ice for a centerpiece with a chain saw.; Alfred Portale, the chef at the Gotham Bar and Grill, browning sugar with blowtorch. (Photographs by Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times) (pg. C3)

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS: THE OVERVIEW;
REPUBLICANS ASSAIL CLINTON AS RADICAL AND BIG SPENDER AND ASSERT BUSH STRENGTHS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The Republicans pressed their lacerating attack on Gov. Bill Clinton and the Democrats in Congress at their National Convention today, as speaker after speaker portrayed Mr. Clinton as a radical liberal who would coddle criminals, disarm America and break the economy with higher taxes and more Government spending.
President Bush worked in his hotel room with his advisers to devise an acceptance speech intended to restore the credibility of the "read my lips" candidate's economic promises. As if previewing his themes, Mr. Bush promised in interviews to put new faces in his Cabinet in a second term, restore economic growth and take a tougher line with Congress.
 
An Image of Diversity
 This produced a wave of reports across the Astrodome that the three men widely regarded as the architects of Mr. Bush's unpopular economic policies -- Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; the budget director, Richard G. Darman; and the chief White House economist, Michael J. Boskin -- would be offered as sacrifices after the election. 
 In the Astrodome, there was no mention of Mr. Bush's broken promise not to raise taxes; apologies were left for the President himself to make on Thursday night. And the night's speeches were a dutiful effort to make the case for Mr. Bush's domestic policies that lacked the full-throated conservatism of Patrick J. Buchanan's speech the previous night or the nostalgic fire of Ronald Reagan's.
A parade of public officials representing minorities, the disabled and even abortion rights advocates took the stage to paint a picture of diversity and to praise President Bush and hammer away at the Republican themes for the fall campaign: Mr. Bush won the cold war and the war against Iraq, he represents "family values" and he is a skilled diplomat.
 
Contenders for '96 Speak
 After an opening night devoted to reassuring the party's conservative wing, today's events reached for a broader audience: from Barbara Bush's appearance at a morning meeting entitled "Black America Salutes the First Family," to the night's main attractions; the keynote address tonight by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a proponent of Federal budget cutting, and a speech by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, the apostle of tax cuts and populist conservatism, who received a rousing welcome from a crowd waving signs bearing his name.
"At the New York convention, Clinton was like a used-car salesman peddling his vehicle for change," said Mr. Gramm, an ex-Democrat who along with Mr. Kemp is a leading contender for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996. "The wax job was shiny, the hubcaps sparkled, the upholstery was spotless, the paint was new. But when you look under the hood, he's peddling a model from the 1970's, a Carter mobile with the axle broken and the frame bent to the left."
Appropriating the images of the Democratic National Convention, the Republicans peppered their speeches with references to their humble beginnings, pledges of tolerance and vows of racial harmony. Despite their adoption of a platform that demands a constitutional ban on abortion, the Republicans tried to heal their rift over the issue by allowing the rallying cry of the abortion rights movement to be sounded at their stage.
"I want the government out of your pocketbook and out of your bedroom," Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts declared, to an even mix of cheers and boos.
Mrs. Bush preached a message of tolerance and warmth on national television. "Don't be judgmental of others," Mrs. Bush said in an interview on CNN. "Everybody's different. Everybody has their own problems."
But behind the scenes, Republican strategists -- driven by the conviction that religion and cultural divides are still powerful tools -- unapologetically proclaimed their intention to follow Patrick J. Buchanan's declaration of a religious and cultural war with the Democrats.
 
Strength and Prosperity
 While Mr. Clinton was portrayed as a threat to the nation's security on Monday night, the line of today's attack was primarily on economic and social issues, coordinated by convention managers who were providing themes to speakers and reviewing their speeches in advance.
Like the Communists in North Korea and Cuba, Mr. Gramm said, the Democrats "believe that the answer to every problem is more government." Mr. Gramm set the tone for the Republicans' counteroffensive on domestic issues: Mr. Bush does have a program, he said, but the Democrats in Congress will not permit it to be enacted.
"Our President asked Congress for the tools to rebuild the economy and for weapons to win back our streets and Congress bent them and broke them and threw them away," Mr. Gramm said.
"Democrats," he said, "Democrats and Republicans agree on one thing: We both want change. The debate is not about who is for change; it's about the direction of the change. Today America stands at the crossroads. It's time for choosing: their way of more taxing or our way of more jobs; their way of more government or our way of more opportunity."
Another theme Mr. Gramm sounded was that the election of Mr. Clinton would lead to a weak America.
"We have not forgotten that the last Democrat in the White House so decimated defense that on any given day, 50 percent of our planes couldn't fly and our ships couldn't sail, because we didn't have spare parts and mechanics," Mr. Gramm said.
"Under Republican leadership, we changed all that," he said. "We modernized our weapons and we recruited and have retained the finest young men and women who have ever worn the uniform of this country. And they wear that uniform all over the world tonight with a new pride and a new confidence, and we Republicans are committed to keeping it that way."
He declared, "We must never -- we must never allow the Democrats to disarm America again."
As is his custom, Mr. Gramm relied heavily in his remarks on one Dicky Flatt of Mexia, Tex., a printer Mr. Gramm gives as an example of a small businessman whose modest resources should always be considered by Congress when it appropriates money.
 
Kemp Acts the Loyalist
 Mr. Kemp's speech, however, was notable for the absence of his favorite subject: the tax cut he has been trying to force on Mr. Bush. Instead, he was a loyal soldier, attacking the Democrats.
"The Democrats' New Covenant is not new," he said. "It's not change. It doesn't put people first; it puts government first. It doesn't empower people; it empowers bureaucracy. It doesn't encourage investment and growth; it spends, and spends and spends."
He added: "We've got a great team. And let me say as an old football player who played in this very stadium: we've got a great quarterback in George Bush."
Mr. Kemp also sought to link Mr. Bush's economic expertise to his international stature, relating a conversation he had with a former mayor of Moscow. The mayor told him he won election by advocating the right to own one's own home and pledging to make downtown a free enterprise zone. "I said, 'Mr. Mayor, where did you get these radical ideas?' " Mr. Kemp said. "He said, 'Mr. Kemp, I got them from the 1980 Republican platform of Ronald Reagan and George Bush.'
"Ladies and gentlemen," Mr. Kemp said, "Communism didn't fall. It was pushed."
After a brief appearance this morning at an anti-drug rally, President Bush and his advisers conferred in his suite in the Houstonian Hotel on a speechfor Thursday night intended to start the process of regaining voters' confidence in him as an economic manager and of re-establishing the credibility of his promises.
Taking a step toward that goal, Mr. Bush signaled today that he would revamp his Cabinet if he were re-elected. "You'll see plenty of new faces, plenty of changes in this Administration," he said in an interview on the "MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour."
There was no official confirmation of the reports about the departure of the top economic-policy officials. But senior campaign aides and Republican office-holders said Mr. Boskin needed to return around the end of the year to Stanford University, where he is a professor of economics, to retain his tenure. They also said the Mr. Brady and his wife have told friends that he did not wish to hold his job into a second term, but that Mr. Darman wanted to stay on.
In the interview, Mr. Bush also promised "a rather booming economy" in a second term and an even more aggressive stance with Congress, going on the offensive against individual lawmakers to sell his programs to the public.
 
Democrats Salt the Wound
 As Mr. Bush toiled, the political climate heated up with an unusual convention-week exchange between the two campaign organizations. In new television advertisements, the Democrats broadcast a commercial hitting a sore point of Mr. Bush: "On Nov. 5, 1990, George Bush signed into law the second-biggest tax increase in American history."
In the convention hall, the lineup of speakers seemed to imitate the Democrats' presentation in New York last month of minorities, women and the disabled. But the convention produced a far more mixed set of signals than the Democrats created in the Clinton-orchestrated convention. Uncertain of their ability to run on the economy, the Republicans were firing a scattershot of campaign themes, some borrowed from the last Presidential contest.
Speakers tried to tar Mr. Clinton with the American Civil Liberties Union, homosexual advocates and radical feminists. Attorney General Dan Lungren of California stunned the morning session into silence by resurrecting the Willie Horton case of 1988 and hurling it at Mr. Clinton as evidence that Democrats are soft on crime.
After months of criticism that its message was not getting through to voters, the Bush campaign moved to reinforce its advertising and communications staffs today, bringing in a veteran strategist, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., to coordinate advertising strategy and policy. It expanded the role of two advisers, James Lake and Roger Ailes, making Mr. Lake communications director and Mr. Ailes a more frequent consultant.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK AGENCY CUTS APARTMENTS FOR THE HOMELESS

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
Attributing an array of new problems in New York City's housing projects to a program to set aside thousands of apartments for homeless families, Housing Authority officials say they plan to sharply reduce the number of apartments given to the homeless in the future.
The shift in policy has created a division between the Housing Authority and other officials of the Dinkins administration who are scrambling to find homes for thousands of families each year and say they are counting on the Authority to provide apartments. 
 At stake, say Housing Authority officials, is the future of the city's 324 housing projects, home to more than 600,000 people. Adding more homeless families, the officials say, could upset the careful balance of low- and middle-income tenants that has produced some of the most successful public housing in the country.
The head of the Housing Authority, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, said she had told the Mayor's staff that the homeless families, many of them ill equipped to live on their own, had brought theft, drug abuse and other crimes to once-stable projects.
 
Promised Services Lacking
 "We told them that public housing is a short-term solution and they will pay a very big price in the long term," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said in an interview yesterday. "They'll destroy the lives of 600,000 other people."
Over the last four years, more than 8,000 homeless families have been moved into city housing projects.
Officials of the city's Human Resources Administration, which operates homeless shelters, said yesterday that they were counting on the Housing Authority to provide 2,000 apartments for the homeless this year.
Mayor David N. Dinkins appointed Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, a longtime ally, to head the Housing Authority five months ago. The authority is a semi-autonomous agency financed by the Federal Government with a three-member governing board appointed by the Mayor.
Housing officials are also complaining that the city has failed to provide the homeless families -- many of whom are struggling with problems ranging from drug abuse to long-term unemployment -- with services it had promised. More than 80 percent do not even have furniture, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said.
"There's clearly a growing problem," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said. "We tracked our first 2,000 homeless families and it is clear that there is a high incidence of contact with the police department, drug dealing and harassment of other tenants."
James L. Capoziello, an H.R.A. official in charge of adult services, said yesterday that there was no reason to conclude that homeless people cause more problems than others who live in public housing. He said the H.R.A. had made substantial efforts to provide social services to the homeless who were placed in public housing and planned to increase the services.
Many experts have attributed the success of New York City's Housing projects to a longstanding practice of screening applicants and strictly apportioning apartments, assigning one third each to the elderly and to low- and middle-income families.
But in 1988 the authority made an exception. It made a four-year agreement with the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch to put 2,000 homeless families annually at the head of a long waiting list for places in the city's housing projects. The average wait for the apartments is 12 years.
 
Concern About Dumping
 Since her appointment, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero has made reassessing the authority's role in aiding the homeless a priority. "I am deeply concerned that we do not dump large numbers of low-income people in public housing in a way that would destabilize the developments and make them impossible to manage," she said.
The policy of giving preference to the homeless has encouraged people to move into shelters, she said, as a way of jumping to the top of the waiting list for space in housing projects. The situation is unfair to those on the waiting list who are only "marginally housed" or living in overcrowded circumstances, she said.
Deputy Mayor Cesar A. Perales said Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's objections had been under discussion for more than a month and the matter had not yet been settled. "The issue is not whether they will take any families, but how many," he said. "It is proving difficult to come to that number."
Some 5,300 families are now living in homeless shelters and hotels and are awaiting placement in either public or private housing.
About 8,000 of the authority's 180,000 apartments are vacated each year. In recent months more than half of the vacancies have been going to the homeless and others with "very low income," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said.
 
Complaints from Projects
 "We are taking families that have not been prepared to be responsible tenants," she said. "They have tremendous social service needs. We're not doing them any good and we're not doing the tenants any good."
Ada H. Gonzalez-Delgado, who supervises the handful of Housing Authority social workers in the Bronx, said she frequently encountered families from city shelters who were greatly in need of social services, but had received almost none.
Many of the families squander money they have been given to buy furniture because they do not know how to shop, she said. Some vastly overpay for household items and others spend their entire furniture allowance for big-screen televisions or stereo equipment, she said.
Wanda Gilliam, the manager of the Borinquen Plaza project in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, said there was tremendous resentment of homeless families. Many of the homeless, she said, "are not realistic about what living in a housing project means."
At the Stanley Isaacs project in Harlem yesterday Rose Bergin, the president of the tenants association, complained that a formerly homeless man was arrested and jailed on charges of rape and sodomy after moving into the complex. To the anger of many in the project, his newly renovated apartment has been kept empty for months since his arrest, Mrs. Bergin said.
Her husband, Jimmy, said he had been forced to call the police once because another of the formerly homeless "walking around nude right in front of the kids."
At the Borinquen Plaza project, two teen-age boys who had been moved in from a shelter terrorized residents for months, robbing them at gunpoint and stealing cars. Tenants complained repeatedly, but the authority was unable to evict them, Ms. Gilliam said. After 17 arrests, the boys are now in jail.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said the authority planned to institute a rigorous new screening process that would be applied to the homeless and all other applicants for public housing. Applicants will be screened for criminal records, rent payment history and their behavior while living in homeless shelters, she said.

PUB-DATE: August 20, 1992

HEADLINE: UNDER THE DOME: The Overview;
REPUBLICANS SEND BUSH INTO THE CAMPAIGN UNDER A BANNER STRESSING 'FAMILY VALUES'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Thursday, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Republicans this morning formally nominated President Bush for a second term, with Barbara Bush leading a nominating parade that cast her husband as the guardian of traditional family values and suggested that the Democrats were far less committed to the cause.
Mr. Bush continued to work on an acceptance speech for tonight that close advisers said would almost certainly include some kind of apology for his handling of the economy. But it was still being debated whether this should be a forthright confession of error for breaking his "no new taxes" pledge or a more general acknowledgement that he should have taken a tougher line on spending and the deficit. 
 The 2,210 delegates set aside their worries about the economy and the election and celebrated the ritual of renominating their President after hearing a beaming Mrs. Bush declare: "Tonight, you will nominate George Bush to lead our nation into its future. With all my heart I say -- and I know him best -- you've made a wonderful choice."
 
Head of the Family
 With that, Mr. Bush joined his family, 22 strong counting children and grandchildren, on the stage before the cheering crowd. It was a glowing tableau of familial warmth, evoking the kinder, gentler George Bush on the eve of what is expected to be a bitter and hard-fought campaign.
"We'll see you all tomorrow night," Mr. Bush said, as the chants of "Four more years" rolled on.
Mr. Bush was officially nominated by the Secretary of Labor, Lynn Martin, who was part of the parade of women who came to the lectern to endorse the President. She also struck another main theme of the convention -- that Mr. Bush has had, on balance, a successful Presidency and has insured an era of Pax Americana.
"Our children can now go to bed in peace and not wake to the fear of nuclear war," Ms. Martin said. "Are we better off than four years ago? Of course we are."
Mr. Bush received the necessary 1,106 delegate votes and went over the top at 12:10 A.M. local time, with the votes of his adopted state, Texas.
A short time after the roll-call, Vice President Dan Quayle was renominated by acclamation.
 
Flag and Nationhood
 Much of the evening was devoted to a theme that Republican strategists hope will win back many of the middle-class voters who have left Mr. Bush because of the economy. Republicans, who seized the symbols of flag and nationhood in 1988 to powerful effect, presented themselves last night as the party of the American family, and presented the Bushes as emblematic of the ideal.
There were two sides to the politics of family here last night -- one embodied by the motherly, embracing oratory of Mrs. Bush, the other by pointed commentary by Marilyn Quayle that seemed intended to evoke an unflattering comparison with Gov. Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary.
Mrs. Quayle gave a combative speech that raised once again the old dividing lines of the 1960's, between those who joined the "counterculture" and those who did not, and a more modern division between career women and those who "love being mothers or wives, which gives our lives a richness that few men or women get from professional accomplishment alone."
Mrs. Bush, whose poll ratings far exceed her husband's and who surrounded herself on the stage with her children and grandchildren, struck an inclusive and tolerant tone. She recounted her own traditional life, but pointedly reached out to parents who follow a different path.
"You may be exhausted from working a job, or two jobs, and taking care of your children, or you may have put your career on hold," Mrs. Bush said. "Either way, you may wonder, as I did every now and then, am I really doing the right thing?"
She paused, looked over the sprawling hall and into the television cameras, and answered, "Yes, you are."
It was a night that gave a feminine voice and face to a party that has often suffered from a gender gap. Among the women who spoke was Mary Fisher, an artist from a prominent Republican family who is infected with the AIDS virus. She talked of her worries for the nation's children in the epidemic, in a speech that moved many of the delegates to tears and served as a gentle rebuke to a party often accused of not doing enough on AIDS.
"People with H.I.V. have not entered some alien state of being," Ms. Fisher said."They are human.
"They have not earned cruelty, and they do not deserve meanness."
Ms. Fisher, who ended with a poignant thought of how she would like to be remembered by her two children, said, "We do the President's cause no good if we praise the American family but ignore a virus that destroys it."
On the third night of their 35th convention, the Republicans, fortified by a poll that showed their offensive was taking a toll on the Democratic nominee, pressed their attacks on Mr. Clinton. A survey by CBS News showed that negative opinions of Mr. Clinton had risen this week while positive views were dropping. Opinions about Mr. Bush had improved, though only marginally.
Earlier Wednesday, Mr. Bush continued to try to rally a nervous party, predicting that the American people would inevitably return to his side as a man who could be trusted with the Presidency. In a speech to a Republican National Committee luncheon, Mr. Bush blasted the Democrats as the "Government-first crowd," a play on their convention promise to "put people first."
In keeping with the theme of the day, he also talked of his life as a young oilman, raising his family in West Texas. "I remember the rhythms of that part of our country, the rhythms of West Texas, Friday night football, Saturday night picnics, and the Sunday sermon," said Mr. Bush, whose speech was interrupted by demonstrators chanting, "What about AIDS?"
Wednesday night, Mr. Bush appeared from the wings of the convention stage after his wife and their 16-year-old grandson, George Prescott Bush, spoke of their love and respect for the President as a family man. Mr. Bush plunged into the embrace of the younger children as the convention rose in applause.
 
Mood Turns Somnolent
 But after the appearance of the First Family, which was timed for maximum television exposure but pushed the nominating procedure back into the early morning hours, the excitement quickly faded. By midnight local time, when the delegates were about halfway through the nominating roll call, complete with evocations of hometown sports teams and even, in the case of Idaho, a paean to the official state tuber, the atmosphere went from electric to somnolent.
The vast stadium was three quarters empty, the VIP booths were abandoned, and delegates, funny hats pulled down over their eyes, sprawled across chairs, sound asleep.
Even as the ritual of rallying behind the President proceeded, the White House still had considerable political work to do. It tried to tamp down rumors on Wednesday about a Cabinet shake-up, speculation that was spurred by Mr. Bush's comments in a PBS interview on Tuesday night that his second Administration would have a new face. And within the Administration, the scrambling continued on Mr. Bush's acceptance speech, which Republican strategists say is critical to restoring his credibility on the economy and domestic policy in general.
 
Rebuilding Trust
 Dealing with his broken vow of "no new taxes," made four years ago when he accepted the nomination in New Orleans, is a central part of the challenge. Mr. Bush has said more than once that he made a mistake when he signed on to the 1990 budget agreement that included new taxes, but a senior Administration official suggested that more was coming: "It's not only what he wants to do; a lot of people think he's got to talk about it if he wants to win people back."
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was in the convention hall of the Astrodome last night as he moved toward taking control of the Bush re-election drive. One senior Republican close to the Administration predicted a major shake-up after Mr. Baker's return. Roger Ailes, Mr. Bush's 1988 media director, was on hand, as well, to assist in speech preparation.
Among the ideas being considered, in a week filled with Adminstration brainstorming on how to generate some momentum for the Bush campaign, was a threat to veto legislation appropriating Congressional salaries unless Congress passes his economic proposals. But a senior Administration official suggested that this kind of brinksmanship with Congress could be counterproductive.
 
Democrats See Distraction
 For their part, Democrats asserted that Mr. Bush was simply trying to distract the American people from the ailing economy with all the pro-family oratory. Mr. Clinton himself on Wednesday tried to seize the moral high ground in the daily war of television images. The Arkansas Governor joined his wife, Hillary; his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, Tipper Gore and former President Jimmy Carter in building a house in Atlanta. "We thought it would be a good day to be building, not tearing down," Mr. Clinton said.
Republican strategists denied that they were appealing to social divisions, insisting they were only drawing a contrast with the Democrats on a range of cultural issues and taking a stand with middle America. But Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst, asserted that the party was trying to "resurrect and repackage" a set of cultural issues that helped create the Republican coalition of the late 1960's, as well as "playing indirectly" to the allegations of infidelity involving Mr. Clinton.
Mrs. Quayle appealed to the voters of the baby boom generation last night -- the ones, she said, who did not "join the counterculture," or demonstrate, or take drugs, or "dodge the draft" or believe "that the family was so oppressive that women could only thrive apart from it."
She did not mention Hillary Clinton, who has been denounced from the Republican stage this week as a militant feminist lawyer who equates marriage with slavery, a charge that Democrats assert is ludicrous. But the comparison was implicit.
Mrs. Quayle noted that she left her law practice to work on her husband's campaigns and raise their children and said she had no regrets. "Most of us love being mothers or wives, which gives our lives a richness that few men or women get from professional accomplishment alone," Mrs. Quayle said.
The Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who ran for the Republican nomination four years ago, also weighed in on the American family last night. "George Bush's vision for America, ladies and gentlemen, is one of faith in God, strong families, freedom, individual initiative and free enterprise," Mr. Robertson said.
"The vision of Bill Clinton is a liberal welfare state that dominates every facet of our lives, burdens free enterprise, redistributes wealth, raises taxes and weakens the family," he said.
Mr. Robertson asserted that Mr. Clinton would "make sexual preference a privileged minority under our civil rights laws" and was "running on a platform that calls for saving the spotted owl, but never once mentions the name of God."
 
Plea for Compassion
 Republican officials said the family-values debate had to do with policies, not personalities. They said that on issues from tuition vouchers for private and religious schools to a private approach to the health-care crisis, Mr. Bush clearly favors policies that would give more power and support to families. In contrast, they argued, Mr. Clinton backs an approach to domestic problems that stresses more of a governmental solution.
The CBS Poll released Wednesday night, based on interviews conducted Tuesday night and Wednesday morning, showed that Mr. Clinton was now viewed favorably by 30 percent of the registered voters, and unfavorably by 31 percent. That marked a deterioration from his standing last week, when he was viewed favorably by 36 percent, unfavorably by 24 percent. The latest poll was based on interviews with 642 registered voters and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Another poll released Wednesday, conducted by The Washington Post and ABC News, showed Mr. Clinton holding a 25-point lead, but it was based on interviews conducted Friday through Tuesday.
