HEADLINE: BIOGRAPHY OF A CANDIDATE: Man in the News;
Making and Remaking a Political Identity: George Herbert Walker Bush

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
It was torture, in 1988, for George Bush to try to explain who he was. Plucking at his chest, as though he could pull his soul out of a buttoned-down shirt, he told campaign aides, "We got to get me out there; we got to get more of me out there."
Throughout his Presidency, he has known, as he once put it, that people were "trying to figure out what makes this crazy guy tick" and wondering whether "there was some there there -- if not in me then in others" around him. 
 Perhaps there has never been a politician who has labored so long, and so reluctantly, to define and redefine, explain and explain yet again, who he is. Four years after pledging to reveal his "heartbeat" in a convention speech, he was frantically working until the last minute on a speech intended to show "what is in my heart."
George Herbert Walker Bush is an existential Yankee -- born in Milton, Mass., reared in Greenwich, Conn., and now living in the moment -- who never seems to understand why he cannot just be. He draws strength from his title. He is President, and therefore he is doing something right, he will tell those who challenge him.
But the problem is this: George Bush has projected many different versions of George Bush over the years, trying to court and hold a disparate coalition. His image now is not so much like his bold bronze statue in the Astrodome, with gaze fixed and body standing firm against the wind. It is more like a hologram that changes depending on the angle from which you look at it.
He can be charming. He can be whiny. He can be passive. He can be hyperactive. He can be conservative. He can be moderate. He can be firm. He can be, as an aide once said, a victim of his last conversation. He bashes Democrats in Congress. He eats barbecue at the White House with Democrats in Congress.
With his mother's voice in one ear, reminding him not to gloat, he can be modest. With his own voice in the other ear, reminding him that he has completed many important missions, he can be proud and confident.
He can be principled, seeming unconcerned about the political cost, as he was when he stood up to Saddam Hussein and when he insisted that Israel freeze settlements in the West Bank as a condition for $10 billion in loan guarantees.
But more often, as with his shifting stands on abortion, taxes and civil rights, political costs seem to determine his principles.
In the most revealing comment ever made about Mr. Bush, the late C. Fred Chambers, a Texas oil executive and a close friend, explained why Mr. Bush, as a young politician in Houston, had changed to a more progressive position on civil rights. "George understands that you have to do politically prudent things to get in a position to do what you want," he said.
Democrats, predictably, put it less kindly. "You can't find an issue in the last 30 years that George Bush hasn't been on both sides of, with the exception of cutting the capital gains tax," said James Carville, a strategist for Gov. Bill Clinton.
Indeed, Mr. Bush's strongest conviction has been born of his class. The boy nicknamed "Poppy" who rode out the Depression in a chauffeured sedan that ferried him to Greenwich Country Day School, the boy whose father was a pillar of the Wall Street establishment, grew up believing that what fuels America is capital and that its preservation is of paramount importance.
"He thinks Bill Clinton would be a disaster as President because he doesn't understand capitalism, as we perceive it," said Jonathan Bush, the President's younger brother.
 
Political Chameleon Eager to Please
 Ever since he began his political career in Houston in the early 1960's, when he appalled his moderate supporters by soothing the John Birch Society-types in the Goldwater movement, Mr. Bush has been making one Faustian bargain after another, veering between the right wing he needed and the moderate Republican wing that was his heritage. He was brought up in a world that valued public service, internationalist goals and noblesse oblige, the responsibility of the powerful to help the less powerful.
It is the worst fear of some friends that he may have sold off too many pieces of himself, in the mistaken belief he could someday get them back; that in his boyish eagerness to avoid conflict, to knit together opposing groups, to please everyone, he may have lost the ability to project a simple, coherent set of political ideas.
Mr. Bush's friend, Thomas (Lud) Ashley, a Washington lobbyist who was a Democratic Congressman from Ohio, said the President "finds it hard to get emotionally involved in passionate dislike of one side or another."
"He's not a confrontational guy; he'd rather get along," Mr. Ashley said of the President, who is about to stake his re-election on attacking the Democratic Congress. "He likes Tom Foley and George Mitchell personally."
Mr. Ashley said Mr. Bush's distaste for domestic affairs came from his belief that it is hard to get anything done. "Domestically, he finds it very difficult to get away from what people expect in terms of programs, promises and benefits of one kind or another," Mr. Ashley said. "He finds it difficult to make appealing the idea of more individual self-reliance through better education."
 
Following Footsteps Of a Notable Father
 Mr. Bush had always strived to measure up to the standards of conduct set by his 6-foot-4-inch father, Prescott Bush, a craggy faced investment banker who preceded his son at Yale and in Skull and Bones, the Yale secret society, and in Congress, as a Senator from Connecticut.
His father did not make much of a mark in his two terms in Congress, although he often played golf with his friend, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, at the Burning Tree Country Club.
But Bush pere always made an impression with his rectitude. At an early manufacturing job in St. Louis, he turned his boss in to the police for skimming profits. He would leave a party if anyone used dirty talk, and, even as a freshman Senator, he stood up to Joe McCarthy.
The first time George Bush returned to the family compound at Kennebunkport, Me., after his election as President, he landed on a green and excitedly told the assembled townsfolk, "We zoomed in there in a great big helicopter, and I wondered what my old man would say if he could see his little boy now."
During the 1988 campaign, when it was suggested that Prescott Bush would have been shocked by the ferocity of his son's right-wing themes, George Bush replied, "Well, I think my Dad would be pretty proud of me because I think we've come a long, long way."
Tellingly, Nancy Ellis, the President's sister, cited only one instance when her brother, normally mild-mannered and anxious to please, reminded her of their father: Mr. Bush's recent angry encounter with the families of American servicemen missing in Southeast Asia. "When George said, 'Shut up and sit down,' that was absolutely Dad," she said.
The President's 91-year-old mother, Dorothy, a tennis champion from a wealthy family, was equally starchy, berating her children if they tried to take too much credit for winning at sports. Now, Mr. Bush, at 68, still worries aloud in public about his mother catching him bragging about his accomplishments, especially the war in the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Bush married in 1945. He and his wife, Barbara, have five children; a sixth child died young.
Although Mr. Bush gets intensely uncomfortable with personal scrutiny -- "Don't put me on the couch," he says -- his Presidency has been largely based on personality.
He wants Americans to elect him, not because of ideas, but because he has been bred and educated for public service, and because he is someone they can trust in any situation that arises to do the "right" thing. He presents it as his great accomplishment that he has kept the White House "decent" and "honorable."
Mr. Bush is so focused on the ritual of the Presidency and his role as the caretaker of the office that he usually refers to himself as "the President."
Just so, his longtime supporters rarely point to his politics when they explain their devotion. They just point to Mr. Bush, himself.
 
A Presidency Of Personality
 The reason the "trust" theme will be the main theme of the 1992 campaign is not simply because Mr. Bush sees it as the most potent way to contrast himself with Bill Clinton.
When he says, "Trust me," he is not just saying, "Don't trust the other guy," although that is an important part of his message. He is also coming back to the idea that it is the person you elect, not the party nor the ideology. When Mr. Bush campaigns, he puts on a new persona with the alacrity that he puts on a campaign T-shirt, and when the campaign is over, he takes it off just as fast.
The day after he was elected in 1988 he reassured reporters at a news conference that they would never again see "George the Ripper," the candidate who had conducted a campaign so negative that his campaign manager, Lee Atwater, would apologize for it before he died.
"Oh, that's all history," Mr. Bush said, dismissing the idea that campaign oratory has lasting meaning as though flicking lint off his lapel.
Again, when Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget chief, told the President that he could break his "no new taxes" pledge because Americans did not expect politicians to keep their campaign promises, that made sense to Mr. Bush -- the disconnection between election oratory and just being yourself as President.
 
Gentle Moments, In the White House
 Asked what the President is made of, his friends, family and advisers offer small gentle moments, not large dramatic ones.
His sister remembers the time last spring when she and her friend Jean Wallace Douglas were bird-watching amid the shrubs on the White House lawn near the tennis court. "I heard this 'Tweet, tweet, tweet' that sounded like spring warblers," she said, "and we swung our binoculars around and it was George, hiding in the grass, surrounded by the Secret Service."
Although Mr. Bush has not consistently been seen as a strong leader, his brother Jonathan said George was a pied piper as a youth. "Everyone was drawn to him," he said. "Morris Greenberg, the groundskeeper of Yale, spent more time at George Bush's house there than all the other baseball players. And George would never say, 'Hey, Morris, it's time to go home.' "
His Presidential counsel, C. Boyden Gray, recalls that in the midst of a bad week last week the President still had time to tease him about the mythical tennis-ranking committee, whereby Mr. Bush keeps track of how his tennis Cabinet is doing.
The President has not governed on the basis of ideas, but on the basis of people. He puts the people he believes in around him, and they make it up as they go along -- most notably Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney.
"I would hate to be President without friendships," Mr. Bush said in the first year of his Presidency.
When he needed Mr. Baker to come back and run his campaign, he developed an ideological argument to justify a pragmatic move. He took his argument that foreign policy and domestic policy are intertwined and used it to explain that he wanted Mr. Baker in the White House to take care of the country while he is out campaigning. But it was clear to everyone that Mr. Bush wanted Mr. Baker to take care of his campaign.
Mr. Baker was needed to rescue the President, even though that was a blow to Mr. Bush's pride, because Mr. Bush divides the world into peers and the help, and only a peer like Mr. Baker could really grab him by shoulders and get him to focus.
Even Mr. Bush's area of expertise, foreign policy, was based on personal relationships. Mr. Scowcroft said Mr. Bush had "established a fundamentally new aspect of the Presidency, which is personal diplomacy, which he has elevated to an art form."
All of this served Mr. Bush well, Mr. Scowcroft said, at a time when the old structures of world politics seemed to be collapsing. Mr. Scowcroft, who has served three Presidents, recalled Mr. Bush trying to break the ice with stodgy President Francois Mitterrand of France by speaking to him in his schoolbook French before the official translators arrived.
But because personality was the cement of his Administration and because he has expended so much energy in getting people to like him, Mr. Bush has found it difficult to go into reverse when he must. Although Mr. Bush hates personnel confrontations, he can wield the bat when the choice is between a subordinate, no matter how loyal, and his own survival.
It took him months, but he fired John H. Sununu as chief of staff, and he did not hesitate to cut loose Mr. Sununu's successor, Samuel K. Skinner, when he needed to make room for Mr. Baker. Now, there are rumors that he will offer up some of his top economic advisers as an election-year sacrifice to the conservatives.
 
A Career Promoted By Close Friends
 The two most formative episodes in Mr. Bush's young life were his experiences in the Navy, where he was shot down in the Pacific as a fighter pilot, and his membership in Skull and Bones.
His faith in personal contacts is borne out because he believes they led him to the Presidency. He is a product of an old boy's network that offered him a prestigious trellis, as he climbed from elective office -- the House -- to appointive office -- United Nations Ambassador, chairman of the Republican Party, envoy to China, Director of Central Intelligence.
In 1988, when he was 17 points behind Michael S. Dukakis in the polls, he was asked how he could possibly win. "I have friends," Mr. Bush replied. As it turned out, his friends -- from Ronald Reagan to James Baker to the 2,000 or so political pals in his famous Rolodex -- pulled him through.
"George has 75 hours in his day," his brother Jonathan said. "Otherwise, he could not call and write letters to so many people."
Where his personal charm can be effective one on one, Mr. Bush has failed to connect with the country at moments when Americans are starving for a leader to articulate their anger, anxiety or excitement.
One of the Democrats' campaign themes this year has been that, no matter how decent his instincts, it is hard for Mr. Bush, given his upbringing and his life experiences, to comprehend how difficult life can be for the have-nots.
In Nicholas King's "George Bush: A Biography," Nancy Ellis remembers visits to their grandfather Walker's South Carolina plantation in the 1930's. "I still remember the wonderful food and the care taken over the slightest things, like the trimmed edges of the grapefruit," she said. "We were waited on by the most wonderful black servants who would come into the bedrooms early in the morning and light those crackling pine-wood fires. It used to be freezing."
Jonathan Bush says the criticism is unfair -- "No one ever said that Jack Kennedy had a problem understanding the disadvantaged," he said -- but Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle must still fight criticism that they govern in a tight circle of affluent white men, with little diversity and not enough empathy.
Indeed, Mr. Bush sometimes acts offended when his Administration's policies are linked to him, personally.
Asked once in 1988 how he could portray himself as a good candidate for black Americans, since he had silently watched for eight years as the Reagan Administration watered down civil rights laws and never once invited black leaders to the White House, Mr. Bush looked genuinely hurt. "But I helped found the Yale chapter of the United Negro College Fund," he replied.
 
Delayed Responses, Muddled Stands
 Last winter, when Americans began to express anxiety about the declining economy and the fate of the country -- fears that Patrick J. Buchanan used to fuel his challenge to the President -- Mr. Bush rejected all pleas from advisers to move swiftly to speak to the country and lay out an economic program.
Instead, he took his budget chief's advice and waited more than a month, until his State of the Union Message, so fixed on Washington's political calendar that he could not understand why he should say anything earlier to the rest of the country.
Mr. Bush said he did not want to answer his election rivals until the formal campaign began in the fall. But that does not explain why he could not have reassured Americans about where the country was going. That is governing, not politics.
It also does not explain why, in interview after interview, even when he was given notice that he would be asked about his goals, the President seemed befuddled, offering banalities about "the whole domestic tranquility in a better-educated America."
Whenever he has been asked why he wanted to be President, he mumbles something like, "Challenges, rewards," as he did in 1988, or talks about the honor of serving, as he does now.
Even in foreign affairs, which does interest him, he could never explain why America had the moral obligation to intervene in the Persian Gulf, but not in Sarajevo.
What Mr. Bush has seen in the last year is the limits of a pragmatic, status quo, spontaneous Presidency.
In 1988, it may have been enough to stand before the Republican National Convention and say that America was yearning for a new leader and "I am that man."
In 1992, his advisers concede, Americans are tired and disillusioned with the politician they turned to fend off the Soviet Union. Mr. Bush, who admits that elections are times of renewal, must now find a vivid new shade in his coat of many colors so he can again be "that man," this time for a country that wants its own problems solved.

HEADLINE: A Shield for the Shiites;
The Use of U.S. Air Power in Southern Iraq Can Protect Rebels, With a Nod to Politics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The decision by the United States and its allies to place a protective military umbrella over the southern third of Iraq is a complete reversal of a policy adopted and aggressively defended just after the Persian Gulf war.
In March 1991, the Bush Administration concluded that shooting down Iraqi helicopters to thwart a crackdown on the Shiite Muslims in southern Iraq would be the first step toward a military quagmire. Today some of the same officials who once urged caution are sounding the alarms, building the case for combat patrols to protect the Shiites. 
 The dramatic turnabout reflects a shift in tactics for undermining President Saddam Hussein and what Administration officials describe as a better understanding of who the Shiites in southern Iraq really are: a persecuted people, and not necessarily the precursors of a radical Islamic state that would align itself with Iran.
 
What About Ground Attacks?
 It is also a way for the Republican White House to demonstrate its resolve in the face of Democratic criticism that Washington ended the gulf war prematurely and that its postwar policy toward Baghdad has been indecisive.
Though Administration officials insist that the patrols, which will be carried out together with British and French forces, are not motivated by election-year politics, they acknowledge that taking a sterner stance toward Iraq is likely to be politically popular.
Although the official reaction to the plan in Arab countries has been muted, many governments fear it may foster instability in the region. [Page A8.]
As a military proposition, the mission to protect Iraqi Shiites south of the 32d parallel is not viewed as especially difficult, though any mission over hostile territory risks casualties. While the Iraqi military has deployed SA-2 and SA-6 antiaircraft missiles in the area, Iraq's air defense system is operating at only one-third of its prewar capability, United States officials say.
Even with an allied air umbrella, Mr. Hussein's forces could still attack the Shiites with tanks and artillery. Bush Administration officials have not said what the allies would do then.
Having proclaimed the need to protect the Shiites, the allies would be hard-pressed not to respond with air strikes to any large-scale ground attacks. In that sense, the decision to establish a defensive umbrella may risk still deeper United States military involvement. But unlike the situation just before the gulf war, nobody is talking about sending ground forces against the Iraqi Army.
 
The Precedent of the Kurds
 The Administration's military involvement inside Iraq has been a reluctant one. After the gulf war, the United States helped set up a Kurdish enclave in the north, but only after British pressure and a flood of public sympathy stirred by television pictures of desperate Kurds fleeing Iraqi forces after a failed rebellion. Today, the United States Air Force flies 40 to 60 flights a day out of Turkey over the Kurdish region, indicating that imposing an air umbrella over the south need not be difficult.
Still, the allies had been reluctant to protect the Shiites. In March 1991, with victorious United States Army divisions in the Euphrates Valley and warplanes routinely flying over Iraq, the Administration watched as the Iraqi military ruthlessly crushed a Shiite rebellion, blowing up mosques and strafing the Shiites from helicopter gunships.
At the time, Administration officials argued that while shooting down the Iraqi helicopters looked like an easy thing to do, Iraq could turn into a quagmire. The idea of limiting involvement to protecting the Shiites from air attacks also ran afoul of the Pentagon's doctrine of using overwhelming force to win a decisive victory, so convincingly applied in driving Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
 
No 'Halfway Measures'
 "Somebody said we'll just shoot down helicopters," Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said on April 15, 1991, justifying the refusal to intervene militarily in southern Iraq. "Well, helicopters aren't the only problem. He's got tanks, he's got artillery, and if you're going to get involved in a military action, if you're going to use United States military force, you're going to send our young men and women into combat, we don't like to do it with halfway measures.
"And one of the reasons we were so successful in the gulf at holding casualties down as low as we did on our side, was because we went with overwhelming force," he added.
Another senior Administration official summed up Washington's decision not to protect the Shiites then in one word: geopolitics.
By that he meant that the Administration wanted to maintain the territorial integrity of Iraq as a buffer against Iran. With the possibility of a power vacuum in Baghdad after the gulf war, the Administration feared that any steps to help the Shiites could lead to the creation of an independent Shiite state with links to Teheran.
 
Convincing the Iraqis
 Bush Administration officials say they do not favor a breakup of Iraq. But their apprehensions about establishing a protected Shiite enclave -- particularly their fear that such an entity would be subsumed by or indebted to neighboring Iran -- have receded.
The creation of a protected zone in southern Iraq is seen rather as a way to demonstrate to the Iraqi military the costs of allowing President Hussein to remain in power. The air patrols send the message not only that Iraq is subject to economic sanctions, but that Baghdad's sovereignty over its own territory will be compromised unless the President is ousted.
 
What Would Be Needed
 Administration officials conceded privately that Washington knew little about the Shiites when the gulf war ended, failed to anticipate their uprising and tended, wrongly, to lump them with the Iranians. Saudi officials have recently played an important role in allaying some of the wariness about bolstering the Shiites, Administration officials say.
And with the Bush Administration proclaiming foreign policy as its strong suit during the election campaign, and Democrats complaining that President Hussein has been thumbing his nose at Washington, the establishment of the protected zone is seen as a way to cut the Iraqi leader down to size.
Continuing reports from the region, including videotapes of Iraqi raids against the Shiites and a study by the United Nations Human Rights Commission on abuses by the Iraqi military in southern Iraq, have added to the pressure to act.
Protecting the Shiites from air attack could involve 80 to 100 flights a day over southern Iraq and northern Saudi Arabia. And while no Administration officials have talked openly about the possibility of bombing raids, the allies would face considerable pressure to respond if the Iraqis launched ground assaults on Shiites. Such counterattacks would likely be carried out by F-15E's and F-111F's and by Navy A-6's.
While the Administration has discarded its earlier arguments against protecting the Shiites, officials may well have been right when they said last year that an allied threat to shoot down Iraqi aircraft might open the door to further military steps.

HEADLINE: British Racial Attacks Grow, Alarming Minorities

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Ruhullah Aramesh fled his native Afghanistan eight months ago, bound for what he hoped would be a better life in England. This month, the 24-year-old immigrant was dead, killed by a group of white teen-agers on a South London street.
Mr. Aramesh, the police said, was the victim of pure racial hatred. Set upon by young toughs after he tried to stop them from harassing a group of female relatives, he was knocked to the ground and repeatedly struck on the head with iron bars, clubs and a sawed-off pool cue. 
 Five teen-agers have been arrested in the beating, during which, witnesses say, the assailants repeatedly shouted, "Die, you Paki!" Paki is a racial epithet broadly used to refer to immigrants from Pakistan, Bangladesh and other South Asian nations.
In poorer parts of inner London, where one of every five residents is a nonwhite member of an ethnic minority, the killing of Mr. Aramesh has had a numbing effect. It has reinforced the worst fears of those who say immigrants and ethnic minorities, who make up less than 5 percent of Britain's population, are increasingly the target of racial abuse or violence.
 
Scapegoats for Economic Woe
 "Such things seems to happen even more when the economy is bad," said Manibhai Patel, who runs the Asian Community Action Group in Brixton, a South London district where many black and Asian families live. "We are the scapegoats. We are the prey."
Statistics made public by Scotland Yard showed 3,373 incidents of racial assault or harassment in London in 1991, a jump of 16 percent over the previous year. About half involved physical assault.
A national survey by a civil rights group last April similarly concluded that incidents of racial assault reported to police agencies in England and Wales grew by nearly a third between 1988 and 1990, to 6,459.
Civil rights organizations and counselors who work among minority groups here argue that the incidents are the most extreme expression of deep-seated racial tensions tugging at the seams of British society, aggravated by a growing population of nonwhites, many of them new immigrants, and a persistent economic recession that has exacted its heaviest toll among the poor and least educated.
Like America, those tensions are usually most acute in racially mixed, low-income neighborhoods where the competition for scarce jobs and housing is already marked, and where new immigrants from Asia or the West Indies are most likely to concentrate.
 
Problems Everywhere<HE
"We all know about Rodney King and what happened in Los Angeles," said Afsana Yahiya, who counsels victims of racial abuse in East London. "But the problems are here, they are everywhere, and the more we acknowledge that, the better for all of us."
In some cases, conflicts have been inflamed by racist gangs, including skinheads or others allied with the British National Party, a small but vocal militant group that appeals to the most xenophobic elements within Britain's class-conscious society. Active in working-class neighborhoods, the group campaigns on the slogan, "Rights for Whites."
Police officers caution that the statistical increase in hate crime may more accurately measure the greater scrupulousness of police and community agencies in keeping track of racist attacks. But civil rights groups say no statistics accurately measure the degree to which ethnic minorities are subjected to racial abuse and intimidation, including physical violence.
"I think any numbers we see seriously understate the degree to which these incidents occur," said Peter Laing of the Congress of Racial Equality. He said one survey in Newham, a London neighborhood, suggested that only one in 20 incidents of racial abuse or assault was reported to the police.
Those incidents involve a wide range of abuse, from physical assault to vandalism, like breaking windows, spraying racist graffiti on walls or pushing excrement through mail slots.
Zakir Khan, a counselor who says he deals with three to four cases of interracial conflict a week from a storefront office in Tower Hamlets, a borough in East London, said many Asian people did not report incidents to the police.
"I have dealt with older Bengalis or Somalis who think if a white person attacks them, it is their right because it is their country," he said. In addition, he said, they are often intimidated by police officers, whom they do not regard as sympathetic.
At the same time, he said, younger Asians, most of them second- or third-generation Britons, are more determined to fight back, and this increases the likelihood of violence.
On the Isle of Dogs, an area in East London where growing numbers of Bangladeshis and Somalis are being resettled in a mostly white public housing project, community workers say racial assaults occur daily.
In recent months, said Ms. Yahiya, who was assigned as the community's first racial harassment case worker in April, troublemakers have poured a bucket of water over the head of a 65-year-old Pakistani man as he was moving into an apartment in an all-white building, beaten up two Bengali men returning from a neighborhood civil rights forum, thrown a pig's head through the window of a local Muslim butcher, and so intimidated members of a Somali family that social agencies say they must relocate them.
Laila Hussein, who immigrated to London two years ago, said her younger brothers and sisters could not play outside their apartment building because some other residents in the mostly white complex had threatened to turn their dogs on them whenever they went outside. "We are all scared and want to leave," Ms. Hussein said.
In the last 25 years, according to Government population data, Britain's combined population of Asians and blacks has more than doubled, from 1.1 million to more than 2.7 million.
 
Most Nonwhites Are Asian
 Nearly 80 percent of those are Asians, including people from the Indian subcontinent, Korea, Southeast Asia and the Philippines. Blacks, who began moving to Britain in large numbers during the 1950's, are mostly immigrants from the West Indies and their descendants.
All together, nonwhites currently make up about 4.9 percent of the overall population of 55.8 million, compared with 2.1 percent in 1966.
While racial attacks involve whites against blacks and, less commonly, assaults by blacks on whites, the greatest increase in recent years has involved assaults by whites, and sometimes blacks, on Asians, the police and civil rights groups say.
Killings are relatively rare. The most highly publicized incident before the attack on Mr. Aramesh was the death two years ago of a 15-year-old black schoolboy, who was killed during a confrontation between white and black youths in Thamesmead, east of London. His 19-year-old assailant was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.
 
Woman Set Afire
 But this year, there have been several especially violent episodes, including an incident in which an Asian woman waiting for a bus in Ilford, in East London, was set afire by a group that included at least one black and one white teen-ager. She suffered burns over 20 percent of her body.
Superintendent John Jones, a London homicide detective, said that while racism was a clear factor in many of these violent crimes, the heart of the problem "is not color but culture."
"Basically, the people who cause these incidents are half-witted thugs, the same sorts of yobos who beat up people in pubs for no reason at all, or run amok at football stadiums," he said. "For them, a different skin color is just one more reason to pick a fight and beat someone up, and sometimes it gets badly out of hand."

NEW YORK CITY
 
MISTAKEN IDENTITY LEADS TO DEATH
A 35-year-old bodega employee was beaten to death by a band of 6 to 15 young men in the Belmont section of the Bronx, and the only witness to come forward has told the police that the victim was a bystander slain in a case of mistaken identity. A1.
 
2 SCHOOLS OF THOUGHT ON THE HOMELESS
The warning by New York City's Housing Authority that it cannot keep setting aside 2,000 apartments a year for homeless families without jeopardizing the stability of its projects reveals sharp disputes and poor coordination on the homeless inside the Dinkins administration. News analysis, B3. 

A VISION FOR 42d STREET
To restore life to the ghostly strip that 42d Street has become, the architect Robert A. M. Stern envisions rooftop restaurants on the scale of Tavern on the Green, dance rehearsal studios with broad plate-glass windows, floodlit architecture and a jumble of giant signs and little stores. B3.
 
POLICE OFFICERS TO BE DISCIPLINED
The Police Department will file disciplinary charges against 11 officers who refused to cooperate with the Brooklyn District Attorney's investigation of a brutality charge by a civic leader in Bedford-Stuyvesant last month. B3.
 
MINORITY ROLE -- OR LACK OF IT -- IN ADS
Some of America's most prestigious marketers of expensive fashion, beauty and cosmetic products were attacked yesterday by Mark Green, the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, for limiting or omitting members of minorities from their magazine advertisements. Media Business, D18.
 
REGION
 
FLORIO GAINS ON WEAPONS BAN
After the Republican-controlled Legislature in New Jersey voted to repeal the state's two-year-old ban on semiautomatic assault weapons, it appeared that one of the nation's toughest gun laws was doomed. But after a campaign by Governor Florio, a Democrat, and some surprising allies, the outcome is now uncertain. B6.
 
DELEGATIONS VOW NEVER AGAIN
After their defeat over the Republican Party's anti-abortion plank, New York-area delegates who support abortion rights said they would never let it happen again, unless, of course, they fail to head off the religious right again. A22.

The plan recently approved by the State Legislature to resolve Nassau County's fiscal crisis was declared dead by county Democrats, who accused Republican leaders of hiding millions of dollars in unspent money. The Republicans responded by accusing the Democrats of holding the county hostage and warned that unless they approved a proposal to borrow $46 million, the county would run out of cash. B7.
 
THE DREAM THAT FAILED
Two decades ago, Wolcott, Conn., thought it had hit the jackpot when developers proposed a $30 million horse race track. Starved for any kind of industry, the community enthusiastically embraced the plan. But the race track was abandoned and the boom never came. Wolcott Journal, B6.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
American exports and imports both set records in June, leaving the trade deficit slightly narrowed at $6.59 billion. The Bush Administration hailed the results -- particularly the exports -- as evidence of renewed economic strength, while Democrats interpreted them as showing stagnation. [Page D1.]
Securities officials are attacking a plan that lets AIDS patients get some money from their life insurance -- by selling their policies to companies that resell them to investors. Although patient advocates laud the plan, state securities administrators say it creates a speculative futures market in death. [A1.]
 
Companies
No, Virginia, the Rockies are out West. A Federal judge upheld Anheuser-Busch in "hoisting Coors by its own petard" in ads that attacked the Colorado brewer, which advertises "the taste of the Rockies," for adding Virginia water to beer sold in the East. [D1.] 
 AMR will have a heavy loss in the third quarter, normally the airlines' strongest, the parent of American told analysts. The bruising summer fare wars have brought planeloads of people and gallons of red ink. A year ago the carrier earned $70.3 million. [D1.]
Pfizer's settlement of a class-action suit over failed heart valves was approved by a Federal judge in Cincinnati. The valves have been cited in 300 deaths. The company, which agreed to pay $500,000 to $2 million per valve fracture, put its cost at $165 million to $215 million. [D4.]
Berlitz International announced a $276 million deal to sell a 67 percent stake to Fukutake Publishing Company. The language instruction and translation company was formerly controlled by the late Robert Maxwell's Macmillan publishing unit. [D4.]
J. C. Penney, GTE Spacenet and Capital Cities/ABC are working on a joint venture to provide audio, video and data communication services to retailers in shopping malls. [D4.]
Calvin Klein, Estee Lauder and other marketers were criticized for not using minority people in ads by Mark Green, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner. [D18.]
 
International
Japan's package of emergency financial measures to stabilize markets, shore up banks and calm investors represents an important policy shift when recession is generally acknowledged. [D1.]
 
Markets
Futures contracts in insurance are to be introduced by the Chicago Board of Trade. Executives say they could make health and property insurance more readily available at lower, more stable prices, but acceptance is by no means assured. [D1.]
Bank stocks dragged the market down, with the Dow Jones average losing 22.42 points to close at 3,307.06. [D8.]
Municipal bonds continued a slide of recent weeks, with little appetite among traders for the glut of recent new issues. [D15.]
Orange juice futures plunged, after Brazil lowered its price to American and European consumers to the level charged by Florida producers. [D16.] The dollar closed mostly lower in listless trading. Gold prices rose. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
If George Bush's 1,000 points of light are snuffed out, why? Sins of omission, say economists, citing joblessness, taxes and budget problems, among others. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Recent enthusiasm for Hong Kong shares seems to have been deflated by rioting in neighboring Shenzhen, provoked by an avalanche of demand for applications for shares. Market Place. [D8.]
"Anybody who leaves advertising to the agencies deserves what he gets," said David F. Webb, president and chief executive of Lever Brothers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Narrows Modestly

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The nation's persistent trade deficit showed scant improvement in June, narrowing only slightly to $6.59 billion as both exports and imports hit record highs, the Commerce Department said today.
The Bush Administration was quick to greet the report -- which showed exports of $38.28 billion, a 7.2 percent increase from May's level -- as a sign of renewed economic strength in the United States. "President Bush's leadership and experience in promoting America abroad is paying off in dividends for us at home -- in the form of jobs and economic growth," Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin said in a statement.
 
Criticism by Democrats
 But as Democrats were quick to point out, the gain in exports was balanced by a 4.7 percent increase in imports, to $44.88 billion, and the overall trade deficit remains far above its level last winter and most of last year. "In the first few months of this year, it looked like significant progress was being made, but that has gone out the window now," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat on the House Subcommittee on Trade. 
 Recent monthly deficits suggest that the trade deficit for all of 1992 could reach $80 billion, up from $65.40 billion last year, Mr. Matsui noted.
But even an $80 billion deficit would still be smaller than the trade deficits of the late 1980's, which peaked at $152.12 billion in 1987.
 
Seasonal Adjustments
 American trade deficits with many regions widened in June, while the overall trade deficit narrowed. The reason is that the overall deficit is adjusted to account for seasonal fluctuations while bilateral deficits are not.
Remove the seasonal adjustment and the trade deficit in June, at $6.48 billion, was the worst since October of last year, according to Commerce Department figures released today.
Trade experts were surprised by the record exports and imports in June. Foreign markets for American products are weak while American economic growth, which tends to determine imports, has been slow, said Robert D. Hormats, a deputy United States trade representative in the Carter Administration who is now a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
"In a way, the numbers don't square with what's happening in the real economy," he said.
Harold B. Malmgren, a former special trade representative in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, said that the increase in exports might prove more lasting because it reflected a long, slow decline in the value of the dollar, which has made American goods cheaper for foreign buyers.
During the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, the monthly trade deficits bobbed up and down in a tight range between $3.29 billion and $5.87 billion. The deficit leaped to $7.06 billion in April and $7.14 billion in May for two reasons: recessions in Western European countries shrank their demand for American goods, while commercial aircraft deliveries sagged as the Boeing Company filled domestic orders. The increase in aircraft exports during June was twice as large as the narrowing of the overall deficit.
 
European Shortfall
 Exports to Western Europe fell again in June while imports increased, as the United States posted a deficit with the region of $89.9 million after a surplus of $966.4 million in May.
Imports from Mexico grew slightly faster than sales of American goods there, so that the nation's trade surplus with Mexico narrowed to $334.2 million, from $434.4 million in May. Mexico, Canada and the United States agreed last week to create a North American free trade area, although the legislatures of all three countries still must approve the pact.
But exports to Japan, after stagnating for the last year, did jump, to $4.16 billion, from $3.66 billion in May. Imports from Japan also increased, but not quite as much, so that the bilateral trade deficit narrowed slightly to $3.39 billion.
Oil imports rose to $4.19 billion in June, the highest level in 17 months. The increase reflected slightly higher oil prices and the continuing decline in American production.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS IN HOUSTON: The Religious Right;
Many Delegates See an Immoral and Scary America

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
It wasn't just souvenirs, choirs, country bands or even Pat Buchanan that drew Karen S. Johnson, Shirley Whitlock and hundreds of other religious conservatives to Houston this week. It was the hermetically sealed moral fiber of the Astrodome. "Everywhere I go there are like-minded people," Mrs. Johnson said. "That's so nice."
The two delegates who came to the Republican National Convention committed to Patrick J. Buchanan have limited exposure to the unlike-minded where they live: Mesa, Ariz., a quiet, conservative town with many mobile retirement homes and Christian churches. 
 And yet, sounding a little like someone who has made it through a primeval forest in search of other walled cities, Mrs. Whitlock explained, "It's so nice to know there are other people in other states like us."
 
Inside Information
 In Mrs. Whitlock's mind, the world outside the Astrodome is a rather menacing place, where even the P.T.A., the library and the school nurse cannot be completely trusted, and where news organizations censor the news. "Here, you get inside information," Mrs. Whitlock said, referring to juicy gossip about Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic arch-rival, that she heard from an Arkansas delegate in the ladies' room.
The views of Mrs. Whitlock and her "like-minded people" on the Republican right flank have dominated their party's convention and platform. Tonight's theme, "family values," is close to their heart. For them it is more than an election-year campaign slogan; it is the password that signals which side they stand on in the religious and cultural war that their candidate, Mr. Buchanan, outlined in his speech Monday night.
The network of politically active religious Republicans that helped another conservative candidate, Ronald Reagan, triumph over the moderate George Bush in the 1980 primaries still rules the convention floor in 1992. Leaders like the television evangelists Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson are not as conspicuous this year, but they do not need to be.
In interviews with members of this crusade this week, the term "family values" unleashed talk of unfairness, of being surrounded, ignored and even persecuted. Whether it was Mrs. Whitlock, a member of Phyllis Schlafly's Eagle Forum and a Mormon with eight children and 28 grandchildren, or Richard J. Rapaport, a middle-aged Jewish painter from New York City, they expressed strong philosophical views about church, taxes, welfare, homosexuality and the breakdown of the family.
But almost all of them could also pinpoint a more direct, personal grievance. For Mrs. Whitlock, it was the Judy Blume series of books for girls. For Mr. Rapaport, it was the Whitney Museum.
 
Patriotic Art
 Mr. Rapaport is fighting for recognition for his art. He had a patriotic art display, "Let Freedom Ring," set up amid stands selling T-shirts, novelties and hot dogs in the exhibition hall next to the Astrodome.
A Syracuse graduate who works in his family's construction business by day, Mr. Rapaport described his paintings of brightly colored flags and eagles as "a new moral vision" to combat "this disorder." But he said gallery owners and curators were only interested in "subway graffiti artists and minorities."
"I sent a hundred letters to people in the art world," Mr. Rapaport said. He said had he contacted the Whitney museum so often that a curator finally gave him some advice. "The Whitney guy told me the art world wouldn't touch my work," Mr. Rapaport said, "because I showed the love of America."
He said he did get a positive review when he sent his art to Washington. "The White House wrote me," he said. "They thought it was beautiful."
 
Distrust of Schools
 Mrs. Whitlock has also carried on a long struggle, hers with local school and community officials. With her encouragement, two of Mrs. Whitlock's daughters have taken their children out of the public school system and placed them in "home school," out of range of sex education, the National Education Association and librarians that recommend books that Mrs. Whitlock considers "shocking."
The popular Judy Blume books for pre-adolescent girls are particularly galling to Mrs. Whitlock. "I mean, there are unwed mothers who have affairs," Mrs. Whitlock said. "It's for little girls, and it promotes the idea that its O.K. to have sex outside of marriage."
A liberal consensus of left-leaning teachers, Democrats and "media types," Mrs. Whitlock said, censor "anything that is pro-Christian and traditional." Citing figures she said she read in Family and America magazine, Mrs. Whitlock said that because the personal income tax exemption had not kept pace with inflation, the tax laws have been unfair to "traditional families where the wife stays home."
Mrs. Whitlock said she knew the reason. "Because of an unwarranted fear of a population boom, they wanted mothers out of the home and working to reduce the size of the family," she said. "They" are the Federal Government, and she felt personally victimized. Because she wanted to stay home, her husband, a state parole officer, was forced to take a night job cleaning offices. She said only "Judeo-Christian principles" could get the country back on track.
 
'Hoity-Toity People'
 Matt Stephens, a 42-year-old country music disk jockey from Nashville, said he had "never mixed with this many hoity-toity people in my life."
Asked about family values, Mr. Stephens mentioned welfare. "I'm not a rich guy," he said, "and I feel there is something wrong about giving someone something for nothing."
Walter Costello, 28, a delegate from Tucson, Ariz., said family values were a matter of example more than law. "You can't legislate morality," he said. "It has to be done in the personal lives of our leaders. If our politicians don't discriminate, if they don't skirt-chase, if they don't harass, if they show respect for their wives and daughters, and the same thing happens in the entertainment and business community, then you'd have a social revolution."
For some delegates, though, the fervor over values was a bit bewildering. "I don't really understand what family values are," said Norman Hildreth, a retired insurance salesman from Oak Ridge, Tenn. "I raised three children and tried to teach them to do the right thing. Is that it?"

HEADLINE: Stocks in Late Drop; Dow Falls by 22.42

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market tumbled in the last hour of trading yesterday, pulled down in part by bank stocks and home-building shares.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 22.42 points, to 3,307.06. 
Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Volume on the Big Board came to 187.1 million shares, up from 171.8 million in the previous session.
Until the late afternoon, the market was relatively quiet and directionless on the eve of President Bush's speech before the Republican convention in Houston. Shares then dropped sharply, ending near the day's lows.
Bank stocks, which were heavily traded, helped drag down the market, said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president with the First Albany Corporation. Citicorp fell 1 1/8, to 16 3/4; Chemical Banking dropped 1 3/8, to 32 3/4, and Chase Manhattan dropped 1 1/2, to 22 5/8.
The selling in bank shares was accelerated by a wide rumor that the nation's largest mutual fund, Fidelity Investments of Boston, was selling Citicorp and other major bank stocks, traders said.
Paula Slotkin, Fidelity spokeswoman, denied the rumor.
 
Starting a Fire
 John Heffern, bank analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons, compared the Fidelity rumor to a spark that starts a brush fire.
Generally speaking, Mr. Heffern said, stock traders are nervous about any corporation with overvalued stock in a sluggish economy. Bank stocks have been rallying for two years.
Home-building stocks also contributed to the slide, dropping after the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation said its third-quarter profit would be lower. The single-family home builder was down 2 1/2, at 11 3/4, while Standard Pacific fell 1/2, to 5 7/8.
On Tuesday, the Commerce Department reported that United United housing starts fell a worse-than-expected 2.8 percent in July.
Investors appeared to shrug off gains overnight in foreign stock prices. In Tokyo, stocks rebounded from a six-year low, while London shares also rose.
The market similarly seemed to ignore good news on the economic front. The Commerce Department said yesterday that the United States trade deficit shrank 7.7 percent, to $6.59 billion in June. Sales of American goods overseas set a new record.
Among other actively traded Big Board issues, Sunbeam-Oster, the consumer goods maker, ended unchanged at 12 1/2 after an initial offering of 20 million shares of common stock was priced at $12.50 a share.
Syntex fell 1 1/8, to 29 1/8, after a market survey showed disappointing prescription performance for oral Toradol, the drug company's new nonnarcotic pain-reliever.
Among blue chips, International Business Machines fell 1 3/8, to 86 5/8; Disney fell 1 3/8, to 34 1/2, after an analyst initiated coverage of the company's Euro Disney affiliate with a "sell" rating, and Bristol-Myers Squibb fell 1, to 69.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index fell 1.49, to 230.41. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index lost 0.92, to 385.89. The Nasdaq index fell 3.26, to 567.61.

HEADLINE: Fashion Advertisers' Record On Minorities Is Denounced

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Some of America's most prestigious marketers of expensive fashion, beauty and cosmetic products, like Calvin Klein and Estee Lauder, were attacked yesterday for limiting or omitting members of minorities from their magazine advertisements.
Other marketers also came under fire, but for using members of minorities in what were deemed stereotypical roles. That judgment is likely to be questioned by those who believe appearances by minority athletes and musicians is a positive development. 
 The castigations came from Mark Green, the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, who issued a study, "Still Invisible," that surveyed 2,108 ads in 10 magazines, from Better Homes and Gardens to Vogue. The study updated a much publicized report, "Invisible People," released 13 months ago, which found blacks in only 3.4 percent of national magazine ads and 4.6 percent of mail-order catalogues.
 
Letters to 14 Companies
 "I'm appealing to corporate advertisers to act in their own economic interest as well as in the public interest," Mr. Green said in a statement, "by including more people of color in their ads."
Mr. Green, an activist commissioner who broadly interprets his mandate to regulate consumer affairs, said that he had written letters to the 14 companies singled out as having the fewest minorities in their ads. Among them were Calvin Klein, zero out of 156 ads; Estee Lauder, zero out of 114; Cover Girl, 1 out of 226, and Ralph Lauren, 4 out of 138.
A spokeswoman for the Estee Lauder Companies in New York said that for its Estee Lauder line, it has been the company's approach to "have one model under exclusive contract as a component of our global trademark." Currently, the model is Paulina Porizkova.
"We think her beauty is quite universal," the spokeswoman added. She said that for All Skins, a line of cosmetics marketed by the Prescriptives line, ads depict "diverse models," including black women.
 
Rebuttal from Ralph Lauren
 A spokeswoman for the Polo/Ralph Lauren Corporation in New York said, "We have prominently featured minorities in our advertising for many years and we plan to continue to do so."
A spokeswoman at Grey Advertising in New York, the agency for Cover Girl cosmetics, did not return a telephone call seeking comment. The trade publication Adweek has reported, however, that Cover Girl has been seeking "a black supermodel" to serve as a spokeswoman for new Cover Girl products for black women.
A spokeswoman for Calvin Klein said that Mr. Klein was on vacation and could not be reached for comment.
Though it concluded that appearances by members of minorities in magazine ads rose to 5.2 percent, the study played down the increase by arguing that many of the additional models appeared in stereotypical roles. For instance, Mr. Green noted that members of minorities appeared in 24 of Toyota's 135 ads. But he complained that one of the ads prominently featured a black person used in the stereotypical role of an athlete; the individual was the basketball player Isiah Thomas.
Many advertising and marketing executives, both black and white, have applauded the inclusion of black celebrities among the nation's roster of star endorsers.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Assails G.O.P. Attacks Aimed at Wife

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark,. Aug. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, offered a stinging criticism of President Bush and the Republican Party today, saying their attacks on his wife were an effort to demonize her just as they used the Willie Horton story to depict Michael S. Dukakis as soft on crime.
"What they're trying to do is kind of make it a Willie Horton thing against all independent working women, trying to run against them in a way that I think is really lamentable," he said. 
 Mr. Clinton, after a day of campaigning in Atlanta with former President Jimmy Carter, assailed the attacks on his wife, Hillary. "This party, this Republican Party has obviously been taken over by the extreme, intolerant right wing of the party," he said. "You look at who has been featured. It's the Pat Robertson, Pat Buchanan, Jerry Falwell, Phyllis Schlafly wing of the party. They control it now. They've got George Bush right where they want him."
Mr. Clinton said that by attacking his wife the Republicans were seeking to portray all working women in negatively. By doing so, he said, the Republicans were trying to turn Mrs. Clinton into a caricature of a woman who would choose a career over her family.
 
Diversionary Tactic Is Seen
 Mrs. Clinton, who traveled with her husband to Atlanta for an appearance with Mr. Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, declined to comment on her husband's remarks.
Mr. Clinton said the Bush campaign's attacks on Mrs. Clinton were beside the point and meant to distract voters from the real choice between the candidates for President. "For Bush to attack Hillary is ridiculous," he said. "You'd think he was running for First Lady instead of for President. I just don't think it will be very persuasive."
Torie Clarke, the spokeswoman for the Bush campaign, said in a telephone interview that the differences between the two campaigns is a matter of values, not personalities.
"I think she's made some very strong statements and obviously has some strongly held opinions," Ms. Clarke said about Mrs. Clinton. "And what you see sometimes is people expressing their opinions in response. But Hillary Clinton is not the issue in this race. It's George Bush versus Bill Clinton."
She said it was insulting to suggest that criticism of Mrs. Clinton could be translated into an attack on all working women.
 
Defense Is First Order
 Mr. Clinton turned every question he received this afternoon into an opportunity to defend his wife against the attacks that have been directed at her by Mr. Buchanan and others.
Mr. Buchanan, the former conservative commentator who unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Bush for the Republican nomination in the early primaries, said in a convention speech Monday night that Mrs. Clinton represented "radical feminism."
Barbara Bush, in an interview on Tuesday, said she understood that Mr. and Mrs. Clinton have planned a "co-Presidency," a charge Mr. Clinton insisted he has never even mentioned.
"They know this is a load of bull," Mr. Clinton said, who added that both President and Mrs. Bush have praised Mrs. Clinton's work on behalf of children's issues. "But they've given themselves over to the right-wing extremists in their party." he said. "And they don't have a record or a vision, so they're going to run whatever they can. And I think American people are really going to react against it.
"It shows the panic and the lack of vision and commitment and real character in the whole Republican campaign."
Mr. Clinton said today that all the Republican attacks have been "about Hillary," but convention speakers have also lobbed direct shots at Mr. Clinton as well, asserting that he would raise taxes, "disarm America" and propose an economic plan that would require extensive new spending.
"I'm a little surprised that they resorted to the attacks on Hillary they have, and that they have done it in a way that required them to falsify and grossly distort her own records and words," Mr. Clinton said. "These people get away with murder because nobody ever stands up to them."
But standing up to the attacks of their opponents is a strategy that the Clinton campaign takes great pride in. Today, for instance, the Democrat's Little Rock headquarters released a two-page press statement called the "Republican Lie Meter," in which the campaign took issue with statements made at the Houston convention.
Mr. Clinton spent the morning helping Mr. Carter build a low-income house being developed by Habitat for Humanity in Atlanta. He turned to the attack on the Republicans this afternoon as he headed back to Little Rock.
"What they've done at this convention is just the 1992 version of what they know how to do," he said. "Slash and burn. Trash your opponent. Try to make them look crazy. And I just think the American people will see through it."
Mr. Clinton also said that Mr. Bush's comments that he would revamp his cabinet in his second term was "a stunning acknowledgement of failure in the first term."
 
Celebrating 46th Birthday
 Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton struck a more high-minded tone as he celebrated his 46th birthday with his wife and daughter and with his running mate, Senator Al Gore, his wife, Tipper, and their four children. Mrs. Gore. who shares a birthday with Mr. Clinton, was 44 years old today.
"We thought it would be a good day to spend the day building and not tearing down," Mr. Clinton said at a break from four hours of construction work.
Mr. Carter, who said he had been reading about, but not watching, the Republican convention, said the Republicans have spent more time on the attack than in talking about needs like housing.
"I haven't heard much discussion at the Republican convention about what will be done for low-income families, working families of America," Mr. Carter said.

HEADLINE: A DELICATE BALANCE: Battle for Texas;
Crippled by Economy, Texas Is Up for Grabs

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Just 19 months ago, when the Republicans announced they would hold their convention here, President Bush seemed to have a lock on Texas. A little more than a month ago Mr. Perot seemed primed to take the state. Now, even some of Mr. Bush's most prominent supporters say he is fighting for his survival in the state that is the birthplace of his political career.
The political landscape in Texas has long favored Republicans at the top of the ticket. But the electoral terrain has been shifting in recent years, and now both he and Gov. Bill Clinton must clamber across uncertain ground. 
 In the suburbs, Ross Perot exercised a mighty appeal over the state's white, middle-class voters and these notorious ticket-splitters are up for grabs now that he's gone. In the Piney Woods of East Texas and out on the staked plains of West Texas, oil drilling is down to levels not seen in a generation, and the blame is being leveled, not at the economy, but at the policy-makers of both parties in Washington.
And in the dusty small towns of South Texas and in crowded urban neighborhoods, Hispanic and black voters are eager for a chance to exercise the clout that has come with their population growth.
 
Cavalry to the Rescue
 Senator Phil Gramm, the state's top Republican office holder, likened the campaign here to a group of pioneers under attack by hostile Indians. "We've got to pull out our sabers, spur our horses and head out for the wagon train and hope we get there on time," he said in an interview with ABC News. "I believe we're going to."
Not since the Democrats had a native Texan, Lyndon B. Johnson, at the top of the ticket has a Republican Presidential candidate faced such difficulties in Texas.
"The Republican tide may have run as far as its going to go here, in fact it may already be running out," said John Connally, a popular Democratic Governor in the 1960's who then switched parties.
When Mr. Bush first entered politics here in the 1950's, "Yellow dog Democrats," so-named because they liked to say they would vote for an ugly beast before voting for a Republican, had ruled the state as a one-party fief since Reconstruction. The first cracks came when Texas went for Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952, eight years before a Republican won any statewide office. Then, along with California and Florida, it became part of the Sun Belt triad that helped keep Republicans in the White House for 20 of the last 24 years.
 
Home of the Ticket-Splitters
 With public opinion polls showing Mr. Bush just as far behind in his home state as he is in the rest of the country, some officials of both parties wonder if they are witnessing another fundamental change in Texas politics.
Kent Hance, an alternate in the Texas delegation who is a former Democrat himself, said he believed the Republicans would hold their advantage even if they did not expand on it. He said, "So many voters have come over to our side in Presidential elections that the shift could have slowed, maybe it's peaked."
George Christian, a White House official in the Johnson Administration who is a Democratic political consultant in Austin, said: "This has become such a ticket-splitting state that we've had some pretty strange elections recently. But this year the fundamentals look better for the Democrats than they have at any time since 1976 at least."
Already this year the allegiances of Texas voters have been teased and tested. Both major-party candidates and Mr. Perot are all familiar figures here, and each has his own, sometimes overlapping, constituencies.
 
One Issue: the Economy
 The economy, such a potent political motivator elsewhere, exercises a particularly profound influence here. While the rest of the nation is responding to a sharp downturn after a long period of prosperity, Texans had just begun to enjoy a recovery from the oil busts of the 1980's when things went flat.
"In the past we've had Presidential campaigns turn on all kinds of ideological and emotional issues, but this one is very fundamentally a campaign of pocketbook issues," Mr. Connally said. "Things may be worse other places right now, but we Texans went through one hell of a ringer." After their long experience of economic pain, he said, Texans are likely to be skeptical of Republicans' claims that they are the party of prosperity.
A key demographic factor in the success of previous Republican candidates has been the large number of independents and Republicans who moved to the suburbs of Texas cities during the oil boom of the 1970's and early 1980's. "This tremendous migration overwhelmingly benefited the Republicans," said Richard Murray, a professor of Political Science at the University of Houston, but he noted that by the late 1980's this movement slowed considerably and even stopped in some places because of the economic problems here.
In 1990, Ann W. Richards narrowly won the race for Governor using a novel strategy for a Democrat that included aggressively seeking suburban votes. "We realized that the Republicans had so eroded the traditional Democratic base that we had to target the swing voters," said Mary Beth Rogers, the Governor's chief of staff. She noted that the Richards campaign went after suburban voters with promises to improve the regulation of insurance companies and that Mr. Clinton was striking similar cords with his emphasis on a national health insurance program.
Gary Mauro, chairman of the Clinton campaign in Texas, said, "Richards changed the landscape when she carried the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex, and now we are now definitely going after the suburban voters."
And the battle for the white, middle class has been inflamed by the peculiarities of this election season.
"We have a real problem in the suburbs because Perot made it possible for those people to say they are not for Bush," said a Texas Republican delegate here speaking on condition of anonymity. "Now they are loose and we have to get them back in the corral before Clinton gets them."
Mr. Clinton has already aggressively courted Hispanic voters, the fastest growing sector of the Texas electorate. Robert Stein, a professor of political science at Rice University in Houston, said poll results show "Clinton has locked the Hispanic vote and locked it early. If he can hold his margins in this community he'll be competitive in Texas."
Like a political frontiersman, Mr. Bush came to Texas when the Republican Party barely existed here, and he has helped build it for nearly 40 years. As a result, he enjoys advantages in personal associations and in fund-raising abilities even beyond those normally bestowed on an incumbent President. History was on his side when he returned to Houston this week, but he cannot afford to take anything for granted.
"We have never just won this state," said Karl Rove, a Republican consultant and alternate on the Texas delegation. "We have to go out and earn it, and this time we can't concede anything or assume anything."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE SCENES: The Campaign Staff;
Triumvirate Shapes Bush Acceptance Speech

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
If President Bush assumes blame or credit for his convention speech Thursday night, responsibility for its language falls mostly to a triumvirate of friends and aides, led by a man who once crafted sound bites for Richard M. Nixon.
He is Raymond Kissam Price Jr., a 62-year-old former newspaper editor who is one of Mr. Bush's old friends and political kibitzers. Among the cognoscenti, Mr. Price is an acknowledged master of the sweeping, uplifting political speech, and the aides say that is the sort of address the President will try to deliver: broad, thematic and generally optimistic in a campaign that so far has had its share of dark moments. 
 Mr. Price has found rainbows in hurricanes before. He first drew public attention in the 1968 campaign, when he coined the phrase "the lift of a driving dream" for speeches that carried Mr. Nixon to the White House.
Mr. Nixon named him chief White House speechwriter in 1970, and Mr. Price later constructed most of the President's Watergate speeches, including the resignation address on Aug. 8, 1974, when Mr. Nixon urged the nation "to put the bitterness and divisions of the recent past behind us."
Mr. Price has not been visibly active in Republican politics since then, but Mr. Bush's decision to make him the chief architect of his acceptance speech is not a surprise.
"He's a friend of the President, and he's talked to him about some ideas he had for the campaign, off and on, for a long time," Mr. Bush's campaign chairman and day-to-day manager, Robert M. Teeter, said in an interview. "He sent him notes and memos, and the President agreed with a lot of it. And when the time came to choose someone for the speech it was logical to turn to him."
The two men's lives and political philosophies have run similar courses. Six years younger than Mr. Bush, Mr. Price graduated from Yale University, Mr. Bush's alma mater, in 1951, and like the President is a member of the secret Yale honor society Skull and Bones.
In 1950 he worked in the first Senate campaign of the President's father, Prescott Bush, a Republican from Connecticut. From 1964 to 1966, Mr. Price was editorial page editor of The New York Herald Tribune.
In structure and theme, the President's acceptance speech is largely Mr. Price's, Bush aides say. But they also say it has been worked over by two Administration officials, Steve Provost and Robert B. Zoellick.
Mr. Zoellick, now Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, is proxy for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who will move to the White House as chief of staff next week.
Mr. Provost (pronounced PRO-voh) is the latest in a parade of chief speechwriters in the Bush White House.

HEADLINE: Businesslike With Business's Help, Cincinnati Schools Shake Off Crisis

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
A year ago, the Cincinnati public school system was, in the words of its superintendent, a system in crisis.
Four in 10 students never graduated from high school. Management and cost controls were weak, contributing to the district's crippling $76 million debt. Public confidence had so eroded that in November 1990 voters rejected a tax levy. The district slipped into state receivership, a form of bankruptcy for public agencies. 
 Something had to be done, but the school system's leaders didn't want to lay off teachers. Aided by local businesses, they devised an overhaul plan that draws heavily from the lessons learned by corporate America's own wrenching restructuring of the 1980's; it called for the district to trim its administrative staff by half, along with taking a variety of other steps to restore quality and improve morale.
The Cincinnati effort has been called a test case in engaging businesses in school restructuring, as well as a test of how far so-called bureaucratic bloat can be reduced.
 
How to Involve Business
 "No school district has come close to this magnitude of change," said Chris Pipho, director of state relations for the Education Commission of the States, a Denver-based education policy and research organization. "It's a good model in that it shows how to involve business in systemic reform."
Systemic reform was necessary, said the superintendent of schools, J. Michael Brandt. "The district was in turmoil," he said. "We needed to improve efficiencies, and we needed to restore confidence." So widespread was the feeling that the schools were a disgrace that the overhaul met virtually no political opposition.
Under the restructuring plan written by the Cincinnati Business Committee, an organization of local corporations, the district has reduced its administration by 65 positions, or 51 percent of the original total of 127 jobs. The reduction will result in a $16 million savings during the next two years that will be diverted to classrooms, for staff, supplies and other needs.
Principals, teachers and parents will be given more control over daily operations. This underpins the decision to cut 65 administrative positions; the layoffs came not from clerical or support staff but from supervisory positions in such areas as curriculum development, special education, vocational education and planning and development. Three "area offices," subsidiaries of the main district office each headed by an assistant superintendent, were completely eliminated.
 
Incentive-Pay Plan
 The district is also working on an incentive-pay plan designed to keep veteran teachers in inner-city schools, which in this and other systems have traditionally been staffed by newer, less experienced teachers. Of the 51,000 students, 57 percent are poor enough to qualify for the Federal free or reduced-price lunch program.
The report, which was adopted last year by the school district, also called for the creation of nine mini-districts, one of which was granted waivers from most state regulations for five years so it can experiment with new approaches. Successful programs it develops will then be replicated in other mini-districts.
This fall, for example, the pilot mini-district, which has five elementary schools, one middle school and a high school, will offer day-care centers for students with children to encourage young mothers to stay in school.
The district's bumpy ride to restructuring began in 1990, when the former Superintendent of Schools, Lee Etta Powell, commissioned the Cincinnati Business Committee to seek ways to improve schools. She resigned in the summer of 1991, leaving Mr. Brandt to sell the changes to the public: If you support the effort and approve a November 1991 tax increase, the new superintendent told voters, the district will follow the corporate recommendations.
 
Emergency Taxes Approved
 Voters did approve the five-year emergency tax increase last fall, an increase that raised the average homeowner's tax bill by about $197 a year. But the $46 million it will generate each year has given the district more financial breathing room: It was removed from receivership after state officials allowed the district to pay back its $76 million in debt over 10 years instead of two as required by state law.
Chief among the changes at the administrative level is a bottom-to-top chain of command that many companies adopted in the 1980's to improve efficiency and give workers more of a stake in the operation. For businesses -- which have long debated among themselves and with educators what role companies could play in the school restructuring movement -- the Cincinnati plan has given them more clarity about their place.
"We can show schools how to be more efficient because we had to do the same thing in the 1980's," said Robert L. Wehling, vice president for public affairs at Procter & Gamble and a member of the National Business Roundtable's Education Task Force. "Unlike schools, which can give 'C' grades and everyone continues, in business if you fall behind people lose jobs, you have to close plants."
 
Free Consultations
 Beyond the report, businesses will remain involved in the district's efforts by offering support staff and consultants free of charge, services that school officials say would ordinarily cost them millions of dollars a year.
Teachers have endorsed the plan, saying they have clamored for many of these changes for years. Their challenge, several teachers said, is to believe the administration when it says that change will occur and that teachers will be major players.
"I welcome the change," said Diana Porter, a high school teacher in the pilot mini-district that will experiment with innovation. "The issue that some teachers still face is trust."
To insure that its teachers are up to the task, the pilot mini-district has held training sessions on how to participate in school-based management, how to teach students differently and how to better relate to parents.
Mrs. Porter, who is one of the lead teachers in the pilot mini-district that received waivers from state regulations, said that changes are still being discussed but that already teachers in that mini-district have decided to experiment with two-hour class periods. That, Mrs. Porter said, has prompted brain-storming sessions on how a teacher instructs differently to students in such classes.
During one recent training session, parents told teachers not to sell their children short. Six in 10 of the city's public school students are black, and some black parents asserted that teachers in the past have stigmatized their youngsters because of their color or socio-economic background.
"I don't want you to think that a child can't learn because of his financial background or neighborhood," said Carol Wallace, a parent with a son in the local schools. "Demand excellence from them."
Another parent, Gloria McGee, who is single and raising two sons, said that in the past teachers had given short shrift to youngsters from single-parent homes. "Sometimes I am working and can't be at school," she said. "That doesn't mean I don't care. You have to be nurturers, and we have to be teachers at home."
