SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 2; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 969 words

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Excerpts From Vice President Quayle's Address

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the speech last night by Vice President Dan Quayle to the Republican National Convention accepting the party's Vice-Presidential nomination, as transcribed by The New York Times.
I know my critics wish I were not standing here tonight. They don't like our values. They look down on our beliefs. They're afraid of our ideas. And they know the American people stand on our side. And that's -- and that's why, when someone confronts them and challenges them, they will stop at nothing to destroy him. And I say to them: You have failed. I stand -- I stand before you, and before the American people -- unbowed, unbroken and ready to keep fighting for our beliefs. 
 I come -- I come from Huntington, a small farming community in Indiana. I had an upbringing like many in my generation -- a life built around family, public school, Little League, basketball and church on Sunday. My brother and I shared a room in our two-bedroom house. And we walked to school together. . . .
Marilyn and I have tried to teach our children these values, like faith in God, love of family and appreciation of freedom. We have also taught them about family issues like adoption -- my parents adopted twins when I was 10 years old. We have taught our children to respect single parents and their challenges -- challenges that faced my grandmother many years ago, and my own sister today.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The gap between us and our opponents is a cultural divide. It is not just a difference between being conservative and liberal; it is a difference between fighting for what's right and refusing to see what's wrong.
Families can also be strengthened by empowering our people -- with low taxes, home ownership, parental choice in education, job training, safe streets, a clean environment and affordable health care. In all of these areas we have a reform agenda, and it's time for Congress to get out of the way and to pass the President's plan.
 
Lawyers and Regulations
 Speaking of reform, our legal system is spinning out of control. The explosion of frivolous lawsuits burdens our economy and weakens our system of justice. America has 5 percent of the world's population and 70 percent of the world's lawyers. Now, I have nothing against lawyers -- at least most of them. I'm a lawyer, and I'm married to a lawyer.
When we worked our way through night law school, Marilyn and I looked forward with pride to becoming part of the finest legal system in the world. But today our country has a problem: our legal system is costing consumers $300 billion dollars a year. The litigation explosion has damaged our competitiveness; it has wiped out jobs; it has forced doctors to quit practicing in places where they're needed most. Every American knows the legal system is broken -- and now is the time to fix it.
The President's Council on Competitiveness, which I chair, will continue to lead the charge against unnecessary Federal regulation. We've worked to save jobs, and to save lives. We have reformed the drug approval process to speed up the availability of new medicines for people with life-threatening diseases like cystic fibrosis, cancer and AIDS.
 
Time to Change Congress
 And what -- what is the response of the Democrats in Congress? They have tried to kill the Council on Competitiveness, which stands up for the American people and against the bureaucrats and against the special interests. They -- they think the Competitiveness Council should go. They don't get it. It's time for them to go. You know -- you know, if the Democrats in Congress -- if the Democrats in Congress can't run their own restaurant, can't run their own post office, can't run their own bank, they sure can't be trusted to run our country.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It's been said, and it is true, that "a leader gives his people character." And once again America is going to choose a leader who has judgment, experience and moral strength. Four years ago, none of us knew that the Berlin Wall would fall, the Iron Curtain would be lifted, the Baltic nations would be free, Communism would be dead and buried, the Soviet Union would cease to exist and the threatening SS-18 ballistic missiles would be history.
Nor did we know that we would be called upon to confront the aggression of a Middle East tyrant.
But four years ago we did know this: Whatever lay ahead, there was a clear choice to lead us. There was one man we could trust to guide our journey to a new century. And because we elected George Bush as our President, America is stronger, and the world is safer.
My friends, listen to this. In an attempt to establish credibility in foreign policy, Governor Clinton recently compared himself to former Gov. Ronald Reagan. I know Ronald Reagan. Ronald Reagan is a friend of mine and Bill Clinton, you're no Ronald Reagan. The Democratic nominee calls America "the mockery of the world," but he and his running mate are the only ones that believe that. To Governor Clinton I say this: America is the greatest nation in the world, and that's one thing you're not going to change.
These last four years, I have worked with a man who represents so much of what is good in our country -- a man whose public and personal life are the embodiment of character. Every day in that Oval Office, I see the dedication of a husband, father and grandfather; the self-reliance of an entrepreneur; the courage of a Navy pilot; the dependability of a loyal friend; the compassion of a man of faith; and the wisdom of the man who married Barbara Bush.
George Bush has given us great victories abroad and performed great deeds at home. But, as Theodore Roosevelt said, "the greatest victories are yet to be won, and the greatest deeds are yet to be done."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: Investors await Speech Stocks Off Slightly

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stock prices eased slightly on Wall Street yesterday, with investors quietly awaiting President Bush's acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention.
A recovery in bank shares, after a big selloff on Wednesday, added some support to the session, which ended mixed. 
 After waffling, the Dow Jones industrial average ended 2.17 points lower at 3,304.89. Losing issues outnumbered gainers by 963 to 779 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume retreated to 183.4 million shares, from 187.1 million on Wednesday.
Investors were awaiting the President's speech in Houston to see whether it would include a proposed change in tax policy or new economic initiatives.
"I don't think there's too much downside, but at the same time, there's not too much upside," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities. "The market's been trading in a 3,200 to 3,400 range."
He said he was somewhat surprised that stocks did not gain much ahead of the President's speech.
 Treasury bonds were little changed in quiet trading, with the 30-year benchmark bond off just 3/32 at 995/32 , where it yielded 7.32 percent, up from 7.31 percent at the end of the day Wednesday.
Some analysts said investors were only using the Bush speech as an excuse to stay on the sidelines.
"There's nothing he can say that will suddenly turn things around," said John McElroy, principal at 1838 Investment Advisors L.P. "I think the speech has been so hyped up."
Among specific issues, "bank stocks showed some resilience," noted John Blair, head trader at County NatWest. Citicorp rose 5/8 to 17 3/8, after Merrill Lynch upgraded its intermediate rating on the banking company. Lehman Brothers repeated "buy" ratings on several banks.
Chemical Banking rose 7/8 to 33 5/8; BankAmerica added 3/8 to 43 5/8, and Chase Manhattan gained 1 1/2, to 23 7/8. Wells Fargo jumped 1 1/4, to 69 1/8, after the billionaire publisher Walter Annenberg disclosed that he owned 5.3 percent of the company.
Novell lost 1 7/8, to 47 1/4. Merrill Lynch cut its intermediate-term rating on the company and fiscal year
Telefonos de Mexico slipped 7/8, to 45 3/8, on options-related selling. Charming Shoppes lost 1 1/8, to 30 1/2, as Alex. Brown downgraded its rating to "buy" from a "strong buy."
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks edged up 0.08, to 418.26. The American Stock Exchange index fell 0.02, to 385.87.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite eased 0.03, to 230.38. The average price per share was unchanged.
The Nasdaq index rose 0.25, to 567.86. The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- which represents the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 4,027.37, down 0.66.

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (78%);

PUB-DATE: August 21, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 4729 words

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Transcript of Bush Speech Accepting the Nomination For Another Four Years

 BODY:
Following is the speech by President Bush to the Republican National Convention last night accepting the party's Presidential nomination, as transcribed by The New York Times.
Thank you very much, and I am proud to receive, and I'm honored to accept your nomination for President of the United States. 
 May I thank my dear friend and our great leader Bob Dole for that wonderful introduction. And let me say this: this nomination's not for me alone; it's for the ideas, principles and values that we stand for. And my job has been made easier by a leader who has taken a lot of unfair criticism, with grace and humor, the Vice President of the United States, Dan Quayle. And I am very grateful to him.
I want to talk tonight about the sharp choice that I intend to offer Americans this fall, a choice between different agendas, different directions, and, yes, a choice about the character of the man you want to lead this nation.
I know that Americans have many questions -- about our economy, about our country's future, even questions about me. And I'll answer them tonight.
And first, I feel great and I'm heartened, I'm heartened, by the polls, the ones that say that I look better in my jogging shorts than the Governor of Arkansas.
Four years ago, four years ago, I spoke about missions for my life and for our country. I spoke of one urgent mission: defending our security and promoting the American ideal abroad.
 
A World Transformed
 Just pause for a moment to reflect on what we've done.
Germany has united, and a slab of the Berlin wall sits right outside this Astrodome.
Arabs and Israelis now sit face-to-face and talk peace.
And every hostage held in Lebanon is free.
The conflicts, the conflict, in El Salvador is over, and free elections brought democracy to Nicaragua.
Black and white South Africans cheered each other at the Olympics.
The Soviet Union can only be found in history books.
The captive nations of Eastern Europe and the Baltics are captive no more.
And today, and today, on the rural streets of Poland, merchants sell cans of air labeled "the last breath of Communism."
If I had stood, if I had stood before you four years ago and described this as the world we would help to build, you would have said, "George Bush, you must have been smoking something, and you must have inhaled."
This convention is the first at which an American President can say the cold war is over, and freedom finished first.
 
Democrats vs. Republicans
 We have a lot to be proud of. A lot. Some want to rewrite history, want to skip over the struggle, claim the outcome was inevitable. And while the U.S. postwar strategy was largely bipartisan, the fact remains that the liberal, McGovern wing of the other party, including my opponent, consistently made the wrong choices.
In the 70's, they wanted a hollow army. We wanted a strong fighting force. In the 80's -- and you remember this one -- in the 80's they wanted a nuclear freeze, and we insisted on peace through strength.
From Angola to Central America, they said, "Let's negotiate, deliberate, procrastinate." And we said, "Just stand up for freedom."
And now the cold war is over, and they claim, "Hey, we were with you all the way." Their behavior, really, their behavior reminds me of the old con man's advice to the new kid. He said, "Son, if you're being run out of town, just get out in front and make it look like a parade."
Make no mistake, make no mistake, the demise of Communism wasn't a sure thing. It took the strong leadership of Presidents from both parties, including Republicans like Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan. And without their vision and the support of the American people, the Soviet Union would be a strong superpower today and we'd be facing a nuclear threat tonight.
 
Defense of Foreign Policy
 My opponents say I spend too much time on foreign policy.
As if it didn't matter that schoolchildren once hid under their desks in drills to prepare for nuclear war. I saw the chance to rid our children's dreams of the nuclear nightmare, and I did. Over the past four years, more people have breathed the fresh air of freedom than in all of human history. I saw a chance to help, and I did. And these were the two defining opportunities -- not of a year, not of a decade, but of an entire span of human history.
I seized those opportunities for our kids and our grandkids, and I make no apologies for that.
Now, the Soviet bear may be gone, but there are still wolves in the woods. And we saw that when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. The Mideast might have become a nuclear powder keg, our energy supplies held hostage.
So we did what was right and what was necessary. We destroyed a threat, freed a people and locked a tyrant in the prison of his own country.
Well, what about the leader of the Arkansas National Guard, the man who hopes to be commander in chief? Well, while I bit the bullet, and he bit his nails.
And two days -- listen to this now -- two days after Congress followed my lead, my opponent said this, and I quote directly: "I guess I would have voted with the majority if it was a close vote. But I agree with the arguments the minority made."
Now, sounds to me like his policy can be summed up by a road sign he has probably seen on his bus tour, "Slippery When Wet."
 
Who Will Lead?
 Look, look, this is serious business. Think about the impact of our foreign-policy failures the last time the Democrats controlled both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue: Gas lines, grain embargoes, American hostages blindfolded.
There will be more foreign-policy challenges like Kuwait in the next four years. Terrorists and aggressors to stand up to, dangerous weapons to be controlled and destroyed. And freedom's fight is not finished. And I look forward to being the first President to visit a free, democratic Cuba.
Who will lead the world? Who will lead the world in the face of these challenges? Not my opponent. In his acceptance speech he devoted just 65 seconds to telling us about the world.
And then he said that America was -- and I quote again -- I want to be fair and factual -- I quote, being "ridiculed" everywhere. Well tell that to the people around the world, for whom America is still a dream. Tell that to the leaders around the world, from whom America commands respect.
Ridiculed? Ridiculed? Tell that to the men and women of Desert Storm.
Let me, let me just make an aside comment here because of what you've been reading in the paper. This is a political year, but there's a lot of danger in the world. And you can be sure, I will never let politics interfere with a foreign-policy decision. Forget the election; I will do right -- what is right for the national security of the United States of America. And that is a pledge from my heart.
 
A Young Man's Decision
 Fifty years ago, 50 years ago this summer, I was 18 years of age. I see some young people in the audience tonight and I remember how I felt. And I believed deeply in this country, and we were faced with a world war. And so I made a decision, to go off and fight a battle much different from political battles.
And I was scared, but I was willing. I was young, but I was ready. I had barely lived, when I began to watch men die. I began to see the special place of America in the world, and I began to see, even then, that the world would become a much smaller place, and faraway places could become more and more like America.
And 50 years later, after change of almost biblical proportions, we know that when freedom grows, America grows. And just as a strong America means a safer world, we have learned that a safer world means a stronger America.
This election, this election is about change. But that's not unusual, because the American revolution is never ending. Today, the pace of change is accelerating. We face new opportunities and new challenges. And the question is, Who do you trust to make change work for you?
My opponent, my opponent says America is a nation in decline. Of our economy, he says, we are somewhere on the list beneath Germany, heading south toward Sri Lanka.
Well, don't let anyone tell you that America is second-rate, especially somebody running for President.
 
Good News and Bad
 Maybe he hasn't heard, maybe he hasn't heard that we are still the world's largest economy. No other nation sells more outside its borders. The Germans, the British, the Japanese can't touch the productivity of you, the American worker and the American farmer.
My opponent, my opponent won't mention that. He won't remind you that interest rates are the lowest they've been in 20 years, and millions of Americans have refinanced their homes. And you just won't hear that inflation, the thief of the middle class, has been locked in a maximum-security prison.
And you don't hear much about this good news, because the media also tends to focus only on the bad. And when the Berlin wall fell, I half expected to see a headline: "Wall Falls, Three Border Guards Lose Jobs." And underneath it probably says: "Clinton Blames Bush."
You don't hear a lot about progress in America. So let me tell you about some good things we've done together.
Just two weeks ago, all three nations of North America agreed to trade freely from Manitoba to Mexico. And this will bring good jobs to Main Street U.S.A.
We passed the Americans with Disabilities Act, bringing 43 million people into the economic mainstream. And I must say, it is about time.
Our children will breathe easier because of our new clean-air pact.
We are rebuilding our roads, providing jobs for more than half a million Americans.
And we passed a child-care law, and we took a stand for family values by saying that when it comes to raising children, Government doesn't know best, parents know best.
I have fought against prejudice and anti-Semitism all my life. And I am proud that we strengthened our civil rights laws, and we did it without resorting to quotas.
And one more thing of vital importance to all. Today, cocaine use has fallen by 60 percent among young people. To the teen-agers, the parents and the volunteers who are helping us battle the scourge of drugs in America: we say thank you. Thank you from the bottom of our heart.
 
Challenge of the 90's
 Do I want to do more? You bet. Nothing hurts me more than to meet with soldiers home from the Persian Gulf, who can't find a job. Or workers who have a job, but worry that the next day will bring a pink slip. And what about parents who scrape and struggle to send their kids to college, only to find them back living at home, because they can't get work.
The world is in transition, and we are feeling that transition in our homes.
The defining challenge of the 90's is to win the economic competition, to win the peace.
We must be a military superpower, an economic superpower and an export superpower.
In this election, you'll hear two versions of how to do this. Theirs is to look inward and protect what we already have. Ours is to look forward, to open new markets, prepare out people to compete, to restore our social fabric -- to save and invest -- so we can win.
We believe that now that the world looks more like America, it is time for America to look more like herself.
And so we offer a philosophy that puts faith in the individual, not the bureaucracy. A philosophy that empowers people to do their best, so America can be at its best. In a world that is safer and freer, this is how we will build an America that is stronger, safer and more secure.
 
Attack on Congress
 We start with a simple fact: Government is too big and spends too much.
And I have asked Congress to put a lid on mandatory spending except Social Security. And I've proposed doing away with over 200 programs and 4,000 wasteful projects and to freeze all other spending.
The gridlock Democrat Congress said, "No."
So, beginning tonight, I will enforce the spending freeze on my own. And if Congress sends me a bill spending more than I asked for in my budget, I will veto it fast. Veto it fast. Faster than copies of Millie's book sold.
Now, Congress won't cut spending, but refuses to give the President the power to eliminate pork-barrel projects that waste your money. Forty-three Governors have that power. So I ask you, the American people, Give me a Congress that will give me the line-item veto.
Let me tell you about a recent battle fought with the Congress, a battle in which I was aided by Bob Michel and Bob Dole. This spring, I worked day and night to get two-thirds of the House members to approve a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.
We almost had it, but we lost by just nine votes. Now listen how. Just before the vote, the liberal leaders of Congress convinced 12 members who cosponsored the bill to switch sides and vote no. Keep in mind, they voted against a bill they had already put their names on.
Something fishy is going on. And look at my opponent on this issue. Look at my opponent. He says he's for balanced budgets. But he came out against the amendment. He's like that on a lot of issues, first on one side, then the other. He's been spotted in more places than Elvis Presley.
After all these years, after all these years, Congress has become pretty creative at finding ways to waste your money. So we need to be just as creative at finding ways to stop them. And I have a brand new idea.
 
Looking at Taxes
 Taxpayers should be given the right to check a box on their tax returns, so that up to 10 percent of their payments can go for one purpose alone: To reduce the national debt.
But we also, but we also need to make sure -- we need to make sure -- that Congress doesn't just turn around and borrow more money, to spend more money. And so I will require that, for every tax dollar set aside to cut the debt, the ceilings on spending will be cut by an equal amount. And that way, that way, we will cut both debt and spending, and take a whack out of the budget deficit.
My feelings about Big Government come from my experience: I spent half my adult life in the private sector. My opponent has a different experience: he has been in government nearly all his life. His passion to expand government knows no bounds.
And he has already proposed -- and listen to this carefully -- he has already proposed $220 billion in new spending, along with the biggest tax increase in history, $150 billion. And that's just to start.
He says he wants to tax the rich, but, folks, he defines rich as anyone who has a job.
You've heard of the separations of powers. Well, my opponent practices a different theory: "The power of separations." Government has the power to separate you from your wallet.
Now let me say this: When it comes to taxes, I've learned the hard way.
There's an old saying: "Good judgment comes from experience, and experience comes from bad judgment."
Two years ago, I made a bad call on the Democrats' tax increase. I underestimated Congress's addiction to taxes. And with my back against the wall, I agreed to a hard bargain: One tax increase one time, in return for the toughest spending limits ever.
Well, it was a mistake to go along with the Democratic tax increase. And I admit it.
But here's the question for the American people. Who do you trust in this election? The candidate who's raised taxes one time and regrets it, or the other candidate who raised taxes and fees 128 times, and enjoyed it every time?
 
Proposals for Congress
 When the new Congress convenes next January, I'll propose to further reduce taxes across the board, provided we pay for these cuts with specific spending reductions that I consider appropriate, so that we do not increase the deficit. I will also continue to fight to increase the personal exemption and to create jobs by winning a cut in capital gains taxes.
That will especially help small businesses. You know they create two-thirds of the new jobs in America. But my opponent's plan for small business is clear, present -- and dangerous. Beside new income taxes, his plan will lead to a new payroll tax to pay for a Government takeover of health care, and another new tax to pay for training. And that is just the beginning.
And if he gets his way, hardware stores all across America will have a new sign up: "Closed for despair." And I guess you'd say his plan really is "Elvis economics:" America will be checking into the "Heartbreak Hotel."
I believe that small business needs relief -- from taxation, regulation, and litigation.
And thus I will extend for one year the freeze on paperwork and unnecessary Federal regulation that I imposed last winter. There is no reason, there is no reason, that Federal regulations should live longer than my friend George Burns. I will issue an order to get rid of any rule whose time has come, and gone.
 
Clinton and Lawyers
 And I see something happening in our towns and in our neighborhoods. Sharp lawyers are running wild. Doctors are afraid to practice medicine. And some moms and pops won't even coach Little League any more. We must sue each other less, and care for each other more. I am fighting to reform our legal system, to put an end to crazy lawsuits. And if that means climbing into the ring with the trial lawyers, well, let me just say, Round 1 starts tonight.
After all, my opponent's campaign is being backed by practically every trial lawyer who ever wore a tasseled loafer. He's not in the ring with them, he's in the tank.
There are other things we need to do to get our economy up to speed and prepare our kids for the next century.
We must have new incentives for research and new training for workers. Small businesses need capital and credit, and defense workers need new jobs.
And I have a plan to provide affordable health care for every American, controlling costs by cutting paperwork and lawsuits, and expanding coverage to the poorest of the poor.
We do not need my opponent's plan for a massive Government takeover of health care, which would ration care and deny you the right to choose a doctor. Who wants health-care, who wants health care with a system with the efficiency of the House post office and the compassion of the KGB?
What about our schools? What about our schools? My opponent and I both want to change the way our kids learn. He wants to change our schools a little bit, and I want to change them a lot.
Take the issue of whether parents should be able to choose the best school for their kids. My opponent says that's O.K., as long as the school is run by Government. And I say every parent and child should have a real choice of schools -- public, private or religious.
So we have a clear choice to fix our problems. Do we turn to the tattered blanket of bureaucracy that other nations are tossing away? Or do we give our people the freedom and incentives to build security for themselves?
 
'The Blame Game
 Here's what I'm fighting for: open markets for American products, lower government spending, tax relief, opportunities for small business, legal and health reform, job training and new schools built on competition, ready for the 21st century.
Now, O.K. Why are these proposals not in effect today?
Only one reason: the gridlock Democratic Congress.
Now, I know Americans are tired of the blame game, tired of people in Washington acting like they are candidates for the next episode of "American Gladiators."
I don't like it either. Neither should you. But the truth is the truth. Our policies have not failed; they haven't been tried.
Americans want jobs. On Jan. 28, I put before Congress a plan to create jobs. And if it had been passed back then, 500,000 more Americans would be at work right now. But in a nation that demands action, Congress has become the master of inaction.
And it wasn't always this way. I heard President Ford tonight. I served in Congress 22 years ago under him. And back then, we cooperated; we didn't get personal. We put the people above everything else. Heck, we didn't even own blowdryers back in those days.
At my first inauguration I said that people didn't send us to bicker. I extended my hand -- and I think the American people know this -- I extended my hand to the Congressional leaders, the Democratic leaders, and they bit it.
And the House leadership, the House leadership has not changed in 38 years. It is a body caught in a hopelessly tangled web of PACs, perks, privileges, partisanship and paralysis. Every day, every day, Congress puts politics ahead of principle and above progress.
 
Congress and Clinton
 Now let me give you just one example. Feb. 20, 1991. It was at the height of the gulf war. On that very same day, I asked American pilots to risk their lives to fly missions over Baghdad. And I also wanted to strengthen our economic security for the future. So that very same day, I introduced a new domestic energy strategy which would cut our dependence on foreign oil by seven million barrels a day.
How many days did it take to win the gulf war? Forty-three. How many did it take Congress to pass a national energy strategy? Five hundred and thirty-two -- and still counting.
I have ridden stationary bikes that can move faster than the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate controlled by the Democrat leadership.
Where does my opponent stand with Congress? Well, up in New York at their convention, they kept the Congressional leaders away from the podium, hid them away. They didn't want America to hear from the people who really make the decisions.
And they hid them for a very good reason -- because the American people would recognize a dangerous combination: a rubber-check Congress and a rubber-stamp President.
Governor Clinton and Congress know that you've caught on to their lingo. They know when they say "spending" you say "oh, oh." So now they have a new word, "investment." They want to "invest" $220 billion more of your money, but I want you to keep it.
Governor Clinton and Congress want to put through the largest tax increase in history, but I will not let that happen.
And Governor Clinton and Congress don't want kids to have the option of praying in school, but I do. Clinton and Congress don't want to close legal loopholes and keep criminals behind bars, but I will. Clinton and Congress will stack the judiciary with liberal judges who write laws they can't get approved by the voters.
Governor Clinton even says Mario Cuomo belongs on the Supreme Court.
Now, wait a minute though. Now wait. Maybe not a bad idea.
If you believe, if you believe in judicial restraint, you probably ought to be happy. After all, the good Governor of New York can't make up his mind between chocolate and vanilla at Baskin Robbins. If he's there, we won't have another court decision for 35 years. And maybe that's all right, too.
 
The Carter Years
 Are my opponent and Congress really in cahoots? Look at one important question: Should we limit the terms of Congress? Governor Clinton says no. Congress says no. And I say yes.
We tried this. Look, we tried this once before, combining the Democratic Governor of a small Southern state with a very liberal Vice President and a Democratic Congress. America does not need "Carter 2."
We do not want to take America back to those days of malaise. But Americans want to know, Where's proof that we will have better days in Washington?
I'll give you 150 reasons, and that's how many members of Congress are expected to leave Washington this year. Some are tainted by scandal; the voters have bounced them the way they bounced their own checks. But others are good members, Republican and Democrat. And they agree with me: The place just doesn't work any more.
A 150 new members, from both parties, will be coming to Washington this fall. And every one will have a fresh view of America's future.
And I pledge today to the American people, immediately after this election, I will meet with every one of these members, before they get attacked by the PAC's, overwhelmed by their staffs and cornered by some camera crew. And I will lay out my case, for change. Change that matters, real change that makes a difference. Change that is right for America.
 
Change and Values
 You see, there is a yearning in America, a feeling that maybe it's time to get back to our roots.
Sure we must change, but some values are timeless. I believe in families that stick together fathers who stick around. And I happen to believe very deeply in the worth of each individual human being, born or unborn. And I believe in teaching our kids the difference between what's wrong and what's right, teaching them respect for hard work and to love their neighbors. And I believe that America will always have a special place in God's heart, as long as He has a special place in ours. And maybe that's why I've always believed that patriotism is not just another point of view.
There are times in every young person's life when God introduces you to yourself. And I remember such a time. It was back many years ago, when I stood watch at 4 A.M. Up on the bridge of a submarine, the United States Finback, U.S.S. Finback. And I would stand there and look out on the blackness of the sky, broken only by the sparkling stars above. And I would think about friends I lost, a country I loved and about a girl named Barbara. And I remember, I remember those nights as clearly as any in my life.
You know, you can see things from up there that other people don't see. You can see storm clouds rise and then disappear. The first hint of the sun over the horizon and the first outline of the shore faraway.
Now, I know Americans are uneasy today. There is anxious talk around our kitchen tables. But from where I stand, I see not American's sunset, but a sunrise.
And the world changes for which we've sacrificed for a generation have finally come to pass and with them a rare and unprecedented opportunity to pass the sweet cup of prosperity around our American table.
Are we up to it? I know we are.
As I travel our land, I meet veterans who once worked the turrets of a tank and can now master the keyboards of high-tech economy. I see teachers, blessed with the incredible American capacity for innovation, who are teaching our children a new way to learn for a new century. And I meet parents, some working two jobs with hectic schedules, who still find new ways to teach old values to steady their kids in a turbulent world.
 
Appealing to America's Spirit
 And I take heart from what is happening in America, not from those who profess a new passion for Government, but from those with an old and enduring faith in the human potential. Those who understand that the genius of America is our capacity for rebirth and renewal. America is the land where the sun is always peeking over the horizon.
And tonight I appeal to the unyielding, undying, undeniable American spirit. I ask you to consider, now that the entire world is moving our way, why would we want to go back their way? I ask not just for your support for my agenda, but for your commitment to renew and rebuild our nation by shaking up one institution that has withstood change for over four decades.
Join me in rolling away the roadblock, join me in rolling away the roadblock at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue, so that in the next four years, we will match our accomplishments outside by building a stronger, safer, more secure America inside.
Forty-four years ago, in another age of uncertainty, a different President embarked on a similar mission. His name was Harry S. Truman.
And as he stood before his party to accept their nomination, Harry Truman knew the freedom I know this evening, the freedom to talk about what's right for America and let the chips fall where they may.
Harry Truman said this: "This is more than a political call to arms. Give me your help, not to win votes alone, but to win this new crusade and keep America safe and secure for its own people.
Well, tonight I say to you, Join me in our new crusade to reap the rewards of our global victory, to win the peace, so that we may make America safer and stronger for all our people.
May God bless you, and may God bless the United States of America. Thank you very much.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 621 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
William Taylor, the F.D.I.C. chairman, died following colon surgery. His death threw into doubt his plan to increase the insurance premiums that banks and savings associations pay to protect depositors. He had cast the tie-breaking vote to lift premiums by an average of 22 percent, when the plan was approved in May. [Page D1.] A career regulator, Mr. Taylor was lauded by both Republicans in the White House and Democrats in Congress. Alan Greenspan called him an "extremely capable public servant of unquestioned integrity. [A22.]
Little change would have occurred in first-time filings for jobless benefits early this month, but for G.M. workers who filed for unemployment insurance when the automaker shut its plants for two weeks. That led to the largest jump in more than 10 years. [D2.]
 
Companies
Olympia & York is seeking a five-year moratorium on debt repayments to its biggest creditors. The goal of the plan, which the world's largest property manager is to file in Canadian bankruptcy court today, is to allow the company to stay in business. [D1.] 
 Negotiations for a possible T.W.A. buyout have stumbled over job security and over how the carrier should make up a shortfall in the pension fund. The pilots' union and Carl C. Icahn, the airline's owner, are trying to put together a deal. [D3.]
Motorola, seeking entry to the $4.6 billion world market for flat-panel display screens, agreed to buy 20 percent of In Focus Systems for $22 million. The companies agreed to form a joint venture to produce the liquid crystal displays in the United States that would compete with the Japanese companies like Sharp and NEC that dominate the market. [D3.]
Coopers & Lybrand is suing executives of Phar-Mor, the discount drug chain and former client that had accused the accounting firm of negligence for not uncovering what it says was a massive fraud perpetrated by former executives. [D3.]
ITT Corporation named Louis J. Giuliano to run its newly combined defense and components divisions. [D3.]
 
Markets
 The dollar sagged to a low against the German mark, closing in New York at 1.4470, beneath the low of 1.4475 set in February 1991. The weak currency, like the ailing economy it reflects, could be a liability for President Bush. [D1.]
Despite a recovery in bank shares after Wednesday's selloff, stocks eased as investors waited to see whether President Bush would give any new economic initiatives in his acceptance speech at the Republican convention. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 2.17 points lower at 3,304.89. [D6.]
Short sales on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a record between mid-July and mid-August. It was the fifth straight monthly gain, a sign of pessimism. [D4.]
Stocks in Tokyo continued to rebounded following the Government's emergency measures to stabilize the Japanese financial system. [D6.]
Treasury bond and note prices slipped in thin trading, as traders hesitated to take positions ahead of the President's acceptance speech. In the auction of $14.3 billion of one-year Treasury bills, the average discount rate was 3.28 percent, the lowest rate since April 10, 1963. [D12.]
Silver futures plunged to new lows on reports of heavy Saudi- and Swiss-based selling. [D13.]

The Gap's star has been eclipsed. The jeans retailer's stock has fallen more than 40 percent this year with earnings growth waning and visions of warehouses bulging with unsold denim dancing in analysts' heads. Market Place. [D6.]
Alternative music of the Nirvana of Soundgarden sort is being used by canny advertisers in commercials to identify products as hip. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Bank Fee Is in Doubt After Death at F.D.I.C.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
William Taylor, one of the nation's senior banking regulators, died today. The death of the widely respected chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation raised serious concerns in Washington about the direction of the agency in the next few months as it is headed by an interim chairman.
Lawmakers and senior Administration officials said today that Mr. Taylor's death had robbed the agency of its influential leader just as it embarks on an important period of writing new regulations. In particular, it throws into doubt his plan to increase the insurance premiums that banks and savings associations pay to protect depositors. 
 The increase, an average of 22 percent, was tentatively approved in May on a 3-to-2 vote by the F.D.I.C. board and was to go into effect in January after a final vote next month. Mr. Taylor cast the swing vote.
He died this morning at a hospital in Fairfax, Va., from complications of colon surgery last week. [Obituary, page A22.]
 
Increase Likely to Be Blocked
 With no sign of any board member's changing his vote, the increase is now considered likely to be blocked by a tie vote next month, although some officials predicted today that the agency might approve a significantly smaller rise. A new chairman, even if named by President Bush this fall, is unlikely to be confirmed by the Senate until next year.
Andrew C. Hove Jr., who is now the acting chairman of the agency, said, "I just don't know what will happen" with the premium. As vice chairman in May, he cast his vote with Mr. Taylor. "It's an issue we are going to have to deal with on Sept. 1," he said.
Fearful that a large taxpayer bailout of the banks will be necessary if the industry does not pay more, the chairmen of the two banking committees in Congress, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, and Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, urged a rate increase upon the agency.
In his 10 months at the agency, Mr. Taylor made the restoration of the insolvent bank insurance fund his primary mission.
But the Administration and many banks hoped to block the premium rise because it would have a broad economic impact, making banking more expensive for customers, who would have to pay more for loans and receive lower yields on deposits. It would also hurt the stockholders of about 14,500 banks and savings associations, reducing the industry's after-tax earnings by more than 4 percent. Some of the premium costs are also borne by taxpayers, because institutions are permitted to write off a percentage of their premium payments on their corporate taxes.
In May, Mr. Taylor and two board members of the F.D.I.C. tentatively approved the plan to raise premiums by an average of 22 percent beginning in January, and also make fundamental changes in the way those premiums are assessed. For the first time since 1934, when the initial fund was set up in the wake of the bank collapses of the Great Depression, weaker institutions would pay a bigger increase than stronger ones.
Two other board members, who are also officials of the Treasury Department, dissented and went along with the Administration's view that such a steep increase was not necessary. Those officials are T. Timothy Ryan Jr., head of the Office of Thrift Supervision, and Stephen R. Steinbrink, Acting Comptroller of the Currency. Hours after the vote in May on the premium increase, Mr. Steinbrink said in an interview that he would have approved a smaller rise in the rates.
A final vote on the premium proposal is scheduled for Sept. 1, and if the remaining four board members vote as they did a few weeks ago, the measure will be defeated.
The bank insurance fund lost about $11 billion last year, giving it a deficit of about $7 billion that it has had to borrow from the Treasury. It has predicted possibly greater losses in the next two years.
The proposed changes would raise an additional $1.25 billion annually. It would raise premiums to an average of 28 cents for every $100 in deposits, from the current 23 cents. The weakest banks, those with the least capital and the most problem loans, would pay an additional 3 cents for every $100 in deposits, and the strongest would pay 3 cents less.
The bank insurance fund, which stood at $18.3 billion six years ago, has been battered by the failures of 885 banks since then, costing more than $26 billion. While assessments have nearly tripled, from 8.3 cents per $100 just three years ago to the current 23 cents, they have failed to keep pace with the devastation of the industry.
In recent months, the deposit insurance corporation has dramatically slowed the number of banks it has seized, citing favorable interest rates that have temporarily helped weak banks. But the agency has been ordered by Congress to change its policy and begin in December to seize weak, though solvent, institutions, on the theory that it is cheaper to rescue banks if they are taken over before they become insolvent.
Mr. Taylor's death leaves the agency in the hands of Mr. Hove probably until sometime next year. No one expects a permanent replacement to be appointed by the White House and confirmed by the Senate before the next administration is in place and a new Congress comes to Washington in January.
Mr. Hove, a 57-year-old former mayor of Minden, Neb., where he also was a banker, said today in a brief meeting in his office with reporters that he would move to carry on the agenda set by Mr. Taylor.
"Perhaps the best tribute we can give Bill Taylor is to continue his agenda," Mr. Hove said. He said the two top priorities for the agency continued to be to nurse the bank insurance fund back to health and "improve the safety and soundness" of the industry.
He appeared to be shaken by the news of Mr. Taylor's death and awkward about meeting with reporters on the same day to discuss the future of the agency.
Mr. Hove arrived in Washington two years ago and is known to his friends as Skip. On the most important votes this year he sided with Mr. Taylor and against the Bush Administration's two representatives on the F.D.I.C. board, although some lobbyists today predicted that the agency would be yielding some of its independence to the Treasury Department.
Normally directed by a five-member board, the F.D.I.C. will now be run by four members -- two of whom are officials in the Treasury Department and two others whose terms expire in February.
"It's a lame-duck board," said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president and top lobbyist for the Independent Bankers Association of America. "The bottom line is the F.D.I.C. will be run by the Treasury."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew C. Hove Jr. became interim F.D.I.C. chairman after the death of William Taylor. (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND FAMILY: SOUTHERN WOMEN - Voices of Women in the 'Family Values' Debate: a Sampling, North and South;
In Atlanta, the Message Strikes Chord, but Not With All

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Sue Weidert is all for family values. She loves Barbara Bush. She thinks Mrs. Bush made important points Wednesday when the Republicans put on a full-court press to lure female voters.
But if the election were today, she would vote for Bill Clinton for President. 
 "I like Mrs. Bush," said Ms. Weidert, who was interviewing for a job in downtown Atlanta today. "I'm very disappointed in President Bush. I like what Mrs. Bush said about family values, and I think it's very important, but I wouldn't vote for anybody just because of that. It's an issue, but not the only issue by any means."
Interviews with more than two dozen women in this city that combines the social conservatism and economic dynamism of a changing South found them divided on the family-values appeal made by Marilyn Quayle and Barbara Bush at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday night. Roughly half found the evening heartwarming and appealing; the remainder found it cynical and irrelevant.
 
Not the Deciding Factor
 But nearly all said their vote would be based on something other than the Bush's show of family unity or Mrs. Quayle's views of a wife's proper role.
Several women interviewed here said Wednesday's focus on women and family issues was probably a good idea, especially because of the sour taste several cited from the hard-edged tone of much of the convention, particularly in the Monday speech by Patrick J. Buchanan, the former Republican Presidential challenger.
"I haven't had the stomach to watch any of the convention since Buchanan's speech," said Roberta Newberry, owner of a court reporting service. "He made me ill. I may have to vote Democratic for the first time in my life."
Indeed, preliminary poll results suggest the convention's beginning may have had more success with men than women. A New York Times/CBS News poll of 1,022 registered voters nationwide taken Aug. 11-14 showed Mr. Clinton with a 17-percentage-point lead, including a 19-point lead among men and a 15-point lead among women.
 
Mrs. Bush? Loved Her.
 A CBS News poll of 1,204 registered voters nationwide taken Tuesday and Wednesday showed a 9-point Clinton lead, with a 7-point lead among men and a 10-point lead among women.
The interviews today, most conducted at a downtown office complex and a suburban mall today, indicated that many women reacted positively to Wednesday night's speeches, particularly the one given by Mrs. Bush.
"I love what she said about family values, going back to the more traditional values I grew up with," said Mary Salvadori, who runs a downtown hair salon with her husband.
To some, the evening was revealing. "It showed me that they were somewhat more interested in women than you seem to get the impression they are," said Kendall Campbell, who recently stopped working as an interior designer to care for her newborn son.
But several women interviewed found the evening irrelevant or worse. "They talk about family values, but it's really just a way to bash the other guys and cover up what they haven't done on the real issues," said Lindy Barnett.
To some, the moral issues and talk about family values are anything but a distraction.
Jean Shumaker, shopping with her 2-year-old daughter Jenny at Cumberland Mall in suburban Cobb County, said: "I definitely know that no one is better to raise a child than that child's mother. I know some women have to work, and I appreciate that. But if the reason is to have two cars and a nice house, that's something else."
But to others family values is something much more complex than the Republicans make it out to be.
Candace Wiggins, a freelance proofreader and writer working for a local law firm, said the remarks by Mrs. Quayle and former Education Secretary William J. Bennett, were an "offensive" attempt to evoke a outdated world of working fathers and stay-at-home moms that most families can't afford even if they want to.
"It was totally out of touch with reality," she said. "It was all a white-bread world. Well, we're wheat toast now. Give me some fiber."

(David Murray Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: ROSS PEROT;
Pay, Not Perot, Lures Workers In Ballot Effort

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Petition-gatherers for Ross Perot were out in force in midtown Manhattan yesterday, part of the disavowed Presidential candidate's continuing effort to get his name on the November ballot in all 50 states.
But the workers were not some of the thousands of volunteers who had labored for Mr. Perot around the country until he unexpectedly withdrew from contention last month. These workers were being paid $10 an hour. 
 Patricia Cox, a 21-year-old college student collecting petitions at 49th Street and Fifth Avenue, said she had been hired "through an agency, as a temp." Another worker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he had been unemployed for two years. "I needed the work," he said.
A Perot spokeswoman in Dallas, Sharon Holman, said volunteers were still gathering petitions in eight states, including New York, in the quest to get their candidate on the ballot in all 50 states. "At this moment, Mr. Perot's on the ballot in 36 states," Ms. Holman said. "There are an additional seven states -- actually those seven include the District of Columbia -- that have turned in their petitions and are awaiting certification."
The remaining eight states where petitions are still being gathered, she said, are New York, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Arizona, Hawaii, Louisiana, Mississippi and Vermont.
"Mr. Perot had encouraged those who were collecting signatures to complete the process," Ms. Holman said. "By staying together, they can be a very powerful force. They will be the swing vote that will force the other two parties to pay attention to Mr. Perot's economic plan. His No. 1 hope is that one or the other candidates will embrace an economic plan that will make sense."
Ms. Holman said she was unaware that petition-gatherers in New York were being paid, and insisted that none in other states were receiving money. Petition-gatherers in Manhattan yesterday knew little about who had hired them, and no one answered a telephone call placed to the number listed in a classified advertisement in Wednesday's New York Times seeking paid Perot campaign workers.
The telephone number given is for the campaign headquarters of Abraham Hirschfeld, a real estate developer who is seeking the Democratic nomination to run against Representative Bill Green, a Manhattan Republican.
Ms. Holman said she did not know Mr. Hirschfeld, and Mr. Hirschfeld could not be reached for comment.
A petition-gatherer near Rockefeller Center, Eudowa Vincent, 25, of Queens Village, Queens, said yesterday that other workers fanned out in Greenwich Village, at Pennsylvania Station and Wall Street as well as in parts of Brooklyn on Long Island and upstate.
Mr. Perot's former New York campaign chairman, Matthew Lifflander, who is now working for the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, said: "The sad thing here is that after having these thousands of wonderful volunteers across the state who broke their hearts and gave their energy free of charge, now he's left with only those that he can buy, by paying to have the petitions carried.
"It's a double tragedy, because he still has a lot of good, substantitve ideas that people ought to be paying attention to," Mr. Lifflander added.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Although Ross Perot has dropped out, the petition drive to get his name on the ballot is still under way in eight states amid reports that not all who are doing the work are volunteers. On Fifth Avenue yesterday, pedestrians shared a crowded sidewalk with Perot workers. (Angel Franco/The New York Times); A classified ad that appeared in Wednesday's New York Times.

HEADLINE: D'Amato Criticizes G.O.P. Over Emphasis on Family Values

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
Heading into a bruising re-election battle this fall in New York, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato took a clearly calculated swipe at his own party yesterday, saying the Republicans had focused far too intensely on "family values" and had failed to address voters' concerns about the economy in great enough depth.
"I don't think any party has a corner on family values, and I don't think that any party should claim that it has one," Mr. D'Amato said in an interview at the Republican National Convention in Houston. "What we should do is talk about programs that will help a family with real challenges, whether it is a traditional family or a single-parent family." 
 Senator D'Amato insisted that his stance merely reflected his disappointment with the tone of the convention. "It's got nothing to do with any election," he said.
But the comments also indicated a need to distance himself from a platform that would represent a severe political liability in New York, even though it might play well in more conservative parts of the nation.
Mr. D'Amato's comments came as the Senate campaign, which has proceeded quietly for the last several months, is taking a much noisier -- and nastier -- turn on the Democratic side, where four candidates are vying for the right to oppose Senator D'Amato in the November general election.
Yesterday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo issued a rebuke to two of the candidates, Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller, and Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General, for barraging former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro with what they said were unanswered questions about her and her husband's finances and possible dealings with members of organized crime. He called their tactics "gutter politics."
"He who lives by the accusation dies by the accusation," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. "It's damaging, it's destructive and this will not help any of them defeat Senator D'Amato."
Ms. Holtzman fired back a two-page letter by facsimile machine to the Governor, detailing a history of Ms. Ferraro's husband's rental of commercial space to a Mafia-linked pornography company.
"If a Democratic candidate is unable to take the 'sleaze factor' right to D'Amato's doorstep, then voters need to know that before the primary, not in October, when it's too late," she told the Governor.
Mr. D'Amato's remarks seemed to represent the evolution of a strategy begun months ago, in which the Senator has tried to distance himself from President Bush's economic policies.
"To get re-elected in this state, he's going to need, in all likelihood, to get more votes than Bush does," said Hank Morris, a frequent consultant to Democratic candidates. "He's got to send a message to Democrats because there are a lot of people in New York who might have been rubbed the wrong way by what Pat Buchanan had to say at the convention."
While Mr. D'Amato has remained a consistent foe of abortion except in cases of rape, incest and where the life of the pregnant woman is at stake, Mr. D'Amato declined in a telephone interview to say whether he had any opinion on other issues that some Republicans have raised as a litmus test for family values.
 
Domestic Partners
 For instance, when asked how he felt about various proposals to confer legal recognition, including shared health benefits, on same-sex couples who register as domestic partners, Mr. D'Amato replied: "I'm not going to get involved in it. I'm not opposed to it and I'm not in favor of it."
Asked whether same-sex couples should be allowed to marry, a policy some Republicans have derisively raised as a possible Democratic initiative, Mr. D'Amato said this was for churches to decide before governments, or senators, should.
And while both Marilyn Quayle and Barbara Bush emphasized the value of mothers deciding to stay home with young children, Mr. D'Amato noted in the interview that he expected that his daughter would be continuing her career as an industrial engineer even as she raises two children. "I wouldn't take any offense at that," he said.
In general, Mr. D'Amato was critical of Republican strategists for what he said was "all the hype" about Mrs. Bush's speech Wednesday night. "All the aides and campaign strategists who said it was going to be 'family values night' actually undercut a very stirring presentation by the First Lady," he said.
Other Republicans at the convention echoed Mr. D'Amato's theme, though many, like Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts or former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, were generally viewed as more liberal than he is to begin with. Representative Susan Molinari of New York said, "I really think that my constituents only wanted one answer from this convention and from the Democrats' convention and that is how are you going to fix the economy so that I know I'll keep my job?"
 
A Critical Juncture
 On the Democratic side, the allegations about Ms. Ferraro that have been raised by Ms. Holtzman and Mr. Abrams are clearly creating a critical juncture in the primary campaign. The major question is whether suggestions of ethical weaknesses on her part will diminish her standing as the front-runner or whether she will be able to capitalize on her strategy of portraying herself as a sympathetic victim of ethnic smears.
A similar strategy in 1984 helped her defuse controversy over her finances as she campaigned for Vice President but also left a perception that she had never addressed some of the questions head on.
Her strategy was much in evidence yesterday as Ms. Ferraro assailed her opponents and released a list of new endorsements from politicians, including Representatives Jose E. Serrano, Thomas J. Downey, Matthew F. McHugh and Robert J. Mrazek, many of whom criticized Mr. Abrams and Ms. Holtzman.
But both Ms. Holtzman and Mr. Abrams said that in all her professed outrage, Ms. Ferraro had resisted many of their questions and demands that she release tax records.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Plummets to Reach Lowest Level Against Mark

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
As President Bush prepared to deliver his acceptance speech to the Republican National Convention in Houston, the American dollar closed yesterday in New York at its lowest level ever against the mark.
The dollar was at 1.447 against the mark in late trading, slipping under the previous record low of 1.4475 set in February 1991. 
 "The weak dollar reflects the market perception that the U.S. economy continues to be weak and, in addition, the political uncertainty of the campaign," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers in New York, said.
The dollar's decline began in force this spring, as chances disappeared for a strong economic recovery, which would have attracted foreign investment. In addition, the gap between the high interest rates in Germany and Europe and the declining interest rates in the United States has widened, making investments in dollar-denominated securities expensive and unappealing.
In other currency trading yesterday, the dollar eased against the yen, closing at 126.52, compared with 126.58 Wednesday. It may be that only Japan's current economic crisis is preventing the dollar from falling to new lows against the yen. The dollar also fell against European currencies.
The fall against the mark yesterday was not dramatic because the dollar has been weak for some time. Like a sick patient, it just gently slipped to this record as its doctors -- the Governments of the United States and of its economic allies -- watched at the bedside. Twice in the last month, the Federal Reserve and central banks from America's economic allies have intervened in concert to support the dollar before it fell to a new low. Today they did not.
The decline could be inopportune for Mr. Bush, if his Democratic opponent, Bill Clinton, choses to point to the declining dollar as a symbol of a weakened American economy and leadership.
The decline has already been tough on Americans abroad, as their vacation costs have soared, while the dollar fell -- 11.5 percent against the mark since the end of April and similar amounts against other European currencies.
The first dollar support effort came July 20 as the dollar once again neared its low against the mark, which was created in 1948. The massive intervention, in which the Fed and more than 10 other central banks bought dollars to lift the currency's value, surprised traders, and the dollar rose.
Since then it has drifted back down, but only cautiously, showing traders were wary of more intervention. If it comes swiftly and unexpectedly, it can result in large trading losses.
The Federal Reserve intervened alone in early August; then the Fed and other central banks joined in another major intervention Aug. 11. But these moves had less impact because they were expected.
Some traders were surprised that the Fed and other central banks did not intervene yesterday. "It makes one wonder if they think it is important to defend the dollar," said Christopher S. Bourdain of Credit Suisse in New York.
Mr. Bourdain noted that because traders are not aggressively selling dollars, intervention might not be that effective. Yet there is likely to be a lot more supportive intervention soon because if the central banks wait too long, the dollar could drop suddenly, shaking confidence around the world and bring the American stock and bond markets down with it.
But in the longer term, the problem for the dollar -- and the Bush Administration during a tough election -- is that intervention can be effective only for a short time. Economic policy changes are necessary to give the dollar real support. But the changes that would be needed -- the lowering of interest rates in Germany and the rest of Europe and an increase in interest rates here -- are out of the question right now.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: NEWS ANALYSIS;
In Economic Plan of '92, Bush Avoids Trap of '88

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
This time, no one will be able to blame President Bush for breaking his promises about the economy at the Republican convention. They are simply too vague, not even remotely resembling the "read my lips: no new taxes" pledge he made four years ago in New Orleans.
He said tonight that if he was re-elected, he would propose tax reductions across the board. But he never said which taxes would be lowered, and he made the pledge contingent on offsetting spending reductions. 
 He said he would place a cap on "mandatory spending." But an overall cap could not work until a spending lid was put on the individual programs -- Medicare, Medicaid, veterans' benefits and the like. Otherwise, one program could gobble up all the money and eventually there would be none left for the others. But Mr. Bush did not say tonight and has never said before what those particular limits should be.
He said he would veto any appropriation bill that exceeded his budget request. During Mr. Bush's Presidency, he and Congress have often disagreed on how much to spend for what, but all told, Congress has voted less money than the President asked for. Mr. Bush has never vetoed a bill on the ground it was too expensive.
 
Facing Reality
 Basically, the President tonight faced up to reality, political reality and economic reality.
On the politics, his party is divided. Some, like Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, favor deep tax cuts to stimulate the economy, the budget deficit be damned. Others, like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, believe the top priority is to bring the deficit under control.
If the President had come down firmly, he would have risked alienating one side or the other. So he straddled.
Furthermore, the Democratic Congress is lying in wait. Almost every specific tax reduction Mr. Bush has offered since he took office proved directly more beneficial to the rich than to the middle class or the poor. That would certainly be true of the two he suggested in general terms tonight: a lower capital gains tax and a higher personal exemption.
The Democrats would like nothing more than to take a specific tax-cut proposal before the election, run it through the computers of the Joint Tax Committee and put out charts portraying the President as the patron of fat cats. By being vague, the President took away that opportunity.
As for the economic reality, Mr. Bush apologized tonight for signing the tax increase in 1990. But he made no apology for the recession.
 
Paying Off 1980's Debts
 Actually, there is precious little that President Bush could do to prevent the recession or stimulate the economy, especially in the short run. So from that perspective, most economists do not hold Mr. Bush responsible for the weakness in the economy during his term.
Mainly, the economy has been stagnant because the country has been paying off the debts that were accrued in the 1980's -- the debts of companies, individuals and the Government. The fact is, most economists agree, the prosperity of the 1980's was borrowed from the 1990's.
In addition, the commercial real estate market collapsed largely because of tax-policy swings in the 1980's, and that has been bad for the construction industry. The collapse of communism led to less Government money for military contractors, and the weakness of the banks and savings and loan associations made for newly tightened lending practices.
 
An Unwanted Distinction
 But Mr. Bush is hardly in the position to make excuses or escape blame. He took so much credit for the prosperity of the Reagan years that he can hardly avoid being held accountable for what has happened since: the worst economic performance on balance of any Presidential term since World War II.
His acceptance speech four years ago is, of course, best remembered for the "no new taxes" line. But he also said then:
"Consider the size of our triumph: a record number of Americans at work, a record high percentage of our people with jobs . . . a high rate of new businesses, a record high rate of real personal income."
In Mr. Bush's term, fewer jobs have been created than in any other four-year term since the World War. More businesses have failed. Growth in after-tax personal income, adjusted for inflation, has been imperceptible.
Of course, Mr. Bush is not the only candidate with a vague economic program. Gov. Bill Clinton's proposals to cut the deficit are based largely on an exceedingly optimistic view of how much the economy will grow in the next few years. A large share of the additional revenue he hopes to bring in would come from foreign corporations who do business in this country. These companies do not vote. But they could withdraw their business in a way that might be devastating for Americans.
Still, Mr. Bush was simply wrong tonight when he said Mr. Clinton was proposing the biggest tax increase in history, $150 billion over four years. The tax law Ronald Reagan signed in 1982 raised taxes by $152 billion over four years. And when the $104 billion in tax cuts Mr. Clinton is proposing are subtracted from his proposed tax increases, the net increase is less than the net $107 billion tax rise Mr. Bush signed in 1990.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA AND THE MESSAGE: CAMPAIGN WATCH;
On TV, a Victory in Family Numbers

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
George Bush may not be able to win the election against Bill Clinton on the economy. He may not even be able to win the fight over so-called family values. But there is one battle he wins definitively: the battle over family numbers.
Mr. Bush has a big family. Mr. Clinton has a small family. 
 Big families don't necessarily produce better leaders than small ones. But watching the President make a "surprise" appearance with his brood Wednesday night, one couldn't help noticing that the Bush family would have an easier time getting up a game of touch football on the White House lawn. And in the battle of television images that is so much of what conventions are about, impressions like this may count for a lot.
The show of Bush family solidarity came toward the end of prime-time Wednesday night, directly after Barbara Bush's address. It presented a triumphantly simple visual -- 23 family members -- for an evening that was otherwise fraught with tension. It was, in fact, the only moment of the evening when the phrase "family values" seemed to have a clear meaning.
 
Different Values
 By the time the President made his brief appearance on the stage, viewers watching the Republican convention on CNN, PBS and C-Span had heard rather conflicting accounts of "family values" from Pat Robertson, the television evangelist; Mary Fisher, the daughter of a prominent Republican fund raiser who is infected with the AIDS virus, and Marilyn Quayle, the wife of the Vice President.
Mr. Robertson's family values were those of a "traditional" family threatened by the Clintons and assorted "left-wingers." Ms. Fisher's were those of a "human" family threatened by ignorance and prejudice. And Mrs. Quayle's family values, it seems, were those of talented women who are not threatened by giving up their careers to stay home with the kids.
"Most women," Mrs. Quayle explained, "do not wish to be liberated from their essential natures as women."
Viewers who did not tune into the convention until the networks began their live coverage at 10 P.M. were spared most of these conflicting signals; they got their version of family values straight from Mrs. Bush. Integrity, responsibility, car pools, Little League games and the Fourth of July, viewers learned, figured prominently in the Bush family's life. But as far as the First Lady was concerned, it seemed, family values could be anything, preferably something that would make Americans vote for George Bush.
"However you define family," Mrs. Bush said, "that's what we mean by family values."
 
Big Looks Better
 By introducing not only her five children but also her 12 grandchildren after her speech, Mrs. Bush shifted the family competition to a level on which the Clintons simply cannot compete; their only daughter, Chelsea, is 12 years old. And viewers watching the extended Bush family link arms and wave to the crowd could not help but be impressed by what an attractive, all-American clan they are. (On a mischievous note, though, during Labor Secretary Lynn Martin's nominating speech, NBC repeatedly cut away to one Bush granddaughter wearing an off-the-shoulders and distinctly low-cut dress.)
Several television commentators noted the paradox of the Bush family special Wednesday night, coming on the heels of repeated Republican attacks on Hillary Clinton. Wasn't it hypocritical, they asked, for the party to call in Barbara Bush to shore up her husband while at the same time claiming it is Mrs. Clinton who wields too much influence?
If this troubled Mrs. Bush, however, she did not show it. Even after delivering one of the convention's most important addresses, she managed on television to maintain the air of a slightly addled grandmother whose major worry is that someone won't like her cooking.
"I don't think it was a very big role," she insisted when Maria Shriver of NBC asked her about her performance Wednesday night. "I thought Marilyn gave a great speech."
And if the Bush family appearance was carefully planned, the family's response to questions about its purpose was equally well managed.
"Was there an attempt in all that to contrast your family with the Clinton family?" Charles Gibson of ABC asked Mr. Bush's daughter, Dorothy Koch, this morning.
"I don't think so," she replied.
