HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE FAMILY: NORTHERN WOMEN - Voices of Women in the 'Family Values' Debate: a Sampling, North and South;
In New Jersey, The Reaction Is 'Show Me'

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Barbara Bush won praise for being warm and wonderful. Marilyn Quayle fared less well among those who listened to the speeches of both women at the Republican National Convention last night, though she won points for emphasizing "family values."
But in this central New Jersey town, the seat of a county where registered Republican voters outnumber Democrats 2 to 1, any political loyalties that Mrs. Bush inspired among women were clearly being put in check today. 
 "I think Barbara is really going to help President Bush in the polls," said Kay Smith, a mother of five who manages the Jewelry Box on the Town Green. "But he's going to have to do a lot more to show me that he's going to get our country back to where it should be, helping the homeless, people with AIDS, our poor, our economy."
 
Looking at Other Issues
 It was a refrain repeated again and again by women in this upscale Northeastern regional center that boomed in the 1980's with an influx of corporate offices. And the refrain transcended boundaries of race, class, family situation -- even political affiliations.
The women of Morris County, interviewed on park benches and offices, street corners and shops here, said that when the speeches ended they had been left wondering why Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Quayle were not talking more about subjects like abortion rights, health care and legislation to provide leaves for workers for family health needs, issues that women often have cited as influencing their votes.
As she sat on a bench on the Green, surrounding by children with dripping ice-cream cones, Catherine Cleffi, a 36-year-old part-time nurse, reflected on Mrs. Bush's speech. While it may have been short on political substance, she said, it was long on appeal.
"I didn't expect to hear much from her about heavy issues," said Mrs. Cleffi, who added that she was not sure how she would vote in November. "But I liked that she talked about the importance of taking care of children, about being there for them while they are growing up. She makes the title of homemaker have a little more respect."
 
Taking It Out on the TV
 Not everyone was so generous.
As Karen Holliday, an I.B.M. consultant, stood waiting for her lunch date near the Green, she looked up from her newspaper with little more than disdain when asked her response to the convention speeches.
"I like Barbara and I expected more of her," she said. "Marilyn's speech? That was even worse."
Ms. Holliday said she watched the speeches at home alone, and, annoyed at Mrs. Quayle's descriptions of liberals, had hurled the remote control at the television set.
"She reminds me of June Cleaver," Ms. Holliday growled. "I don't buy her at all. The whole convention should have been about educating Americans and giving us information about the issues."
Jacqueline M. Boyle, a 36-year-old district manager of Dress Barn, a women's clothing store, was equally vitriolic. "I don't think the Republicans are really for women," she said.
"It's fine and great to say all those things," Ms. Boyle said, referring to remarks about staying home with children and devotion to their husband's careers. "But the reality is that most women have to work."
 
Seeing a Need for Help
 Other women were more ambivalent.
Mary A. Cullen, an 82-year-old longtime Republican, tipped her hand from side to side to describe her feelings about the speeches and about President Bush. "I admire Mrs. Bush," she said. "But I don't like some of the things he's done."
Six years ago when she was newly widowed, Mrs. Cullen said, she was forced for financial reasons to sell her home and move into public housing, a hard move for a woman who had worked all of her life to help send her five children to college. Since then, she said, she had seen many families in need of improved social services.
"We need a lot of help right now in the U.S.," she said.
Maria H. Acevedo, a 25-year-old native of Colombia, said she watched the convention with her family, though she is not yet a citizen and cannot vote. She said she had not watched Mrs. Quayle's speech, but had liked Mrs. Bush's remarks with one caveat. She wanted to hear "more specifics" about what kind of "family values" Mrs. Bush talked about.
"I think that the family is the heart of the society and that the mother is the heart of the family," Miss Acevedo, a legal secretary, said. "And I think women should be more preoccupied with what is happening in the homes.
"I feel the same way about Mr. Bush: he should pay more attention to what is happening at home."

HEADLINE: In Downtown Syracuse, the Streets Get Emptier;
The Closing of the Last Department Store Causes the City to Try to Redefine Its Core

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Some people say that Syracuse's proud old downtown began to die when Interstate 81 was built in the 1960's. Others think the suburban malls did it, each more grandiose than the one before, sucking stores and people from the city like so many vampires. Whatever the cause, Doris Smith now finds that her modest office building in the heart of downtown is half-empty and eerily quiet.
"It is very sad and very depressing," said Mrs. Smith, a receptionist for an advertising agency where the ground floor was vacated by yet another failed store just two weeks ago. "It's hard to bring any visitors into this city, because it doesn't look very good anymore." 
 On Monday, the last of Syracuse's big downtown department stores, Addis & Dey's, announced that it would shut for good on Saturday, saying it was no longer profitable to operate in a place where few people shop. With city leaders pouring money into downtown in an effort to build it up again, the closing of the store, which began as Dey Brothers more than 100 years ago, was particularly poorly timed.
 
A Downtown Era Ends
 However much the city is trying, its residents are keenly aware of the symbolism in the decision by Addis & Dey, once one of a half dozen large department stores downtown.
"With this store leaving it's going to make Syracuse dead, dead, dead," said Deborah Young, 29 years old, hunting for bargains at the store. "It's going to create a very big empty space here."
Syracuse's experience mirrors that of scores of small cities and big towns across the Northeast. Already irrevocably altered by the decades-long exodus of the population to the suburbs, downtowns everywhere have been doubly hit by the lingering recession, which has brought layoffs and devastated all vestiges of the traditional retail center of town.
In Newark, residents already demoralized by their dwindling downtown had more bad news earlier this year, when Macy's, the last holdout department store, closed. Other cities been able to put off what may be inevitable: faced with the shutdown of its own Macy's, New Haven recently managed to keep it open with a $12 million package of city and state grants to improve a parking garage, a tax freeze and reduced electricity rates.
"We've been affected by the same things that all midsize towns have been," said Joe C. Mareane, Syracuse's director of development. "The era of the giant department store is over in downtown."
In Syracuse, the seat of the Onondaga County government and a major banking and insurance center in upstate New York, between 3,000 and 4,000 downtown jobs -- about 10 to 15 percent of the work force -- have been lost since 1988, said Steven E. Shulman, vice president and project director of the Galleries of Syracuse, an office and retail center right next to Addis & Dey's.
That affects everything that used to make downtown prosperous: restaurants where the workers ate, stores where they shopped and office buildings where they worked. In a two-block radius in the core of downtown, some 400,000 square feet of space is vacant, said Thomas H. Greenwood, president of Greenwood Commercial-Investment Realtors in Syracuse. No new use has been planned for the Addis & Dey building either.
 
Vacancies at Main and Main
 To the 164,000 residents of Syracuse -- many of them elderly people and minorities left behind when others moved to the suburbs -- that means that from the heart of their community on South Salina and Jefferson, known locally as Main and Main, streets stretching out in any direction are now thick with "for rent" signs.
As the vacancies have made downtown more depressing, people have naturally been drawn to the dozen or so malls and shopping centers on Syracuse's outskirts. The latest and most spectacular of these is the Carousel Center, featuring more than 170 stores, its own post office, a glass-domed top, and an indoor carousel.
So glamorous is the mall that 30-year-old Estelle Acocella of Syracuse's north side recently took her out-of-town cousins there, instead of downtown. "There's no parking and no variety of stores downtown," she said, a bit sheepishly, holding a newly purchased satchel and watching her cousins and their children window-shopping nearby. "I might go downtown sometimes, but I wouldn't get out of the car to shop."
Addis & Dey already has several stores in malls, but its departure from downtown was a shock to the city, which had laid out more than $2.3 million to buy the building that houses the store, and was charging no rent, in an effort to get the store to stay.
The city is also in the midst of a $10 million campaign to widen sidewalks, plant hundreds of trees and replace the grim urban lights with more friendly street lamps. The city is also building a $96 million convention center and renovating a number of buildings downtown, all in the hopes of attracting businesses and people back to the area.
Syracuse, its leaders say, is coming around to the notion that the way to salvage downtown is not by building more retail giants, but by emphasizing other things -- museums and cultural attractions, for instance, or neighborhoods like Armory Square, a refurbished historic district of tony shops and restaurants that is flourishing just blocks from Salina Street.
 
City Officials Rethink
 Dennis J. Connors, executive director of the Onondaga Historical Association, said the city was just beginning -- a bit late, perhaps -- to figure out what it wanted to do with the downtown. Several years ago, for instance, the city pinned some hopes on the Galleries, a downtown mini-mall with soaring glass architecture and a mix of stores, offices and the county library. But the Galleries could hardly compete with the suburban mega-malls, and today, many of the stores are vacant.
"The city leaders are only beginning to recognize the fact that you can't beat the malls at their own game, that you must redefine downtown to make it unique," Mr. Connors said.
But it remains to be seen whether the new attractions, including a hands-on science museum and the convention center, will actually draw people back downtown. At Addis & Dey's this week, shoppers mourned the demise of a once-great store and said they could only worry about the future.
"They're trying to revitalize Syracuse by making the sidewalks wider, but it's really sad -- there's nothing left here now," said Dorothy Carpenter, 73, who remembers Dey Brothers from its glory days in the 1950's.
And, perched at her ultra-quiet desk down the street, in a building that has seen company after company move away or close, Mrs. Smith of the advertising firm said that above all, it made her gloomy. "I've always worked here, and I wouldn't want to work anywhere else," she said. "But it used to be fun, and now it's so depressing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: First came the suburbs, then the interstates, and, finally, the shopping malls. The seemingly inevitable has taken hold of Syracuse and left expanses of its downtown empty of businesses and its streets nearly deserted; The crowds have gone to the malls surrounding Syracuse, the newest and most spectacular of which is Carousel Center, which features 170 stores, its own post office and parking space to accommodate all visitors. HEADLINE: Olympia Proposes Debt Delay

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Three months after Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the world's biggest property manager, filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada, it is asking its biggest creditors to back a five-year moratorium on debt payments to allow the company to stay in business. The battle has been uphill all the way.
Under a proposal Olympia says it will file in a bankruptcy court here on Friday, bank lenders, bondholders and holders of short-term Olympia i.o.u.'s are being asked to postpone the payments on Canadian debts totaling $8.6 billion in return for various forms of equity. 
 The Reichmann brothers of Toronto, Olympia's publicity-shunning owners, disclosed today that they would offer to turn over 51 percent of their privately owned company to creditors, if the plan was accepted -- and up to 80 percent at the end of five years.
 
Trying to Avoid Breakup
 "We believe that is a far better outlook for all concerned than the immediate bust-up of the company," said Olympia's chief debt negotiator, Robert S. Miller Jr., who is on leave from the New York investment banking firm of James D. Wolfensohn Inc.
Justice Robert Blair of the Ontario Court's General Division set the Friday deadline after the company was unable to meet an earlier target of July 13. The company and its creditors spend the first seven weeks since court protection was granted on May 14 bickering over who would pay expenses of the restructuring effort, including millions of dollars a month of fees to armies of lawyers and advisers. In three months the legal bill has come to more than $10 million.
To help meet the costs, the Reichmann family, which built the real estate empire from a small tile-importing business in Toronto in the mid-1950's, have sold their Gulfstream executive jet to American Barrick Ltd. for $6.5 million and put up for sale a mansion in Hampstead Heath, London, valued at $4 million. The family's homes in the Bathurst Street area of north central Toronto are not for sale.
The family hopes to keep the company as an operating entity that once had a balance sheet brimming with billions of dollars. The company now has no net worth, despite $22 billion of premier real estate assets in Canada, the United States and Britain.
According to its latest financial statements, huge write-offs last year left Olympia $134 million (Canadian) in the red on Jan. 31, compared with a net worth of $2 billion a year earlier.
And even that data did not include any markdown of the value of the bankrupt Canary Wharf office building project in London, the company's flagship development, on which it spent about $3 billion. The project is now in danger of outright liquidation.
 
Maneuvering by Creditors
 Secured creditors in Canada are asking whether they would not be better off taking over the buildings themselves, getting new managers and either selling into the market or just holding on and hoping for appreciation. Some of Canada's largest banks, which together are owed about $3 billion, have already asked Judge Blair to remove the buildings that collateralize their loans from the bankruptcy proceedings -- an action that could hasten disintegration of the Canadian empire.
The banks argue that since these structures, which include some of the most prestigious business locations in downtown Toronto, enjoy a positive cash flow, unlike the Reichmann assets as a whole, there is no need for them to be part of a restructuring. The judge has said he will hear arguments on these motions after Olympia files its plan. The company's court protection will be in effect until Oct. 21.
"It's an incredible challenge to try to get the approval of all the creditors," said Harry Rannala, real estate analyst at McLean McCarthy, Inc., an investment house controlled by the Deutsche Bank of Germany. "Just one dissenting voice throws up a major roadblock."
John Ing, president of Maison Placements Inc., another investment house, added, "There would still have to be an awful lot of arm-twisting to get an agreement."
Oddly, analysts note, the decline in commercial real estate values, which contributed to the collapse of the Olympia empire, might just work in Olympia's favor in trying to cobble an agreement.
With the weak economy and a glut of office space, some analysts think the market in Canadian office property has yet to hit bottom. So if good values cannot be obtained by foreclosing and then liquidating buildings, it could be to everyone's advantage to sit tight and keep the portfolio together under Olympia's management.
"I think if you can keep priorities of creditors alive, then it makes more sense to hold the company together," said one Toronto property analyst who spoke only on condition of anonymity. "Olympia's real estate management abilities are good. Since the banks aren't interested in managing the properties themselves and hardly want to sell into this market, they'd have to contract the business out anyway. So why not just hold on and wait for the recovery."
His comments echoed an argument that Olympia officials themselves are making, noting that the Reichmanns' expertise as property managers, while intangible, still has a value that should not be underestimated.
Olympia's president, Gerald Greenwald, said a survey in June by an independent market research firm for the company found that the "responses reflected overwhelming support for the value of retaining Olympia & York's ownership and management roles.".
Apart from keeping the Canadian properties intact, a main objective of the family, led by its chief strategist, Paul Reichmann, has been to salvage some of the stake in Canary Wharf, which was placed under court administration in Britain in May after Olympia ran out of construction funds. It is now controlled by court-appointed administrators and a group of 11 lenders.
Mr. Reichmann recently approached a group of investors, led by Lewis Ranieri, former Salomon Brothers vice chairman and a longtime Reichmann family adviser; Lawrence Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation of New York, and Sanford Weill, chairman of the Primerica Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., and persuaded them to make a proposal, which if accepted could allow Olympia to stay as manager.
Negotiations are under way, but the prospects of a deal are not rated highly. Some London commentators predict the area will probably never become the bustling part of the metropolis envisaged when plans for the project were being laid in the middle to late 1980's.
Another objective of Paul Reichmann has been to maintain the segregation of Olympia's American properties. The hope is to quietly restructure their debts, while avoiding the kind of bankruptcy court protection Olympia was forced to seek in Canada.
The company has stressed that its United States properties are healthier and it has support of the banks there.
But Olympia faces heavy interest rate payments on Jan. 1 that may be difficult to meet. Even more worrisome is a threat of court action in New York made earlier this month by an international banking syndicate led by J. P. Morgan & Company and co-led by the Bank of Montreal.
Specifically the syndicate is seeking receipts from six office towers in New York and Los Angeles, which were pledged as collateral for a $160 million (United States) loan made to Olympia in 1991.
Olympia and the syndicate have negotiated for months to try to resolve a dispute. The six buildings are both towers of the World Financial Center, 59 Maiden Lane in New York, 245 Park Avenue, New York, 400 South Hope Street, Los Angeles, and 11601 Wilshire Boulevard, Los Angeles.
Should the syndicate make good its threat, Olympia could be pushed closer to bankruptcy proceedings in the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Retreat in Price

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury bond and note prices fell slightly yesterday in thin trading as investors waited to see what economic proposal President Bush would make in his acceptance speech and whether the rally in the market would resume soon.
"All eyes are on Texas," said John Costas, managing director of government trading at the First Boston Corporation. 
 "The uncertainity is everywhere and that is why the market is going nowhere," added Peter McTeague, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data, a research firm in Boston.
But today after they know what Mr. Bush promised at the Republican National Convention, investors and traders will be able to return their focus to the slow-growing economy and declining inflation -- the two forces that have driven yields on the long bond to the lowest level in five and a half years.
And the market's direction today is what traders and investors will be watching.
"If he does not pull a rabbit out of the hat, the initial trading will lower prices," Mr. McTeague said, referring to the reception for Mr. Bush's acceptance speech.
But he said he expected investors and traders to begin buying Treasury securities again as long as there was no startling bad news and as long as the economic data affirmed that inflation was declining and the economy was still sluggish.
 
Impact of Uncertainty
 And if there is some leftover political uncertainty or anxiety, that will push investors to concentrate their buying in shorter maturities, like three-year and five-year notes, which are less risky because their prices will not fall as much as 30-year bonds if there is some sudden bad news.
In late trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at a price of 99 5/32 , down 3/32 to yield 7.32 percent, compared with 7.31 percent Wednesday.
Economic data released yesterday did nothing to alter the picture of a weak economy. The 71,000 jump in initial unemployment claims to 474,000 was expected because of the temporary closing of plants by the General Motors Corporation and did not signal any worsening trend.
But the decline in the dollar to record lows against the German mark is not helping. Mr. Costas of First Boston said that analysts feel that the decline could make it less likely that the Federal Reserve will ease short-term interest rates in the next month. A cut in short-term rates by the Fed would further weaken the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities less attractive to foreign investors.
In the auction of $14.3 billion of one-year Treasury bills yesterday, the average discount rate was 3.28 percent, the lowest rate since April 10, 1963. But the average was one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, higher than the one-year auction in July.
 
More Squeezes
 Some traders said yesterday that they expect the demand for five-year Treasury notes, which has already caused "squeeze" conditions this week, to continue and possibly create the same kind of bind for some dealers and investors after the new five-year note is auctioned next week.
But that would not be unusual because traders said that there has been a squeeze in several of the recent five-year notes, which are auctioned monthly.
A "squeeze" occurs when there is such a shortage of a desired security, or such a high demand, that the price of that security or the cost of borrowing it is pushed extraordinarily high. A squeeze is not illegal, however, unless it is created by a manipulation of the market. Traders said they see no such manipulation in the current case. But the Government is investigating the possibility of illegal squeezes in conneciton with the Salomon Brothers trading scandal last year.
 
High Cost Securities
 The current 5.5 percent note due in July 1997 was in such demand this week that the traders said some investors or dealers were being forced to borrow the securities at a very high cost.
In the market for borrowing securities, an investor offers to make a loan in exchange for the securities he wants. As the demand for the security increases, the interest rate on the loan declines.
The loss for the investor borrowing the securities is the difference between what could be made by lending the money at current overnight rates, around 3.25 percent a year, and the low rate that must be offered to borrow the five-year notes. Well, last week this rate hit zero several times, several traders said.
"This is not the end; I expect similar type results," said one government trader of the new five-year note. "It is likely it will enyoy a better reception than the supply can handle."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Clinton Needles Bush, Trying to Quiet His Thunder

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton returned to the campaign trail today to restake his claim to the votes of the disenchanted Democrats who went Republican in the 1980's.
"I ran hard to the Reagan Democrats in the primary," the Democratic Presidential nominee said. "And I intend to do it in the general election Well, we want them back." 
 By returning to the road in appearances here and in Battle Creek, Mich. on the day President Bush delivered a politically crucial acceptance speech at the Republican convention in Houston, Mr. Clinton sought to steal back some of the thunder the Republicans had made off with this week.
"What does my opponent say?" the Arkansas Governor asked a noontime lunch crowd in Battle Creek. "He says Bill Clinton's going to cost a million jobs. Let me tell you something. He's already cost a million jobs with defense cuts. Because he didn't reinvest the money in the American economy and putting the American people back to work."
 
Backed by Police Group
 Mr. Clinton also received the endorsement of the National Association of Police Officers, a 135,000-member organization which did not endorse a Presidential candidiate in 1988. In what has become a traditional campaign photo setting, Mr. Clinton posed for the announcement in front of a phalanx of blue-uniformed police.
Today's trip was another part of a Clinton strategy to keep the nominee in the political mix, in part to offset the favorable public-opinion bounce Mr. Bush was expected to take with him as he left the convention and entered what he has called "campaign mode."
In remarks to reporters today, Mr. Clinton seized on Labor Secretary Lynn Martin's defense of the Bush Administration, in which she said Wednesday that Americans were certainly better off than they were four years ago because the cold war had been won.
"I'm glad she asked that question," Mr. Clinton said. "That's what they said the test is. If they want to stay with the test that Ronald Reagan and George Bush imposed in 1980 -- Are you better off today than you were four years ago? -- then they have to lose the election. Because America is not better off."
 
'It's a Frame-Up'
 Mr. Clinton's cause was aided today as he accepted the backing of the police group from its president, Robert Scully. "In the last two days, some folks down in Houston sent out an all-points bulletin for a pair of lunatics who they say are going to ruin our country," Mr. Scully said. "Well, let me tell you something. We have thought long and hard about Bill Clinton and Al Gore. And we just don't see the resemblance. It's a frame-up, and a bad one at that."
Mr. Scully's remarks could have been written at the campaign headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., so perfect were his words for the message the campaign was trying to send today. Mr. Scully spoke of them as "the new kinds of Democrats" and denounced President Bush for not supporting gun-control legislation.
"George Bush's promises haven't stopped any murders, but getting handguns out of the hands of criminals will," he said.
Mr. Clinton has promised to support a waiting period for handgun sales and increase the number of police officers by 100,000.
 
Inconsistency Is Seen
 Mr. Clinton, speaking to a small crowd at the airport here, said the issue of crime control was "an issue like so many others, where this Administration says one thing and does another."
"They're down there in Houston talking about family values, and yet their No. 1 priority in the first two days of the convention were to attack my wife and my family," he said. "Near as I can tell, it didn't do them much good."
But Mr. Clinton said he expected Mr. Bush to live up to expectations and deliver "the speech of his life" in accepting the Republican nomination.
"But he gave the speech of his life four years ago when they said he had to give it," Mr. Clinton said. "And he gave the speech of his life four years ago in which he promised 15 million new jobs, no new taxes, an environmental Presidency, an education Presidency. It was a wonderful speech, but now we no longer have to read his lips. We can read his record."

HEADLINE: William Taylor of F.D.I.C. Dead at 53

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
William Taylor, one of the nation's senior banking regulators, died this morning at Fairfax Hospital in Fairfax, Va. He was 53 years old.
Mr. Taylor, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation since October, died of complications after undergoing surgery for colon blockage on Aug. 13, a spokesman for the agency said. The spokesman, Alan Whitney, said Mr. Taylor had developed pneumonia over the weekend and had had a heart attack this morning. 
 Mr. Taylor headed the F.D.I.C. at a pivotal point in the nation's banking crisis. A career regulator, he earned the high regard of Republicans in the White House and Democrats in Congress at a time when regulation had become increasingly partisan.
 
Praised as Man of Integrity
 "He was an extraordinary person -- a well-respected and extremely capable public servant of unquestioned integrity," said Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who was a close friend.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, said Mr. Taylor's death "is a loss to the nation."
"Of all the regulators I have known during nearly 31 years on the committee," Mr. Gonzalez said, "Bill Taylor stands out pre-eminently as the man who stood up to the most powerful political and financial forces in our country, never compromising his integrity."
Mr. Taylor was among the most seasoned financial regulators in Washington. He was the American representative in London last year coordinating the worldwide seizure of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. A few months before that, he was the Federal Reserve's top man for the rescue of the Bank of New England. And in the mid-1980's he was involved in supervising banking crises in Ohio and Maryland.
When Mr. Taylor was sworn in as the F.D.I.C.'s 15th chairman on Oct. 25, to replace L. William Seidman, he took over the leadership of an agency that had been battered by hundreds of bank failures and run out of money to protect depositors at weak and insolvent banks. The agency was facing the prospect of a wave of bank failures that many experts said had threatened the collapse of the financial system and could be averted only through a huge infusion of taxpayer money.
 
Pressure on Bank Regulators
 Further complicating the agency's job was the emergence of a new climate of tighter lending, prompting the Bush Administration to chastise regulators and push them hard to ease lending restrictions and encourage banks toward making more loans.
In the last few months, he faced the skepticism of members of Congress who accused his agency of delaying the seizure of scores of institutions until after Election Day and the criticism of bankers who insisted that the worst was over and there was no reason to increase the insurance premiums they paid, eating into their profits.
Mr. Taylor's approach to bank regulation was to chart a middle course. In the first days of his tenure, he pushed Congress hard and quickly received a large taxpayer loan of more than $70 billion to bail out the Bank Insurance Fund. Later, he led the agency to increase the contributions paid by banks into the insurance fund. That effort came in the face of an intensive lobbying effort by the banks and the Bush Administration to keep the premiums from rising.
Often self-depreciating and dry in his humor, he confided in May on the eve of the vote on bank premiums that he had "felt enormous pressure everywhere" and that he had told his wife that after the job was done he might be pumping gasoline.
"That's self-service for you," he said.
On other issues, Mr. Taylor signaled his willingness to work with the White House. He took steps to make it easier for banks to challenge those bank examinations that were considered too tough and discouraged lending. He kept a file in his desk of complaints and frequently told officials in the field offices that the agency would not tolerate regulators who were unfairly hard on the banks.
 
Proposal for 'Bank Hospitals'
 One of his highest and most controversial priorities was trying to resolve the problems of ailing banks without liquidating them. He spoke frequently of "bank hospitals" in which a staff of bankers would take over weak institutions on behalf of the Government and nurse them back to health before they were sold.
And, in a few instances, he took the approach of bailing out institutions that some argued would have been less expensive to just sell or close.
His decision to invest in Crossland Savings at a cost of $1.2 billion, rather than sell it or close it, encountered significant criticism. He reached the decision after walking through Brooklyn and concluding that closing the institution, New York's largest savings bank, could have a devastating impact on the local economy.
In recent weeks, facing pressure from the industry, he refused to revise the agency's estimates of the possible Government costs of rescuing the banking industry, even though many banks around the nation had posted significant profits and benefited enormously from declining interest rates.
He arrived at the F.D.I.C. after serving as head of banking supervision at the Federal Reserve Board, where he was Mr. Greenspan's right-hand man. Despite his added responsibilities and increased stature, he was paid $35,000 less in his new post than his $150,000 salary at the Federal Reserve.
A native of Chicago, Mr. Taylor joined the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago as a bank examiner in 1961 after graduating from Cornell College in Mount Vernon, Iowa. In 1968 he joined Chicago's Upper Avenue Bank as vice president in charge of lending. In 1972 he became manager of the Chicago office of James W. Rouse & Company, a real estate development and mortgage banking firm, and returned to the Federal Reserve in 1976.
Mr. Taylor's is survived by his wife, Sharon; two daughters, Claire and Emily, and a son, William Taylor 3d, who is a sophomore at North Carolina State University.

HEADLINE: Charles L. Austin, 89, Steel Company Leader

 BODY:
Charles Lee Austin, former president and vice chairman of the old Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, died Wednesday at the Mayflower Place nursing home in West Yarmouth, Mass. He was 89 years old.
Mr. Austin, a native of Port Chester, N.Y., graduated from Princeton University in 1924 and was an executive at several companies before joining J. & L. as treasurer and a director in 1942. 
 He became executive vice president of the steelmaker, then one of the country's largest, in 1948 and was elected president four years later. Within weeks, the company and the rest of the steel industry underwent one of its worst crises, in a wage-price dispute with its labor force and the Government.
President Harry S. Truman, citing military requirements for steel, ordered the seizure of the industry in early May. The Supreme Court voided the order in June, and 600,000 steelworkers went on strike. A settlement on wage and price increases was not reached until July.
Mr. Austin became vice chairman of J. & L. in 1956 and retired the next year. He then served for three years as a steel consultant to the World Bank.
J. & L. combined with the Republic Steel Corporation in 1984 to form the LTV Steel Company of Cleveland, part of the LTV Corporation of Dallas.
Mr. Austin is survived by his wife of nearly 64 years, the former Louise Bradley Wilson; two sons, Charles Lee Austin Jr. of Manhattan and John Bradbury Austin of Evanston, Ill., and one granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Lindsley F. Kimball, 97, Is Dead; Founded New York Blood Center

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Lindsley F. Kimball, a longtime Rockefeller family associate who organized the New York Blood Center and also headed the U.S.O. and National Urban League, died on Sunday at his home in Newtown, Pa. He was 97 years old.
He died of an intestinal hemorrhage, a family spokeswoman said. 
 Mr. Kimball led the founding of the blood center, the nation's largest, in the early 1960's. The center ended the chaos in the region's blood supply that sometimes resulted in tainted blood donations and shortages that delayed operations and even forced emergency transfusions with wrong blood types.
The new centralized system serves metropolitan New York and New Jersey and distributes a tenth of the nation's blood bank supply. Its research center, named for Dr. Kimball, identified and isolated hepatitis B virus and helped develop a hepatitis B vaccine.
The blood center was only one of many charitable and social service agencies to which Dr. Kimball applied his organizational skills until his retirement in 1979.
 
A Presidential Medal
 In World War II and the Korean War, he served as president of the United Service Organizations, the coalition of groups assisting American military men and women. His efforts won a presidential medal from Harry S. Truman.
For several years he served as president of the National Urban League, where he recruited Whitney Young as executive director.
Dr. Kimball also was the national fund-raising chairman for the United Negro College Fund for several years and the vice president of the General Education Board, an organization supporting higher education.
He conducted a study that led to the formation of the Greater New York branch of the American Red Cross in a merger of its borough units and also helped create the national Council on Foundations.
His positions with the Rockefeller family included executive vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, trustee and treasurer of Rockefeller University, associate of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and aide to John D. Rockefeller Jr.
 
A Wartime Invention
 Mr. Kimball was born in Brooklyn. He graduated from Columbia University in 1917.
In World War I, he served four years in the United States Navy. There he invented a mathematical device to adjust the aim of turret guns for the listing of a ship. He became the commanding officer of a submarine-chasing squadron and reached the rank of lieutenant.
After the war Mr. Kimball worked four years in the managerial offices of the Underwood Typewriter Company and studied accounting.
His career in nonprofit work began as a young Sunday school superintendent at St. Paul's Congregational Church in Brooklyn. Under his direction, enrollment multiplied from fewer than 100 to more than 500. His church work continued for decades. In Manhasset, L.I., where he lived much of his life, he was founding member of the Congregational Church and supervised its school as its rolls grew to more than 1,000.
His next cause was the Boy Scouts of America. He founded a troop in Brooklyn and eventually left his job at Underwood to become the full-time chief executive of the Brooklyn Council, the nation's largest. His work earned high ratings and led to regional and national scouting posts.
While with the Boy Scouts, Mr. Kimball resumed his studies and earned a doctorate in economics and sociology from New York University in 1930.
In 1938 he became a top officer in the new Greater New York Fund, which later merged with United Way. His work there with corporate executives caught the attention of Mr. Rockefeller, who recruited him to work on special projects.
Surviving are his wife of nearly 66 years, the former Maude Kouwenhoven; two sons, Richard T. of Wyomissing, Pa., and Dean F. of Westford, Mass.; 12 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Took Biggest Lep Since '82

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON Aug. 20 (AP)

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits took its largest jump in more than 10 years early this month as a result of a two-week shutdown of General Motors operations, the Labor Department said today.
Excluding the G.M. factor, first-time applications for unemployment insurance would have been little changed, said Paul Lally, an economist with R. H. Wrightson & Associates in New York. 
 "No real improvement," he said, "but no real deterioration either."
"We're still locked into a slow-growth employment path," agreed Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. "It could be worse, but it should be better."
The Labor Department said the number of new claims surged by 71,000, to 474,000, in the week ended Aug. 8, reflecting the "large number of claims in the state of Michigan resulting from the temporary shutdown of General Motors during the final two weeks of July."
 
Biggest Rise Since '82
 It was the largest one-week increase since the 83,000 in the week ended Jan. 23, 1982, during the previous recession. And it raised the total to the highest level since 479,000 applications were filed in the week ended Dec. 7, 1991.
Claims had been hovering in the low-400,000's since spring, dropping to 400,000 for the week ended July 18. That had been the smallest number since Oct. 6, 1990, when 382,000 people made their first trips to the unemployment office.
The G.M. shutdown was first reflected in the week ended July 25, when claims surged by 69,000, to 469,000, as auto workers outside Michigan sought benefits. But applications in Michigan, which had switched to a mail-in filing system, were not reported until today.
Mr. Lally said he believes claims may drop below 400,000 this fall, although the labor market probably will not show any real improvement until the fourth quarter or early next year.
The new claims pushed the four-week moving average to 436,500, the highest since 438,000 for the period ended April 4.
The number of new claims rose by 74,221 in Michigan alone.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Charles Hagen

 BODY:

Still a Good Deal
Photography remains a relatively bright spot in the otherwise dismal art market of the last two years, with a number of photography dealers reporting that sales have been holding steady, or even rising. A major reason for this appears to be the widespread sense among both dealers and collectors that photographs, which are still relatively inexpensive compared with works in other media, are underpriced as well.
Moreover, photography didn't experience the same frantic rise in prices that hit much of the rest of the market during the 1980's, and so did not have as far to fall when boom turned to bust. 
Laurence Miller, a New York photography dealer, points to the increased number of painting galleries that include photography among their offerings. "That's where a lot of the action is," he says.
Another reason for photography's continued success in the marketplace is a recent series of large purchases by institutions, both in the United States and abroad. "There's been a big growth in museum acquisitions internationally," Mr. Miller says.
Peter MacGill, of the Pace/MacGill Gallery in Manhattan, agrees: "The top artists translate everywhere."
 
Bulk Sales to Europe
 As evidence for this new trend, Mr. MacGill points to a recent sale, organized by his gallery, to the Maison Europeene de la Photographie, a new museum in Paris devoted to recent photography. Included in the sale were 40 prints by Irving Penn and a set of prints by Robert Frank from his classic book "The Americans." Mr. MacGill also cites recent purchases of large groups of works by various artists, including Emmet Gowin, Josef Koudelka and Henri Cartier-Bresson, as well as Mr. Penn and Mr. Frank, by a private foundation in Spain. The work is slated to be donated to the Valencia Institute of Modern Art.
It's not just European museums that are buying photographs in bulk. For several years, Sarah Greenough, curator at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, has been purchasing large numbers of photographs by a few major figures, among them Harry Callahan, Walker Evans and Mr. Frank. And in the spring the Art Institute of Chicago acquired 100 prints by Joel Sternfeld as the first entry in what Colin Westerbeck Jr., assistant curator in the department of photography, describes as a new "archive of work by prominent contemporary color photographers."
 
Matching Sets
 But because color photographs are notoriously susceptible to fading, there's a twist to the story: the acquisition actually consists of two matching sets of 50 prints each, produced especially by Mr. Sternfeld for the occasion. One set, Mr. Westerbeck explains, will be used for exhibitions and day-to-day research, while the other will be kept in the institute's cold-storage facilities, where the risk of their fading will be greatly diminished. These prints will be taken out only to be examined by selected scholars.
"It's not so meaningful now," Mr. Westerbeck concedes, "but in five years, or 10 years, someone who wanted to see a mint set of the work could look at the prints" that had been kept in the freezer.
Mr. Sternfeld's pictures, some of which are on view at the Art Institute through Oct. 11, are a promised gift from Richard Press, a member of the institute's photography committee, and an anonymous partner. Mr. Press is an investment consultant with the Chicago financial firm of Stein, Roe & Farnham.
 
Down, but Not Drastic
 Auction prices in a number of sectors of the art market have suffered in the current economic downturn. But photography has been a relatively steady performer. Beth Gates-Warren, head of photography for Sotheby's in New York, reports the house's April auction of photographs went "reasonably well," with a total of $1.5 million realized and 70 percent of the offered lots sold. This is down from the $2.3 million brought in during Sotheby's photography sale in October 1990. By comparison, the total achieved in Sotheby's auctions of contemporary art fell from $82 million in spring 1990 to $19.4 million last spring.
At Christie's in New York, Rick Wester, who took over as head of the photography department on June 1, reports similar results. "It wasn't gangbusters," he says of Christie's April photography sale, but he describes the results, with a total of $1.3 million and 76 percent of the lots sold, as "pretty encouraging."
Both Ms. Gates-Warren and Mr. Wester see the market sorting itself out, with prices for established artists continuing to rise. "I don't think prices for major photographers have suffered," Ms. Gates-Warren says. "But prices for lesser lights have fallen off a bit. Buyers are not quite as curious right now."
"Good prints by good photographers always sell well," Mr. Wester says.
The October session is Mr. Wester's first auction in his new job. The 35-year-old Mr. Wester was a private dealer in New York the last 10 years, and an assistant at the Light Gallery there before that. He takes over from Claudia Gropper, who left Christie's after the October 1991 sale. Monika Half, who organized last spring's sale for the house, is staying on as a senior specialist.
Mr. Wester is particularly enthusiastic about a complete edition of Edward S. Curtis's "North American Indian," which will be offered on Oct. 13. Published between 1907 and 1930, the set is made up of 20 text volumes and 20 portfolios and includes 2,257 large photogravures printed on handmade etching paper. Curtis's pictures of American Indian life have been widely criticized as overly romantic and often staged, but over the years they have also attracted an enthusiastic audience. Christie's estimates that the set, one of fewer than 100 printed on this kind of paper, will sell for $150,000 to $200,000.
 
Mexican Gems
 Ms. Gates-Warren, too, is preparing for her next photography sale, to be held at Sotheby's on Oct. 15 and 16. The offerings include two prints by Tina Modotti, the Italian-born photographer who worked in Mexico in the 1920's before taking up a career as a Communist revolutionary. Two years ago, the photo world was set atwitter when a print by Modotti was bought by Susie Tompkins, the owner of the Esprit Sportswear Company, for the record price of $165,000, including a 10 percent buyer's premium. Ms. Gates-Warren estimates that each of the Modottis being offered this fall will bring a more modest $25,000 to $35,000. The gem of Sotheby's sale is another picture made in Mexico in the same period but this time by Edward Weston, who was Modotti's lover and mentor. The presale estimate for the 1929 picture, which Weston referred to as a "pear-shaped nude," is $75,000 to $100,000.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Call Your Broker: Stocks Outperformed N.F.L. Teams

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Attorneys for eight players suing the National Football League on antitrust grounds said today that some financial conclusions of the league's economist were incomplete.
A University of Iowa professor, George Daly, testified on Wednesday and earlier today that N.F.L. owners earned less money by buying football teams than they would have in other industries in the 1980's. 
 Jeffrey Kessler, an attorney for the players, stressed that Daly's conclusions did not include the money owners made in salary and operating profit on their teams.
Taking the Philadelphia Eagles as a case in point, Daly had testified that the rate of return for the owner, Norman Braman, was slightly more than 9 percent on his $67.5 million purchase in 1985, if the franchise was worth $125 million today.
The same $67.5 million invested in a mutual fund specializing in the Standard and Poor's 500 index would have returned 18.1 percent, or almost twice as much, Daly testified.
"What is not included in that number is all of the profits on the books of the Philadelphia Eagles, all of the profits he has taken out of the team in the seven and a half years he has owned the team," Kessler said in his cross-examination of Daly.
 
Eagles Turned Profits
 The Eagles were one of the N.F.L.'s most profitable teams in the late 1980's, earning a reported $34.3 million from 1985 to 1989. In addition, Braman paid himself a $7.5 million salary in 1990.
The Standard and Poor's 500 index Daly used to compare rates of return included dividends, while the N.F.L. values did not, Kessler said.
Daly said the rate of return to owners of professional football teams based on the value of their franchises rose 16 percent from 1980-89. That rate is lower than the returns of other industries, including broadcasting, entertainment, foods and drugs, Daly said.
 
Disagrees With Davis
 Kessler said there were instances in the broadcasting industry where cable companies earn monopoly profits much like the N.F.L. The league is arguing that it does not enjoy the benefits of a monopoly.
Daly said even though there were 28 bidders for Phoenix safety Tim McDonald, the interest in the player did not mean that he would receive a higher salary than he got from the Cardinals.
Daly also disagreed with Al Davis, the Los Angeles Raiders' managing general partner, who said in his deposition that dynasties were good for professional football.
"Football people are experts about football," Daly said. "Football people are less expert about the demand for football."
The trial was scheduled to recess later this afternoon until Wednesday while Judge David Doty attends to other cases.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Lombard's Madcap Recipe: Hauteur, Chic and Humor

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
THE initial setting in Howard Hawks's "Twentieth Century" (1934) is a bare Broadway stage where Oscar Jaffe (John Barrymore), a theater impresario deferentially called "sire" by his press agent, is taking the first day of rehearsals of his new production. The show is a ghastly romance set in an antebellum South whose fictional apogee would be reached a few years later in "Gone With the Wind." The air is thick with out-of-state "Ah-declares" and "you-alls."
Oscar is having difficulty with his latest discovery, an ex-lingerie model nee Mildred Plotka (Carole Lombard), whom he has newly christened Lily Garland. Eager and ambitious but painfully shy, Lily isn't screaming the way Oscar demands when she hears that her daddy has shot her lover dead on the front lawn. Her best attempt is a tentative "eek." Oscar, a Krakatoa waiting to erupt, is gentle and avuncular. 
 "That kind of acting," he says, "is for pins in a basement." He urges her to let herself go, but the "eeks" only become more self-conscious. Finally, at the moment that Lily is again required to scream, Oscar picks up a hatpin only a little smaller than a rail spike. With the authority of Zeus letting go a thunderbolt, he directs it at her rear end.
As Lily bellows the surprised fury of an impaled mother elephant, Carole Lombard roars into the collective consciousness as the grandest, most skilled, most uninhibited American comic actress of her day, and of any day since. At the same time, "Twentieth Century" is on its way to becoming the most delectable American film farce ever made or, at least, the first among a trio of equals that would include Ernst Lubitsch's "To Be or Not to Be" (1942) and Billy Wilder's "Some Like It Hot" (1959).
Just how much the dazzling Lombard contributed to both "Twentieth Century" and "To Be or Not to Be" can be seen in "Nothing Sacred: Silver Screenings With Carole Lombard," the not-to-be-missed 10-day retrospective organized by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. It begins today at the Walter Reade Theater.
The opening attraction? "Twentieth Century." It will be half of a double bill today and tomorrow with another of Lombard's 1934 films, "Bolero," a rather elegant studio pot-boiler, directed by Wesley Ruggles, in which George Raft receives top billing.
Lombard was -- is -- a phenomenon. With her strong, almost classical features, her pale blond hair and sleek figure, she is downright gorgeous but capable, on cue, of looking and sounding like a fishwife. The voice is alternately soothing and abrasive. She can call hogs if necessary. Satin evening gowns, worn without bras and fitted to the skin of her hips, give her a sensuousness that is often seriously, uproariously compromised by full-bodied, unladylike laughter. Even at her most chic, playing characters of monumental egos, Lombard gives the impression of being the least vain of actresses. She's someone who might compete in the frosty icon department with Garbo, Dietrich and Crawford, except that she can't keep a straight face. She's a woman with a low tolerance for institutional fraud. When, with the best of intentions, she goes for the gold in so-called serious drama, something seems not right, as when she plays the heroic English nurse in "Vigil in the Night" (1940), directed by George Stevens.
Having been nominated for an Oscar for her performance as the manic Irene Bullock in the classic screwball comedy "My Man Godfrey" (1936), and having lost to Luise Rainer of "The Great Ziegfeld," Lombard was convinced that she stood another chance with "Vigil in the Night." She wasn't even nominated, probably for the wrong reasons. The film was released early in the year and wasn't a big box-office hit.
More to the point: though she is quite good in "Vigil in the Night," she is an actress who is least convincing when she is trying to scale herself down to the solemn proportions of missionary denial and sacrifice. She is much better in her other 1940 film, Garson Kanin's adaptation of Sidney Howard's "They Knew What They Wanted." The film itself is a piece of cheese, not helped by Charles Laughton's hammy performance as a Napa Valley grape farmer or by a ludicrously moral ending dictated by the Production Code. The rural environment doesn't suit her talent, but Lombard has a tough, breezy authenticity as Laughton's mail-order bride.
Watching her play more or less straight drama is to see a great actress working at half speed. It throws her off her pace. One result is her inability in "Vigil in the Night" to deliver conviction to the ripe line "Our war never ends. You can't sign a peace treaty with disease." The expectation is that she will screw her tongue into the corner of her mouth, as she does every time she tells a whopper in "True Confession," a not-quite-successful 1937 screwball comedy in which she appears as a pathological liar.
Playing sincere in "Vigil in the Night" and "Made for Each Other" (1939), a decent but contrived domestic drama in which she co-stars with James Stewart, Lombard seems faux naive. Thus reined in, she suggests an aspiring 14-year-old about to deliver Portia's "quality of mercy" speech. She is an actress whose intelligence is fully expressed only in comedy.
The Lombard career is an odd one. She was born in 1908, made her first film as a child actress in 1921 and later had a short run as a Mack Sennett bathing beauty. She didn't really move into the major studios until 1928, just as talkies were coming in. Between 1928 and her death in January 1942 in an airplane crash, she appeared in 45 features, often as the star. She probably survived more dreadful movies than any other major actress of her time.
Several of these are included in the Walter Reade retrospective, though now they have a certain historical interest: "Supernatural" (1933), a tepid horror film in which she plays a society girl possessed by the soul of a convicted murderer; "Lady by Choice" (1934), a flabby follow-up to Frank Capra's 1933 hit "Lady for a Day," and "Fools for Scandal" (1938), a comedy-with-music (two songs) to accommodate her European co-star, Fernand Gravet, whose Hollywood career was not long.
Of far more interest in the retrospective are those classy if uncharacteristic Lombard romantic dramas that were considered in their day to be far more prestigious than her comedies: "Made for Each Other" and "In Name Only" (1939), both directed by John Cromwell. "In Name Only" presents the curious spectacle of Lombard and Cary Grant, two of the most accomplished comic performers of their time, playing a sudsy wife-versus-mistress triangle in upper-middle-class Connecticut.
Not included in the retrospective are "No Man of Her Own" (Wesley Ruggles, 1932), by all reports a minor film but the only time she played opposite Clark Gable, whom she would later marry, and "My Man Godfrey" (Gregory La Cava), one of her most fondly remembered hits, in which she plays opposite her ex-husband, the incomparable William Powell. The film society's apparent reason for not including "Godfrey" is that the film is shown so frequently on television and is available on video.
The absence of "Godfrey" is unfortunate in any summation of the Lombard career. It is one of the richest films in the screwball tradition so closely associated with life in Depression America. It also shows Lombard to be the equal of Irene Dunne and Claudette Colbert as the much-beloved, madcap screwball heroine.
If there's any doubt about this, check out the retrospective's showings of "Hands Across the Table" (1935), directed by Mitchell Leisen, in which Lombard, co-starring with Fred MacMurray, plays a manicurist out to catch a rich husband; "The Princess Comes Across" (1936, directed by William K. Howard, also with MacMurray and notable for Lombard's marvelous imitation of Greta Garbo; "Nothing Sacred" (1937), with Fredric March, written by Ben Hecht and directed by William Wellman, about a scheming young woman from Vermont who makes her fortune by saying she's dying of radium poisoning, and, a must-see, "Mr. and Mrs. Smith" (1941), written by Norman Krasna and directed by Alfred Hitchcock.
This is one of the most underrated comedies of its time, largely ignored by the critics and the public because Hitchcock was not expected to make a screwball comedy. Yet it's one of Lombard's best and, as is always the case in her successful films, she has a leading man who is her psychic match, Robert Montgomery.
"My Man Godfrey" is also missed for the way it demonstrates the differences between screwball comedy and the kind of pure farce so gloriously defined by "Twentieth Century" and "To Be or Not to Be." Screwball comedy is, even if indirectly, a product of the political, social and economic conditions of the times. Great farce is something else. It takes place as if in a glass bubble floating through space, detached from earthly laws of gravity and conventional systems of rewards and punishments.
It's not necessary to know anything about the Broadway theater of the 1930's to respond to the delirious, hermetically sealed world of "Twentieth Century," evoked by the brilliant script by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur, and by Hawks's magical direction. The film tells you all you need to know to appreciate the hilarious love-hate relationship of Oscar Jaffe and Lily Garland. The main setting is the crackerjack train speeding from Chicago to New York with Oscar, Lily and a most enchanting crew of oddballs, including two bewildered cast members of the Oberammergau Passion Play.
"To Be or Not to Be," written by Edwin Justus Mayer, is set in Nazi-occupied Poland but is just as far removed from reality as "Twentieth Century," which was the reason Lubitsch was roundly criticized at the time of its release in 1942. It, too, is about self-absorbed theater folk, mainly Joseph and Maria Tura (Jack Benny and Lombard), ham actors supreme who somehow manage to outwit the entire German Army before they are done. Though the Mel Brooks-Anne Bancroft remake is almost as fine, the Lubitsch-Benny-Lombard original is about as close to heaven as movie farces ever get.
In each of her classic films, Lombard plays opposite an actor who is her screen equal. Barrymore's performance in "Twentieth Century" forever transformed her talents. Otherwise untrained, Lombard learned a lot from Barrymore. He gave her insight into a comic method that goes beyond screwball to farce and that would be evident later in everything she did. It's especially apparent in her work with Powell, Montgomery and even Benny, whose performance in "To Be or Not to Be" is completely unexpected of a radio comedian, even a great one.
Lombard never became a figure of camp, perhaps because she wasn't around long enough, though I doubt that's the reason. Rather, I suspect, it's because she obviously was too passionate and too committed as a woman of ordinary appetites. She never stands alone in her films, like Garbo, Dietrich and Crawford. She was never a queen bee. If the actor isn't up to her measure when he starts out with her, he quickly learns the ropes, as did MacMurray, with whom she played in four films.
It would be chauvinist to say that Lombard needs a man. It's rather more accurate to say that, given the opportunity, she responds to men. She likes them. Lombard in her films seems complete only with a man, which is why there is such a magnificently daffy human face on even her most over-the-top comedies. Yet she's never subservient to the man. She is his equal.
If the man doesn't understand, then like Oscar Jaffe, he may have a number of large precious objects hurled at his head with the accuracy of a Dizzy Dean. Lombard is simultaneously of this earth and divine.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
U.S. Seeks New Mechanism To Try to End Balkan War

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The United States will press next week for tighter sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro and for the creation of a more durable international negotiating "mechanism" aimed at ending the Balkan conflict, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, said today.
In an interview, Mr. Eagleburger, who will take over the State Department as Acting Secretary on Sunday, said he would bring both proposals to a conference in London that begins on Wednesday. Last June the United States joined other members of the United Nations in imposing economic and political sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, which are viewed as the supporters of Serbian aggression in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 "I think we have to do what we can to tighten down the sanctions," Mr. Eagleburger said. "I hope we'll get agreement at the conference on that."
The resignation of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd is effective Sunday, when he will become White House chief of staff, and Mr. Eagleburger will serve as Acting Secretary at least until the Presidential election on Nov. 3.
The United Nations Security Council has also authorized the use of force to protect the shipment of food and medicine to beleaguered civilians in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In Brussels today, military authorities of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization completed a plan to protect such shipments by deploying 6,000 to 11,000 troops. Alliance members are scheduled to confer on the plan Monday in Brussels.
According to diplomats at the United Nations, a major unanswered question about whatever troops are deployed is who will lead them -- the United Nations or some sort of European-led authority. American negotiators joined with representatives from other countries to discuss this issue with representatives from the Balkan countries.
The sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro followed a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning the two republics, which now constitute Federal Yugoslavia, for aggression against neighboring Bosnia and Herzegovina.
According to State Department assessments, the sanctions have begun to bite in Serbia and Montenegro, but loopholes remain, especially along Serbia's frontier with Romania, a major part of which runs along the Danube.
 
U.S. May Monitor Danube
 The United States has begun discussions with Romania about dispatching United States technical personnel to monitor shipping on the Danube and other border traffic to prevent evasion of the embargo, particularly shipments of oil. Serbia produces about 15 percent of its own petroleum needs.
The three-day London conference next week is scheduled to bring together representatives of the warring parties from former Yugoslavia along with the 12 European Community members, the United Nations and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Representatives of all six former Yugoslav republics have been invited, but Mr. Eagleburger said it was not clear who might attend. "I gather Milosevic is playing coy," he said, referring to Slobodan Milosevic, the president of Serbia, who is treated by the Bush Administration as the main instigator of the Balkan fighting.
Of the London discussions, Mr. Eagleburger said: "You cannot expect and should not expect that this conference is going to end the war. But what we can do is something that deals with it on a day to day basis more directly."
"The thing I hope for the most," he said, was agreement by the London conference on "an establishment of some sort of permanent mechanism." He described this as "a mechanism that's there every day to try to deal with this issue, to pursue negotiations for peace.
 
Seeks Permanent Negotiators
 He said he could not provide more details about the mechanism, but that it would set up a permanent negotiating staff and location under European or United Nations auspices to serve as a forum for ending the war and resolving the political disputes that led to it.
Mr. Eagleburger said the London conference would also address the problem of how to assist the more than 2.2 million refugees scattered about the Balkan territory as a result of the fighting in Croatia and Bosnia.
"I hope there will be a fairly substantial agreement on some steps," he said. "We are going to have to deal with a lot of refugees this winter."
Under the NATO plan drafted in Brussels today, mechanized infantry forces would be used to guard relief convoys from the Adriatic port of Split in Croatia to Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, while aircraft would fly protective missions overhead. The bulk of that route is under the control of Croatian forces. The last stretch, mostly through mountains, is controlled by Serbian forces.
 
U.S. Offers Air Support
 The new plan comes in the wake of recent statements by Britain and France that they are prepared to deploy modest forces to ensure the delivery of aid. The United States has so far said only that it is willing to provide air power. Mr. Eagleburger repeated that position today.
The new plan represents a substantial scaling back of a proposal orginally drafted by the NATO military authorities at the request of the Bush Administration, which urged the alliance to devise a plan for carrying out the United Nations Security Council resolution earlier this month that authorizes the use of force.
Originally, NATO military authorities concluded that 100,000 troops were needed to secure the land route from the Adriatic to Sarajevo and to protect the airport. But last week that plan was rejected by alliance members because it called for too large a force.
The plan circulated today is deemed more politically acceptable but would entail higher military risks. Under the plan, forces would not seek to secure the land route but would use armed escorts and air cover to protect road convoys. The size of the force would depend on the disposition of the United Nations. If the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia stayed in place, 6,000 additional troops would be needed. If the United Nations force pulled out, NATO envisons the deployment of 11,000 troops.

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE FAMILY: ISSUES: FAMILY VALUES;
'Family Values' and Women: Is G.O.P. a House Divided?

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Family values, the 1990's version of apple pie and motherhood, has taken on a far more ominous meaning this week at the Republican National Convention.
Republicans have tried to define family values by suggesting that they have them and that Bill and Hillary Clinton do not. But by painting Mrs. Clinton as an unwifely feminist with undue influence on her husband's policy-making -- Gloria Steinem with the claws of Madame Nhu -- Bush strategists may have unleashed an issue that is dividing members of their own party at the same time it is distinguishing their party from the Democrats. 
 The attempt to portray Mrs. Clinton as outside the American mainstream is part of a broader cultural message, and it has prompted debate over the political benefits of defining "family values" in a way that casts aspersions on women who work.
The Census Bureau says 56 percent of women over 15, and more than half of the women who vote, are in the work force. To the degree that the Republicans' attempt to define "family values" divides them from women who do not, there is fear that the strategy could backfire, alienating Republican women already distressed over their party's rigid anti-abortion platform.
 
Some Have Misgivings
 There is a paradox in tone between the two women the campaign has presented as avatars of Republican family values. Mrs. Bush, who cared for her family and never pursued a profession, sounded an inclusive note by saying women should be encouraged to do either or both. Mrs. Quayle, who is a lawyer but gave up her profession, seemed to criticize women who disagreed with her choice.
The injection of family into politics has fueled a wide range of emotions on the issue at the convention and beyond. Even many delegates -- and party leaders -- expressed misgivings about focusing on "family values" in a way that could divide the Republican family.
"I didn't come down here thinking about family values," said Joan Rader, the vice-chairwoman of the Connecticut delegation. "I came down thinking about the economy."
Jode Rell, another delegate, said she feared that the focus on family values could lead to "more of a backlash" in the fall.
Republicans who want the party to reach out to all women -- and all configurations of family -- fear that it mainly seems to be condemning the choice made by Mrs. Clinton.
Mrs. Quayle said in her speech that women should be free to choose a job and family and accused the Democrats of denigrating women who prefer to stay home.
But Representative Constance A. Morella of Maryland said, "I had a little concern that she was designating the proper role of women," although she did not think Mrs. Quayle meant to be divisive.
She said Mrs. Quayle's speech reminded her of a long-discredited Supreme Court opinion that Justice Joseph P. Bradley wrote in 1872 on the role of women. She knew it by heart. "The paramount destiny and mission of women are to fulfill the noble and benign offices of wife and mother -- this is the law of the Creator."
 
The Elusive Definitions
 Many elected officials spoke of fears of a backlash to the family-values campaign. "I am a little concerned about this continued emphasis on us against them," said Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island. "I think a tone was set that seems to imply that only Republicans have family values, and I represent a lot of Democrats who hold family values and who exemplify family values very well."
Republican speakers at the convention invoked "family values" in support of their positions on abortion, homosexuality and the size of government, but many voters see the phrase in more economic terms.
"There is the issue of day care and how to afford it," said Ann Ault, an accountant and lifelong Republican, who was attending a business meeting today at the Galleria, an upscale shopping complex. Mrs. Ault said that her sister was a housewife but that she herself could not afford to stay home. "If you do work, people ask you where your child is and what you're doing about it," she said, "Even my sister-in-law, she feels guilty staying at home."
 
Exploiting Insecurity?
 The Republicans seem eager to exploit the feelings of insecurity of women like Mrs. Ault's sister.
Bush campaign aides say the assault on Mrs. Clinton is aimed at appealing to suburban voters, a group the Bush campaign considers crucial. (After the Los Angeles riots, Mr. Bush's advisers anxiously polled suburban areas to determine what the President's exact response should be.)
"It's specifically directed at the women who are tired of hearing that they have to have careers, and if they give them up, they're somehow not as good," said one senior campaign official. "Voters who live in the suburbs and are sick of being told they made the wrong choices, that they are not politically correct, that their life styles are somehow wrong.
That "silent majority" approach in the 1960's, pitting housewives against feminists, showed up in Mrs. Quayle's speech. Siding with the part of her generation that loathed Woodstock, she spoke of "liberals," who are "disappointed because most women do not wish to be liberated from their essential natures as women."
But Mrs. Quayle's sentiments are not always easy to find in suburbia. "I'm not a career woman, but the women have a real struggle," said Phoebe Duggan, a retired teacher who was eating frozen yogurt at the Northwest Mall, 20 miles from the Astrodome. "They try to be all things to their husband and follow a career."
The most conservative voices in the party have already supplied an answer to a question that even Sigmund Freud could not answer: "What do women want?" But Republicans closer to the middle want their party to embrace working women as well as more traditional wives.
Ms. Rell, a Connecticut State Representative, said that even though she disliked Mrs. Clinton, she feared a backlash from women against the party. "Does she represent mainstream American women?" she asked. "I think that is different for everybody."
Some women at the convention see a feminist message in the family-values campaign. "The Republican Party is saying that American women have the intelligence and ability to be working mothers and to do it well," said Martha Fallgatter, a 44-year-old delegate from Bakersfield, Calif., who is a divorced mother of five. "And the other message coming through is that if you as a woman choose to be a mother and not have a career, that is also a good value choice."
But that message may be getting lost outside party headquarters. "The Republicans are the old way and they are reluctant to change," said Suanne Tennant, an equipment sales representative. A Republican, she said she might vote for the Democrat this year: "The Republicans want it all, but it's a Catch-22."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);
