HEADLINE: UNDER THE DOME: NEWS ANALYSIS;
No Choice but to Confront the Economy

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
When the Republicans arrived in Houston last weekend, the salient issue of the 1992 Presidential campaign was the economy, and when they leave town this weekend, it will still be the economy.
But President Bush reframed the debate tonight, promising across-the-board tax cuts next year if the new Congress agrees to spending cuts to offset them. It was a bold attempt to persuade the American people to forgive him for the increases he accepted in June 1990, and give him another chance. It was also a brisk challenge to the Democrats -- the Democrats who control the House and Senate as well as Mr. Bush's Democratic opponents this fall. 
 In effect, the President apologized, something Presidents seldom do. He invited those who voted for him in 1988 and have had their doubts since to choose between himself, a tax-cutter reborn, and Bill Clinton, whom he and innumerable convention speakers have portrayed as a tax-raiser unrepentant.
The Republicans talked mostly about other things during their time here, and Mr. Bush devoted a lot of time to foreign policy for someone who has been castigated for devoting too much. Once again he took credit for his party for winning the cold war, and he gleefully zapped Mr. Clinton for his views on the Persian Gulf war: "While I bit the bullet, he bit his nails."
Then, in a hard-nosed acceptance speech that was rapturously received in the echoing, jam-packed Astrodome, the President turned back to dollars and cents. He had no real choice. Parties run on economics when the numbers are with them, and they run away when the numbers are against them. But there are limits, especially when the voters have been telling poll-takers for at least 20 months that the economy matters more to them than anything else.
 
'Driven by the Economy'
 "This election is going to be driven by the economy," said Max M. Fisher, the Detroit real estate man who has been one of the party's most sedulous fund-raisers for decades. "If we can make a convincing case on that, we have a chance to win. If not, I'm afraid that I doubt it.'
So Mr. Bush had to grapple in his speech, and will have to grapple in his campaign, with the slowest growth rate since Herbert Hoover (a name the Republicans would love to banish from political discourse), with the President's broken promise not to raise taxes, and with the budget deficit.
Fickle Fate didn't help him; the biggest jump in more than a decade in the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits for the first time was reported a few hours before the President walked onto the Astrodome podium.
On the first three nights of the convention, the Republicans did their best to change the subject. Abortion, crime, foreign policy, education and health care got copious attention, as expected. Equally predictable were the comparisons of George Bush's big-time experience to Bill Clinton's lack of it, and the unanimous assertion that the President was therefore more worthy of trust than the Democrat.
The surprise was the searing intensity of the attacks, under the guise of defending "family values," on homosexuals and on Hillary Clinton. They and the supporters of abortion rights are the designated infidels of the Republicans' cultural crusaders.
"Americans try to raise their children to understand right and wrong," Mr. Quayle said, "only to be told that every so-called 'life-style alternative' is morally equivalent. That is wrong. The gap between us and our opponents is a cultural divide. It is not just a difference between conservative and liberal, it is a difference between fighting for what is right and refusing to see what is wrong."
Ward and June Cleaver are no longer archetypes; only a quarter of American households are two-parent homes with children. Nonetheless, they account for more than half of all Americans over the age of 25, and they are not only more likely to vote than the population as a whole, but also more conservative.
 
Life Through a Soft Lens
 The Republicans, however, are casting their "family values" nets even more widely than that.
Sometimes people can be persuaded to view life through a soft lens and vote for a nostalgic image they never knew. The Republicans and Mr. Bush tried for that this week, betting that the country longs for and identifies with Cleaverism the way it longed for and identified with a Hollywood version of small-town America in the Reagan years. Mr. Quayle evoked both tonight, as did Barbara Bush last night, surrounded by children and grandchildren.
If that makes people forget their economic woes, or assign them a lower priority, the President may benefit. But it is easy to overdo the social-issue approach. Poll data suggest that most voters think homosexuals should be protected from job discrimination and harassment, even if they do not approve of their sexual orientation, so gay-bashing has its perils. So does Hillary-taunting, if the electorate comes to see it as intolerance of working women in general.
Already, the party's hard line on abortion has cost votes, although it is impossible even to estimate how many. A prominent Republican woman who favors abortion rights said all the right things in an interview today, promising to vote for Mr. Bush because "he is right on so many other things." When the on-the-record interview ended she changed her tune, promising that "they'll get theirs this fall when we vote for Clinton."
 
Clues, but Not Road Maps
 Conventions provide clues to the campaigns that follow them, not detailed road maps thereof.
Mr. Bush is not obliged to advocate everything the Republican platform does, let alone everything said by the featured orators here this week. He is hardly likely, for example, to endorse Patrick J. Buchanan's praise for "force, rooted in justice, backed by courage" as a means of dealing with racial unrest.
But the President he will not be able entirely to eradicate, even if he should want to, the tenor of negativism created by this week's events, and that worries the governors and former governors of the big states all across the country where the cultural boundaries are much less distinct.
It worries them because of voters like Scott Epelbaum of Columbus, Ohio, who runs a private security agency. Interviewed at the Ohio State Fair this week, he said he wished the Republicans "would talk about something other than morals and Murphy Brown and my bedroom," especially the economy.
Usually a Republican, he plans to vote for Mr. Clinton, he said. "I dont know if he's better, but he's no worse, and he's different."
In a year when voters seem unusually hungry for answers to intractable problems, this week's attack politics could cost the Republicans some votes while gaining them others. That helps explain the absence of some vulnerable office-holders, like Gov. Pete Wilson of California, and the relative invisibility of others, like Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania.
Contrary to some assertions, this was not the bitterest Republican convention in modern memory. While there were more splits on major issues than at any convention in the last quarter-century -- abortion and the economy, to name just two -- they were kept largely below stairs.
No prominent Republican rose to attack another, the way Everett McKinley Dirksen denounced Thomas E. Dewey at Chicago in 1952 as the man who had too often taken the party "down the path to defeat," and no Republican moderate was booed as was Nelson A. Rockefeller on the dais in San Francisco in 1964.
"We weren't about to let democracy break out on the floor," said Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., a former Republican chairman. "We've learned over the last 10 or 20 years that that's bad for your political health."
The Democrats will try at every turn to drag the discussion back to the economy. Mr. Bush is unlikely to get any significant help between now and Election Day from the numbers-crunchers; Allen Sinai, the chief economist at the Boston Company, an investment advisory firm, said, "It's hard to see anything that's going to snap the economy back between now and November."
No President in this century has been re-elected with an economy that has performed as poorly as the economy is and has been performing in the last year. Mr. Bush must hope that the nation will believe his new campaign manager, James A. Baker 3d, when he promises that the President can learn to hit the big-league economic curve ball if only he is given another chance.

HEADLINE: Cry for Brazil

 BODY:
The Western Hemisphere's second-largest country is in an uproar. Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's first freely elected President since the 1960's, is accused of widespread corruption and faces impeachment. To stay in office he is recklessly dispensing patronage, despite surging inflation and international commitments to austerity.
It is for Brazilians, not Americans, to decide Mr. Collor's political future. Washington's interest is in continued democracy and economic recovery, not personalities. Fortunately, all sides pledge to follow constitutional procedures. But economic recovery is threatened in any event -- through the profligacy of Mr. Collor or his replacement by an untested Vice President, Itamar Franco. 
 Mr. Collor is currently being investigated by a congressional panel on charges that he tolerated a vast influence-peddling and kickback scheme run by one of his closest associates, Paulo Cesar Farias, and received millions of dollars from Mr. Farias for household expenses. This comes at a time when most Brazilians remain mired in shocking poverty and involves a President who rode to office on a promise to rout governmental corruption.
The congressional findings are expected to be highly critical of Mr. Collor. Impeachment requires a two-thirds vote. With no large party of his own, he is shopping for support. His ministers have even begun to solicit requests for new spending.
This fiscal binge comes as Brazil has just begun to win back international financial credibility despite a foreign debt of $123 billion, the developing world's highest, and an inflation rate close to 250 percent, the highest in Latin America. Marcilio Marques Moreira, the Economy Minister, recently negotiated deals with the International Monetary Fund and foreign banks that hinge on continued fiscal and monetary austerity. Ballooning deficit spending could compel him to resign.
Brazilians may be forced to choose between keeping an elected President who has put his own future ahead of the country's or replacing him with his carelessly chosen running mate. Either way, Mr. Collor has embarrassed Brazil.

HEADLINE: In Today's Russia Too, the Rich Get Richer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"How to Take Over the Store" (The Week in Review, Aug. 2) -- a success story of a Russian store manager, Natalya Maloletneva, turned proprietor of the store -- blurs some fundamental detail, which, I am afraid, leaves your readers in the dark about the basic prerequisite for such a success in the Commonwealth of Independent States. 
 Ms. Maloletneva paid 2.2 million rubles to purchase the Lyudmila store from the state. This was "roughly three or four months of profit" of the store -- one of the most popular women's clothing stores in Moscow. Since the store's staff savings were insufficient to collect such a sum, Ms. Maloletneva withheld the shop's sales revenues and did not turn them over to the appropriate state authority. The equivalent of such behavior in this country would be a company's not paying its taxes to the United States Treasury. Everybody here knows what the consequences are likely to be.
In Moscow, Ms. Maloletneva was able to get away with it, and now she proudly boasts to your correspondent about such "violation of the rules," as she innocently puts it. This shows to what extent law enforcement is nonexistent in Russia today.
Next Ms. Maloletneva personally bought 4 of the 24 shares of the corporation that now owns Lyudmila. For this she paid 60,000 rubles "from her savings and those of her husband."
For many years, I was a Moscow professor in the highly paid academic profession. For me to accumulate 60,000 rubles, I would have to save my total salary to the last kopek for 10 years. I am sure that very few honest working families in Russia, with the exception of the narrow circle of popular authors or movie stars, could have saved that much money, even if one of the wage earners was a colonel in the Soviet army. From this it follows that Ms. Maloletneva, being a manager of a big store, managed to cream off the top and bottom of each transaction, as is usually done in Russian commerce. This is where the bulk of her savings had to come from.
I write not to pass moral judgment on Ms. Maloletneva and her ilk. For 99 percent of the Russian population such a method of "privatization" is out of reach. What Ms. Maloletneva did is now called the "nomenklatura" privatization: the managers of state stores, restaurants and enterprises by hook or by crook lay their hands on state ("people's") property, while the majority of the population is being pauperized.
And that explains the widening gap between the rulers and the ruled in the process of that "popular democratic revolution" whose anniversary the Russian people will "celebrate" with tap water at the end of this month.
 
HENRY TROFIMENKO
Elon College, N.C., Aug. 3, 1992

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Merchants of Hate

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
"GOP Needs a Kremlin to Bash," the lead headline in The Chicago Tribune said the day before the convention. It neatly stated the seeming dilemma of a Republican Party that for 40 years had made a theme of denouncing the Democrats as soft on Communism.
But the collapse of the Soviet Union did not faze Pat Buchanan, Pat Robertson or the others who speak for the Republican Party today. They bashed the un-Christian and the un-straight. They bashed Hillary Clinton and Bill Clinton. And they even managed to flog the Red menace. 
 If the Democrats won this election, Republican chairman Rich Bond suggested, Jane Fonda would be sleeping in the White House "as guest of honor at a state dinner for Fidel Castro."
The sleaze was so thick on the ground here in Houston, the attacks so far-fetched, that some people may be tempted to dismiss them as funny. Not I. I remember Joe McCarthy. I have been going to national political conventions since his day, and I do not recall one as mean in spirit as this one.
God was much spoken of. But He was a God without compassion, a God of intolerance.
If the official Republican platform is carried out, a 13-year-old girl who becomes pregnant as a result of being raped by her father and has an abortion could end in the gas chamber. The platform says that every abortion, whatever the reason, however early in the pregnancy, is the unjustified killing of a human being. For the woman and the doctor, no mercy.
The 1964 Republican Convention, which nominated Barry Goldwater, has until now been regarded as the angriest in its tone. Delegates shouted down Nelson Rockefeller and attacked the press.
But Barry Goldwater is a moderate compared with those in charge now. In fact former Senator Goldwater opposed the party's 1992 position on abortion as politically disastrous.
The Houston convention was significant in a number of ways. First, it marked a big advance in influence by the religious right.
The Democrats this year did much to erase their reputation for yielding to special interests outside the party. But the Republican Party has actually been taken over to a remarkable extent by the special interests of the hard right and religious conservatives, who worked precinct by precinct to capture state delegations.
The success of the extremists was evident in the choice of the two Pats, Buchanan and Robertson, to address the convention. But even the supposed moderates, like Rich Bond, shrilled themselves up.
The nastiness had a purpose, and that was the second significant point in the convention. The idea was to take people's minds off the real issue in the 1992 election: the economic suffering of millions of Americans.
Conservatives came to power when Ronald Reagan combined right-wing social ideas with a new economic idea: the supply-side miracle. The Government would cut taxes, increase spending and balance the budget.
The result has been to push the world's richest country toward bankruptcy, and to leave the average American earning less in real terms than he or she was 12 years ago.
That is why Republicans on and off the floor talked about everything they could to get people's minds off jobs and pay and their hopes for their children -- that is, real subjects.
Day after day some Bush surrogate spoke of Governor Clinton's sex life. But probably nastiest of all were the references to Mrs. Clinton.
Literature sold in the Republican "Spirit of America" hall next to the arena called Mrs. Clinton a "femi nazi." The Reverend Robertson said she and her husband were out to "destroy the traditional family." That of a woman whose efforts to help children learn were praised by the Barbara Bush Foundation for Family Literacy in a 1989 book.
Of course every effort was made to keep President Bush above the slime -- to give him deniability. He sounded Presidential. But anyone who thinks his attack dogs were acting on their own must believe in Peter Pan.
Will the meanness work? I doubt it, though it was effective in 1988. In any event, Republicans might remember that Lee Atwater, the 1988 chairman, apologized before he died last year for what he called his "naked cruelty."

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 3; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1797 words

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS IN HOUSTON - MAN IN THE NEWS;
A Vice President Who Has Been Tested: James Danforth Quayle 3d

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan was about to deliver his most memorable zinger, the line about how Gov. Bill Clinton "sat up in a dormitory in Oxford, England, and figured out how to dodge the draft." An impish producer at NBC News, who had an advance text of Mr. Buchanan's Monday night speech to the Republican convention, ordered the cameras trained on Vice President Dan Quayle.
As the Astrodome crowd erupted in cheers, Mr. Quayle sat stiff and expressionless, his eyes shifting self-consciously to the left and then to the right. The camera lingered. Mr. Quayle, whose own candidacy was bombarded by questions about the draft four years earlier, did not smile. 
 Even as Mr. Quayle wages an aggressive campaign to reintroduce himself to the electorate, the old demons, it seems, are always lurking.
This time it happened on a night when both President Bush and former President Ronald Reagan went out of their way to bolster Mr. Quayle's promise of a "new Dan Quayle," portraying him as a leader who has been severely tested. Mr. Reagan called him "someone who has repeatedly stood up for his deepest convictions." Mr. Bush added, "This guy stood there in the face of those unfair critics and he has never wavered."
 
Moving Forward, Sliding Back
 Indeed, Mr. Quayle has been tested unlike virtually any other American politician, forced to spend four years chipping away at the devastating caricature created in the first week of his 1988 campaign. And yet, each time Mr. Quayle has given the country reason to take him seriously, he has said something, done something or spelled something that instantly reversed the progress and fed the stereotype.
In June, just as he was riding a public relations boost provided by a favorable series of articles in The Washington Post, he made one of the most embarrassing goofs of his tenure by misspelling the word "potato" at a grade school spelling bee.
And misfortune struck twice this week, producing smirking headlines. First he confused the year of the next Presidential election. "Let us see George Bush re-elected this November and then we'll talk about 1994," he said in a CNN interview on Tuesday. Then he misspoke in a speech Wednesday about term limits. "This is not a bipartisan issue because Democrats, Republicans and independents support term limitations," he said.
Each time it happens, Mr. Quayle's aides and allies wince at the prospect of lost momentum. "It just seems that whenever he gets his head above water and gets a couple of breaths of air, the next wave comes crashing down on him," said Senator Daniel R. Coats, a former aide to Mr. Quayle who succeeded him as Indiana's Republican junior Senator.
 
A Risk-Taking Activist
 Although he is now 45 years of age, with a wisp of gray at his temples and crow's feet at the corners of his gleaming blue eyes, Mr. Quayle still has an unmarked look that cartoonists exploit to suggest an inner vacuity.
The Vice President says he has been as loyal to Mr. Bush as Mr. Bush was to Mr. Reagan. But unlike Vice President Bush, Vice President Quayle has been an aggressive, risk-taking activist, knowing he can only overcome his reputation for buffoonery by 1996 if he establishes a serious record of his own.
To that end, he has become the Bush Administration's lead emissary to the Republican right. He has converted his office into a war room for the Administration's battle against government regulation, transforming the Council on Competitiveness, which he heads, into a policy-making body that is both respected and feared.
He has become inseparably identified with the Republican crusade on "family values." But unlike former Education Secretary William J. Bennett, who defined family values in cogent and specific terms when he nominated Mr. Quayle on Wednesday night, the Vice President's oratory on the issue rarely moves beyond platitudes about "hard work, integrity and personal responsibility."
 
Some Notes of Vitality
 For much of the time in the last few months, Mr. Quayle and his coterie of neoconservative aides injected one of the few notes of vitality into the Bush-Quayle campaign. Before the convention, at least, they formed an independent power base within the White House, often acting without the knowledge or approval of Mr. Bush or his handlers, and often making the President look drowsy by comparison.
And yet, Mr. Quayle's public approval ratings have continued to slide to an all-time low. As the Bush-Quayle campaign floundered last month, Mr. Quayle became a natural scapegoat. Even those who argued for keeping him on the ticket rarely did so by cataloguing his political strengths.
The perception of the Vice President as a bumbler limits his effectiveness in the campaign. When he assails the Democratic ticket, for example, aides to Mr. Clinton dismiss his message by ridiculing the messenger.
 
1988 Convention Scrutiny
 Mr. Quayle spent this week racing through a frantic schedule of 20 public appearances, as against four by Mr. Bush, all intended to highlight the attributes that were so thoroughly obscured at the 1988 convention by stories about his enlistment in the Indiana National Guard instead of being drafted or volunteering for active duty in the Vietnam War, even though he personally approved American involvement in that war. He was also subjected to intense scrutiny of his mediocre academic record and his family's wealth.
After four years Mr. Quayle can justifiably add at least one meaningful line to his political resume: He is a survivor. Republican leaders maintain that even Richard M. Nixon did not suffer the level of attack by journalists and comedians that Mr. Quayle has endured. And unlike the former President, Mr. Quayle has shown remarkable resilience without public displays of either bitterness or vengeance.
"I'm sure he's learned what hell is," said Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming. "He's been bombarded with more stuff than anybody I've known since I came to Washington, and I admire the way he's taken the heat."
 
Chance to Prove Himself
 Like a jujitsu master, Mr. Quayle has learned to turn his disadvantages into advantages. Rather than indulging the politician's instinct for denial, he concedes that he is the object of ridicule, and then argues that this has given him the chance to prove himself in battle, in Washington if not in Vietnam.
"I stand before you and before the American people -- unbowed, unbroken and ready to keep fighting for our beliefs," Mr. Quayle said in his acceptance speech tonight.
In rebutting his critics, Mr. Quayle has constructed a demonology of evildoers, ranging from the news media to the American Bar Association, who he maintains are responsible for the deterioration of the economy, the family and his own reputation. The argument sells well with conservative Republicans, who readily embrace Mr. Quayle's contention that an offense to one is an offense to all.
"The elites laughed at the reference to Murphy Brown and sneered at my defense of basic values," Mr. Quayle said on Monday in a speech to Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition. "But it wasn't just me they were laughing at, my friends. It was you and your families and your values."
Inherent in the case made by Mr. Quayle and his allies is the view that few of his wounds have been self-inflicted. Mr. Quayle's wife, Marilyn, blames the press for his problems.
"There was a great deal invested in Dan Quayle's being portrayed as someone out of nowhere, that he was a lightweight, instead of really looking at his Senate career and what he'd accomplished there," Mrs. Quayle said last week in an interview at the Vice-Presidential residence in Washington. "His Senate record is far more substantive in real accomplishment and creativity than Al Gore's is, but you don't hear that because we never played the stroke-the-media bit."
 
Childhood in Two States
 James Danforth Quayle 3d was born in Indianapolis on Feb. 4, 1947, the eldest of the four children of James C. and Corinne Pulliam Quayle. Mr. Quayle's maternal grandfather was Eugene C. Pulliam, whose publishing organization included conservative newspapers in Indiana and Arizona.
Mr. Quayle divided his childhood in those two states. He received a B.A. degree from DePauw University and a law degree from the Indiana University School of Law. It was at law school that he met Marilyn Tucker, a classmate whom he married 10 weeks after their first date. The Quayles, who are Presbyterian, have three children -- Tucker, 18, Ben, 15, and Corinne, 13.
After graduating from law school in 1974, the couple opened a law practice in Huntington, Ind., where Mr. Quayle's father published the family paper. While Mr. Quayle was working as associate publisher, local Republican leaders recruited him to run for Congress.
He upset his Democratic opponent, served two terms, and then ran for the Senate in 1980, when he upset the Democratic incumbent, Birch Bayh. Mr. Quayle was re-elected by a large margin in 1986 and then was chosen as a running mate in 1988 by Mr. Bush, who wanted to balance the ticket with youth, conservatism and a Midwesterner.
As Vice President, Mr. Quayle has aggressively pursued an agenda that includes calls for parental school choice, civil justice reform, term limitations for Congress and environmental deregulation.
 
Enemy of Environmentalists
 He maintains that the Council on Competitiveness has saved consumers and small businesses tens of billions of dollars. But in the process, he has become a mortal enemy of environmentalists, who complain that he has weakened regulations intended to preserve open land and limit pollution.
With an eye on 1996, Mr. Quayle has enthusiastically pursued the traditional party-building duties that go with being Vice President, appearing at hundreds of events for Congressional candidates and helping to raise nearly $30 million for his party's candidates.
And he has assembled a staff that is widely admired in Washington for its political acumen. But the abilities of his aides, and particularly his chief of staff, William Kristol, have led to reports that Mr. Quayle is the puppet of underlings preoccupied with their own political and ideological ambitions.
"Look, you've got people out there who are not going to give me credit for anything," Mr. Quayle said. "So now that they've got to give me grudging credit for doing a competent job as Vice President, they don't want to give me the credit so they just say, 'Oh, well, it's someone else.' Well, who do you think makes these decisions? Who hires these people? Who encourages them to come up with ideas?"
He added: "On the other hand, you can take it as a backhanded compliment that we're having an impact. And that's important."

HEADLINE: America West Airlines Shrinks to Try to Survive

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz.

 BODY:
In the logo of America West Airlines, the stylized initials suggest a lovely burgundy sun flying over mountain peaks. But for the present at least, a more appropriate symbol might be the creosote bush, a desert shrub that survives droughts by shedding a branch at a time, cutting back just enough to sustain life until rain returns.
The last big airline to be founded since deregulation of the industry in 1978, America West has had no choice in recent months but to cut back again and again, shedding planes, employees and even its founder. 
 It is burdened now by a $1.2 billion debt, has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy laws since June 1991 and is struggling to convince travelers and creditors that it will not go the way of Pan Am, Eastern, Midway, People Express and Braniff.
"There is no question America West is going to make it," Michael J. Conway, the carrier's president and chief executive, said during a recent interview at corporate headquarters here in suburban Phoenix. His optimism was fueled by recent agreements with GPA Group P.L.C., the airline's main supplier of leased planes, and with a consortium of Phoenix-based businesses, for $43 million in new loans.
 
Dangers in the Economy
 "But if we run into serious deterioration of the economy or high fuel costs," he said, "it could still be very difficult."
Some analysts think it is already very difficult. "The funding amounts to a life extension of three more months," said Samuel Buttrick, an airline analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. "But America West has extremely limited resources and little in the way of unencumbered assets to generate cash for funding continuing operating losses."
The nine-year-old carrier has run on red ink in six of those years and in the last eight consecutive quarters. In the second quarter of 1992 it suffered a net loss of $33.4 million, compared with $30.9 million a year earlier, in part, officials say, because of the negative impact of the lower industrywide fares introduced by American Airlines in April.
Equally troubling, America West's traffic was off 13.3 percent through July compared with the first seven months of 1991, despite a half-price sale that has generated record boardings for many airlines this summer.
But Mr. Conway, 47 years old, the Brooklyn-born son of a New York City taxi driver, predicts a turnaround in the fourth quarter, barring another war in the Persian Gulf, high fuel costs or other such problems. By then he expects the economy to pick up and the carrier to benefit from cost-cutting measures intended to save more than $100 million.
He also said he expected an infusion of at least another $137 million of equity from the suppliers of America West's planes and other sources, including the Boeing Company, GE Capital and Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services, a unit of Transpacific Enterprises Inc. of Australia. GPA Group, the principal supplier of aircraft, and these other companies own about 40 percent of America West's fleet, and they helped the carrier through a cash shortage last year by deferring $100 million in payments. In addition, GPA gave the airline another $35 million in what is called debtor-in-possession financing last year, while Kawasaki Leasing International Inc. added a $23 million DIP and Northwest Airlines put up $20 million.
"The new money gives the business plan a chance to work, but it will be a tough call," Edward R. Beauvais, America West's founder, said in interview in reference to the $45 million.
Mr. Beauvais (pronounced Bo-vay) stepped down as chief executive in September and as chairman last month. Although people involved with the airline say he was forced by the airline's creditors to step aside, Mr. Beauvais, 55, said only: "When a company is not doing well you really can't have two leaders, because the prospects of additional financing are better with one. It also demonstrates that the welfare of the company is more important than that of any single individual."
 
Hard-Pressed Work Force
 To America West workers who have been let go, that statement might well have a hollow ring. For that matter American West employees, widely recognized as highly dedicated and adaptable, have long been paid less than their industry co-workers, and substantially less than Mr. Beauvais, who made almost $1 million in 1990.
According to a report by Roberts & Associates Inc. of Hayward, Calif., prepared for a group of America West shareholders critical of company management, the carrier's average employee earned $25,210 in 1990 -- 45 percent that of the average Delta employee and 61 percent that of the average Southwest employee. Since that report, employees' salaries were cut 10 percent across the board (with senior management taking far bigger pay cuts).
Moreover, in part to help compensate for low salaries, employees were required to buy stock in the carrier amounting to 20 percent of their first year's salary. Thus employees hold about 20 percent of America West's 23 million shares of common stock, which is now virtually worthless.
That stock is likely to be totally worthless before long, since the carrier said it was contemplating swapping debt for equity. "But at the time of reorganization, hopefully early next year," said Alphonse E. Frei, the carrier's chief financial officer, "it is anticipated employees will be given a meaningful stake in the new company."
Yet the morale of employees who have survived the periodic cutbacks, which will have cut its 15,000-member work force to 10,200 by the end of the year, remains surprisingly high. "We all have our fingers crossed that we'll make it," said Scott Johnson, a flight attendant, during a recent nonstop flight from New York to Phoenix. "This is a good airline and it deserves to survive."
Management is also reducing its fleet size from 123 planes to 86. By January, it will have dropped flights to 20 of its 50 cities, including Des Moines and Moline, Ill.
And it is also talking with Phoenix officials about reducing gates, ticket counters and office space at Sky Harbor International Airport, the airline's main hub, on which it pays $2.2 million a month in rent.
In April it sold its Honolulu-Nagoya, Japan, route to Northwest for $15 million. And while awaiting Federal Aviation Administration approval to substitute a two-engine Boeing 757 for its current four-engine Boeing 747 between Phoenix and Honolulu, the carrier will essentially contract that nonstop service to American Trans Air, beginning Sept. 16. Trans Air's three-engine Lockheed L-1011 will burn 1,100 gallons of fuel an hour less than the 747.
 
Too Far, Too Fast
 Within the industry, mention of Honolulu and Japan invites criticism that America West, initially a regional carrier serving five cities with three aircraft and 280 employees, expanded too far too fast. It even bid for the Eastern shuttle, losing out to Donald Trump.
Mr. Beauvais never met an airline route he didn't like is how some describe it.
While acknowledging that the route to Japan proved disastrous, both he and Mr. Conway defend the strategy that carried them there. By their separate accounts, America West had to grow to stave off a takeover. Then it had to expand into important markets from San Francisco to New York to compete with other carriers' frequent-flier programs. Then it had to add Honolulu, the most popular frequent-flier destination.
As for Japan, Mr. Beauvais conceded, "Had I known the economic cycle would have been so severe, I would never have bought that route."
The airline began that service about the time the gulf war broke out. "Almost immediately international traffic plummeted," Mr. Frei said, "and the Japanese Government advised its citizens to avoid American carriers."
 
Understandable Strategy
 Timothy Pettee, transportation analyst with Alliance Capital Management, said the carrier's strategy was not hard to understand, however. "Everybody had unbridled optimism about the Pacific market," he said, "and had it continued to grow at the expected 12 percent a year their sins would have been overlooked. In retrospect, their timing couldn't have been worse."
Similarly, the decision to open a hub in Columbus was based on getting close to the populous cities of the East and Midwest, in a market that is itself the headquarters of many corporate headquarters or plants. The goal was to attract more business travelers, who pay higher fares than the discretionary leisure travelers who dominate America West's Phoenix and Las Vegas hubs.
But not only did the lingering recession stifle business travel, in April, but the industry also adopted American Airlines' simplified fare structure, which reduced first-class and full-coach fares up to 38 percent. But in the spring -- six months after America West opened its Columbus hub -- no-frills Southwest Airlines showed up there, complete with its usual frequent flights and low-cost fares.
In the long term, America West can make money in Columbus, analysts say, but much less and at a far slower pace than its corporate game plan called for.
Publicly at least, Mr. Conway, a former marine, remains gung ho about America West's prospects.
"No one else has going for it what we have," he said, ticking off the carrier's motivated work force, modern fleet, a perfect safety record and unit operating costs that he says will soon be the lowest in the industry. "We've also carved out a niche," he said, "that isn't a direct frontal attack against a major competitor."
Whether or not the retrenchment is too late, Alliance Capital's Mr. Pettee sees an important lesson: "The swiftness with which their fortunes declined is a grim reminder to all airline investors."

HEADLINE: UNDER THE DOME: THE OVERVIEW;
BUSH PROMISES ACROSS-THE-BOARD TAX CUT AND AN ECONOMIC REVIVAL IN A SECOND TERM

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
President Bush tonight appealed for a second term with a promise of new, across-the-board tax cuts next year, a pledge to control Government spending and an attack on his opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton, as a throwback to failed Democratic policies at home and abroad.
Mr. Bush, accepting his party's nomination here before 2,210 delegates in the Houston Astrodome, presented himself as a tested leader on the world stage who was now committed to waging the struggle for economic revival at home. 
 He proudly claimed credit for helping usher in the sweeping changes of the last four years, from the unification of Germany to the commencement of Arab-Israeli peace talks, from the easing of conflict in Central America to the collapse of the Soviet Union.
"The world changes for which we've sacrificed for a generation have finally come to pass," Mr. Bush said, "and with them a rare and unprecedented opportunity to pass the sweet cup of prosperity around our American table." [Transcript, pages A14-A15.]
 
Admits Erring On Taxes
 He apologized for breaking his "no new taxes" pledge of 1988, but he cast his acceptance of the 1990 budget agreement, which included new taxes, as a one-time error. Seeking to reclaim the Republicans' political advantage as the party of fiscal restraint, Mr. Bush declared, "Who do you trust in this election? The candidate who raised taxes one time and regrets it, or the other candidate, who raised taxes and fees 128 times, and enjoyed it every time?"
This speech, capping the final night of the 35th Republican National Convention, did not reach the emotional heights that Mr. Bush attained in 1988, when his acceptance speech was widely hailed as the "speech of a lifetime." Mr. Bush was forced onto the defensive by an ailing economy, and he went into great detail blaming a "gridlock Democratic Congress" for blunting the promise of his current term.
But this partisan audience and his beaming advisers clearly thought he had succeeded in the essential chore of softening up Mr. Clinton and his poll ratings before the long slog through September and October. For that reason, the 58-minute address veered sharply from the visionary tone of its opening passage to the routine battering of a typical campaign speech.
 
Promises to Propose Cuts
 On balance, Mr. Bush seemed to have more energy for defending his record and for assailing his opponents than for laying down a roadmap for a second term.
In promising to call for new across-the-board reductions in taxes when Congress returns next year, Mr. Bush said he would insure that they were tied to spending reductions so they did not increase the deficit. The President said he would propose several actions to cut spending, including vetoing any appropriations bill that exceeded his budget request and pushing for a cap on mandatory spending programs like Medicare, Medicaid and veterans' benefits.
 
Defends Economic Record
 But he did not specify which taxes he would reduce or which mandatory spending programs he would cap.
In contrast, Mr. Bush said of Mr. Clinton, "His passion to expand government knows no bounds." Throughout his speech, Mr. Bush said this election would pose a "sharp choice" between policies, philosophies and character, and he presented Mr. Clinton as a man committed to taxing, spending, and ever bigger government.
The audience chanted, "Hit him again, harder, harder!" and "Thank you, George!"
Mr. Bush sought to defend his economic record of the last four years, which many polls suggest is at the heart of his political difficulties. Echoing a theme struck here throughout the week, Mr. Bush said the Democratic-controlled Congress had blocked his package to spur economic growth.
"I extended my hand to the Democratic leaders, and they bit it," he said.
 
Cites Foreign Policy
 He also proudly declared that the fall of Communism during the last four years was not an accident but rather a result of strong Republican stewardship, and he warned that Mr. Clinton was untested and unprepared for the job of Commander in Chief.
"My opponents say I spend too much time on foreign policy," Mr. Bush told his audience of roaring, flag-waving Republicans. "I saw the chance to rid our children's dreams of the nuclear nightmare, and I did. I seized those opportunities for our kids and our grandkids, and I make no apologies for that."
Here, as on the issue of the economy, Mr. Bush asserted that Mr. Clinton was tied to failed Democratic philosophies. "While the U.S. postwar strategy was largely bipartisan, the fact remains that the liberal, McGovern wing of the other party -- including my opponent -- consistently made the wrong choices."
 
Recalls Gulf War Leadership
 Mr. Bush also proudly recounted his conduct of the war in the Persian Gulf, and scoffed at his opponent's ability to do the same. "What about the leader of the Arkansas National Guard, the man who hopes to be Commander in Chief?" he asked. "Well, while I bit the bullet, he bit his nails."
Mr. Bush's speech clearly defined the coming battle over the economy, and the Clinton campaign quickly asserted that Mr. Bush's promise of new tax cuts was irresponsible and as politically motivated as his "no new taxes" promise four years ago.
George Stephanopoulos, the communications director for the Clinton campaign, asserted, "The President said he would do anything to get re-elected, and he obviously meant it. This makes 'read my lips' look truthful and responsible."
The President said this election presented two distinct visions on how to insure the nation's economic security. "Theirs is to look inward, and protect what we already have," he said. "Ours is to look forward -- to open new markets, prepare our people to compete, to restore the social fabric, to save and invest so we can win."
He said his approach to change, the issue Mr. Clinton has claimed, would emphasize open markets, less Government spending, tax relief, opportunities for small business, "reform" of the legal and health-care systems, job training and better schools.
 
The Mark of Baker
 The speech was two minutes longer than Mr. Clinton's acceptance speech at Madison Square Garden last month. It seemed to bear the distinctive mark of Mr. Bush's new chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, who arrived in Houston last night and spent the day working on the text in what aides described as a frantic series of rewrites.
In past campaigns, Mr. Baker has favored making a few precisely targeted proposals and then using repetition and a tough, combative campaign to drive them home. Mr. Baker, currently the Secretary of State, takes over at the White House on Monday, but he is already in control of the campaign's tactics.
The speech did not, however, include one proposal floated earlier in the week that would have had Mr. Baker assume the role of domestic policy czar in a second Bush term.
Among the economic measures Mr. Bush proposed was a checkoff on tax returns that would allow taxpayers to designate 10 percent of their payment for cutting the national debt. He did not explain how such a proposal would work.
 
'A Cultural Divide
 Vice President Dan Quayle, in his acceptance speech tonight, presented himself as a proud warrior for traditional values and for morality itself, standing tall against the mockery and hostility of the Democrats and the "elites" of Hollywood and the news media.
"The gap between us and our opponents is a cultural divide," he said. "It is not just a difference between conservative and liberal. It is a difference between fighting for what is right and refusing to see what is wrong."
The Vice President's speech, with its implicit notion that the Republicans had better morals than their Democratic counterparts, gave the convention's final night a razor's edge.
The Vice President assailed Governor Clinton as the creature of "special interests," including the "education lobby," trial lawyers and the news media. "He can't fight for the traditional family, because his supporters in Hollywood and the media elite won't let him," Mr. Quayle declared.
Former President Gerald R. Ford brought a personal touch to a comparison the Republicans have been seeking all week, noting that he lost in 1976 to another Democrat who promised change. "Remember, change isn't a magic word that makes everything rosy," Mr. Ford said. "Change may get you 13 percent inflation. Change may get you a 17 percent home mortgage rate."
Even before Mr. Bush took the stage tonight, Republicans were cheered by three new polls that showed the convention had already tightened the race for the Presidency, which kicked off a rough new Republican assault on the Democratic nominee's character and an attempt to portray him as outside the mainstream of American life.
 
Jockeying for 1996
 There were many subplots here this week, despite the often plodding nature of the proceedings on the floor, which left even some delegates grumbling about the level of Republican oratory after Ronald Reagan had reminded them of their glory days on Monday.
One of the principal plot lines was the jockeying for position for 1996. Mr. Quayle, who has struggled for four years to establish himself as a serious political player, was clearly trying to use this moment of national attention to maximum advantage.
Mr. Quayle described himself as "unbowed, unbroken, and ready to keep fighting for our beliefs," and he presented his trials as the inevitable result of challenging the cultural elites. He also sought a lighter touch, telling a favorite Quayle joke on himself.
"For more than a month, the media have been telling us that Bill Clinton and Al Gore are 'moderates,' " Mr. Quayle said. "Well, if they're moderates, I'm a world champion speller."
 
Economy the Central IssueElection's Central Theme
 Mr. Bush and his advisers wrestled to the very end with tonight's speech; it was crucial to making an affirmative case for his re-election after a convention that had often seemed more occupied with presenting the case against his opponent. Moreover, it was up to Mr. Bush to come to grips with the central issue of this election so far: the economy.
Reviewing the tenor of this convention, Mr. Clinton's strategists said they hoped the Republicans had spent so much time cultivating their conservative base that they would pay a price with voters in the center. "Do I think they're going to get a 6-point bounce out of this convention?" said Stan Greenberg, the polltaker for the Clinton campaign. "At least. But I think they laid down some markers here that will eventually alienate the swing voters they need."
Mr. Clinton himself tried to stoke that alienation as he campaigned in Michigan today, where he said that "the party of Abraham Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt and Dwight Eisenhower is not very much in evidence in Houston this week."
Still, The new polls made public tonight showed that the convention was giving Mr. Bush a substantial boost. A New York Times/CBS News Poll taken just before the convention showed Mr. Clinton with a 17-point lead among likely voters. A new one, by CBS News, which surveyed 1,204 registered voters on Tuesday and Wednesday, showed that Mr. Clinton's lead had narrowed to 9 percentage points. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Mr. Bush was the choice of 37 percent of those surveyed, while Mr. Clinton had the backing of 46 percent. When undecided voters were pushed to voice a preference, the trial heat showed Mr. Bush with 40 percent and Mr. Clinton with 41 percent. The poll suggested that before Mr. Bush took the stage tonight, the Republicans had succeeded in raising doubts about Mr. Clinton, but had done little to improve Mr. Bush's standing.
The other new surveys were by Cable News Network and USA Today and by ABC News, and they showed similar convention benefits for the Republicans.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 22, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about President Bush's speech at the Republican National Convention misstated a finding of a CBS News poll taken Tuesday and Wednesday. Once undecided voters were pressed to voice a preference between Mr. Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, they supported Mr. Clinton 51 percent to 40 percent, not 41 percent to 40 percent.

HEADLINE: BAHAMIAN LEADER LOSES IN ELECTION

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASSAU, Bahamas, Aug. 20

 BODY:
After 25 years in office, the Prime Minister of the Bahamas, Sir Lynden O. Pindling, who led this Caribbean island nation to independence from Britain and in recent years quarreled with the United States, has been swept from power in a parliamentary election held here on Wednesday.
Plagued since the early 1980's by persistent accusations that he has taken bribes from cocaine and marijuana traffickers and saddled more recently with an economic decline that has left thousands without jobs, Sir Lynden's Progressive Liberal Party was resoundingly defeated by Hubert Ingraham, a former protege who broke with the party and now heads the Free National Movement. 
 Preliminary election results indicate that the Progressive Liberal Party has lost at least half the 32 seats it held in the 49-member House of Assembly. Arthur Foulkes, press secretary for Mr. Ingraham, a 45-year-old lawyer whose campaign slogan promised "deliverance to the nation," predicted that the Free National Movement would win about 60 percent of the popular vote.
Though clearly shocked by the dimensions of his defeat, which saw several Cabinet Ministers and the Speaker of the House lose their seats, Sir Lynden, whose supporters called him "the Moses of the Bahamas," accepted the rejection of his leadership calmly and without the rancor that characterized the months of campaigning.
"The people of this great little democracy have spoken in a most dignified and elegant manner," he said in a concession speech today. "And the voice of the people is the voice of God."
For his part, Mr. Ingraham vowed in remarks today that the new Government would be more accountable and open to the Bahamian people and "far more receptive to foreign investment" and visitors. "We shall seek to restore the Bahamas as a tourist destination of first choice and insure that people feel comfortable here," he said.
There were basically two campaign issues: corruption and recession. Mr. Ingraham, a former Cabinet member who was expelled from the Progressive Liberal Party in 1986 after accusing Sir Lynden and fellow party leaders of corrupt practices, pledged throughout the campaign that he would reform the government from top to bottom.
Sir Lynden, who is 62 years old and has been in office longer than any leader in the Western Hemisphere except Fidel Castro of Cuba, has been vulnerable on the corruption issue since an official 1984 commission of inquiry into drug trafficking through the Bahamas found widespread evidence of corruption in the Prime Minister's Cabinet and the Bahamian police. The commission cleared Sir Lynden of any wrongdoing, but said he and his wife had at least $3.5 million in bank deposits the sources of which could not be accounted for.
At the 1987 Jacksonville trial of Carlos Lehder, a founder of the Medellin cocaine cartel, prosecutors charged that Mr. Lehder and other drug traffickers had paid at least $5 million to Sir Lynden for permission to use the Bahamas as a trans-shipment point for cocaine and marijuana bound for the United States. Several drug smugglers testified that they had made such payments directly to Sir Lynden. The Prime Minister denied the accusations.
 
Drug Dealer's Property
 Mr. Lehder acknowledged that he had purchased Norman's Cay, an island south of Nassau that included a marina, an airstrip, three homes and several airplanes. After his conviction, the United States sought to confiscate Mr. Lehder's holdings here, but was rebuffed by Sir Lynden.
To emphasize Washington's unhappiness on the drug issue, when Ambassador Carol B. Hallett arrived here for the first time after her appointment in 1986, she flew in on a United States Drug Enforcement Administration airplane. After the Progressive Liberal Party won a convincing election victory in 1987, Foreign Minister Clement Maynard said critics in the United States could "go to hell."
Mr. Lehder repeated many of the accusations of the drug payoffs last year, during the trial of Gen. Manual Antonio Noriega of Panama. A few weeks ago, a lawyer who is a friend and business partner of Sir Lynden, Nigel Bowe, who had been indicted in the United States in 1985 on charges he accepted drug payoffs, surrendered to the American authorities in Miami, where he is scheduled to go on trial soon.
For many voters, though, the decline of the economy in the last five years was the decisive factor in the election. Tourism is by far the largest source of employment and revenue in this nation of 255,000 people spread over 700 islands just off Florida, and the Bahamas has found it difficult to compete with other vacation destinations in the Caribbean and North America, even with cut-rate air fares and hotel packages.
 
U.S. Officials Pleased
 State Department officials in Washington, who refused to be identified, said they looked forward to working with Mr. Ingraham. A senior official of Drug Enforcement Administration said that the drug shipments through the Bahamas had been trailing off in recent years, and that the Free National Movement had made clear their opposition to drug trafficking.
"We see no huge changes in our position or joint operations," the senior official said. "We do not operate in the Bahamas with the blessing and approval of just one party. We have an apolitical subject whose suppression is something the Bahamians of all tendencies agree is to their benefit."
Sir Lynden was first elected Prime Minister in 1967, ending a tradition of white minority rule that had been in place for centuries. He devoted his first term of office to securing independence from Britain, which was formally granted in 1973, and used the prestige gained from that accomplishment to win five more elections.
But many first-time voters apparently thought of Sir Lynden not as the father of his country but as a politician of dubious reputation who was unable to find them jobs. Strategists from the Free National Movement said that Sir Lynden had fared worst among young voters and that he had committed a fundamental error by scheduling the vote during the summer, when college students traditionally return from studies overseas.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 24, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the election in the Bahamas described the islands incorrectly. They are in the Atlantic Ocean, not the Carib-
bean.

HEADLINE: New York City Begins Another Search for a Film Chief

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

 BODY:
Under pressure from an ailing film industry, New York City officials said yesterday that they are starting from scratch in the four-month search for a film commissioner who can woo Hollywood back to New York.
 The choice of a new head for the relatively low-budget office became the subject of intense controversy after local film makers protested that four finalists chosen in June by a nine-person search committee simply were not up to the job. Film and television production is an important business in New York City, where a seven-month strike that ended in May 1991 cost the city half its normal number of production days. This year, the number has continued to decline, slipping 5 percent further. 
Barry F. Sullivan, deputy mayor for finance and economic development, said yesterday that he had agreed to throw out the committee's conclusions and begin again.
 
'Major Source of Revenue'
 "I want to get this right rather than wrong," he said. "It's a major source of revenue." The initial search was too unfocused, he said, adding that it is time to bring in professionals.
 The city hopes to find someone with an intimate knowledge of the business and the kind of Los Angeles ties that will keep New York ahead of the pack when locations are chosen for new projects. Once in New York, film crews need help with permits, access to locations and a host of logistical details. So, the director must also be able to cut negotiate the city bureaucracy, snipping red tape and keeping both artists and officials happy.
 Last evening, a group of 12 local producers, directors and movie union representatives met to craft a job description for the $78,000-a-year position, which was vacated last April. As early as today, Mr. Sullivan said, he would begin turning over a stack of unsolicited resumes to Russell Reynolds Associates, where the head of the executive search agency has volunteered to conduct the search at no cost to the city.
 The job is now filled by an acting director, Nina Streich. But several City Council members say the delay in permanently filling the vacancy is costing the city money. Next Tuesday, the City Council's Intergroup Relations Committee will hold a hearing on why the position has not yet been filled.
 Alan S. Gordon, Eastern executive secretary of the Directors Guild of America, said he will testify at the hearing, urging city officials to "prevent the death of New York City's film production industry."
 Mr. Sullivan said he expects the city to hire a new commissioner by the end of the year. The job is a combination of marketing the city to film producers increasingly leery of New York's high cost and strong unions, and of helping ease the process of film making -- arranging for access, blocking streets and the like.
 Some in the movie business said yesterday that they were enthusiastic about the city's new approach to filling the position.
 "It's the right thing to do to get professionals involved, and the people who've been most affected by the loss of work in the city," said Terry Casaletta, an official of the Director's Guild. Critics in the film business had complained that the original finalists for the job were chosen as friends of those on the search committee rather than as industry insiders capable of lunch as art. The sorry state of the economy only heightened their anxiety.
 Jaynne Keyes, who left the commissioner's post in April -- and headed the original search committee -- defended the process and said any of the four candidates was completely qualified to become director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting.
 
'Everything Is Incestuous'
 "There weren't any friendships that entered into it," said Ms. Keyes, who is now an agent at William Morris. "We had 50 resumes and each of us took 8 or 10 home with us. Although it is hard in New York, where everything is incestuous."
 Ms. Keyes said the process actually went awry because others in the industry wanted their own friends hired for the job. "Where it messed up was there were people out there that had their own people they wanted, and they started going to the press."
 Two of the four finalists dropped out "when the press hit the fan," she said.
 The remaining candidates were Lori Rosenfield, a former development executive at Fox, who declined to comment on the renewed search, and Caitlin Buchman, a former agent and film consultant who runs Film Strategies. Ms. Buchman could not be reached for comment yesterday. Mr. Sullivan said neither would be excluded from consideration in the new search.
 But meanwhile, Ms. Keyes said, "I worry that nobody's out there selling the city."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 21, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 21 about New York City's search for a film com missioner referred incorrectly to a labor dispute in New York last year between the major motion picture studios and film craft union mem bers. The studios boycotted New York for seven months during a con tract dispute over compensation; there was no strike by cinematogra phers and stagehands. An accord was reached last summer. A reader pointed out the error in a letter dated Aug. 31; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.
